Country Forecast India January 2020 Updater

Abstract: The budget deficit will widen as a percentage of GDP in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March), owing to a slew of fiscal measures announced by the government, most notably a corporate tax cut that will crimp revenue collection. Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) government to serve out its second five-year term, which expires in 2024. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration in 2020-24.
- Relations with the US will remain warm in 2020-24, albeit punctuated by trade tensions. Despite efforts to normalise relations, ties with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's rising influence in South Asia. Bilateral relations with Pakistan will also remain strained in 2020-24. Small-scale military exchanges cannot be ruled out, but we do not expect outright hostilities.
- The budget deficit will widen as a percentage of GDP in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March), owing to a slew of fiscal measures announced by the government, most notably a corporate tax cut that will crimp revenue collection. During the forecast period, the fiscal deficit will remain wide overall, as the government will continue to spend heavily on infrastructure and subsidy payments. However, we do not expect it to implement additional fiscal stimulus.
- The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to leave its policy interest rates unchanged in 2020 before embarking on a tightening cycle from 2021.
- Real GDP growth will slump to 4.9% in 2019/20, owing to a slowdown in private consumption and infrastructure investment. Economic growth will recover to an annual average of 6.3% in 2020/21-2024/25.
- We expect consumer price inflation to exceed the mid-point of the central bank's 2-6% target range in 2020-24. The key driver will be a sustained recovery in domestic demand. Our forecasts assume normal monsoons.
- The rupee is forecast to depreciate slightly against the US dollar in 2020, averaging Rs70.6:US$1 in 2020. The currency will remain weak in 2021-24, owing to a persistent current-account deficit and rising domestic inflation.
- India will remain dependent on imports for its fuel and capital goods needs. The merchandise trade deficit will therefore widen during the forecast period. Business process outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

- India's score rises over the forecast period owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.

Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or their merger or acquisition by other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Restrictions on foreign investment in multi-brand retail are partially removed.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: A limited trade war with the US continues, despite the damage it inflicts on bilateral strategic ties.
2022-24: Full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes 2020-21: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax (GST).
Financing 2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks, raising risks to banking sector stability but improving the availability of finance for corporate borrowers.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad issues persist in public-sector banks.
The labour market 2020-21: Reforms to labour laws move at a glacial pace owing to obstruction by trade unions and opposition groups.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at central-government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure 2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation for projects such as the Bharatmala road connectivity scheme.
2022-24: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness 2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by regional standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.35bn people in 2018, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2018 when measured in nominal US dollars or in purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the Westminster model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be slight.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's domination of the central government at any point during its full term (2019-24). This will ensure continuity in policy, particularly as this is the second consecutive term for the BJP.
The results of the 2019 election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised around the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts. The PMO and the National Security Advisor, Ajit Doval, played a key role in the outgoing government, and we believe that they will continue to dominate the policy agenda in the next five years.
Social unrest will pose a threat to political stability during the forecast period. Clashes between religious groups will intensify in states with a history of communal violence, such as Uttar Pradesh and Assam. In contrast to the country's current secular constitution, several far-right groups, including some affiliated with the BJP, have long been pushing for India to be recast as a Hindu nation-a view that puts them at odds with minority groups, notably Muslims. Violent protests are continuing across India following the enactment in December of the Citizenship (Amendment) Act 2019, with some fearing that the change will erode secularism and others concerned that it will lead to unchecked immigration. However, state governments (which control the local police in India) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, although some may not implement the changes to the citizenship law.
The security situation in the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will remain a key concern in the early part of the forecast period. The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state of J&K sparked protests. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders within the area, instances of further unrest can not be ruled out. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move has also increased the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch The next general election is expected to be held around May 2024. The focus before then will be on the outcome of state assembly elections to gauge support for the BJP. However, the results of recent state elections suggest that voters treat state and national elections differently, and that local issues tend to be more important. The Legislative Assembly Election in Delhi is scheduled for February, and that in Bihar will be held later this year.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they command less than half the total number of seats. Assuming that the BJP retains control of key state assemblies and wins control of a few more in the next few years, the party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) could secure a simple majority in the upper house. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval. However, it will struggle to win the two-thirds majority needed to make constitutional changes unchallenged. We believe that the BJP will perform poorly in the Delhi state election due on February 8th and in the Bihar state assembly elections.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Tensions with Pakistan will be exacerbated by the Indian government's move in August to revoke the special status granted to J&K. Shortly after the revocation was announced, Pakistan downgraded its diplomatic ties with India, and India responded in kind. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties between the two countries. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir in the short term. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors there. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
Trade tensions between the US and India will persist over the next few years, slowing the expansion of bilateral trade flows. However, they are unlikely to escalate into a serious deterioration in relations. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence.
China's growing influence in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. Despite some attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2020-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. One area of priority will be resolving bad debt problems in the banking sector that have held back lending to business. In the budget delivered in July 2019, the government announced plans to provide Rs700bn (US$10bn) to help to shore up public-sector banks in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March). We believe that this sum will help to address balance-sheet problems. It will also improve liquidity in the banking sector. However, given weak business sentiment, this initiative is unlikely to have led to a significant increase in lending.
We expect incentives to be offered to four key labour-intensive sectors: construction, tourism, gems and jewellery, and garments and textiles. However, these incentives will be market-distorting, protectionist and a point of contention with countries such as the US in 2020-24. More positively for India's economic productivity, the government plans to liberalise foreign investment restrictions in sectors including insurance, the media and aviation.
The government is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements, could be undertaken. Nevertheless, we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the Bharatmala roads project and the Smart Cities Mission-will remain a priority, partly as a response to the rapid pace of urbanisation, and partly to boost the business environment. However, many projects will face financing difficulties, as they envision a level of public-private partnership that seems unlikely to be realised, given how subdued private investment activity remains.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The government announced a slew of fiscal stimulus measures in August and September in response to weak GDP data for April-June 2019. The measures included initiatives for ailing sectors of the economy, such as automotive, banking and housing. Notably, the government also gave companies the option to pay corporate tax at a lower rate of 22% (25.2% including various surcharges), from 30% previously. This was backdated to the start of fiscal year 2019/20, in order to spur private-sector activity.
Fiscal stimulus measures and the revenue foregone owing to the corporate tax cut will leave a large hole in government finances. We expect the fiscal deficit to widen to the equivalent of 3.9% of GDP in 2019/20. As the economy recovers, the government will attempt to consolidate the fiscal finances, leading to an improvement in the budget deficit to 3.1% of GDP by 2022/23. Thereafter, spending pressures will increase in the run-up to the parliamentary election in 2024, resulting in a widening of the budget deficit in 2023/24. Our forecast assumes no more tax cuts in 2020/21-2023/24.
Efforts to deepen the tax base and increase levels of tax compliance will, nevertheless, continue over the forecast period; India's tax-to-GDP ratio remains relatively low compared with those of its regional peers. Welfare payments and infrastructure spending will remain key areas of focus for the government. It will seek to expand the reach of schemes such as the Ayushman Bharat health insurance scheme. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment. Over the medium term, the fiscal deficit will remain significant, averaging the equivalent of 3.4% of GDP a year in 2020/21-2024/25.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits being recorded by several state governments, which are not included in the national figure. The deep deficits in some states, such as Punjab, will present implicit liabilities for the central government and could pose downside risks to GDP growth over the next five years by crowding out private investment.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will maintain inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%, throughout 2020-24. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two hawkish heads of the bank under BJP rule-means that inflation is more likely to trend above 4% than below it.
Weak inflation, ebbing growth and pressure from the government have led the RBI to loosen policy several times in 2019. However, we believe that with inflation gradually recovering and policy rates already low by historical standards, the RBI will hold rates in 2020. The central bank will then undertake some tightening in 2021-22 as demand-side pressures associated with the country's rapid economic growth build. As the pace of growth moderates in 2023-24, the RBI will return to a neutral stance.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth The Indian economy grew at its slowest rate in more than six years in the quarter ending September 2019. Real GDP growth slowed to 4.6% year on year compared with a rate of 5% in April-June. Weak consumer sentiment and tepid investment were the main reasons for the slowdown. The data have reinforced our view that the process of economic recovery will be protracted. Nevertheless, a series of stimulus measures enacted by the government, coupled with a low-interest-rate environment, are likely to spur demand and investment from the second half of 2019/20. Overall, we expect the economy to grow by 4.9% in 2019/20. Fiscal and monetary stimulus implemented in 2019 will help to underpin business and consumer confidence, paving the way for a strong rebound in real GDP to 6.1% in 2020/21.
A sustained recovery in global growth in 2021 will support exports and an anticipated acceleration in investment growth. Real GDP growth is expected to average 6.3% per year in 2021/22-2024/25. Growth would be much faster were it not for the fact that we do not expect any additional fiscal stimulus during this period, nor do we expect monetary policy to be loosened. Indeed, an anticipated tightening of monetary policy in 2021-22 will weigh on business and consumer sentiment in those years. We also expect progress on structural reforms to be too slow to give real GDP a significant boost.
In factor-cost terms, the services sector will remain the largest component of the economy and will grow at a relatively brisk pace over the forecast period. Conversely, manufacturing will remain below potential, owing to structural limitations such as challenges relating to land acquisition. Meanwhile, the agricultural sector's contribution to GDP will continue to decrease over the forecast period. Public investment in the agricultural sector will be aimed at short-term gains, rather than fostering improved productivity.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation We have revised our consumer price inflation forecast for 2020, following a modest upward revision to our global oil price forecast for the same year. We still believe that the lingering adverse effects of an extended monsoon in 2019 will exert upward pressure on overall prices in the early months of 2020. However, we now expect consumer prices to increase by an average of 4.7% for the year as a whole, compared with 4.2% previously. In 2021 sharp increases in food and global oil prices will lift consumer price inflation to 4.6% on average. Food and beverages have a weighting of around 45% in the consumer price index, and so any volatility in agricultural output will affect price stability. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon in that year.
The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance by the RBI in late 2021 will offset the inflationary impact of continued strengthening in oil prices in 2022, keeping consumer price growth steady at 4.4%. As oil prices stabilise in 2023-24 and the RBI accords a higher priority to containing inflationary pressures, consumer price growth is expected to ease to an average of 4.3%.
Low global prices for oil and industrial raw materials will keep producer price inflation muted at 1.7% in 2020. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an average of 3.4% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive monetary loosening stance in 2019, along with high political risks associated with the removal of J&K's special constitutional status and changes to the citizenship law, have weighed on the exchange rate. We now believe that ongoing anti-citizenship protests will depress the rupee:US$ exchange rate in the first quarter of this year, and that the rupee will depreciate on an annual average basis to Rs70.61:US$1. We had previously expected the rupee to stabilise at around Rs70.27:US$1. However, the rate of depreciation will be shallow as the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) loosens monetary policy further.
In 2021-23 the rupee will continue its gradual depreciating trend against the US dollar, reflecting India's persistent current-account deficit and relatively high levels of inflation. We expect the rupee to appreciate slightly in 2024, owing to an easing of external payment pressures. However, the country's real effective exchange rate will remain relatively stable during our forecast period, and benefits to India's export sector from the rupee's weakening against the US dollar will therefore be limited.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector Stronger investment from 2020 and higher oil prices from 2021 will swell the import bill, resulting in a widening of the trade deficit. Merchandise exports will grow at a faster pace than imports over the next five years, but India's export manufacturing sector will be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth of India's key service export sectors, particularly business process outsourcing and information technology. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit, averaging the equivalent of 1.7% of GDP annually in 2020-24.
Inward direct investment will remain strong in 2020-24, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses. We expect annual direct investment inflows to rise to US$60bn by 2024, from an estimated US$47bn in 2019. Inward portfolio investment slid into negative territory in July-August 2019, owing to higher taxes imposed on foreign institutional investors. These tax changes were later rolled back as part of the government's efforts to revive the economy. We therefore expect these inflows to remain positive in 2020-24 as investor confidence is restored.

In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.

Full text: - The Economist Intelligence Unit previously expected the socioeconomic crisis (which has been ongoing since 2019) and the subsequent collapse in oil revenue to trigger regime change. However, in recent months risks to this assumption have risen, and our baseline forecast now assumes that the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, will retain power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. On this basis, we expect an ongoing deterioration of the economy, continued outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions, and their impact on oil production, the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through its strict control over the security forces.
- The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime continues to be challenged economically and politically. We do not expect the US government to renew waivers on Chevron and other US oil companies in July 2020; this will destabilise crude production, at least in the short term. Moreover, given that it will lose control over the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure in 2020 to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
- The government has recently allowed the official exchange rate to float, which has alleviated pressures on its foreign-exchange reserves. Furthermore, de facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding, which aids price stability and therefore increases the availability of some basic goods. These measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis within the forecast period.

- Venezuela is in 82nd position globally in the business environment rankings for 2020-24, down from 80th in the 2015-19 historical period, as the economic crisis deepens, despite minor improvements. Reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.

Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance Policy towards private enterprise and competition 2020-21: Limited rollback of interventionist measures, such as price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain subdued, and red tape and ad hoc interventionism continue.
Policy towards foreign investment 2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls 2020-21: Currency controls are made less opaque, but restrictions remain on private-sector access to foreign currency.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves, albeit slowly.
Taxes 2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures declines.
Financing 2020-21: Inflation remains high, and concerns surrounding economic instability restrict financing to only short term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market 2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour creates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure 2020-21: Underinvestment in water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts. A new government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2022-24: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but continued risk of water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness 2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in support for both parties and culminated in the 1998 election of Hugo Chávez, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his own popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus at 3.6% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability The Economist Intelligence Unit had long maintained that Venezuela's economic crisis would be a trigger for regime change. However, the risks to this assumption were always high and have grown in recent months. We have therefore changed our baseline forecasts to assume that the military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) will retain power, despite severe economic and international pressure. Mr Maduro has remained in office amid a deepening humanitarian crisis in what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. The imposition of US sanctions has taken a dramatic economic toll on Venezuela, in particular by causing a collapse in oil production. However, in recent months a shift towards Asian markets has provided some stability to oil production, as has support from Russia and Cuba to circumvent US sanctions. In addition, the regime continues to benefit from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities. These sources of US dollar have prevented sanctions from fatally wounding the regime's patronage system. It is this patronage-along with strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces, and purges within its ranks-that has allowed the regime to manage internal dissent.
Internal and external efforts to oust Mr Maduro are fading. The opposition, led by the president of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum that it held in early 2019 after abortive dialogue efforts and, in particular, after a failed uprising in April. International pressure has plateaued as the administration of the US president, Donald Trump, has shifted its attention to the November 2020 US presidential election; meanwhile the Lima Group (a multilateral body of mostly Latin American nations set up in 2017 to discuss the situation in Venezuela) and the Organisation of American States (OAS) seem to have exhausted most of their diplomatic ammunition. Large-scale emigration has also benefited Mr Maduro. The exodus has eased pressure on the Maduro regime, and increasing inflows of workers' remittances provide the regime with hard currency. Furthermore, the population has grown protest-weary, and the economy has stabilised, in relative terms. De facto dollarisation has brought about an improvement in price stability and, combined with a de facto lifting of price and foreign-exchange controls, has increased the availability of some basic goods.
Although it is no longer our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is still a high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as low. Although negotiations sponsored by Norway are set to resume (it is unclear when), we believe that trust issues on both sides are insurmountable and therefore do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis. We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The risks of such a political transition will be particularly high in 2020. We expect the Trump administration to refuse to grant an additional sanctions waiver to Chevron and other US oil services firms in July. This will again destabilise oil production in the short term and test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. Perhaps most important, however, is the fact that the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly-the only remaining legitimate body-in January 2021, assuming that the regime engineers rigged elections in late 2020. Without such power, the possibility of a transition towards an opposition-led or mixed administration would plummet. Mr Guaidó and the opposition will therefore be under pressure to try to force a regime change before then; the prospect of the PSUV clinging to power on a permanent basis could prove a trigger for a renewed popular uprising. In such an environment, and if sanctions bite further, pragmatists within the government and the military could finally turn on Mr Maduro, paving the way for some sort of political transition. The country's crumbling infrastructure could also act as a trigger for transition. A particularly dry summer (January-April) could exacerbate what is already likely to be a difficult season in 2020, leading to severe electricity and water shortages, with the prospect of protests against the regime.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch On the assumption that the Maduro regime clings to power, legislative elections will take place in December 2020. These elections will be neither free nor fair, and so the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority and attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although achieving this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community, but efforts by most governments in Latin America (under the Lima Group banner) to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. The most important of the US sanctions is a freeze on Venezuelan assets abroad, which will further complicate the regime's attempts to sustain the current patronage system; in September the US also introduced a travel ban on senior Venezuelan officials. Moreover, we expect waivers that allow Chevron and other US oil companies to continue operating in Venezuela not to be renewed in July 2020, given the approaching US presidential election. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given Mr Trump's aversion to such adventurism. However, if tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of US dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure the long-term future of PDVSA, the state oil company. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seems to have had little success in securing finance for investment. That said, Russia is believed to be helping PDVSA to circumvent US sanctions (for a fee). However, Russia's interest in Venezuela is mainly geopolitical, not economic. If a transition from the Maduro regime were to come about, we believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with Mr Maduro's successor in order to protect their current investments.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends Given our view that Mr Maduro will retain power for the duration of our 2020-24 forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. In recent months there has been evidence of attempts to tighten monetary policy, in order to rein in hyperinflation and abandon foreign-exchange controls (official exchange rates are in line with the black market). De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. De facto elimination of a host of controls is also occurring, and has had a beneficial impact on the availability of goods. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the survival of the regime. Such efforts are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of a comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the present regime. In this environment, domestic supply will be persistently weak.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit in 2020 to remain well into double digits as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, growing remittance inflows and the collapse of domestic demand will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. The public debt/GDP ratio will remain high in the coming years; however, the sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. At present we assume no debt restructuring during the forecast period. The country's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October and was not paid. A US federal appeals court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government, which will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, is seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. However, the US, which does not recognise Mr Maduro as the legitimate president, currently considers Citgo and its Caribbean facilities to be under Mr Guaidó's purview. As a result, the latest sanctions from the US Treasury department include provisions forbidding the transfer of Venezuelan assets, thus shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors. We expect the Trump administration to keep these measures in place during 2020. However, once the PSUV retakes control of the (currently legitimate) National Assembly, Citgo assets will no longer be safeguarded.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. However, a significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of 2019 and a strong contraction in domestic demand have had a temporary steadying effect, which has slowed hyperinflationary pressures and allowed some stabilisation of the bolívar in 2019. Nevertheless, the underlying causes of inflation remain unaddressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the pace of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of more than 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect a further decline of 20.5% in 2020. This will be driven by weaker private demand, owing to falling real incomes, continued migration, and-most importantly-a further contraction in oil output. We forecast that economic growth in 2021-24 will contract at an annual average rate of 4.6%, a more moderate rate of decline than in previous years, assuming a stabilisation of oil output. Private consumption will continue to contract in 2020 as unemployment, violence and falling incomes continue to force mass migration, further weakening domestic demand.
We expect the US's prohibition of Chevron and other US oil companies from operating in Venezuela to curb oil production at the Petropiar joint venture (between Chevron and PDVSA) in the Orinoco Belt. The impact on oil production will be limited in the short term; after the ban PDVSA would either take full control of the venture or assume joint control with other partners, most likely the Russian oil company, Rosneft. Even so, we expect oil output to slip to just 600,000 barrels/day in 2020. Under PDVSA control, crude production will fail to reach previous figures. In the medium term we expect oil output to continue to fall-albeit more gradually-owing to serious operational problems, such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or in finding qualified staff.
Export volumes will start to recover marginally in 2022-24, on the back of moderately higher global oil prices, and as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. In addition, import compression will continue, which means that net exports will partly offset chronically weak internal demand.
There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which are based on the assumption that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our forecast period. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of this improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation Severely reduced domestic supply, currency constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were published recently by the BCV, but there is a significant divergence between these figures and data from other sources. Amid continuing questions regarding the data, we will, for now, continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit will cause inflation to come down from the hyperinflationary rates of recent years. Nevertheless, inflation will remain high for as long as the Maduro regime is in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, as well as the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or the introduction of a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. With few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime announced a loosening of currency controls in mid-2019. Although this is a positive move, access to US dollars via formal means is limited, as significant barriers remain in place that in practice restrict access to dollars. We continue to believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On December 12th the official exchange rate was BsS46,234:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS47,100:US$1. The premium (currently at 2%) is small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector We have recently revised our current-account data in line with the BCV's publication of official figures for 2017-18. These show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period, on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus as a result of growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019).
We expect the current account to remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, averaging 4.3% of GDP in 2020-24. The trade surplus will recover gradually as international oil prices increase moderately and the country steps up exports to Asian markets. This recovery will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Domestic data Budget balance: non-financial public sector

External debt; World Bank, International Debt Statistics

Threats to European political stability over the medium term include the damaging impact of the UK's decision to leave the EU; the impact of the America First policies put in place by the US president, Donald Trump; disagreement over how to manage migration policy and the proper balance between national sovereignty and "pooled sover-eignty"; the impact of an economic growth slowdown on already dwindling support for the mainstream political parties; and increased divergence over values between political elites and electorates.

Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars. The EU's creation dates back to the Rome Treaty of 1957, which created the European Economic Community between the six founding EU member states (France, Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg). After four enlargements in 1973 (UK, Denmark, Ireland), 1981 (Greece), 1986 (Spain and Portugal) and 1995 (Austria, Finland and Sweden), the EU counted 15 members. The collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU; UK-EU negotiations on the UK's exit from the EU have so far been difficult. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than those of other east European countries. The effects of war in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped developments in south-eastern Europe. In the Commonwealth of Independent States, many countries continue to have deep economic and political ties with Russia.
Political structure: All 28 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular, the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-notably those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at EU level. A total of 19 EU members share the euro as their currency and are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank. They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have sometimes been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis, several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) received financial support from the EU and the IMF in return for fiscal and economic reforms. Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform and institutional change vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster-and more successfully-with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. About 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.

Summary
Political stability
Popular disaffection with traditional mainstream parties will persist during the forecast period (2020-24), leading to a more fragmented political landscape and making government formation difficult.
The centre-right European People's Party (EPP) and centre-left Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) lost their parliamentary majority after the May 2019 European Parliament elections.
The elections resulted in a more fractious parliament, leading to a contested appointment process for the new European Commission and a difficult start for its president, Ursula von der Leyen.
Ms von der Leyen has put forward an ambitious policy agenda, but geopolitical and policy divisions in the EU will stymie progress, including on budgets, foreign policy and security, migration and trade.
Following the Conservative Party victory in the UK in a snap election on December 12th, parliament will pass the withdrawal agreement negotiated by the prime minister, Boris Johnson, and the UK will leave the EU on January 31st 2020.
Economic policy
The euro zone will resist steps towards full fiscal integration, but the Franco-German axis will drive forwards some plans for innovation and industrial strategy. Some countries will push back against EU and euro zone rules.
At its September 2019 meeting, the European Central Bank (ECB) announced a new stimulus package, sending a strong signal that ultra-loose monetary policy will persist in the medium term and at least into 2021.
Economic growth
The euro zone's economic recovery stalled in 2019 and we expect a substantial slowdown in growth rates across the bloc this year and next, before growth picks up again from 2021.
The main reason for the slowdown is a deterioration of the external environment since the start of 2018, with softer global trade volumes, high geopolitical uncertainty and the ongoing risk of a "no-deal" Brexit.
However, domestic demand has remained firm, with private consumption supported by widespread labour market improvements, and investment growth fuelled by high capacity-utilisation rates and favourable lending conditions.
Business environment rankings
The business environment has improved in most European countries, as the post-crisis economic recovery has gathered pace, and this will continue.

Political outlook: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects political risk to remain high in Europe throughout the forecast period (2020-24). Threats to European political stability over the medium term include the damaging impact of the UK's decision to leave the EU; the impact of the America First policies put in place by the US president, Donald Trump; disagreement over how to manage migration policy and the proper balance between national sovereignty and "pooled sover-eignty"; the impact of an economic growth slowdown on already dwindling support for the mainstream political parties; and increased divergence over values between political elites and electorates.
The negative political fallout from the global financial crisis and euro zone crisis, as well as the long-term erosion of the traditional political party system, is proving to be electorally disruptive. The fragmentation of the political landscape is leading to delays in forming governments after elections and an increase in unstable coalition governments. The populist insurgency has hampered reform efforts at both the national and regional levels, and a meaningful overhaul of the European institutional framework is unlikely.
Brexit will present a major challenge to the unity of the EU in the medium term
The UK's vote in June 2016 to leave the EU represents a challenge for the bloc, and the departure of one of the EU's largest members will continue to reverberate after the UK leaves (at the end of January 2020 according to our forecast). The country's departure will leave a hole in the EU budget, which will be difficult to overcome without generating antagonism within the bloc. So far Brexit has resulted in increased European solidarity because leading member states such as France and Germany are keen to send a strong political message that a departure from the bloc will be more damaging for the exiting member state than for the EU. However, over the medium to longer term such unity could fray, especially if the UK were to thrive outside the EU.
Building consensus for strategic change at the European level will be difficult
The European Parliament elections in May 2019 resulted in a more fragmented parliament, and the subsequent process of appointing candidates to the top jobs was protracted. In July EU heads of state reached a compromise on Ursula von der Leyen as European Commission president; Christine Lagarde as the president of the European Central Bank (ECB); Charles Michel as president of the European Council; and Josep Borrell as high representative for foreign affairs and security policy. Ms von der Leyen's Commission had a difficult start, however, with three proposed commissioners being rejected by Parliament, resulting in the Commission taking office a month later than planned, on December 1st.
Ms von der Leyen plans to run a "geopolitical commission", presenting Europe as an alternative model to the US or China, with an emphasis on multilateralism, fair trade and the rules-based order, rather than protectionism or authoritarianism. Her ambitious policy agenda will address changes in climate, technology and demographics in the EU, with a European Green Deal that aims to make the EU carbon neutral by 2050 to be presented first. However, we expect the Commission to face significant challenges-and not just from policy disagreements in these areas. Negotiations on the upcoming seven-year multi-annual financial framework will take up significant time and energy in 2020. EU enlargement is a controversial topic that the French president, Emmanuel Macron, has recently inflamed, and building consensus on difficult issues within a fragmented European Parliament will be a tough task.
The political scene in Germany will be less stable than in the recent past
Germany is a leading example of a country where support for the traditionally dominant mainstream parties has declined sharply as the landscape of voter support has become more fragmented. The government installed in Germany in March 2018 is another grand coalition comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU) with the Christian Social Union (CSU, its Bavarian sister party) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD). However, the seat share of these parties has declined from almost three-quarters of parliament in 2005 to 56% now. Parties that take a clear line on migration and openness have benefitted most from this-notably the far-right, anti-immigrant Alternative for Germany (AfD), which is now the largest opposition party, and Alliance 90/The Greens, a centre-left party that stands for an open Germany.
The stability of the political scene has been brought into question since the leadership election for the SPD at the end of November resulted in a win for two candidates who had suggested that they would be keen to quit the grand coalition. They will push the CDU hard for policy concessions-such as a higher minimum wage, a more radical environmental approach, and greater infra-structure and welfare spending-in the second half of the government's term and will threaten to pull out from the government if these are not met. Neither party is well placed for an early election, so we expect some compromises to be reached. Nonetheless, there remains a substantial risk of the SPD quitting the coalition, which could see the CDU continue as a minority government, or an early election in 2020, in which the CDU and The Greens would do well.
Germany has played an important role on the EU stage in recent years, and its economic dominance within the euro zone means that this will continue. The German position on questions of reform-a consensus against further fiscal transfers within the bloc, lukewarm support for euro zone reform, and stronger support for a redesign of security and refugee policy-are unlikely to change. However, Angela Merkel's decision to step down as chancellor at the end of her term has already led to something of a power vacuum and a less proactive role for Germany. The French president, Emmanuel Macron, has filled this vacuum in 2019, with a series of dramatic policy interventions on the future of EU enlarge-ment and the role of NATO.
In France strikes and demonstrations will continue to hamper policy progress
In France Mr Macron enjoys the support of a solid majority of deputies in the National Assembly (the lower house of parliament), which has enabled him to make substantial progress on his ambitious legislative agenda since taking office in May 2017. He came to power determined not to give in to the sort of street protests that had derailed so many of his predecessors' plans, and front-loaded difficult structural reform efforts in the hope that the results would materialise before the end of his term in 2022.
However, weekly protests by the "Gilets Jaunes" in late 2018 and early 2019 forced a change in course. Mr Macron pledged EUR10bn in tax concessions to the protesters in December 2018 and held a national debate in January-March 2019 in order to reconnect with voters who had grievances to express. This resulted in a new package of reforms that make up "Act II" of his presidency, and Mr Macron's approval ratings stabilised. Nonetheless, public opposition remains vocal, with extensive industrial action planned in December 2019. Many of the protests are driven by opposition to the government's efforts to overhaul the pensions system, whereas others (such as strike action by some hospital workers) are related to growing strain on public services following budget cutbacks in recent years. We expect the government to make further fiscal concessions where necessary and water down reform plans in 2020 to avoid any resurgence in social unrest. Efforts to bring down France's hefty public debt load will be postponed.
Political stability will improve in Spain, but the Catalan issue is still unresolved
In Spain politics has become increasingly unsettled in recent years. Parliamen-tary fragmentation, a litany of political graft scandals and rising regional nationalism in Catalonia pose serious challenges to governance. Against this backdrop, in April 2019 Spain held its third general election since December 2015. The snap vote was triggered by the rejection of the 2019 budget-proposed by the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) government-by two Catalan pro-indepen-dence parties. A highly fragmented parliament, lack of experience in coalition build-ing and shifting party positions resulted in a repeat election in November.
The political environment will remain uncertain in 2020-24. We expect the PSOE to form a government and avoid another election in 2020. However, any government that the PSOE forms will not obtain an absolute majority in parliament. Given that it will be running a minority administration, the PSOE will have to find external support for many of its legislative initiatives, and building cross-party consensus will prove challenging. Ousting a sitting govern-ment is difficult in Spain; the next election will take place at the initiative of Pedro Sánchez, the leader of the PSOE. The timing will thus depend on the difficulties encountered by the new government and on the PSOE's standing in opinion polls. The issue of Catalan independence will continue to rumble on. Support for independence dipped slightly in 2019, but a rebound cannot be excluded. A further radicalisation of support for independence may ensue if the political process is perceived as having reached a dead end.
Complex negotiations will continue even after the UK leaves the EU
The UK held an early general election on December 12th, and the Conservative Party won a landslide victory, giving it a majority of 80 seats. The prime minister, Boris Johnson, will now easily be able to secure enough parlia-mentary support to pass the (revised) withdrawal agreement. This means that the UK's exit from the EU is now assured, and will take place on January 31st. At this point the UK will enter a transitional period during which it will remain within the EU single market and customs union, while negotiating its future trade relationship with the EU. This transition will legally expire on December 31st 2020, but can be extended for up to two years provided both the EU and the UK agree to this before July 1st 2020. Mr Johnson has stated his commitment to leaving this transitional period on December 31st 2020. However, given the complexity of negotiating and implementing a final status arrangement, an extension will probably be necessary. Even if a deal is secured in 2020, any changes to the UK's terms of trade and customs procedures, particularly in Northern Ireland, would require over a year for businesses and government bodies to implement. Nonetheless, there is a significant risk that Mr Johnson will not request an extension, leaving businesses and government bodies with insufficient time to prepare for an orderly exit at end-2020.
The Italian government will be unstable and will not last a full term
Political stability in Italy has improved since the formation in late August 2019 of a new coalition government led by the prime minister, Giuseppe Conte, and comprising the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S) and the centre-left, pro-European Partito Democratico (PD). M5S and the PD used to be fierce political opponents, but unexpectedly put aside their differences to prevent a snap general election following the collapse of Mr Conte's previous govern-ment in early August. The collapse occured when M5S's former coalition partner, the right-wing Lega, led by Matteo Salvini, withdrew from the coalition to try to engineer an early election in order to turn its surge in electoral support into seats in parliament, where it is only the third-largest party, behind M5S and the PD.
We believe that the new Conte government is unlikely to last until the end of the parliamentary term in 2023, but will hold together for 12-18 months. Political instability will remain a feature of Italian politics, especially since the coalition commands a tight majority in the Senate (the upper house of parliament). Nonetheless, with the Lega continuing to top opinion polls, we expect the second Conte government to cling on to power for as long as possible, as both the governing M5S and the PD would fear defeat in a general election.
Turkey has completed its transition towards one-man rule
In Turkey Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected in mid-2018 as president for a second term in the first round of a snap election, and the conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP), in an election that was mostly free, but largely unfair.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers with little oversight (including in the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary) and has abolished the role of prime minister. This greatly curtails the role of parliament.
We expect the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in mid-2016, to remain in power until 2023. Mr Erdogan and the AKP suffered a clear blow to their credibility when the opposition candidate, Ekrem Imamoglu, increased his margin of victory over Binali Yildirim of the ruling coalition in the Istanbul mayoral election rerun at the end of June 2019. However, Mr Erdogan will continue to clamp down on political dissent to maintain his dominance of Turkish politics in the coming years.
Security risk remains high. Attacks by Islamic State (IS) and the independence conflict being waged by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) pose a constant risk. Turkey's incursion in October 2019 into the north-east of Syria to remove the main Kurdish group from that region has increased the risk of PKK violence.
The transition to a post-Putin Russia has led to greater political jockeying
In March 2018 the president of Russia, Vladimir Putin, was comfortably re-elected for a fourth term, which runs until 2024. Mr Putin's re-election itself was a non-event, given his high approval ratings and the absence of credible opposition candidates. As a result we expect broad continuity in his policy agenda, which focuses on "conservative cultural values", an authoritarian political culture and overt anti-Westernism. We also expect a renewed focus on domestic policy in an effort to arrest the current decline in living standards and bolster growth. Despite occasional pro-market rhetoric, economic policy will remain statist, nationalist and protectionist. Economic sovereignty-understood as insulating the economy from external shocks-will remain a priority.
However, given how heavily the political system relies on Mr Putin's charismatic leadership and popularity, attention will gradually shift to how he will manage an eventual presidential transition, assuming that he stands down at the end of his term (our core forecast). This risks ushering in a period of political un-certainty as various factions of the elite jockey to secure their positions in the post-Putin political order. The transition will result in great uncertainty owing to the weakness of most political and legal institutions, as well as the personalised and opaque governance system around Mr Putin.
Russia's ambition to bolster its credentials as a major regional and inter----national player will continue to shape its foreign policy. Its influence will be strengthened by the conclusion of international deals in strategic sectors such as oil and gas, nuclear power plants and military equipment.
The CIS region will be mostly stable
We do not expect political or economic upheaval in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) in the near term. The exceptions to this are Uzbekistan, where the new president will continue to pursue a reformist course, and Armenia and Georgia, where street protests in 2018 led to a change in government, and where economic growth will outpace that of most other countries in the region. Kazakhstan will undergo a managed political transition, after Kassym-Jomart Tokayev (the chosen successor to Nursultan Nazarbayev) won a landslide victory in the June 2019 presidential election. We believe that no significant political or economic change will take place in the other central Asian countries (the Kyrgyz Republic, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan).
Political outlook: Election watch
General elections across Europe since 2017 have confirmed rising disaffection with the political establishment, which has been reflected in the decline of the two-party system and the rise of insurgent populist parties. Increasing political fragmentation across the region has resulted in a more complicated policy-making outlook, but has also made forming governments more difficult and given rise to some unusual coalitions.
Awkward coalitions are becoming a recurrent feature in Austria
Austria provides one example of this. Following the expulsion in May 2019 of the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ), the then chancellor and leader of the centre-right People's Party (ÖVP), Sebastian Kurz, lost a vote of no confidence, supported by the Social Democrats (SPÖ) and the FPÖ. This led to the appointment of a placeholder government until an early election in September. The ÖVP emerged as the largest party from the election, after campaigning on a more hardline policy towards migration and integration. However, the party does not have enough support to govern alone, requiring another coalition. We expect the Greens to enter government for the first time as the ÖVP's coalition partner, owing to good personal relations between the two parties' leadership. However, there is limited policy overlap, which could stymie a coalition deal.
A repeat election in Spain failed to solve the problems posed by fragmentation
The repeat election in Spain delivered another fragmented parliament. The PSOE, led by Mr Sánchez, won the most votes at the general election on November 10th, but its share of the vote fell to 28%, from 28.7% at the April election. The election confirmed the emergence of far-right Vox at the national level, as the party saw its vote share surge from 10.3% to 15.1%, making it the third-largest party in parliament. Vox was buoyed largely by concerns about the rise of the pro-independence movement in Catalonia, after weeks of riots following the jailing of nine secessionist leaders, and the collapse in support for the market-friendly Ciudadanos (Citizens), which obtained 6.8% of the vote, compared with 15.9% in April. We expect the PSOE to form a minority government either in coalition with the far-left Unidas Podemos (UP) and the support of Catalan separatist parties, or with the support of a number of right-wing parties. Another repeat election in 2020 is unlikely given the political cost for all parties.
Fine Gael minority coalition in Ireland will not survive a full term
The Fine Gael-led minority coalition government in Ireland does not have the capacity or cohesion to address the mounting economic and political chal-lenges in the country effectively, and our view remains that the government will not survive a full term to February 2021. We currently expect a snap election to take place in spring 2020-although we do not expect this to produce a government any more stable or effective than the current coalition. The administration-led by the taoiseach (prime minister), Leo Varadkar-relies on the support of a disparate group of independent members of parliament (MPs), and a three-year "confidence and supply" agreement between Fine Gael and the main opposition party, Fianna Fail. The agreement with Fianna Fail was exten-ded in December, as neither Mr Varadkar nor Micheal Martin, the leader of Fianna Fail, was willing to trigger an early election while there was still great uncertainty regarding Brexit. However, both Mr Martin and Mr Varadar have expressed their desire for a spring election, and so we expect an election to take place in April or May.
