Political outlook: Intra-regional tensions
Policy-related tensions remain high within the euro zone, but the risk that they will prompt rows between EU members has fallen sharply since 2016, in the context of an economic recovery across the bloc in 2016-18. The European Central Bank (ECB) has overcome objections in a number of countries-notably Germany-to its use of unconventional policy instruments. However, political leaders have not used the breathing space created by the ECB's programme of sovereign quantitative easing (QE) to bolster the economic recovery and have failed to reach a strong united position on fiscal policy and structural reform.
Huge political capital has been invested in keeping the euro zone together in recent years. There were fears that one or some euro zone countries might exit the bloc during the financial crisis. However, this scenario now seems unlikely, and the financial stability of the bloc looks strong, despite the high public debt levels of some south European countries (such as Greece, which exited its bail-out programme in August 2018, and Italy).
Italy's relations with the EU will continue to improve
Italy's relations with the EU and its main European partners have improved since the formation of a government including the centre-left, pro-European PD in late August 2019. We expect the new PD-M5S government coalition to be less confrontational towards EU rules on migration and fiscal policy than the previous administration. It remains to be seen what Mr Conte can realistically achieve regarding his government's demands for a revision of the EU's Stability and Growth Pact in favour of economic growth-friendly policies, and a review of the Dublin Regulation to ensure burden-sharing among member states in dealing with migrants seeking asylum in the EU. The prospect of obtaining some concessions on the fiscal front is better than the chance of winning concessions on the highly divisive migration issue.
Hungary and Poland will continue to clash with the EU over illiberal policies
The nationalist, socially conservative governments in Hungary and Poland have come into conflict with the EU over the EU's refugee-relocation policy and also over the creation of what the Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, has called-in reference to his own country-an "illiberal" state. In addition to refusing to take their allocation of refugees, the Hungarian and Polish govern-ments have curbed the independence of the judiciary, imposed government control over the public-service media and clamped down on civil-society groups. The Commission has referred several of these measures to the European Court of Justice (ECJ), but has so far struggled to find an effective response. Steps taken by the Commission and the European Parliament since December 2017 to invoke Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, possibly resulting in the suspension of a member country's voting rights, are unlikely to succeed, as they require the unanimous vote of all members, and Hungary and Poland have made clear that they would support one another in such an event.
Turkey's foreign policy with the EU and US will be increasingly confrontational
Turkey's relationships with the EU and the US have shifted under the AKP since the early 2000s. Declining trust in the US and the EU, and an ambition to make Turkey a regional power have all incentivised the AKP to pursue a "Turkey first" approach to foreign policy. By putting its interests first, the country has started to establish transactional co-operation with countries with which it was previously a rival or had limited relations, such as Russia and China. On the downside, Turkey's foreign policy will leave the country strategically isolated, and Turkey's relationship with the US will become increasingly transactional.
The deep distrust between Turkey and the US has increased since the early 2000s, making this scepticism more entrenched and harder to reverse. The watershed moment was the failed military coup by part of the Turkish military in 2016 and a perceived lack of Western solidarity in its aftermath. The sub-sequent resistance of the US to extradite a self-exiled Turkish imam, Fethullah Gulen, from the US for his alleged role in the failed coup further fanned the flames of anti-US sentiment in Turkey. Prior to the coup attempt both countries had already clashed on several issues, including the collaboration of the US with Iraqi and Syrian Kurds.
Turkey-US relations reached new lows in early 2019 when Turkey bought Russian military equipment (an S-400 air-defence system) that is not inter-operable with NATO standards. We expect that Turkey will activate the missile-defence system in April 2020, which is likely to result in US sanctions on Turkey under the Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act. However, sanctions will lean towards the less onerous side to avoid pushing Turkey fully into Russia's orbit and to ensure a degree of collaboration on other issues. Turkey's incursion in north-eastern Syria in October has further raised tensions with the US and the EU. The operation has been successful so far. After reaching an agreement with Russia (one of the main Syrian regime backers), Turkey has managed to disrupt the territorial expansion by Syrian Kurds who were seeking to estab-lish an autonomous region along Turkey's south-eastern border. The government has also provided a narrative to counter the growing hostility among Turks towards Syrian refugees, who are perceived as putting strain on the economy. The operation in Syria is the most recent example of a closer collaboration between Russia and Turkey. In the near term we do not expect the operation to lead to the imposition of new sanctions on Turkey from the US, for fear of Turkey further deepening ties with Russia. However, we do expect a further estrangement between Turkey and the US.
Russia-West tensions are at their highest level since the cold war
Political tensions between Russia and the West are at their highest since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Western countries have accused Russia of financing extremist opposition parties in western Europe, employing cyber-warfare against Western targets and engaging in a propaganda war through media outlets that it controls in the West. Meanwhile, Russia is seeking to reassert its role on the global stage, as recently highlighted by Russia's mediation efforts following Turkey's incursion into northern Syria, which further en-hanced Russia's role as the main power broker in the regional conflict. Russia is also dismantling the security and arms control agreements that were put in place at the end of the cold war. Russia's opposition to the post-cold war security architecture was evident in its decision to withdraw from the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe in 2015, and its subsequent breach of the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which bans short- and medium-range ballistic missiles.
Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014 and the Donbas conflict, which started in the same year, served Russia's objective of preventing Ukraine from becoming more closely integrated with NATO and the EU. In response, the EU and the US imposed sanctions on Russian officials, and the financial, energy and defence sectors. We expect these sanctions to remain in place over the medium term, and it is likely that the US sanctions will be expanded further.
Progress has resumed in the dialogue between Russia and Ukraine
After years of low-intensity conflict in eastern Ukraine, where Russia backs separatist rebels in the Donbas region, some significant developments have taken place. Dialogue between Russia and Ukraine resumed in mid-July, the demilitarisation process is making progress and the first meeting of the Normandy Four-comprising the heads of state of Germany, France, Russia and Ukraine-in more than three years will take place on December 9th in Paris. There is still a long way to go for a peace settlement to be reached between both parties, especially with regards to the future status of the Donbas region, and we do not expect any major breakthrough to be made during the meeting. That said, Mr Putin, Volodymyr Zelenskyi-the Ukrainian president-and Mr Macron are all keen to show progress on the foreign policy front to boost their support domestically and improve their status on the global scene. Therefore, we expect negotiations to continue and a compromise between Ukraine and Russia to be reached within our forecast period-although low-level conflict will continue.
The EU has labelled China a systemic rival, and the BRI divides opinion
The EU has labelled China a "systemic rival" and has adopted a regulation setting up a framework to scrutinise foreign investments from non-EU countries, a move that is widely understood to be directed towards foreign direct investment from China. Although the EU supports improving connectivity between Europe and Asia (as pointed out in the EU Connectivity Strategy), it has not formally come out in support of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)-China's flagship foreign policy initiative that aims to create a "New Silk Road" of trading routes and to expand China's economic and diplomatic ties. However, despite the EU's reluctance to support the BRI, several European countries have signed up to it, including Italy, Portugal, Greece and several countries in the western Balkans.
One of the points of concern for the EU regarding the BRI is the near monopoly that Chinese companies enjoy in implementing these projects. Until trans-parency regarding the terms of BRI funding improves and the procurement processes are made more inclusive and competitive (allowing for participation from European companies), the EU is unlikely to change its stance on the BRI.
Macroeconomic policy
The Franco-German axis will drive fowards some euro zone reform plans
The commitment in 2012 by the then-president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Mario Draghi, to do "whatever it takes" to preserve the euro represented a turning-point for the bloc. In 2017 EU leaders renewed their push for further integration of the economic and monetary union to boost the bloc's resilience to future shocks, and in June 2018 Germany and France presented a shared set of proposals. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects progress to remain patchy.
We do not expect the emergence of the type of full fiscal integration that the French president, Emmanuel Macron, has been pushing for, but the strength of the Franco-German axis, with support from a number of southern member states, is likely to be sufficient to lead to a relatively ambitious set of reforms, which will nevertheless take several years to implement fully. These would include reform of the current bail-out fund, the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), which could be turned into something akin to a version of the IMF. Such a move could shift the responsibility for fiscal and economic monitoring of member states away from the European Commission to the revised ESM, and include restructuring of sovereign debt as a strict conditionality in any bail-out. One of the three pillars of the banking union, the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS), which has yet to be implemented, will continue to meet political resistance from several north European member states. The planned EDIS would increase the responsibility of healthy economies for bad debts in others.
Future-proofing the EU's industrial strategy is a priority
Industrial strategy is receiving more attention, as the EU has realised that it risks being left behind by innovations in the US and China, and the rising pace of technological disruption. After the Commission decided in February to block the planned mega-merger between two train manufacturers-Alstom (France) and Siemens (Germany)-over competition concerns, there was push-back from both France and Germany. Proposals to revamp EU competition policy to allow the creation of regional champions capable of competing with Chinese state-owned rivals (for example) have made little progress so far. However, the new French commissioner for the single market, industrial policy, defence and space, Thierry Breton, can be expected to spar with Margrethe Vestager, the com-missioner for com-petition, on this issue. Greater investment into artificial intelligence, electric car batteries and digital innovation will be a priority under the new Commission, with plans to develop in these areas already under way. Further proposals for EU reform-such as strengthening the EU's defence capabilities, owing to concerns about NATO's reliability-will prove more controversial.
Talks over the EU's next seven-year budgetary framework will be tough
Tensions arising from negotiations over the EU's seven-year budget framework for 2021-27 have emerged in the second half of 2019. The most contentious issue is the Commission's proposal to increase member states' financial contributions to meet the shortfall created by the withdrawal of the UK-a major net contributor. Although some southern and eastern member states are willing to contribute more, fiscally hawkish countries-namely Germany, the Netherlands, Austria, Sweden, and Denmark-oppose this. Another point of controversy is the Commission's proposed cuts to the EU's common agricultural policy (which essentially provides subsidies for farms) and spending on regional development to finance new policy priorities such as climate change, security and migration. East European countries such as the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia, which could lose up to 25% of their EU funds if these changes were implemented, strongly oppose these cuts. Another contentious issue is conditionality in the next budget cycle, linking the transfer of funds to rule-of-law compliance. This idea emerged in response to the illiberal drift in countries such as Poland and Hungary, and has created an east-west split. The EU multi-annual budget requires unanimous approval at the European Council and an absolute majority in the European Parliament. There has not been much progress in negotiations on the 2021-27 budget so far, but EU leaders will be under pressure to reach an agreement by end-2020 to avoid a rollover of the current budget.
The 2021-27 budget will also include a new, small euro zone budget, after a compromise was reached between France and Germany. Far from providing a fiscal stabilisation function-as favoured by Mr Macron-the euro zone budget will instead be channelled to countries looking to improve competitiveness and convergence. The topic has proved contentious among the so-called New Hanseatic League, a group of fiscally hawkish Nordic and Baltic countries led by the Netherlands.
Macroeconomic policy: Fiscal policy

Fiscal policy will play a minor role in 2020, despite the economic slowdown
A conservative fiscal bias has prevailed across most of the region since the global crisis in 2008-09, leaving policymakers to rely on low interest rates and unconventional monetary policy tools as the main levers with which to manage their economies. Monetary policy looks set to remain as the main macroeconomic policy tool, particularly after the ECB presented a substantial easing package on September 12th. This includes a cut to the deposit rate (to -0.5%, from -0.4% previously), enhanced forward guidance, another round of quantitative easing (QE2) and the introduction of a tiered deposit system, in order to dampen the hit to banks' profitability from negative interest rates.
Although most European countries have substantially reduced their budget deficits compared with 2009, improved fiscal positions since 2015 have largely been the result of an economic recovery, which has generated sizeable revenue windfalls, and of lower debt-servicing costs following the policy measures taken by the ECB. Fiscal consolidation across the EU has, however, lost momen-tum, and many member states still have sizeable fiscal imbalances.
The average euro zone government debt/GDP ratio was 87.2% at end-2018, and Belgium, Greece, Italy, Cyprus and Portugal all had ratios in excess of 100%, and those for France and Spain were only slightly below 100%. Hefty debt loads will remain a challenge for much of the zone for many years, even more so in the current environment of low growth and muted inflation.
Against a worsened economic outlook, a mildly expansionary fiscal stance in 2020 will provide limited support to growth. A larger fiscal loosening, although desirable, remains off the agenda. Member states that wish to boost public spending lack the fiscal space to do so, while member states with abundant fiscal space lack the need-or the will, in case of Germany-to use it. EU and national fiscal rules also require high-debt member states to further reduce their structural deficits.
A greater loosening of fiscal policy in the coming period remains unlikely. Developments in Germany could alter the dynamics of the political debate in Europe about fiscal discipline, but despite a substantial economic slowdown, the German government has not yet felt any pressure to deviate from its "schwarze Null" policy (a commitment to avoiding budget deficits). A more protracted downturn could change the political calculus in Germany, but this is not our central forecast.
Italy will continue to test EU fiscal rules
The tone of recent discussions between Italy's new pro-EU government and the Commission has been much more co-operative than in 2018. The previous Italian government, which included the Eurosceptic, far-right Lega, mounted a serious challenge to euro area fiscal rules, proposing an expansionary 2019 budget that the Commission regarded as violating the debt-reduction criterion of the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP). A protracted stand-off between the government and the Com-mission followed, unnerving financial markets and pushing up Italy's borrowing costs. The administration eventually reached a compromise with the EU institutions on a deficit target of 2% of GDP in 2019.
The Italian government's fiscal plan envisages a budget deficit of 2.2% of GDP in 2020, unchanged from its latest estimate for 2019, narrowing to 1.8% and 1.4% of GDP in 2021 and 2022 respectively. The Commission has warned the Italian government about its "slightly expansionary" fiscal stance in 2020, stating that it is at risk of non-compliance with EU debt-reduction targets. However, the Commission has not taken any immediate action, deferring any further steps to spring 2020, when the country's fiscal plans will be reviewed. We believe the government fiscal targets to be overly optimistic, and expect the fiscal deficit to average 2.5% in 2020-21, before narrowing slightly thereafter. Public debt was almost 135% of GDP at end-2018, and we expect it to rise in 2020 before declining only marginally, to about 134%, by end-2024.
The UK government has shifted towards a looser fiscal stance
In the UK, fiscal policy was relaxed modestly in 2019 after a period of austerity from 2010-18 in which real government spending grew by an annual average of 0.9%. The Conservatives have pledged further spending increases in 2020 and beyond. In his annual spending review, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sajid Javid, promised more than £13.8bn in additional expenditure across all government departments, concentrated in health, education and police. On top of those commitments, the Conservative manifesto commits to an additional £2.9bn in current spending by 2024, and to raising the cap on borrowing for investment from 2% of GDP to 3%. We expect that this fiscal easing, combined with continued economic uncertainty, will result in a deficit equivalent to 2.6% of GDP in 2020, following an estimated deficit of 2% in 2019. We expect the deficit to average 2.5% of GDP in 2021-24, spiking in 2022 and 2023 as increased trade barriers with the EU slow growth. We expect public debt to remain relatively constant over the forecast period, at about 83%.
Fiscal performance in central Europe will worsen modestly as growth slows
A slowdown in real GDP growth across the region, coupled with increasing government expenditure means that fiscal performance will worsen in central European countries in the 2020-24 forecast period. We expect narrow deficits of less than 1% of GDP in both the Czech Republic and Slovakia in 2020-24. However, the Slovak government has not prioritised achieving a balanced budget, and ahead of the parliamentary election in February 2020 we expect the government to ramp up spending. In Hungary we expect the fiscal deficit to average about 2% of GDP in the forecast period, largely unchanged from 2015-19, and in Poland we expect the deficit to widen to about 2.5% of GDP by 2024. Public debt, which is equivalent to 50% or less of GDP in the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovakia-but is about 70% of GDP in Hungary. Given Hungary's high public debt, the country's fiscal position and currency will remain vulnerable to volatility on world markets.
Higher oil prices are easing fiscal constraints in Russia
The tight budget constraints facing Russia's government are abating owing to higher global oil prices. We expect international oil prices to average US$69.2/barrel in 2020-24, up from an average of about US$55.5/b in 2015-18. The Ministry of Finance intends to relax fiscal policy slightly in 2020-22, but fiscal stability will remain a central objective, which will ensure budget surpluses and growth in sovereign reserves. Spending related to the "National Projects"-the government's plans for infrastructure modern-isation-will push up expenditure. Military spending will remain high as well, but some spending will be redirected towards health and education, as recently promised by the president, Vladimir Putin. Meanwhile higher global oil prices-and the government's conservative oil price forecasts (retaining a US$40/b oil price assumption)-almost guarantee that revenue will outperform expec-tations. We expect that the budget, which returned to surplus in 2018, will not dip under 1% of GDP in 2020-24.
Turkey's fiscal position looks relatively solid
The public finances have traditionally been one of Turkey's most reassuring economic features. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past.
After substantial fiscal stimulus, we estimate that the budget deficit will widen from 2% in 2018 to 3% of GDP in 2019, remaining around this size in 2020-22 in line with the government's preference for fast growth reflected in its medium-term programme. The deficit will remain large in 2023-with the shortfall reaching about 2.8%, owing to the presidential and parliam-entary elections that year-before narrowing to 2.1% of GDP in 2024. Public debt will remain at about 30% of GDP in the forecast period.
Macroeconomic policy: Monetary policy and exchange rates
Interest rates (av; %) 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023 2024
Euribor -0.4 -0.4 -0.4 -0.4 -0.2 0.0
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate 2.1 1.5 1.5 1.8 2.2 2.3
US 10-year government bond yield 2.1 1.5 1.7 2.2 2.6 2.7
10-year German government bond yield -0.2 -0.2 0.3 0.8 1.2 1.5
The ECB adopted a loose monetary policy in response to the European sover-eign debt crisis that began in 2011. Interest rate cuts were followed by the introduction of a quantitative easing (QE) programme in 2015-18. However, economic growth in the euro zone started to slow in early 2018 on the back of an industrial downturn triggered by both weaker foreign demand and dis-ruptions to the auto industry. Growth has remained weak, and headline and core inflation have failed to pick up to the target set by the ECB of "close to, but below, 2%". Against this background, the ECB announced a bold package at its September 2019 meeting, which involved a cut to the deposit rate (from -0.4% to -0.5%); the start of an open-ended QE programme, which will run at a monthly pace of EUR20bn; stronger communication on the forward guidance on interest rates; the introduction of a tiered deposit system; and more favourable terms for long-term loans to commercial banks.
The second round of quantitative easing will run until late 2021
We expect the September policy package to be maintained in the medium term. The second round of QE should run until late 2021, and a small increase in the deposit rate will come in 2022 as the trade outlook improves and inflationary pressures build. Christine Lagarde, the new ECB president, will face pressures to reverse part of the package, but we deem this to be unlikely. Ms Lagarde is instead likely to announce the ECB strategic review-the first to be conducted in 16 years-at the Bank's December meeting. We do not expect the review to result in a significant overhaul to the ECB's strategy. However, we do expect a change to the inflation target, which will become symmetrical around 2%, instead of "below, but close to, 2%", as at present.
The BoE will set monetary policy according to Brexit developments
Decisions made by the Bank of England (BoE, the UK's central bank) in 2020-24 will depend heavily on the degree of volatility in both prices and demand created by Brexit implementation. On November 7th the monetary policy committee (MPC) of the BoE kept the policy interest rate unchanged, at 0.75%, where it has been since August 2018. However, two members of the MPC supported an immediate rate cut, citing the accelerated timetable for leaving the single market and slowing global growth. Although the BoE has been wary of cutting rates, in order to retain monetary policy space for a potential disorderly Brexit, this split decision has led us to believe that the BoE will cut rates once in 2020 to combat uncertainty related to negotiations with the EU and slowing growth. We anticipate that once Brexit uncertainty dissipates in 2021, the BoE will tighten rates to regain policy space, but will have to undertake a more accommodative monetary policy at the end of 2022 owing to the supply shock created by leaving the single market, cutting rates to 0.25%. We expect the BoE to maintain this accommodative policy until 2024, when it will begin tightening again.
Turkey still faces a risk of another sharp depreciation of the lira
Turkey's currency crisis in 2018 and the ensuing recession have put severe pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets. After the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August 2018, the Central Bank of Turkey raised its main policy rate to 24%, from 17.75% previously. Since then the lira has recovered and annual consumer price inflation has started to ease. Meanwhile, major central banks have been loosening monetary policy. Under these conditions, the MPC of the Central Bank of Turkey slashed the bank's main policy rate-the one week repo lending rate-to 19.75% in July, 16.5% in September, 14% in October and 12% in December.
We expect further rate cuts in 2020. However, we expect the cuts to become smaller and more gradual. Further substantial rate reductions could undermine the lira and pose upside risks to the annual inflation rate. The rate cuts reflect the government's continued pro-growth stance and pressure on the central bank to keep nominal rates below what would credibly be required to reach its inflation target. This rate forecast implies that the real policy rate will be close to zero in the second half of 2020. Tightening by the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) in 2021 and still-high inflation in Turkey will cause the central bank to raise rates again in that year. Thereafter, in 2022-24, we expect gradual cuts alongside moderating inflation.
In 2020 we expect volatility in the lira to continue, but we anticipate reduced downward-value directionality for the lira and forecast a more moderate depreciation, of 1.8%. An accommodative monetary policy stance in advanced economies will partially offset the downward effect on the lira's value that stems from tensions with the US. In 2021-24 still-high inflation, a large current-account deficit and an inadequate monetary policy stance will result in gradual depreciation of the lira in nominal terms.
Russia is operating an accommodative monetary policy to boost demand
The Central Bank of Russia (CBR, the central bank) cut its policy rate five times in 2019, to 6.25% in December. This reflected the weakness of domestic demand and a significant downward revision to official 2019 year-end inflation forecasts, which prompted the largest rate cut in two years (by 50 basis points) in October. Any downward shock to global oil prices or new stringent sanctions on Russia would prompt the CBR to tighten policy quickly to soften the resulting depreciation of the Russian currency against the US dollar.
Many currencies in eastern Europe remain pegged to the euro
For central and east European countries with currencies pegged to or managed against the euro (mostly in the western Balkans), risks of volatility have moved in line with expectations of the Fed and the ECB's policy trajectory. However, we do not believe that there are significant risks to the currency boards in Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) or Bulgaria, or to the peg in North Macedonia. Croatia had been more of a cause for concern, in the light of the 2015 legislation to force banks to convert Swiss franc-denominated loans into euro. However, the country's improved external and fiscal positions, and increased demand for the kuna as a result of strong tourism performance, have eased these concerns.
We expect broadly accommodative monetary policy stances in Central Asia
Currencies across the former Soviet Union depreciated sharply in 2015, as a result of the weakening of the rouble and lower oil prices, which hit commodity exporters. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan officially abandoned their US dollar pegs in 2015. In practice, only Kazakhstan has allowed its currency to float. Given Kazakhstan's trade ties to the Russian economy, it would lose competitiveness if the tenge appreciated significantly against the rouble. Azerbaijan appears to have returned to a US dollar peg since April 2017. The monetary policy stances of oil-exporting countries, such as Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, are closely linked to oil price fluctuations, as the exchange-rate movements of these countries are closely linked to global oil prices (which determine export earnings). With global oil prices expected to remain firm in our forecast period, these countries will maintain an accommodative monetary policy, which will also support domestic economic growth.

The external environment will hold back growth in Europe in 2020
Economic growth in the euro zone was robust in 2015-17, but slowed in 2018 as the external environment became less supportive. Slower growth in China, weakness in major trading partners such as the UK and Turkey, and the US-China trade war were the main drivers of the slowdown, which was further amplified this year by a global slump in the automotive sector and a cyclical downturn in consumer electronics. The export-oriented German economy, with its large industrial sector and automotive industry, has been particularly badly affected, contracting slightly in the second quarter of 2019. The Italian economy is also stalling, dampened by domestic policy uncertainty as well as slowing external demand. Both economies will face further headwinds in 2020. How-ever, the economic prospects of other big economies are brighter: in Spain and France growth momentum remains strong.
Overall, the picture is of a difficult external environment, which is weighing on exports, while domestic demand continues to expand at a healthy pace. Labour markets remain tight and wage growth is holding up. House prices are rising, leading to positive wealth effects, and inflation has softened. The exceptionally loose monetary policy stance of the European Central Bank (ECB) is supporting growth, and some countries-such as France and the Netherlands-are con-ducting fiscal stimulus programmes as well. Meanwhile, high capacity utilisation rates, especially in the construction sector, are encouraging invest-ment, although prevailing uncertainty (around the risk of a "no-deal" Brexit and additional US tariffs on EU goods and services, in particular) will keep business sentiment and investment growth contained in the short term.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects global trade growth to start to improve in 2020 as the automotive industry sees a modest recovery and electronics trade volumes bounce back. However, the majority of the uptick in exports will come from non-OECD countries, so the impact on exporters in Europe will be limited, especially given still-slowing growth in the US and Chinese economies. We expect economic growth in Europe to remain constrained in 2020, but to strengthen from 2021 as the external context improves more robustly.
The German economy is struggling with weak external demand
The German economy has been slowing since a recent peak in 2017, and the economy contracted marginally in the second quarter of 2019, before returning to growth in the third quarter, dispelling fears of a recession. The main driver of the German slowdown was external, and we believe that there were three main aspects to this. First, there has been a noticeable slowdown in German exports to China, in line with slowing Chinese economic growth and the US-China trade war. Second, German exports to other significant trading partners, such as the UK, Sweden and Turkey, have been dampened by weak demand over the past year. Third, the automotive sector is facing a number of challenges. Global car sales fell in 2019, reflecting slowing demand in China and India, and at the same time structural shifts-including the decline of diesel and rise of e-mobility-are disrupting the industry.
We expect growth in Germany to remain subdued until 2021, when the external environment will become more supportive. That said, Germany's domestic economic fundamentals remain strong, and the main driver of growth over the medium term will be private consumption, with investment also contributing robustly. The government has agreed on a more expansionary fiscal policy in 2020 and 2021, and may be pushed by political pressures into spending more. Discussion about whether the government's commitment to maintaining a balanced budget remains appropriate has intensified, but we do not expect a shift in stance on this question.
Growth will remain comparatively strong in France, in a European context
Growth in France has also slowed since 2017, when the cyclical upswing in the euro zone reached its peak. Nonetheless, growth in 2019 has been robust in a European context-particularly compared with Germany and Italy. This partly reflects the larger share of domestic demand in the economy: exports are equivalent to about 30% of GDP in France, versus almost 50% in Germany. It also reflects the fiscal stimulus enacted over the past year; the government responded to the "Gilets Jaunes" protesters in late 2018 with measures to sup-port purchasing power. The government's reform agenda has been slowed down by these protests and by a new surge of industrial action at the end of 2019, but we nonetheless expect a continued gradual improvement in the business environment, especially the tax system and the labour market, in the second half of the government's term. We expect the economy to grow by a similar rate in 2020 as in 2019, and to pick up more robustly from 2021 as the external environment improves and supply side reforms continue to bear fruit.
Italy's growth has been stagnating since mid-2018
Real GDP growth in Italy has essentially been stagnating since mid-2018, dampened by domestic political and economic uncertainty, as well as global trade tensions. Following mild contractions in the second and third quarters of 2018, real GDP increased by just 0.1% quarter on quarter in the fourth quarter of last year and in each of the first three quarters of 2019. We forecast that economic growth will pick up only moderately, from an estimated 0.2% year on year in 2019 t0 0.4% in 2020, owing to stronger internal demand and a recovery in industrial production. From 2021 to 2024 we expect a respectable growth performance by Italian standards, but it will still be weak in the context of other euro area economies, as structural rigidities, a high level of sovereign debt, clogged credit channels and policy uncertainty will continue to exert a drag on growth.
Structural reforms have improved the context for growth in Spain
In Spain, a combination of reform and austerity has improved the context for growth since 2014. The financial sector is now in a better position owing to reforms undertaken as part of Spain's EUR41.3bn bank bail­out process. A landmark labour market reform was implemented in 2012. This lowered dismissal costs, clarified and narrowed the definition of unfair dismissal, reduced the collective bargaining power of trade unions, and made it easier for companies to cut wages and working hours. Structural reform will proceed at a more gradual pace in 2020-24 (the forecast period) compared with the reform-intense period under the absolute majority of the People's Party (PP) in 2011-15. Under the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE), the Congress of Deputies (the lower house of parliament) will be dominated by the left of centre for the first time since the 2008-11 legislature. In these circumstances, policymaking will tack to the left. In 2019 the PSOE unfroze public pension revaluations and substantially increased the minimum wage using powers of decree. In January 2019 the minimum wage rose by 22%, to EUR900 per month, and the government also approved a 2.3% rise in public­sector salaries, effective from January 1st. Real GDP growth has decelerated since 2015, as the economic recovery has matured. In 2020-24 we expect this gradual slowdown to continue towards the economy's potential growth rate.
The recovery in Greece remains fragile, with political instability a central risk
Greece exited its third bail-out programme in August 2018, but we are sceptical that the country will experience rapid and sustained growth. Greece's economy has been in almost permanent recession since 2008. Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than a quarter, government con-sumption by almost a quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile, and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. Under-investment during the economic crisis and the depletion of Greece's capital stock are likely to restrict growth potential in the medium term. After estimated growth of 1.9% in 2019, we forecast that real GDP will grow by an average of 2.2% per year in 2020-24. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed and com-petitive-ness gains are not eroded; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political and financial market instability.
The UK economy is suffering from the uncertainty stemming from Brexit
Growth in the UK since the Brexit referendum has been driven by private consumption-supported by real wage growth, which reached post-crisis highs in 2019-and an estimated unemployment rate of 3.8% this year. However, employment growth stalled in 2019, as the economy is already near full employment, and productivity growth remains low. Further growth in private consumption will be constrained, particularly in 2022 and 2023, before re-bounding in 2024 as Brexit uncertainty decreases. Additionally, we expect only modest increases in gross fixed capital formation (GFCF), bolstered by loose fiscal policy, but offset by a deterioration in the external sector and limited growth in the consumer sector. We expect real GDP growth to remain subdued, at 1.3% in 2019 and 2020. Once there is greater clarity over the future relation-ship between the UK and EU, we expect GDP growth to rebound, before declining again as the UK loses access to the single market.

The Visegrad countries will continue to post above-average growth rates
Central Europe, particularly the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia), will register real GDP growth well above the EU average in 2020-24. However, growth will decline in the forecast period compared with recent years, driven in part by the slowdown in the global automotive market. Furthermore, most central European economies are deeply entrenched in German supply chains, especially in the automotive sector, and so Germany's performance will have a knock-on effect on overall economic per-for-mance in the region. Nonetheless, increasing employment and soaring wages in the Visegrads will continue to fuel private consum-ption in the fore-cast period. A recovery in global trade from 2020 onwards will support overall eco-nomic growth in central Europe in 2020-24. In the longer term, much of central Europe will face a challenging environment, given the poor demographic outlook.
Economic activity accelerated in south-eastern Europe, but is now moderating
In south-eastern Europe economic recovery is continuing, although growth has generally lost momentum. In the region's largest economy, Romania, we expect growth to slow from an estimated 3.8% in 2019 to a still-strong 2.9% in 2020. In both years growth will be supported by private consumption and, to a lesser extent, exports and fixed investment. We expect that real wages will continue to grow robustly, and that real credit expansion will support growth in consumer spending. With a general election in 2020, the government will maintain an overall broadly accommodative stance, particularly regarding household spending. We expect fixed investment growth to decelerate sharply in 2020, after double-digit growth in 2019. In Bulgaria, a recovery in domestic credit growth, a strengthening labour market and firmer real wage growth have underpinned the acceleration of economic growth in recent years. We forecast that annual real GDP growth will average 3% per year in 2020-24, compared with an estimated 3.8% in 2019, reflecting less favourable global conditions and labour capacity constraints.
Structural imbalances in the western Balkans have been largely corrected
Economic activity in the western Balkans (Albania, Bosnia and Hercegovina, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia) broadly picked up in 2015-18, reflecting a combination of favourable base effects and externally driven cyclical factors, such as low oil prices in 2015-16 and a strong pick-up in demand from the euro zone in 2017. The region has undergone a significant economic adjustment in the years since the 2008-09 global financial crisis, largely correcting fiscal and current-account imbalances (with some exceptions, such as Montenegro). Inflation has fallen to historical lows for the region, allowing a more accommodative monetary policy that has supported growth. The revival of investment is set to continue, and over the medium and long term the western Balkans should benefit from the structural reforms that are now in progress in most countries. On the downside, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) continued large fiscal deficits remain impediments to faster growth. Political cronyism, corruption, vested interests and a poor demographic profile are also a drag on growth across the region. We forecast average real GDP growth in the western Balkans of about 3.3% in 2020-24.
We expect the Turkish economy to grow above its potential rate in 2020-24
In Turkey government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand caused real GDP growth to accelerate sharply in 2017, but this surge exacerbated internal and external discrepancies. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredict-ability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short--term capital inflows, tighter global liquidity and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira depreciating by about 24% on average against the US dollar in 2018.
The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of large foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dented the economic outlook. The crisis pushed the Turkish economy into recession in the second half of 2018. In 2019 we estimate that real GDP will have grown by only 0.1%, as a result of base effects arising from the economic recession in the second half of 2018. In 2020-24 we expect annual average growth of 3.7% as the government attempts to meet its annual growth target of 5%. This growth rate will be above a potential real GDP growth rate of about 3%. With the government consistently pushing economic growth above potential growth, there is a risk of a significant loss of investor confidence at some point in 2020-24.
Growth in Russia will pick up slowly after a particularly weak 2019
We estimate that real GDP growth in Russia slowed sharply in 2019. This was mostly due to a fall in household spending following an increase in value-added tax (VAT). However, a dip in global oil prices and low investment also played a role as major infrastructure-construction projects related to the 2018 World Cup were completed and implementation of the so-called National Projects-the president's blue-print for his fourth presidential term to 2024-was slow. Growth will pick up slowly in 2020, as the National Projects have now been made a priority in the 2020 draft federal budget, which should support activity in the industrial and construction sectors. However, we expect the projects to gain traction only slowly. Growth in household consumption will slow in 2020, as the Central Bank of Russia (CBR) introduced tighter prudential requirements in October 2019, which will reduce unsecured lending. Weaker foreign demand growth and a dip in global oil prices mean that export receipts will also remain soft. International sanctions, and broader political and business uncertainty will remain significant constraints on investment, as will the lack of a "culture of failure" (the absence of entrepreneurial spirit weighs heavily on innovation and investment). In the medium term outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, low prod-uctivity growth, a difficult business environment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth to an annual average of 1.7% in 2020-24.
Faster than expected progress on structural reforms represents an upside risk in Ukraine
Real GDP fell by a cumulative 16.4% in Ukraine in 2014-15 amid conflict and a chaotic political situation. The disruption of these years accentuated a structural change in the Ukrainian economy away from heavy industry and towards agriculture. The economy has been recovering since 2016, driven by vigorous growth in private investment and private consumption. We estimate that economic growth will have remained strong in 2019, as rising wages and solid growth in capital investment will have supported domestic demand.
In 2020-24 we expect household consumption to drive growth. Private con-sumption growth will soften gradually in the forecast period, while remaining strong owing to high inflows of remittances from abroad, and higher wages and pensions (especially in the first half of the forecast period). Improving global conditions in 2021-24 will increase the contribution of the external sector to GDP growth. Faster than expected progress on structural reforms could improve investment and represents an upside risk to our growth outlook. A downside risk stems from the possible abrupt end of Russian gas transit through Ukraine on January 1st 2020, when the current transit contract expires (although we expect Ukraine and Russia to sign a short-term agreement covering gas supplies in 2020).
Growth rates in the CIS will be similar in 2019 to those recorded in 2018
Growth and exchange-rate movements in the Commonwealth of Indep-endent States (CIS) are highly correlated to movements in global oil prices, especially in large oil exporters such as Russia, Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan. Owing to important trade links and high levels of remittance flows, the performance of the Russian economy has an impact on that of smaller countries in Central Asia (especially the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan) and the South Caucasus (Armenia and Georgia, not CIS members). Given our forecast for an oil price corridor of about US$60-75/barrel in 2020-24, the growth outlook for most countries is unlikely to diverge significantly from their 2019 final outturn.

Price pressures have weakened in 2019 across the euro zone on the back of softer economic momentum and lower global energy prices. As a result, headline inflation in the euro zone decelerated from 1.7% in 2018 to an estimated 1.2% in 2019. In 2020 price growth will pick up only slightly, to 1.3%, as global energy prices remain broadly stable and wage growth fails to pick up. Capacity constraints have eased in the bloc's industrial sectors and employ-ment growth is slowing down. Nevertheless, still resilient domestic demand should ensure that price growth remains decent in 2020, albeit well below the ECB's target of "close to, but below, 2%". Inflation will pick up more pronouncedly in 2021-24, averaging 1.8% per year. This will reflect both higher wage pressures as the trade outlook improves and a rise in global energy prices.

Business environment rankings cover 82 countries
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its major components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of 11 categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into 11 categories.
There is a moderate improvement in Europe's aggregate regional scores between the historical period (2015-19) and the forecast period (2020-24), reflecting the transition from the post-crisis period to one in which recovery and repair are, in most countries, well under way. Western Europe is ranked second globally out of six regions, after North America, and eastern Europe is ranked fourth, after North America, western Europe, and Asia and Australasia, but ahead of Latin America and the Middle East and Africa.
EU countries and Nordics score particularly well in our rankings
EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of countries in western Europe in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (a post-crisis rise in social and political tensions notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we do not forecast a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Business environment in eastern Europe has improved since 1990s
T he investment climate of central and eastern Europe has improved consid-erably in recent years. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even there. Factors such as a low-cost, but well-qualified, labour force, proximity to developed markets, and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region over the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges, including high levels of emigration, a declining workforce and a high social security burden. Meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. Throughout the region, the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable. In Russia, the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the Russian government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. However, low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to seek to open up and diversify their economies.
Data sources and definitions
Methodology
The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, the Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.

GDP growth and inflation: relevant central banks or national statistical offices, also available in OECD, National Accounts

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2015-19) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2020-24). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2015-19. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2020-24 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2015-19 ranges are then used to derive 2020-24 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2020-24, not to the likely situation in 2024 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2017 or 2022). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) government to serve out its second five-year term, which expires in 2024. Its re-election in May 2019 will underpin political stability. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration in 2020-24.
Relations with the US will remain warm in 2020-24, albeit punctuated by trade tensions. Despite efforts to normalise relations, ties with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's rising influence in South Asia. Relations with Pakistan will also be fractious, owing to continuing border tensions. Low-level military clashes between the two countries remain likely in 2020-24.
The budget deficit will widen as a percentage of GDP in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March), owing to a slew of fiscal measures announced by the government, most notably a corporate tax cut that will crimp revenue collection. During the forecast period the fiscal deficit will remain wide overall, as the government will continue to spend heavily on infrastructure and subsidy payments.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to leave its policy interest rates unchanged in 2020 before embarking on a tightening cycle from 2021.
Real GDP growth will slump to 4.9% in 2019/20, owing to a slowdown in private consumption and infrastructure investment. Economic growth will recover to an annual average of 6.3% in 2020/21-2024/25.
We expect consumer price inflation to exceed the mid-point of the central bank's 2-6% target range in 2020-24. The key driver will be a sustained recovery in domestic demand. Our forecasts assume normal monsoons.
The rupee is forecast to stabilise against the US dollar in 2020, averaging Rs70.3:US$1 in 2020. The currency will weaken against the US dollar in 2021-24, owing to a persistent current-account deficit and rising domestic inflation.
India will remain dependent on imports for its fuel and capital goods needs. The merchandise trade deficit will therefore widen during the forecast period. Business process outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

India's score rises over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.
Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or their merger or acquisition by other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment
2020-21: Restrictions on foreign investment in multi-brand retail are partially removed.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2020-21: A limited trade war with the US continues, despite the damage it inflicts on bilateral strategic ties.
2022-24: The government makes some further efforts to ease the process of borrowing overseas for companies and to reduce capital-account restrictions. However, full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes
2020-21: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax (GST).
Financing
2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks, raising risks to banking sector stability but improving the availability of finance for corporate borrowers.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad issues persist in public-sector banks.
The labour market
2020-21: Reforms to labour laws move at a glacial pace owing to obstruction by trade unions and opposition groups.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at central-government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure
2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation for projects such as the Bharatmala road connectivity scheme.
2022-24: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness
2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by regional standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.35bn people in 2018, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2018 when measured in nominal US dollars or in purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the Westminster model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be slight.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.
