Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's domination of the central government at any point during its full term (2019-24). This will ensure continuity in policy, particularly as this is the second consecutive term for the BJP.
The results of the recent election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised around the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts. The PMO and the National Security Advisor played a key role in the outgoing government, and we believe that they will continue to dominate the policy agenda in the next five years.
Tensions between Hindus and Muslims have increased in recent years. There is a heightened possibility of communal violence in the light of the Supreme Court's decision in mid-November to allot a disputed piece of land in Ayodhya, located in the state of Uttar Pradesh, for construction of a Hindu temple. However, the state government (which controls the local police) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, in order to avoid public criticism and international scrutiny.
The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) pose risks to political stability. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders within the area, instances of unrest have been reported. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move will also increase the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch
State assembly elections held in October resulted in a BJP-led government in Haryana, but a hung assembly in Maharashtra. Uddhav Thackeray, president of the Shiv Sena, was eventually sworn in as the new chief minister of Maharashtra in November, depriving the BJP representative of seats in the upper house of parliament. However, the state government led by Mr Thackeray is likely to be an unstable one. The coalition comprises the Shiv Sena, the Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) and the Indian National Congress; all three are traditional rivals. Assembly elections commenced in Jharkhand at end-November. We expect the ruling BJP to secure another term in office there.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they are significantly short of a majority. Given the BJP's strong performance in the general and state elections, the party and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) are expected to achieve a majority in the Rajya Sabha by mid-2021. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations
Tensions with Pakistan will be exacerbated by the Indian government's move in August to revoke the special status granted to J&K. Shortly after the revocation was announced, Pakistan downgraded its diplomatic ties with India, and India responded in kind. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties between the two countries. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir in the short term. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors there. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
Trade tensions between the US and India will persist over the next few years, slowing the expansion of bilateral trade flows. However, they are unlikely to escalate into a serious deterioration in relations. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence. To this effect, India has boosted security co-operation with the US in recent years, and this will continue during our forecast period.
China's growing influence in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. Despite some attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2020-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends
The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. One area of priority will be resolving bad debt problems in the banking sector that have held back lending to business. In the budget delivered in July 2019, the government announced plans to provide Rs700bn (US$10bn) to help to shore up public-sector banks in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March). We believe that this sum will help to address balance-sheet problems. It will improve liquidity in the banking sector but given weak business sentiment, this initiative is unlikely to boost lending in the months ahead.
We expect incentives to be offered to four key labour-intensive sectors: construction, tourism, gems and jewellery, and garments and textiles. However, these incentives will be market-distorting, protectionist and a point of contention with countries such as the US in 2020-24. More positively for India's economic productivity, the government plans to liberalise foreign investment restrictions in sectors including insurance, the media and aviation.
The government is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements, could be undertaken. Once the NDA has control of the Rajya Sabha, from mid-2021, the legislative process will be eased. However, we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the Bharatmala roads project and the Smart Cities Mission-will remain a priority, partly as a response to the rapid pace of urbanisation, and partly to boost the business environment. However, many projects will face financing difficulties, as they envision a level of public-private partnership that seems unlikely to be realised, given how subdued private investment activity remains.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy
The government announced a slew of fiscal stimulus measures in August and September in response to weak GDP data for April-June. The measures included initiatives for ailing sectors of the economy, such as automotive, banking and housing. Notably, the government also gave companies the option to pay corporate tax at a lower rate of 22% (25.2% including various surcharges), from 30% previously. This was backdated to the start of fiscal year 2019/20, in order to spur private-sector activity.
Fiscal stimulus measures and the revenue foregone owing to the corporate tax cut will leave a large hole in government finances. We expect the fiscal deficit to widen to the equivalent of 3.9% of GDP in 2019/20. As the economy recovers, the government will attempt to consolidate the fiscal finances, leading to an improvement in the budget deficit to 3.1% of GDP by 2022/23. Thereafter, spending pressures will increase in the run-up to the parliamentary election in 2024, resulting in a widening of the budget deficit in 2023/24. Our forecast assumes no more tax cuts in 2020-2023/24.
Efforts to deepen the tax base and increase levels of tax compliance will, nevertheless, continue over the forecast period; India's tax/GDP ratio remains relatively low. Welfare payments and infrastructure spending will remain key areas of focus for the government. It will seek to increase the reach of schemes such as the Ayushman Bharat health insurance scheme. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment. Over the medium term, the fiscal deficit will remain significant, averaging the equivalent of 3.4% of GDP a year in 2020/21-2024/25.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits being recorded by several state governments, which are not included in the national figure. The deep deficits in some states, such as Punjab, will present implicit liabilities for the central government and could pose downside risks to GDP growth over the next five years by crowding out private investment.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will maintain inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%, throughout 2020-24. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two heads of the bank under BJP rule-means that inflation is more likely to trend above 4% than below it.
Weak inflation, ebbing growth and pressure from the government have led the RBI to loosen policy several times in 2019. In October the RBI sanctioned a 25-basis-point reduction in the repurchase (repo) rate to 5.15%, a nine-year low. Consequently, the reverse repo rate was reduced to 4.9%. However, we believe that with inflation gradually recovering and policy rates already low by historical standards, the RBI will hold rates in 2020. The central bank will then undertake some tightening in 2021-22 as demand-side pressures associated with the country's rapid economic growth build. As the pace of growth moderates in 2023-24, the RBI will return to a neutral stance.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth
The Indian economy grew at the slowest rate in more than six years in the quarter ending September 2019. Real GDP growth slowed to 4.6% year on year in April-June, compared with a rate of 5% in the previous quarter. Weak consumer sentiment and tepid investment were the main reasons for the slowdown. The data have reinforced our view that the process of economic recovery will be protracted. Nevertheless, a series of stimulus measures enacted by the government, coupled with a low-interest-rate environment, are likely to spur demand and investment from the second half of 2019/20. Overall, we expect the economy to grow by 4.9% in 2019/20.
We now believe that the scope for further tax and interest-rate cuts is limited over the forecast period. As a consequence we have revised down our forecasts and expect real GDP to grow by an annual average of 6.3% in 2020/21-2024/25, compared with 6.5% previously. A recovery in global growth in 2021 will support exports, but an anticipated acceleration in investment growth will suck in more imports of goods and services, which will exert a drag on the headline GDP figure. Growth is expected to moderate to an average of 6.3% in 2024/25 as tighter monetary conditions dampen investment growth and temper consumption. India will, nevertheless, remain among the fastest-growing major economies during the forecast period.
In factor-cost terms, the services sector will remain the largest component of the economy and will grow at a relatively brisk pace over the forecast period. Conversely, manufacturing will remain below potential, owing to structural limitations such as challenges relating to land acquisition. Meanwhile, the agricultural sector's contribution to GDP will continue to decrease over the forecast period. Public investment in the sector will be aimed at short-term gains, rather than fostering improved productivity.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation
Lower crude oil prices will have a dampening effect on prices in 2020, but this will be more than offset by the lagged effect of currency depreciation in 2019 and the lingering adverse effects of an extended monsoon. Consumer price inflation is forecast to accelerate in 2020, to an average of 4.2%, from an estimated 3.4% in 2019. In 2021 sharp increases in food and global oil prices will lift consumer price inflation to 4.4% on average. Food and beverages have a weighting of around 45% in the consumer price index, and so any volatility in agricultural output will affect price stability. Our forecast assumes a normal monsoon in that year.
The adoption of a tighter monetary policy stance by the RBI in late 2021 will offset the inflationary impact of continued strengthening in oil prices in 2022, keeping consumer price growth steady at 4.4%. As oil prices stabilise in 2023-24 and the RBI accords a higher priority to containing inflationary pressures, consumer price growth is expected to ease to an average of 4.3%.
Low global prices for oil and industrial raw materials will keep producer price inflation muted at 1.8% in 2020. As prices for oil and other commodities strengthen, producer price inflation will firm to an average of 3.5% in 2021-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates
We expect the rupee to end 2019 at a weaker rate of Rs71.8:US$1, compared with Rs69.8:US$1 at end-2018. The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive monetary loosening stance in 2019, along with high political risks associated with the removal of J&K's special constitutional status, have weighed on the exchange rate. Weakness in the economy will exert depreciatory pressure on the currency in 2020. Nevertheless, the rupee will stabilise at an average of Rs70.3:US$1 as a further drop in global oil prices leads to a narrowing in the current-account deficit as a proportion of GDP. This stabilisation will be supported by an interest-rate cut by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) against the backdrop of an anticipated economic slowdown in the US. In the near term, the rupee:US dollar exchange rate will remain vulnerable to temporary spikes in the level of political risk in India.
In 2021-23 the rupee will return to a gradual depreciating trend against the US dollar, reflecting India's persistent current-account deficit and relatively high levels of inflation. We expect the rupee to appreciate slightly in 2024, owing to an easing of external payment pressures. However, the country's real effective exchange rate will remain relatively stable during our forecast period, and benefits to India's export sector from the rupee's weakening against the US dollar will therefore be limited.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector
Stronger investment from 2020 and higher oil prices from 2021 will swell the import bill, resulting in a widening of the trade deficit. Merchandise exports will grow at a faster pace than imports over the next five years, but India's export manufacturing sector will be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth of India's key service export sectors, particularly business process outsourcing and information technology. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit, averaging the equivalent of 1.8% of GDP annually in 2020-24.
Inward direct investment will remain strong in 2020-24, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses. We expect annual direct investment inflows to rise to US$60bn by 2024, from an estimated US$47bn in 2019. Inward portfolio investment slid into negative territory in July-August 2019, owing to higher taxes imposed on foreign institutional investors. These tax changes were later rolled back as part of the government's efforts to revive the economy. We therefore expect these inflows to remain positive in 2020-24 as investor confidence is restored.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit previously expected the socioeconomic crisis and collapse in oil revenue since early 2019 to trigger regime change. However, in recent months, risks to this assumption have risen and our baseline forecast now assumes that the civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, will retain power throughout the 2020-24 forecast period. On this basis, we expect an ongoing deterioration of the economy, continued outward migration, and a poorer and more violent Venezuela. Despite US sanctions, and their impact on oil production, the Maduro regime has managed internal dissent through a patronage system that rewards loyalty, as well as through strict control of the security forces.
The scale of the socioeconomic collapse and the elevated level of political instability will ensure that the Maduro regime will continue to be challenged economically and politically. In July 2020 we expect the US government to not renew waivers on Chevron and other US oil companies; this will destabilise crude production, at least in the short term. Moreover, given that it will lose control over the legislature in 2021, the opposition will be under strong pressure in 2020 to step up its efforts to oust the regime. Mr Maduro will continue to face challenges to maintain the current patronage system and remain in control.
The government has recently allowed the official exchange rate to float, which has alleviated pressures on its foreign-exchange reserves. Furthermore, de facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding, which aids price stability and thus the availability of some basic goods. These measures are not a product of economic orthodoxy, but of policy decisions to ensure the regime's survival. We do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis.

Venezuela is in 78th position globally in the business environment rankings for 2020-24, up from 80th in the 2015-19 historical period. As the economic crisis begins to bottom out in 2020, some improvements are expected, but reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment are unlikely.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2020-21: Limited rollback of interventionist measures, such as price controls. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2022-24: Contract rights remain subdued, while red tape and ad hoc interventionism will continue.
Policy towards foreign investment
2020-21: Most attempts to attract investment prove unsuccessful, owing to political instability.
2022-24: Actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights deteriorate.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2020-21: Currency controls are made less opaque, but restrictions remain on private-sector access to foreign currency.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves, albeit very slowly.
Taxes
2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political instability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major rise in public spending.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but declining risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures.
Financing
2020-21: Inflation remains high and concerns around economic instability restrict financing to only short-term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour creates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2020-21: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts. A new government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2022-24: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but continued risk of water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent. Deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election of Hugo Chávez in 1998, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power before his death in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to US$20.9bn in 2018, as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus at 3.6% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit had long maintained that Venezuela's economic crisis would be a trigger for regime change. However, the risks to this assumption were always high and had grown in recent months. We have therefore changed our baseline forecasts to assume that the military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) will retain power, despite severe economic and international pressure. Mr Maduro has remained in office amid a deepening humanitarian crisis in what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. The imposition of US sanctions has taken a dramatic economic toll, in particular by causing a collapse in oil production. However, a shift towards Asian markets has provided some stability to oil production in recent months, as has support from Russia and Cuba to circumvent US sanctions. In addition, the regime continues to benefit from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities. These sources of US dollars have prevented sanctions from fatally wounding the regime's patronage system. It is this patronage, along with strict control over the military, the police and paramilitary forces, and purges within its ranks, which has allowed the regime successfully to manage internal dissent.
Internal and external efforts to oust Mr Maduro are fading. The opposition, led by the president of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó, has lost the momentum it held in early 2019 after abortive dialogue efforts and, in particular, after the failed uprising in April. International pressure has plateaued as the administration of the US president, Donald Trump, shifts its attention to the November 2020 US presidential election; meanwhile, the Lima Group and the Organisation of American States (OAS) seem to have exhausted most of their diplomatic ammunition. Large-scale emigration has also benefited Mr Maduro. The exodus has eased pressure on it, while increasing inflows of workers' remittances, which provide the regime with hard currency. Furthermore, the population has grown protest-weary and there has, in relative terms, been some stabilisation of the economy; de facto dollarisation has brought about an improvement in price stability and thus increased the availability of some basic goods.
Although it is no longer our baseline forecast, we recognise that there is still a very high risk of some sort of political transition. There are three main paths to this: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as very low. Although negotiations sponsored by Norway are set to resume (it is unclear when), we believe that trust issues on both sides are insurmountable and therefore do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis. We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup.
The risks of such a political transition will be particularly high in 2020. We expect the Trump administration to refuse to grant an additional waiver to Chevron, and other US oil services firms, in July. This will again destabilise oil production in the short term and test the regime's ability to maintain cohesion among its ranks. But perhaps most important is the fact that the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly-the only remaining legitimate body-in January 2021, assuming that the regime engineers rigged elections in late 2020. Without such power, the possibility of a transition towards an opposition-led or mixed administration would plummet. Mr Guaidó and the opposition will therefore be under pressure to try to force regime change before then; the prospect of the PSUV clinging to power on a permanent basis could prove a trigger for a renewed popular uprising. In such an environment, and if sanctions bite further, pragmatists within government and the military could turn on Mr Maduro, paving the way for some sort of political transition. The country's crumbling infrastructure could also act as a trigger for transition. A particularly dry summer (January-April) could exacerbate what is already likely to be a difficult season in 2020, leading to severe electricity and water shortages, with the prospect of protests against the regime.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch
On the assumption that the Maduro regime clings to power, legislative elections will take place in December 2020. These elections will be neither free nor fair, and so the opposition will lose control of the National Assembly. If the opposition were to secure some sort of political change in 2020, the interim government would pursue deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority, and would attempt to hold a vote within 12 months of its formation, although this would be a major challenge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community. However, efforts by most governments in Latin America (under the Lima Group banner) to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted several rounds of crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. The most important of the US sanctions is a freeze on Venezuelan assets abroad, which will further complicate the regime's attempts to sustain the current patronage system; in September it also introduced a travel ban on senior Venezuelan officials. Moreover, we expect waivers that allow Chevron and other US oil companies to continue operating in Venezuela not to be renewed in July 2020, given the imminence of the US election. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given Mr Trump's aversion to such adventurism. However, if tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-required to stabilise the economy and secure the long-term future of PDVSA, the state oil company. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seemingly with little success in terms of finance for investment. That said, Russia is believed to be helping PDVSA to circumvent US sanctions (for a fee). However, Russia's interest in Venezuela is mainly geopolitical, not economic. If a transition from the Maduro regime came about, we believe that Russia (and China) would be willing to work with its successor in order to protect their current investments.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends
Given our view that Mr Maduro will retain power for the duration of our forecast period, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. There has been evidence of attempts to tighten monetary policy in recent months, in order to rein in hyperinflation and abandon foreign-exchange controls (official exchange rates are in line with the black market). De facto dollarisation of the economy is expanding; although this was not a tacit goal for the regime, Mr Maduro now welcomes it. Other under-the-radar adjustments are possible in the coming years, as long as these benefit the survival of the regime. Such efforts are unlikely to bring about economic stability, owing to the absence of comprehensive microeconomic reform or improvements in the rule of law, and policy predictability will not be forthcoming under the present regime. In this environment, domestic supply will be persistently weak.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy
The authorities have not published complete data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit this year to remain well into double digits as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Money printing will continue to finance the government's deficits in 2020-24. However, growing remittance inflows and chronically weaker domestic demand will partly offset the need to monetise budget deficits. The public debt/GDP ratio will remain very high in the coming years; however, the sovereign's default on most of its interest and principal repayments will curb government spending. At present, we assume no debt restructuring during the forecast period. Moreover, the country's weak fiscal position is complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears. However, bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. The key PDVSA 2020 bond, which was secured using 50.1% of the shares of Citgo (PDVSA's US subsidiary) as collateral, fell due at end-October and was not paid. A US federal appeals court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government, which will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, is seeking to seize shares of Citgo stock. That said, the US considers Citgo and its Caribbean facilities to be under Mr Guaidó's purview. As a result, the latest sanctions from the US Treasury department include provisions forbidding the transfer of Venezuelan assets, thus shielding Citgo assets from seizure by creditors. We expect the Trump administration to keep these measures in place during 2020. However, once the PSUV retakes control of the (until now legitimate) National Assembly, Citgo assets will no longer be safeguarded.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. However, a significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of the year and a strong contraction in domestic demand have had a temporary steadying effect, which has slowed hyperinflationary pressures and allowed some stabilisation of the bolívar during 2019. Nevertheless, the underlying causes of inflation remain unaddressed. Hyperinflation has quickened the rate of dollarisation of the economy (more than 50% of transactions are now thought to be conducted in US dollars). We believe that Venezuela is heading towards overall de facto dollarisation. Monthly inflation will rise again in the short term and will remain substantial. However, given the effect of dollarisation on price stability, we do not expect a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced in 2018.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 36.2% in 2019 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 70% since 2013), we expect a further decline of 20.5% in 2020. This will be driven by weaker private demand, owing to falling real incomes and continued migration, and-most importantly-a further contraction in oil output. In 2021-24 we forecast that economic growth will contract at an annual average rate of 4.6%, a more moderate rate of decline than in previous years, assuming a stabilisation of oil output. Private consumption will continue to contract in 2020 as unemployment, violence and falling incomes continue to force mass migration, further weakening domestic demand.
We believe that the Trump administration will bar Chevron and other US oil companies from operating in Venezuela, probably in July 2020. We expect this action to curb oil production at the Petropiar joint venture (between Chevron and PDVSA) in the Orinoco Belt. The impact on oil production will be limited in the short term; after the ban, PDVSA would either take full control of the venture or assume joint control with Russian oil company Rosneft. Even so, we expect oil output to slip to just 600,000 barrels/day in 2020. Under PDVSA control, crude production will fail to reach previous figures. In the medium term, we expect oil output to continue to fall-albeit more gradually-owing to serious operational problems, such as difficulties in obtaining equipment for repairs or in finding qualified staff.
Export volumes will start to recover marginally in 2022-24, on the back of moderately higher global oil prices and as producers become more accustomed to the new post-sanctions export markets. In addition, import compression will continue, which means that net exports will partly offset chronically weak internal demand.
There are substantial risks to our forecasts, which are based on an assumption that Mr Maduro will retain power throughout our forecast period. In the event of a transition, there would be upside risks to our medium-term baseline; the degree of this improvement would depend on the characteristics of the transition and on the new government's macroeconomic programme.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation
Severely reduced domestic supply, currency constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were recently published by the BCV, but there is a significant divergence between these and data from other sources. Amid continuing questions over the data, we will, for now, continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. Dollarisation and the regime's heavy restrictions on credit will see inflation come down from the hyperinflationary rates of recent years. Nevertheless, it will remain very high for as long as the Maduro regime stays in power, given huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand, as well as the need for the regime to monetise its fiscal deficits. Weather-related shocks are a perennial risk to the inflation outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates
Given incessant inflation and its effect on nominal values, we believe that another currency denomination (as in March 2018) or the introduction of a new currency is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to forecast. With few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime announced a loosening of currency controls in mid-2019. Although this is a positive move, access to US dollars via formal means is limited as significant barriers remain in place that in practice restrict access to dollars. We continue to believe that the government will maintain a number of indirect controls on the foreign-exchange market. In this environment, a black-market exchange-rate premium is inevitable. On November 29th the official exchange rate was BsS38,930:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of BsS41,594:US$1. The premium, although sizeable, was still small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector
We have recently revised our current-account data in line with the BCV's publication of official figures for 2017-18. These show that Venezuela posted current-account surpluses in this period, on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. In 2019 the collapse of goods export earnings (owing to US sanctions on the oil trade) has hit the trade balance hard. Nevertheless, based on the latest data, we estimate that the current account remained in surplus as a result of growing inflows of workers' remittances and the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn this year).
We expect the current account to remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, averaging 3.6% of GDP in 2020-24. The trade surplus will recover gradually, as international oil prices increase moderately and as the country steps up exports to Asian markets. This will be supported by continued weakness in domestic demand, rising remittances from abroad and the fact that the sovereign will remain in default throughout the forecast period.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Muhammadu Buhari won a second and final four-year presidential term on February 23rd. The policy agenda he campaigned on did not involve root-and-branch reform, only cosmetic improvements to the business environment.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
Policy will be interventionist. Import bans on agricultural and manufactured goods will be widened to support local industry and farmers, and the Central Bank of Nigeria will maintain an overvalued official naira rate with which to channel cheap US dollars to preferred buyers.
The multiple-exchange-rate regime will not be dismantled under a Buhari administration; the arrangement is critical for making petrol subsidies affordable and underpins the government's interventionist approach to industrialisation.
Even though a multiple-exchange-rate system will persist, non-official rates will converge and so in reality Nigeria will run a dual exchange-rate regime. Oil prices will be high enough to prevent a return to capital controls (as temporarily imposed in 2016), but import restrictions will be widened, especially on food.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2020-24) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to restrict imports and support local producers. This in turn will keep credit conditions tight; even with some reduction in the central bank's policy rate from 2021, inflation will be running too high for sustained monetary loosening, and credit growth will generally be slow.
In 2020 export earnings will fall as global oil prices decline, but imports will also fall. Imports and exports will both rise in 2021-24, and a current-account surplus will be maintained throughout the forecast period.

Nigeria's business environment score worsens slightly for the forecast period (2020-24), as do its global and regional rankings, as the administration struggles with the reform process.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2020-21: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector remains characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2022-24: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress is slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2020-21: In 2020 the government aims to squeeze revenue from oil companies to address fiscal imbalances. New royalty rates in the offshore subsector harm direct investment inflows from foreign oil majors.
2022-24: Higher world oil prices and so easing fiscal pressures lessen the need to embark on a divestment programme. Energy firms are in any case hesitant to increase their presence in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2020-21: Import bans are widened dramatically, but capital controls prove unnecessary, barring another oil price crash.
2022-24: A premium between the overvalued official and parallel-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2020-21: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Value-added tax (VAT) is increased in 2020 from 5% to 7.2% to fund a higher minimum wage, introduced in 2019.
2022-24: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation, particularly for offshore oilfields. The need for new consumer taxes is alleviated by higher world oil prices and, as a result, hydrocarbons revenue.
Financing
2020-21: Domestic interest rates are high, but fall as restrictions are loosened on local participation in some parts of the money market. The government seeks soft multilateral loans wherever possible, but also depends on Eurobonds.
2022-24: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts savings and investment.
The labour market
2020-21: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2022-24: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff; unemployment remains high and the market loose.
Infrastructure
2020-21: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints and is crowded out by other spending categories, including debt-servicing and higher public-sector wages. Although growth in private-sector investment is likely, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2022-24: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2020-21: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2022-24: Research spending remains low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multiparty democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in 2015, and Mr Buhari secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability
Muhammadu Buhari won the February 2019 presidential election and will stay in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. He will be under immense pressure to restore stability across Nigeria, but managing the country's myriad security threats will prove an insuperable challenge, mainly because the military and police are overstretched and will be unable to tackle simultaneous security crises. Emergencies will in effect be triaged, with resources being deployed to whichever is seen as most pressing at any given time.
Conflict in the north-east between the government and two Islamist terrorist groups, Boko Haram and Islamic State West Africa Province (ISWAP), is an urgent issue. As the area is a stronghold of the ruling party, the president will be keen to reassert control. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the region will remain a low-level conflict zone, and the campaign will divert security forces away from pockets of instability elsewhere.
One other hotspot is the agricultural Middle Belt, where farmers and nomads are in conflict over land and water resources. Formal land-titling is a potential solution to the crisis, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious.
Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to violence in the Middle Belt. Vigilantes will be deployed to make up for shortfalls in formal security personnel, but will not be an effective substitute. Again, the direct effect of the conflict on the security situation will be localised, but the entire country will feel the secondary effects in the form of reduced food supplies and higher prices.
Another localised conflict with wide-ranging consequences will be militant activity in the oil-producing south, where insurgents are demanding more hydrocarbons revenue to be retained locally for development. Weak governance in the region has, as a by-product, encouraged oil theft and sabotage of pipelines and other facilities. Millions of barrels of oil are lost annually (22m in the first half of 2019). Reforming how federal revenue is allocated is a massive, politically loaded task that continually divides parliament. The Economist Intelligence Unit's assumption is that attacks on oil infrastructure by aggrieved militants and saboteurs will continue to be a major security problem in Delta state, with indirect consequences for the entire federation in the form of disrupted oil exports.
In a more general sense, the military and the police will be too poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping across the country. Widespread poverty and unemployment are feeding into a cycle of crime that will be difficult (if not impossible) to break, given a bleak economic outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch
The next national elections are in 2023. Custom dictates that the presidential candidates of both main parties will be from the south, which is a stronghold for the main opposition party, the People's Democratic Party (PDP)-allowing them to improve on abysmally low turnout there in the last presidential vote in 2019. Moreover, Nigeria's economic outlook up to the next elections does not point towards a material decrease in widespread poverty. Frustration with declining living standards and high levels of crime and instability will be directed at the governing All Progressives Congress, giving the PDP a winning edge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat that they pose. Trade relations with South Africa have boomed recently but diplomatic ties have deteriorated over xenophobic attacks against Nigerians living in South Africa (and, in response, against South African businesses in Nigeria). The South African authorities have long struggled to curb xenophobic violence and serious bouts do occasionally occur-although the issue is emotive, it is unlikely to undermine high-level ties.
As regards investment, India is the largest market for Nigerian oil and will become a bigger source of foreign finance. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will fall short of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player in Sub-Saharan Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused.
Exasperation over smuggling-which policymakers view as undermining a protectionist agenda-has led to all of Nigeria's land borders being closed for goods traffic. The measure will prove temporary, as social unrest would be a risk if consumer prices were to rise for any sustained period. However, the move underlines erratic commitment to regional trade, particularly when it threatens local agriculture or manufacturing competitiveness. Meaningful participation in an Africa-wide free trade agreement that the government acceded to in 2019 is therefore unlikely.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends
An advisory council has been set up by the president to assist on economic reform, but the direction of economic policy under Mr Buhari will remain interventionist. Courting technocratic advisors is a common tradition among Nigerian leaders, but in reality liberal policy intentions flounder if they stand to upset the delicate status quo: market distortions in Nigeria have reached proportions whereby undoing them would necessitate a major correction-something that Mr Buhari is likely to balk at.
Measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be completed. Electricity tariffs have barely changed since 2015, meaning that the adjustment needed to allow distributors to turn a profit would be enormous-and a recipe for high inflation and a severe political backlash. Likewise, an overvalued official rate for Nigeria's currency, the naira, is critical for maintaining petrol subsidies (over 90% of petrol is imported), and Mr Buhari will not willingly reverse pump-price caps and risk popular outrage (attempts to hike petrol prices in the past have led to disruptive protests).
Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of multiple exchange rates carries an ever-present risk of capital controls being imposed and will be off-putting to those acquiring illiquid assets in Nigeria; foreign direct investment inflows are expected to be equivalent to less than 1% of GDP throughout the forecast period. Adding to these concerns, to defend foreign reserves and the official rate, the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) will probably widen restrictions on foreign exchange access for imported goods (currently 44 items are barred) in 2020 as the average price of oil falls.
Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state-owned companies such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but no structural reforms will take place. Generally, the preference of the Buhari administration will be to sanitise loss-making state companies rather than relinquish control over them. There will be some effort to reduce the NNPC's stake in the upstream oil joint ventures that it has with international oil companies, but uncertainty about fiscal terms and a difficult operating environment mean that investor interest will fall short of official expectations, and parliament will resist selling off key public assets cheaply.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits in 2020-24. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to collect overdue taxes and a planned increase in the value-added tax (VAT) rate from 5% now to 7.5% in 2020. (We assume that this will go ahead, despite some parliamentary resistance and with numerous exemptions for consumer goods, as it underpins the whole budget.) Revenue increases in 2020 will be held back by low oil prices, however, and the fact that the new VAT rate is still among the world's lowest. Tax avoidance is widespread, and instability impedes collection in many parts of the country.
Petrol subsidies (whereby losses incurred by the NNPC's retail arm are deducted from federal revenue) will be another drain, and overambitious oil production targets mean that budgeted revenue targets will not be reached. For example, in 2020 the government expects output of 2.2m barrels/day-a level that has not been seen since the oil price slump and is unobtainable, given underinvestment and probable OPEC production quotas. Federally retained revenue is not expected to rise above 3.8% of GDP in 2020-24.
With revenue being so low, fiscal spending power will be highly limited, and budget flexibility will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and, therefore, revenue-under pressure combined with considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Following which, there will be another decline in expenditure in 2024.
In all, we expect an average budget deficit of 2% of GDP a year in 2020-24, with the highest shortfall (2.2% of GDP) in the election year of 2023. These will be financed externally and by soft loans wherever possible, but the bulk of finance will come from commercial debt and local borrowing.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against an abnormally low revenue base. Debt service can take up to half of federal revenue, which is alarming even by heavily-indebted emerging-market standards. A sovereign default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is weaker.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The CBN is inclined towards boosting the supply side of the economy, but inflation is well above the targeted upper limit of 9% and monetary loosening in 2020 could lead to capital outflows and put downward pressure on the naira at a time of low oil prices. Overall, we do not expect interest rates to move until 2021, when inflation will enter a sustained downward trend, giving the CBN a chance to act on a growth-first impulse. We also expect that oil prices will rise in 2021-23, driving higher foreign-exchange inflows and lessening the need to support the naira through portfolio inflows.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth
Economic growth will remain weak but will pick up as the forecast period progresses. In 2020 the economy will grow by just 2%, unchanged from 2019, held back by power shortages, insecurity, elevated inflation and tight credit conditions. With high debt-servicing costs leaving no room for fiscal activism, monetary policy is the main lever that can drive a recovery. In 2021, as external conditions strengthen with faster global growth and inflation gradually decelerates-allowing for monetary easing-the rate of growth will quicken to 2.9%. Growth will average 3.2% in 2021-24, a level that is well below potential.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agricultural growth will be lacklustre. Although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will continue to be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and investment will be held back by uncertainty about future fiscal terms; hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels seen prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery that is due to come on stream by late 2021 will boost downstream oil activity and wider economic growth in 2022-24. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of electricity shortages, although looser credit conditions will stimulate growth as the forecast period progresses. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth, but it will nonetheless be held back by the impact of protectionism on trade (which accounts for over 15% of GDP).
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation
After averaging an estimated 11.4% in 2019, inflation will stay high in 2020, at 11.3%, well above the CBN's target ceiling of 9%. Widening foreign-exchange restrictions on imports of manufactures and food at a time of inadequate local supply will be the main cause. A probable hike in VAT from 5% to 7.5% will also contribute, but the inflationary impact will be muted by exemptions across multiple consumer-goods categories. With base effects from this fading, and with oil prices rising (reducing the need for further import restrictions as a means of defending the naira), core inflation will gradually ease over the remainder of the forecast period, bringing the headline rate down with it, to an average of 8.3% in 2024. Conflict and agricultural supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-will prevent a faster slide.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2020-24, with an official rate for government business and a more market-determined rate for investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors or firms (including the NNPC, which budgets for petrol imports at the official rate) deemed important for economic or political reasons.
The central bank governor, Godwin Emefiele, has proven willing to adopt unconventional measures to keep the naira stable, which he argues is essential to avoid an inflationary spike and capital flight. As oil prices decline in 2020, foreign-exchange restrictions will be widened to curb what has been a surge in import demand. However, there will not be a need for capital controls (which were introduced temporarily in 2016), as we expect a current-account surplus to persevere, and easier global monetary conditions in 2020 will support the naira through portfolio inflows. Higher global crude prices thereafter will continue to support the official rate.
Currency stability means steady real appreciation of the naira against the currencies of Nigeria's trading partners as inflation remains high relative to those countries. For this reason there is a downside risk of policymakers opting to devalue in order to regain international competitiveness for the non-oil sector. However, the CBN's industrial strategy (the central bank has long had similarities with a development agency) is focused on supplying the domestic market, and such an eventuality is not forecast. We forecast that the naira will weaken to an average of N313.7:US$1 in 2024, from an estimated average of N306.6:US$1 in 2019.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. It also best represents exchange-rate policy. Indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued, which is in line with official calculations.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector
Export earnings will move in tandem with oil production and price trends. In 2020 falling oil prices will offset rising production and cause earnings to decline. In 2021-23 higher global prices and output gains (with a new mega-refinery due to come on stream in 2021, which we expect to be export-oriented) will lead to a return to strong export growth, which will slow in 2024 as oil prices retreat again.
The government promotes import-substitution through foreign-exchange restrictions on imports of certain goods (mainly manufactures and agricultural products). After a sharp rise in purchases across various import categories in 2019, widening import restrictions will cause the import bill to drop back in 2020. Lower oil-and so petrol-prices that will also have a dampening effect year (refinery capacity is low, and Nigeria imports much of its petrol). As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23 and global oil prices rise, imports will grow again.
Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, although they will dip in 2020 as growth falters in the US, which is home to a large Nigerian diaspora. Overall, the current-account surplus will widen from an estimated 0.4% of GDP in 2019 to 1.9% of GDP in 2024 as imports fall in 2020 and exports-of both crude oil and refined products-rise.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the National Democratic Alliance (NDA) government to serve out its second five-year term, which expires in 2024. Its re-election in May 2019 will underpin political stability. We expect the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration in 2020-24.
Relations with the US will remain warm in 2020-24, albeit punctuated by trade tensions. Despite efforts to normalise relations, ties with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's rising influence in South Asia. Relations with Pakistan will also be tense, owing to continuing border tensions. Low-level military clashes between the two countries remain likely in 2020-24.
The budget deficit will widen as a percentage of GDP in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March), owing to a slew of fiscal measures announced by the government, most notably a corporate tax cut that will crimp revenue collection. During the forecast period the fiscal deficit will remain wide overall, as the government will continue to spend heavily on infrastructure and subsidy payments.
Real GDP growth will slump to 4.9% in 2019/20, owing to a slowdown in private consumption and infrastructure investment. Economic growth will recover to an annual average of 6.5% in 2020/21-2024/25.
We expect consumer prices to increase by an annual average of 4.3% in 2020-24. Lower global crude oil prices will help to contain inflationary pressures in 2020, allowing the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to maintain an accommodative stance. The RBI will take a more hawkish stance from 2021 as stronger domestic demand adds to price pressures.
Owing to an expected widening of the interest-rate differential with the US, the rupee is expected to appreciate slightly in 2020. The currency will weaken against the US dollar in 2021-24, averaging Rs72.2:US$1 in those years, owing to a persistent current-account deficit and rising domestic inflation.
India will remain dependent on imports for its fuel and capital goods needs. The merchandise trade deficit will therefore widen during the forecast period. Business process outsourcing and information technology will remain the key service export sectors in 2020-24.

India's score rises over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.
Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2020-21: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies.
2022-24: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closure of loss-making businesses or their merger or acquisition by other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment
2020-21: Restrictions on foreign investment in multi-brand retail are partially removed.
2022-24: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2020-21: A limited trade war with the US continues, despite the damage it inflicts on bilateral strategic ties.
2022-24: The government makes some further efforts to ease the process of borrowing overseas for companies and to reduce capital-account restrictions. However, full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes
2020-21: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands.
2022-24: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax (GST).
Financing
2020-21: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks, raising risks to banking sector stability but improving the availability of finance for corporate borrowers.
2022-24: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad issues persist in public-sector banks.
The labour market
2020-21: Reforms to labour laws move at a glacial pace owing to obstruction by trade unions and opposition groups.
2022-24: Some labour reforms make headway at state level. However, reforms at central-government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure
2020-21: The government increases its budgetary allocation for projects such as the Bharatmala road connectivity scheme.
2022-24: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness
2020-21: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore. Expenditure on research and development as a proportion of GDP remains low by regional standards.
2022-24: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.35bn people in 2018, according to the UN. Its economy was the third-largest in the world in 2018 when measured in nominal US dollars or in purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the Westminster model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be slight.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2020-24, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.
