Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability
The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's dominance of the central government at any point during its full term (2019-24). This will ensure consistency in policy, particularly as this is the second consecutive term for the BJP.
The results of the recent election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised around the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts. The PMO and the National Security Advisor played a key role in the outgoing government, and we believe that they will continue to dominate the policy agenda in the next five years.
Sporadic instances of street violence occurred during the term of the first Modi government, directed particularly towards minority groups. The BJP's right-wing affiliates and sister organisations within the larger Hindu right-wing ecosystem (colloquially known as the Sangh Parivar) used the BJP's political power to pursue their socio-cultural agenda. This includes a goal of recasting India as a Hindu state-a view that puts them at odds with the country's large Muslim minority. Such attacks will persist over the forecast period, but we do not expect them to have a major impact on the business environment.
There is a risk that clashes between religious groups will intensify in states with a history of communal violence, such as Uttar Pradesh and Assam. Tensions between Hindus and Muslims have increased in recent years amid concerns among some Hindu groups about an influx of people from the neighbouring Muslim-majority nation of Bangladesh. However, state governments (which control the local police in India) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, in order to avoid public criticism and international scrutiny.
The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state of Jammu and Kashmir (J&K) will result in a marked deterioration in political stability in that region. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders within the area, instances of unrest have been reported. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move will also increase the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch
On October 21st assembly elections will be conducted in two states, Maharashtra and Haryana. Assembly elections for Jharkhand are expected to take place in November. The BJP and its allies currently hold over 85% of all available Lok Sabha seats in these three states, and we expect the outgoing BJP governments in all three to secure a second term in office.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they are significantly short of a majority. Given the BJP's strong performance in the general election, we now believe that the party will dominate the upcoming state elections, enabling it to nominate more members to the upper house (Rajya Sabha members are elected by state assemblies). The BJP and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) are therefore expected to achieve a majority in the Rajya Sabha by mid-2021. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations
Tensions with Pakistan will be heightened further by the Indian government's revocation of the special status granted to J&K. Shortly after the Indian government announced the revocation, Pakistan downgraded its diplomatic ties with India, and India responded in kind. We expect relations to remain strained, but do not anticipate a complete breakdown of diplomatic ties between the two countries. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir in the short term. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors there. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2020-24, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
Trade tensions between the US and India will persist over the next few years, slowing the expansion of bilateral trade flows. However, they are unlikely to escalate into a serious deterioration in relations. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence. To this effect, India has boosted security co-operation with the US in recent years, and this will continue during our forecast period.
China's growing influence in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. Despite some attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2020-24.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends
The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. One area of priority will be resolving bad debt problems in the banking sector that have held back lending to business. In the budget delivered in July 2019, the government announced plans to provide Rs700bn (US$10bn) to help to shore up public-sector banks in the 2019/20 (April-March) fiscal year. We believe that this sum, if delivered in full, would be sufficient to substantially address balance-sheet problems, but implementation may be a challenge.
We expect incentives to be offered to four key labour-intensive sectors: construction, tourism, gems and jewellery, and garments and textiles. However, these incentives will be market-distorting, protectionist and a point of contention with countries such as the US in 2020-24. More positively for India's economic productivity, the government plans to liberalise foreign investment restrictions in sectors including insurance, the media and aviation.
The government is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements, could be undertaken. Once the NDA has control of the Rajya Sabha, from mid-2021, this will ease the challenges in the legislative process. However we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the Bharatmala roads project and the Smart Cities Mission-will remain a priority, partly as a response to the rapid pace of urbanisation, and partly to boost the business environment. However, many projects will face financing difficulties, as they envision a level of public-private partnership that seems unlikely to be realised, given how subdued private investment activity remains.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy
The government announced a slew of fiscal stimulus measures in August and September following the release of GDP data for April-June, which showed the economy expanding by 5%, representing the slowest pace of growth since the first quarter of 2013. The measures included initiatives for ailing sectors of the economy, such as automotives, banking and housing. Notably, the government also gave companies an option to pay corporate tax at a lower rate of 22% (25.2% including various surcharges), from 30% previously, effective from fiscal year 2019/20, in order to spur private sector activity.
Fiscal stimulus measures and the revenue foregone owing to the corporate tax cut will leave a large hole in government finances. We expect the fiscal deficit to widen to the equivalent of 3.8% of GDP in 2019/20. As the economy recovers, the government will attempt to consolidate the fiscal finances, leading to an improvement in the budget deficit to 3.2% of GDP by 2022/23. Thereafter, spending pressures will increase in the run-up to the parliamentary elections in 2024, resulting in a widening of the budget deficit in 2023/24.
Efforts to deepen the tax base and increase levels of tax compliance will continue over the forecast period; India's tax/GDP ratio remains relatively low. Welfare payments and infrastructure spending will remain key areas of focus for the government. It will seek to increase the reach of schemes such as the Ayushman Bharat health insurance scheme. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment. Over the medium term, the fiscal deficit will remain significant, averaging the equivalent of 3.4% of GDP a year in 2020/21-2024/25.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits being recorded by several state governments, which are not included in the national figure. The deep deficits of some states, such as Punjab, will present implicit liabilities for the central government and could pose downside risks to GDP growth over the next five years by crowding out private investment.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) will maintain inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%, throughout 2020-24. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two heads of the bank under BJP rule-means that inflation is more likely to trend above 4% than below it.
Weak inflation, ebbing growth and pressure from the government have led the RBI to loosen policy several times in 2019. In October the RBI sanctioned a 25-basis-point reduction in the repurchase (repo) rate to 5.15%, a nine-year low. Consequently, the reverse repo rate was reduced to 4.9%. We expect the central bank to cut rates one more time in 2019, at its next monetary policy meeting in December, to provide a further lift to economic growth. However, we believe that with inflation gradually recovering and policy rates already low by historical standards, the RBI will hold rates in 2020. The central bank will then undertake some tightening in 2021-22 as demand-side pressures associated with the country's rapid economic growth build. As the pace of growth moderates in 2023-24, the RBI will return to a neutral stance.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth
The Indian economy grew at the slowest rate in more than six years in the quarter ending June 2019. Real GDP growth slowed to 5% year on year in April-June, compared with a rate of 5.8% in the previous quarter. Depressed consumer sentiment and tepid investment were the main reasons for the slowdown. Despite recent weak economic data, we believe that growth in most components is likely to have bottomed out and that the economy will start to regain momentum from the July-September quarter. A series of stimulus measures enacted by the government, coupled with a low-interest-rate environment, are likely to spur demand and investment in the remaining quarters of 2019/20. Overall, we expect the economy to grow by 5.2% in 2019/20.
Real GDP growth is expected to recover further to an average of 6.7% in 2020/21-2021/22 as domestic demand strengthens. A recovery in global growth in 2021 will also stimulate exports; however, higher domestic investment will also suck in imports. Growth is expected to moderate to 6.4% by 2024/25 as tighter monetary conditions dampen investment growth and temper consumption. India will, nevertheless, remain among the fastest-growing major economies during the forecast period.
In factor-cost terms, the services sector will remain the largest component of the economy and will grow at a relatively brisk pace over the forecast period. Conversely, manufacturing will remain below potential, owing to structural limitations such as challenges relating to land acquisition. Meanwhile, the agricultural sector's contribution to GDP will continue to decrease over the forecast period. Public investment in the sector will be aimed at short-term gains, rather than fostering improved productivity.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation
Lower crude oil prices will have a dampening effect on prices in 2020, but this will be more than offset by a modest pick-up in domestic demand growth, the lagged effect of interest-rate cuts and currency depreciation in 2019. Consumer price inflation is forecast to accelerate in 2020, to 4.1%, from an estimated 3.4% in 2019. An expansionary fiscal policy will also contribute to a rise in price pressures. Prices of food and oil will remain the key factors driving inflationary pressures in 2020-24. Food and beverages have a weighting of around 45% in the consumer price index, and so any volatility in agricultural output will affect price stability.
Later in the forecast period, relatively strong economic growth will stoke demand-pull inflation, while a weakening of the rupee:US dollar exchange rate will exert an upward influence on prices in 2021-23, by pushing up the cost of imports. As oil prices soften in 2024, inflation will moderate slightly in that year.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates
The RBI's adoption of a fairly aggressive monetary loosening stance in 2019 is expected to weigh on the exchange rate this year. The narrowing of interest-rate differentials with other economies, particularly the US, will increase depreciatory pressure on the rupee in the final months of 2019. The rupee will appreciate slightly against the US dollar in 2020, supported by interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) against a backdrop of an anticipated economic slowdown in the US. We expect the rupee to appreciate from an estimated average of Rs70.2:US$1 in 2019 to Rs69.4:US$1 in 2020. In the near term, the rupee:US dollar exchange rate will remain vulnerable to temporary spikes in the level of political risk in India.
In 2021-23 the rupee will return to a gradual depreciating trend against the US dollar, reflecting India's persistent current-account deficit and relatively high levels of inflation. We expect the rupee to appreciate slightly in 2024, owing to an easing in external payment pressures. However, the country's real effective exchange rate will remain relatively stable during our forecast period, and benefits to India's export sector from the rupee's weakening against the US dollar will therefore be limited.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector
A slowdown in merchandise imports, resulting from lower global oil prices and depressed demand for investment goods, will drive a narrowing of the merchandise trade deficit in 2019. From 2020 onwards, stronger investment and higher oil prices (from 2021 onwards) will swell the import bill, reversing that trend. Merchandise exports will grow at a faster pace than imports over the next five years, but India's export manufacturing sector will be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth of India's key service export sectors, particularly business process outsourcing and information technology. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit, averaging the equivalent of 1.7% of GDP annually in 2020-24.
Inward direct investment will remain strong in 2020-24, as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses. We expect annual direct investment inflows to rise to US$60bn by 2024, from an estimated US$47.5bn in 2019. Inward portfolio investment slid into negative territory in July-August 2019, owing to higher taxes imposed on foreign institutional investors. These tax changes were later rolled back as part of the government's efforts to revive the economy. We therefore expect these inflows to remain positive in 2020-24 as investor confidence is restored.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela, is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit has for some time believed that the Maduro regime's position is unsustainable. We currently base our forecasts on a political transition within the five-year period (2020-24) that introduces an interim administration, which we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. Currently, we view some sort of regime change as inevitable. The timing and shape of the transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
Our expectation of a change of government implies sweeping modifications to policymaking, as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented under the transitional and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already. The interim administration of Juan Guaidó has sought to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions-as well as potential donor nations-of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry.
The pace and depth of the adjustment measures will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of a new administration, and how this stability might be impaired by likely demands from multilateral and bilateral lenders for politically difficult reforms. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and other multilaterals, and by the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, the state-owned oil company, PDVSA, will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.

3.36 4.11   80 78   12 12

Venezuela is in 78th position globally in the business environment rankings for 2020-24, up from 80th in the historical period. Assuming regime change, improvements are expected, but it will take time for reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment to bear fruit.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2020-21: Rollback of interventionist measures, such as price controls, begins; concerns over political instability slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2022-24: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the removal of the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2020-21: Regulation by a new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt to attract investment.
2022-24: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2020-21: Currency controls are made less opaque, but restrictions on private-sector access to foreign currency remain.
2022-24: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves, albeit very slowly.
Taxes
2020-21: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public-spending increases.
2022-24: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but declining risk of discriminatory, ad hoc tax measures.
Financing
2020-21: Inflation remains high and concerns around economic instability restrict financing to only short-term.
2022-24: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2020-21: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Past emigration of skilled labour creates skills shortages.
2022-24: Labour-market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2020-21: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid leads to continued rationing and unpredictable blackouts. A new government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2022-24: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2020-21: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2022-24: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election of Hugo Chávez in 1998, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices, combined with strict sanctions on trade from the US, has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to an estimated US$18.8bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus at 2.1% of GDP.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability
The civic-military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) is under severe economic and political pressure, and The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that its position is unsustainable. We currently expect a political transition within our 2020-24 forecast period that introduces an interim administration, which will undertake emergency adjustment measures and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. We originally assumed that regime change would take place by end-2019, but Mr Maduro has clung to power amid a deepening humanitarian crisis in what is becoming a much less populous and much poorer country. The timing and shape of the transition process is therefore highly uncertain. Nonetheless, we continue to believe that regime change is inevitable. The crisis has deeply damaged support for Mr Maduro among the population; we believe that it will also ultimately erode his backing among key supporters in the military who are propping him up in power. It is less clear, however, what the exact trigger for regime change will be.
There are three main paths to a political transition: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as very low. Although negotiations sponsored by Norway are set to resume (it is unclear when), we believe that trust issues on both sides are insurmountable and therefore do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis. We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The escalation of US sanctions means that Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee the regime's raison d'être-the enrichment of its members-and we expect pragmatists within government and the military to turn on him, paving the way for some sort of political transition. However, a failed uprising on April 30th demonstrated the difficulty of this kind of initiative, and has incurred a heavy political cost, as the regime has become more vigilant of discontent among its ranks. The April uprising-which reportedly included top-ranking government officials alongside the president of the National Assembly, Juan Guaidó-confirmed cracks in the regime's ranks at the highest levels. Our forecast for regime change therefore still stands.
This forecast is underpinned by three key assumptions. The first is that regime pragmatists will prevail over hardliners. Despite the ongoing collapse of the patronage system, there are risks to this assumption, not least frequent purges within the military. The presence of dozens of important military figures also leads to co-ordination problems. Secondly, we assume that regime members will deem amnesty offers to be credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and a fear of being prosecuted outside Venezuela (a well-founded concern, given accusations of drug- and weapon-trafficking against regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast is a continued lack of hard currency to sustain the patronage system. Risks to this assumption stem from greater than expected support from Russia or China, and from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, which could provide the regime with more hard currency than we currently expect.
We recognise the very high risks to our baseline view, and believe that there are two main alternate scenarios. The first (and more likely) is the maintenance of the status quo, with the population protest-weary, the regime hunkering down, the opposition deflating, and the country becoming increasingly isolated and impoverished. The second is one of prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict among regime factions. However, we expect neither of these scenarios to be feasible in the medium to long term. With no prospect of real reform, we believe that a chronically weak economy will ultimately make Mr Maduro's position untenable. Violent conflict in Venezuela could prove the trigger for some kind of military action by the US, or by Venezuela's Latin American neighbours, to put an end to the crisis. We continue to believe, therefore, that regime change in the forecast period remains highly likely, even if it does not occur in 2019. Despite our anticipation of a political transition, we expect political instability to persist throughout the 2020-24 forecast period.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch
The opposition's plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities, and for elections within 12 months of its formation. Although this timeline is extremely ambitious-given the scale of the task-we expect national elections to take place early in our forecast period, under a transitional government. International assistance in organising elections would be necessary (and forthcoming). Deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority, the electoral registry and the voting system will be required, but rebuilding trust in the system will be difficult. If the Maduro regime manages to maintain the status quo, legislative elections would take place in December 2020. However, these elections would be neither free nor fair.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community. However, efforts by most governments in Latin America (under the Lima Group banner) to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. The US introduced several rounds of sanctions, the most important of which is a freeze on Venezuelan assets abroad that will further complicate the regime's attempts to sustain the current patronage system; in September it also introduced a travel ban on senior Venezuelan officials. The US administration will remain hawkish in its approach to foreign policy, but we believe that a military intervention is unlikely, given Mr Trump's aversion to such adventurism, especially ahead of the 2020 US election. However, if tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Russia may well be helping the state oil company, PDVSA, to circumvent US sanctions (for a fee). However, both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and the long-term future of PDVSA itself. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seemingly with little success in terms of finance for investment. We believe that Russia and China would be willing to work with a successor government in order to protect their current investments.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends
Our expectation of a government transition implies huge modifications to policymaking, as a new administration would seek to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until the transition occurs, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. There has been evidence in recent months of attempts to tighten monetary policy in order to rein in hyperinflation and (in theory) to abandon foreign-exchange controls. However, we believe that such efforts are doomed to failure, in the absence of comprehensive microeconomic reform, improvements in the rule of law and policy predictability that will not be forthcoming under the present regime.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented under the transitional and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, The prospective Guaidó administration is seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and potential donor nations-such as the US and European countries-of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and in particular, how this might be impaired by probable demands from multilateral and bilateral lenders for politically difficult reforms. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and other multilaterals, totalling US$47bn in an initial four-year deal in 2020-23, with additional smaller agreements thereafter. We also assume a restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. Meanwhile, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself up to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy
The authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit this year to remain well into double digits as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Under our expectation of substantial currency adjustment, the public debt/GDP ratio will rise dramatically in coming years. However, our forecasts assume that a combination of debt restructuring and deep fiscal adjustment will gradually bring the ratio under control. The process will be complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds are in arrears, as are all but one of PDVSA's bonds. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. A US federal appeals court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government, which will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, is seeking to seize shares of Citgo, PDVSA's US subsidiary. However, the latest US sanctions forbid the transfer of Venezuelan assets. This will (for the time being) shield Citgo and its Caribbean facilities, which the US now considers to be under Mr Guaidó's purview.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. However, a significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of the year-and a strong contraction in domestic demand-have had a temporary steadying effect, which has slowed hyperinflationary pressures and allowed the bolívar to stabilise to some extent in recent months. We expect monthly inflation to rise again in the short term, as the underlying causes of inflation remain unaddressed. However, given our assumption that a transitional government-with a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation-will come to power, we do not currently project a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced in 2018 (although there are substantial political risks to this forecast). Instead, under a new government, we expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of an emergency macroeconomic stabilisation plan. In this context, the introduction of a new currency, a temporary peg or outright currency substitution, is highly likely.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 34.1% in 2019 (and a cumulative contraction of almost 66% since 2013), we expect a further slight contraction of 1% in 2020, as the economy begins to stabilise. Our forecast of an economic recovery in 2021-24 assumes a political transition that is supported by international assistance and produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP. There are downside risks to this forecast, depending on the timing of the eventual political transition. If the regime clings to power longer than expected, the economic crisis could be prolonged, delaying any recovery further.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2020, albeit less severely than in recent years, as inflation comes down from the hyperflationary rates of recent years (although it remains in triple digits). Private consumption will rise later in the forecast period assuming that political transition leads to more macroeconomic stability. We forecast a recovery in investment from 2020 under the assumption of political transition and a pick-up in oil investment. We expect oil output to bottom out at 650,000 barrels/day (b/d) by end-2019, prevented from slipping any lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. In line with our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government, oil production will start to recover in 2020, but even in 2024 it will still be well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will start to recover in 2020 on the back of recovery in the oil sector, but a rise in domestic demand (which has been artificially constrained) will initially absorb some of the projected increase in oil output. Import demand will rise sharply in 2020 and remain elevated through the forecast period. These factors will initially constrain the rebound of GDP, but we expect real GDP growth to gather pace in 2022-24, averaging 4.5% per year.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation
Severely reduced domestic supply, currency constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were recently published by the BCV, but there is a significant gap between these and data from other sources. Amid continuing questions over the data, we will, for now, continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. Huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand persist, and we expect inflation to remain high for as long as the Maduro regime stays in power. On the basis of our assumption of regime change in the short term, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation, but supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates
Under our baseline forecast of inevitable political transition, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) to tackle inflation is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to predict. Our forecasts assume extremely large currency adjustments that restore some competitiveness to the local currency in real terms over time. With few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime has announced a loosening of currency controls. Access to dollars via formal means will remain difficult and we believe that the foreign-exchange system will stay highly controlled in practice. In this environment, a strong black-market exchange-rate premium is likely to re-emerge. At end-September the official exchange rate was BsS20,720:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of almost BsS21,300:US$1. The premium was wide, although still small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector
We have recently revised our current-account data in line with the BCV's publication of official figures for 2017-18. These show that Venezuela continued to post current-account surpluses in this period, on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. However, we estimate that the current account shifted into deficit in 2019 amid the collapse of export earnings owing to US sanctions on the oil trade-despite the non-payment of interest on bonded debt (saving in excess of US$5bn in 2019).
We expect the current account to remain in deficit throughout the forecast period, averaging 7% of GDP in 2020-24. The trade surplus will grow gradually as oil production comes back on stream, but this will be offset by a rise in services imports, given limited domestic capacity and dependence on foreign shipping services. Decreased interest payments (on the assumption that the new administration will secure sufficient finance) will also stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this outlook. It hinges on substantial IMF finance, rapid macroeconomic stabilisation, speedy resolution of a debt-renegotiation process, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Muhammadu Buhari won a second and final four-year presidential term on February 23rd. The policy agenda he campaigned on did not involve root-and-branch reform, only cosmetic improvements to the business environment.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
Policy will be interventionist. Import bans on agricultural and manufactured goods will be widened to support local industry and farmers, and the Central Bank of Nigeria will maintain an overvalued official naira rate with which to channel cheap US dollars to preferred buyers.
The multiple-exchange-rate regime will not be dismantled under a Buhari administration; the arrangement is critical for making petrol subsidies affordable and underpins the government's interventionist approach to industrialisation.
Even though a multiple-exchange-rate system will persist, non-official rates will converge and so in reality Nigeria will run a dual exchange-rate regime. Oil prices will be high enough to prevent a return to capital controls (as temporarily imposed in 2016), but import restrictions will be widened, especially on food.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2020-24) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to restrict imports and support local producers. This in turn will keep credit conditions tight; even with some reduction in the central bank's policy rate from 2021, inflation will be running too high for sustained monetary loosening, and credit growth will generally be slow.
In 2020 export earnings will fall as global oil prices decline, but imports will also fall. Imports and exports will both rise in 2021-24, and a current-account surplus will be maintained throughout the forecast period.

Nigeria's business environment score worsens slightly for the forecast period (2020-24), as do its global and regional rankings, as the administration struggles with the reform process.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2020-21: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector remains characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2022-24: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress is slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2020-21: An attempt to sell the state's interest in oil joint ventures with multinationals meets serious challenges (the policy has been around for years), with resistance in parliament to the permanent loss of a revenue stream.
2022-24: Higher world oil prices and so easing fiscal pressures lessen the need to embark on a divestment programme. Energy firms are in any case hesitant to increase their presence in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2020-21: Import bans are widened dramatically, but capital controls prove unnecessary, barring another oil price crash.
2022-24: A premium between the overvalued official and parallel-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2020-21: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Value-added tax (VAT) is increased in 2020 from 5% to 7.2% to fund a higher minimum wage, introduced in 2019.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation, particularly for offshore oilfields. The need for new consumer taxes is alleviated by higher world oil prices and, as a result, hydrocarbons revenue.
Financing
2020-21: Domestic interest rates are high and borrowing by government crowds out the private sector. The government looks increasingly to international capital markets and wherever possible soft multilateral loans for deficit-financing.
2022-24: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts savings and investment.
The labour market
2020-21: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2022-24: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff; unemployment remains high and the market loose.
Infrastructure
2020-21: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints and is crowded out by other spending categories, including debt-servicing and higher public-sector wages. Although growth in private-sector investment is likely, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2022-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2020-21: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2022-24: Research spending remains low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multiparty democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in 2015, and Mr Buhari secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

Outlook for 2020-24: Political stability
Muhammadu Buhari won the February 2019 presidential election and will stay in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. He will be under immense pressure to restore stability across Nigeria, but managing the country's myriad security threats will prove an insuperable challenge, mainly because the military and the police are overstretched and will be unable to tackle simultaneous security crises. Emergencies will in effect be triaged, with resources being deployed to whichever is seen as the most pressing at any given time.
Conflict in the north-east between the government and two Islamist terrorist groups, Boko Haram and Islamic State West Africa Province (ISWAP), is an urgent issue, with Islamist fighters better equipped and more capable than in recent years. As this is a ruling party stronghold, the president will be keen to reassert control. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the north-east of Nigeria will remain a low-level conflict zone, and the campaign will divert security forces away from pockets of instability elsewhere. One such hotspot is just to the south, in the agricultural Middle Belt, where violent clashes between settled farmers and nomads competing for land and water resources have killed thousands in recent years. Formal land-titling is a potential solution to the crisis, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to violence in the Middle Belt. Vigilantes will be deployed to make up for shortfalls in formal security personnel, but will not be an effective substitute. Again, the direct effect of the conflict on the security situation will be localised, but the entire country will feel the secondary effects in the form of reduced food supplies and higher prices.
Another localised conflict with wide-ranging consequences will be militant activity in the oil-producing south, where insurgents are demanding more hydrocarbons revenue to be retained locally for development. Weak governance in the region has, as a by-product, encouraged oil theft and sabotage of pipelines and other facilities. Millions of barrels of oil are lost annually (22m in the first half of 2019). Reforming how federal revenue is allocated is a massive task and one that The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect to be achieved in the forecast period. Our assumption is that attacks on oil infrastructure by aggrieved militants and saboteurs will continue to be a major security problem in Delta state, with indirect consequences for the entire federation in the form of disrupted oil exports.
In a more general sense, the military and the police will be too poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping across the country. Widespread poverty and unemployment are feeding into a cycle of crime that will be difficult (if not impossible) to break, given a bleak economic outlook.
Outlook for 2020-24: Election watch
The next national elections will be in 2023. The previous ones, in February 2019, reaffirmed a deep electoral divide between the north, which supports the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC), and the south, a stronghold of the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP). In 2023 custom dictates that the presidential candidates of both main parties will be from the south, giving the PDP a chance to improve on abysmally low turnout there in the 2019 presidential vote. The contest will be the opposition's to win. Nigeria's economic outlook up to the next elections does not point towards a material decrease in widespread poverty. Frustration with declining living standards and high levels of crime and instability will be directed at the APC, giving the PDP a winning edge.
Outlook for 2020-24: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat that they pose. Relations with South Africa have recently deteriorated over xenophobic attacks against Nigerians living in South Africa (and, in response, against South Africans living in Nigeria). The South African authorities have long struggled to curb xenophobic violence, and serious bouts do occasionally occur, but although the issue is emotive, it is unlikely to undermine high-level ties.
India is the largest market for Nigerian oil and will become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will fall short of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player in Sub-Saharan Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. For example, although Mr Buhari recently signed a continent-wide free-trade agreement, it is likely that protected sectors (notably in agriculture, where other countries would have a competitive advantage) will be shielded from foreign competition. Nigeria's closure of its border with Benin in late August over rice smuggling makes this clear-both countries had signed up to the free-trade accord together.
Outlook for 2020-24: Policy trends
Economic policies under Mr Buhari will be interventionist, and measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be pursued. An overvalued official rate for Nigeria's currency, the naira, is critical for maintaining petrol subsidies (over 90% of petrol is imported), and Mr Buhari will not willingly reverse pump-price caps and risk a popular backlash. Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of multiple exchange rates carries an ever-present risk of capital controls being imposed and will be off-putting to those acquiring illiquid assets in Nigeria; foreign direct investment inflows are expected to be equivalent to less than 1% of GDP throughout the forecast period. To defend foreign reserves and the official rate, the Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) will probably widen import restrictions in 2020 as the average price of oil falls. Impetus to this policy will also come from a British court ruling that an Irish natural gas firm can apply to seize US$9bn in Nigerian government assets in the UK and potentially in 160 other countries.
Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state-owned companies such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but no structural reforms will take place. Generally, the preference of the Buhari administration will be to clean up loss-making state companies rather than relinquish control over them. There will be some effort to reduce the NNPC's stake in the upstream oil joint ventures it has with international oil companies, but uncertainty about fiscal terms (with proposed legislation to reform the management of hydrocarbons revenue having stalled) means that investor interest will fall short of official expectations, and parliament will resist selling off key public assets cheaply. As a result, the NNPC will continue to dominate the oil sector.
Outlook for 2020-24: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout the forecast period. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to collect overdue taxes and a planned increase in the value-added tax (VAT) rate from 5% now to 7.2% in 2020. Revenue increases will be from an extremely low base, however, and the new VAT rate is still among the world's lowest. Tax avoidance is widespread, and instability impedes collection in many parts of the country. Petrol subsidies (whereby losses incurred by the NNPC's retail arm are deducted from federal revenue) will be another drain, and overambitious oil production targets mean that budgeted revenue targets will not be reached. For example, in 2020 the government expects output of 2.2m barrels/day-a level that has not been seen since the oil price slump, and that is unobtainable given underinvestment and OPEC production quotas. Federally retained revenue is not expected to rise above 3.8% of GDP.
There is a clear need to address the budget deficit, and with revenue being so low the approach to spending will be austerity-minded early in the forecast period. Generally, fiscal flexibility will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and, as a result, revenue-under pressure and with considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. We expect an average budget deficit of 1.8% of GDP a year in 2020-24, with the highest shortfall (2% of GDP) in the election year of 2023. These will be financed externally and by soft loans wherever possible, but the bulk of finance will come from commercial debt and local borrowing.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against an abnormally low revenue base. Debt service can take up to half of federal revenue, which is alarming even by heavily-indebted emerging-market standards. A sovereign default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is weaker.
Outlook for 2020-24: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The CBN is inclined towards boosting the supply side of the economy, but inflation is well above the targeted upper limit of 9% and monetary loosening in 2020 could lead to capital outflows and put downward pressure on the naira at a time of low oil prices. Overall, we do not expect rates to move much in 2020, thus keeping bond yields in Nigeria attractive to foreign capital as monetary policy in the US loosens. Our baseline forecast is that interest rates will fall from 2021 as inflation enters a sustained downward trend, giving the CBN a chance to act on its growth-first strategy. We also expect that oil prices will rise in 2021-23, driving higher foreign-exchange inflows and lessening the need to support the naira through portfolio inflows.
Outlook for 2020-24: Economic growth
Economic growth will remain weak but will pick up as the forecast period progresses. In 2020 the economy will grow by just 2%, unchanged from 2019, held back by power shortages, insecurity, high inflation and tight credit conditions. With high debt-servicing costs leaving no room for fiscal activism, monetary policy is the main lever that can drive a recovery. In 2021, as global markets strengthen and inflation gradually decelerates-allowing for some monetary easing-the rate of growth will quicken to 2.9% and to an annual average of 3.2% in 2021-24, although this remains well below potential.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agricultural growth will be lacklustre. Although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will continue to be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and investment will be held back by uncertainty about future fiscal terms. Egina, a new offshore oilfield, will drive higher condensate output, but hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery that is due to come on stream by late 2021 will boost downstream oil activity and wider economic growth in 2022-24. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of electricity shortages, as well as cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by the impact of protectionism on trade (which accounts for over 15% of GDP) and by the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2020-24: Inflation
After averaging an estimated 11.4% in 2019, inflation will stay high in 2020, at 11.3%, well above the CBN's target ceiling of 9%, because of widening foreign-exchange restrictions on imports of manufactures and food at a time of sluggish economic growth and so inadequate local supply. The hike in VAT from 5% to 7.2% will likewise push up consumer prices across multiple index categories. With base effects from this fading, and with oil prices rising (reducing the need for further import restrictions as a means of defending the naira), core inflation will gradually ease over the remainder of the forecast period, bringing the headline rate down with it to an average of 8.3% in 2024. Conflict and agricultural supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-will prevent a faster slide.
Outlook for 2020-24: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2020-24, with an official rate for government business and a more market-determined rate for investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors or firms (including the NNPC, which budgets for petrol imports at the official rate) deemed important for economic or political reasons.
The central bank governor, Godwin Emefiele, has proven willing to adopt unconventional measures to keep the naira stable, which he argues is essential to avoid an inflationary spike and capital flight. As oil prices decline in 2020, foreign-exchange restrictions will be widened to curb what has been a surge in import demand, but there will not be a need for capital controls (which were introduced temporarily in 2016). Easier global monetary conditions in 2020 will support the naira through portfolio inflows. Higher global crude prices thereafter will continue to support the official rate.
Currency stability means steady real appreciation of the naira against the currencies of Nigeria's trading partners as inflation remains high relative to those countries. For this reason there is a downside risk of policymakers opting to devalue in order to regain international competitiveness for the non-oil sector. However, the CBN's industrial strategy (the central bank has long had similarities with a development agency) is focused on supplying the domestic market and such an eventuality is not forecast. We forecast that the naira will weaken to an average of N313.7:US$1 in 2024, from an estimated average of N306.6:US$1 in 2019.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. It also best represents exchange-rate policy. Indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued, which is in line with official calculations.
Outlook for 2020-24: External sector
Export earnings will move in tandem with oil production and price trends. In 2020 falling oil prices will offset rising production and cause earnings to decline. In 2021-23 higher global prices and output gains (with a new mega-refinery due to come on stream in 2021, which we expect to be export-oriented) will lead to a return to strong export growth, which will slow in 2024 as oil prices retreat again.
The government promotes import-substitution through foreign-exchange restrictions on imports of certain goods (mainly manufactures and agricultural products). After a sharp rise in purchases across various import categories in 2019, widening import restrictions will cause the import bill to drop back in 2020. Lower oil-and so petrol-prices that year (refinery capacity is low, and Nigeria imports much of its petrol) will also have a dampening effect. As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23 and global oil prices rise, imports will grow.
Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, although they will dip in 2020 as growth falters in the US, which is home to a large Nigerian diaspora. Overall, the current-account surplus will widen from an estimated 0.7% of GDP in 2019 to a high of 2.2% of GDP in 2023 as imports fall (2020) and exports-of both crude oil and refined products-rise (2021-23). In 2024, as oil prices slide, the surplus will ease to 2% of GDP.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development

Country Forecast South Africa September 2019

Full text: South Africa--highlights: Political outlook
An election win for the ruling African National Congress (ANC) in May 2019, albeit with a reduced vote share, gives the president, Cyril Ramaphosa a full five-year term. The ANC's installation of Mr Ramaphosa, a pragmatic and reputable figure, as president in February 2018-in place of the scandal-tainted Jacob Zuma-helped to restore the party's fortunes and has positive implications for politics, society and the economy. Mr Ramaphosa faces a range of challenges, including the fragile state of the economy (marked by weak growth and high unemployment) and persistent divisions within the ANC, both between reformers and resisters, and between the pragmatic centre and the interventionist left-wing. A failure to push ahead with economic reforms could erode ANC support at municipal elections in 2021 and the next general election in 2024.
South Africa--highlights: Business environment outlook

South Africa falls to 56th in the business environment ranking in 2019-23 as improvements in market opportunities and infrastructure are offset by declines in the macroeconomic environment, political stability and taxes. Supporting factors include a sound banking system, disciplined monetary policy, investment in infrastructure and the expanding black middle class. Constraints include skills shortages, frequent strikes, strict labour laws and the burden of complying with black economic empowerment regulations. Other areas of controversy are a reworked mining charter, which loosens some rules while tightening others, and a proposal to embrace expropriation without compensation to speed up land reform, although we believe that this will be limited in extent, limiting the threat to property rights. Opportunities for public-private partnerships will increase.

South Africa's economy, being relatively small and open, will remain vulnerable to global developments, such as the US-China trade war, and to commodity price fluctuations. Growth will pick up from 2020 onwards, driven by consumption and investment, and improved sentiment. However, expansion will happen too slowly to reduce high unemployment levels, which continue to constrain demand. Fiscal consolidation will also limit growth. Global developments will put pressure on the rand, but the inflation outlook is relatively benign, and we expect interest rates to move within a fairly narrow band. The budget and current-account deficits will trend lower in 2019-23.

South Africa's population growth rate will remain muted in 2019-23, averaging just 1.2% a year, constrained by the adverse impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic. The number of new infections and the annual death toll from AIDS are both on downward trends, and life expectancy is rising, helped by the expansion of treatment programmes, but the damage will persist into the medium term. The labour force will grow at a faster rate than the overall population, highlighting the urgency of job creation.

South Africa's market will expand during the forecast period as the poor black majority becomes increasingly engaged with the mainstream commercial economy, boosting demand for a wide range of goods and services. The high unemployment level will, however, continue dragging on aggregate demand, aggravated by fiscal consolidation. An uptick in GDP growth, higher levels of financial inclusion, the spread of digital technology, regional economic integration and infrastructure investment (including in low-cost housing and power supply) will underpin market opportunities.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
We forecast that real GDP growth will quicken to 3.6% a year on average in 2019-30, helped by rising life expectancy, improved healthcare, investment in infrastructure, regional integration and global commodity demand. Technological advances, such as cloud computing and 3D printing, will give a further boost to growth and productivity. Growth will quicken to 4.3% a year in 2031-50 as the ICT revolution gathers momentum and African integration deepens. Growth in capital stocks will outpace growth in labour productivity throughout the period, owing to a combination of skills shortages and investment in new technology.

Background: South Africa became a full democracy in 1994, when it first held all-race elections. The African National Congress (ANC) won, and has dominated all subsequent elections-in 1999, 2004, 2009, 2014 and 2019. However, support ebbed steadily from a peak of nearly 70% in 2004, to 62.1% in 2014 and 57.5% in May 2019. The ANC feared a worse result, but the installation of Cyril Ramaphosa as president in February 2018, replacing the scandal-tainted Jacob Zuma, provided a mild bounce. Mr Ramaphosa will now serve a full-five years as president and would be eligible for a second term.
Political structure: South Africa is a constitutional democracy with a bicameral parliament and a president elected by parliament. The constitution is the supreme law. The 400-member National Assembly is elected by proportional representation; the National Council of the Provinces consists of indirectly elected representatives of the nine provinces. The judiciary is independent and includes an 11-member Constitutional Court. The constitution provides for an independent corruption watchdog-the Public Protector-and commissions on human rights, gender equality and restitution of land rights.
Policy issues: Boosting growth, creating jobs, advancing black economic empowerment and reducing inequality-while maintaining fiscal and monetary discipline-are the main policy aims. Mr Ramaphosa's election victory in May 2019 heralds deeper economic reform, but persistent divisions within the ANC will impede progress. Advances to date include restarting a private-sector-led renewable energy programme and reworking the mining charter, but the labour market will remain rigid and marked by frequent strikes, exacerbated by the trade unions' political power. Skills shortages will persist, reflecting weaknesses in education. The environment for private enterprise will remain broadly accommodating, marked by opportunities for public-private partnerships, but policy uncertainty will persist, including over land reform, owing to ANC backing for expropriation without compensation, albeit in limited circumstances. Competition law, a new national minimum wage and a new carbon tax are other areas of concern.
Taxation: Value-added tax (VAT) is levied at a flat rate of 15%-after a rise from 14% on April 1st-although some essentials are zero-rated. Corporation tax (of 28%), income tax and VAT were left unchanged in the 2019/20 budget. Some tax concessions are available, including in special economic zones.
Foreign trade: South Africa has a relatively open economy, with foreign trade (imports plus exports) accounting for around 52% of GDP in 2016. China, the EU, the US and Japan are among its largest trading partners. Trade with the rest of Africa has become progressively more important, and it is the only region with which South Africa has a trade surplus.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: The African National Congress (ANC), the dominant political party since the 1994 election ended apartheid and white minority rule, retained power in May 2019, although with a smaller voting share of 57.5%. This marks a worst-ever showing for the ANC in general elections and comes after a steady fall from a peak of 69.7% in 2004, when Thabo Mbeki was president, to 65.9% in 2009 and 62.2% in 2014, when Jacob Zuma held office. Mr Zuma's growing unpopularity, largely linked to corruption, saw the ANC's vote tumble to just 54% in municipal elections in 2016, but the party's replacement of Mr Zuma by Cyril Ramaphosa in February 2018 led to a mild bounce in the 2019 general election. The ANC continues to hold a large majority of seats in parliament under South Africa's proportional representation system of voting. The party also retained eight of the nine provinces in 2019. The ANC rules in partnership with the Congress of South African Trade Unions (COSATU) and the South African Communist Party (SACP) in a tripartite alliance.
Opposition: The Democratic Alliance (DA), which draws most of its support from minority voters (white, mixed-race and Indian), saw its vote share ebb to 20.8% in 2019, down from 22.2% in 2014, partly because of defections by conservative whites angered by the party's bid to strengthen its appeal to black urban voters. Under Mmusi Maimane, the DA's first black leader, elected in 2015, the party made strong gains in 2016's municipal polls but could not maintain the momentum in 2019 because of internal splits and the ANC's "Ramaphosa bounce". The populist Economic Freedom Fighters (EEF), founded by Julius Malema in 2013 after his expulsion from the ANC, was the main gainer in 2019, lifting its vote to 10.8%, up from 6.4% in 2014, although it failed to make a major breakthrough. The two other main opposition parties are the KwaZulu-Natal-based Inkatha Freedom Party, and Freedom Front Plus (a conservative white party), which both made small gains in 2019, taking 3.4% and 2.4% of the vote respectively.
