Next elections: The next general election is scheduled for May 2024
Political outlook: Political stability
Mr Ramaphosa, re-elected president by the new National Assembly on May 22nd-after the ANC won a comfortable (albeit smaller) majority in the May 8th general election-faces a series of political and economic challenges during his five-year term. After 15 months as interim president before the election, Mr Ramaphosa will now have greater authority to shape the policy agenda and the structure of government, and drive through reforms. Nevertheless, he faces numerous obstacles, both political and economic. Boosting investment, growth and job creation, overhauling Eskom (the dysfunctional power parastatal) in the face of trade union resistance, sustaining the crackdown on corruption, and tackling policy conundrums such as land reform are among the major tests confronting the new government. Aggravating these challenges, Mr Ramaphosa faces deep divisions in the ANC, both between reformers and resisters-exemplified by supporters of the former president, Jacob Zuma (2009-18)-and between centrists and the left wing, including the trade unions. Politics will limit Mr Ramaphosa's room for manoeuvre, especially given the ANC's election losses, to recently formed parties like Julius Malema's radical, populist Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF).
Mr Ramaphosa's new cabinet illustrates both his ambitions and his problems. Several key ministers already appointed by the president remain in place, such as Tito Mboweni at the Ministry of Finance and Pravin Gordhan at the Ministry of Public Enterprises. The ANC's diversity requires a broad-based cabinet, however, hence the inclusion of prominent left-wingers (such as Ebrahim Patel), veterans, rising stars and some pro-Zuma figures, although several of Mr Zuma's acolytes were omitted (or left parliament). Cabinet divisions pose some risks, although a greater threat to the president's authority comes from the ANC hierarchy, wherein pro-Zuma figures, such as the secretary-general, Ace Magashule, are more entrenched. Mr Ramaphosa is also threatened by the seemingly biased public protector, Busisiwe Mkhwebane (appointed by Mr Zuma in 2016), who is probing both Mr Gordhan and the president. However, court rulings against Ms Mkhwebane's previous reports-including fresh legal setbacks in August-have damaged her credibility.
Being a persuasive negotiator with experience of both business and organised labour, Mr Ramaphosa is well suited to the tasks ahead. Having already acted to revitalise key institutions that Mr Zuma weakened, such as the National Prosecuting Authority and the South African Revenue Service, the president will focus on further institutional reforms. A judge-led inquiry into "state capture" could lead to several prosecutions. But reforms will take time to deliver benefits, given objections from vested interests (such as patronage networks and trade unions), leading to pressure from impatient voters and the emboldened EFF ahead of municipal elections in 2021. Moreover, not all changes will be positive, with the ANC committed to land expropriation without compensation (albeit in limited circumstances), in a bid to reduce the EFF's appeal. A failure to revive the economy could see Mr Ramaphosa's leadership challenged at the ANC's next electoral summit in 2022. Economic stagnation also raises the risk of increased civil unrest.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Government effectiveness declined during Mr Zuma's presidency (2009-18) because of a steady rise in corruption and patronage, and his appointment of cronies to key positions in vital institutions, such as the National Prosecuting Agency, which eroded their independence and credibility. The ANC's ousting of Mr Zuma in February 2018, and his replacement by Mr Ramaphosa, a pragmatic, experienced and reputable figure, heralds a significant transformation, including a crackdown on corrupt networks and the rebuilding of institutional integrity, although progress will be gradual and subject to occasional setbacks, given the embedded nature of patronage networks and divisions within the ruling party. Key actions taken by Mr Ramaphosa, who was handed a full five-year term in the May 2019 election, include removing the Zuma-appointed heads of both the South African Revenue Service and the National Prosecuting Authority (NPA) in 2018-on the grounds of adverse legal judgements-and installing competent figures in their place in 2019. The NPA, now under Shamila Batohi, will regain its credibility and effectiveness, although, as with other institutions subject to rebuilding, the process will be gradual, given the expertise lost during years of mismanagement and government interference.
The Constitutional Court-the arbiter of South Africa's widely respected and painstakingly negotiated post-apartheid constitution-alongside the wider judicial system, played a key role in holding Mr Zuma to account, and is one of the few key institutions, alongside the South African Reserve Bank (the central bank), that escaped being weakened by the former president. The battle against corruption and patronage will gather momentum, helped by an ongoing inquiry into Mr Zuma's agenda of "state capture"-led by a respected judge, Raymond Zondo-that kicked off in August 2018. Mr Zondo will not report back until 2020 at the earliest, but in conjunction with other anti-corruption probes, some of the architects of state capture, including Mr Zuma, could be prosecuted and jailed. Mr Zuma also faces a possible trial over corruption charges laid-then controversially dropped-before he became president in 2009. Exposing past corruption and punishing the perpetrators is vital for democratic deepening and government effectiveness.
South Africa's political system is robust, underpinned by the constitution, which provides for a clear separation of powers (between the executive, the legislature and the judiciary) and strong, independent institutions. Despite the serious damage caused by Mr Zuma, the fightback by the judiciary and other organs of state, and by his opponents in the ANC, illustrates the underlying strength of the political architecture. There are, however, some weaknesses that work against effective government. The electoral code, based on pure proportional representation and a party list system, means that there is no direct link between members of parliament and their constituents, which gives Luthuli House (the ANC headquarters) and the executive much greater influence over legislators than would otherwise be the case. In addition, the ANC's large parliamentary majority, coupled with opposition weaknesses, means that many important debates are hidden from public view within the party hierarchy. Trends suggest that ANC dominance will fade as opposition influence rises, which is positive for democracy, but lower turnout in the 2019 election highlights the risk of disengagement, especially if the economy continues underperforming.
Political outlook: Election watch
The ANC's vote share fell in May 2019 for the third consecutive general election, to an all-time low of 57.5% (down from 62.1% in 2014), although the party retained a comfortable majority, to claim 230 out of the 400 National Assembly seats under South Africa's system of proportional representation. The ruling party's losses would have been greater, however, had the ANC not replaced the graft-tainted Mr Zuma as president with Mr Ramaphosa in February 2018. The increase in the EFF's vote share (to 10.8%, up from 6.4% in 2014) and its seat tally (to 41, from 25) almost exactly mirrors the ANC's decline, but it failed to make a major breakthrough, held back by the ANC's "Ramaphosa bounce".
The centrist Democratic Alliance (DA) remains the official opposition, but it saw its vote share dip (to 20.8%, down from 22.2%), along with its seat tally (to 84, down from 89), because of defections by white, conservative voters to VF Plus, which gained six seats, taking its tally to ten, aggrieved by the DA's bid to attract more black voters.
Radical parties therefore benefited the most, although the shifts in voting patterns since 2014 were not dramatic. A greater concern, from the perspective of democratic engagement, is a sharp drop in turnout to 66%, down from 72.4% in 2014, indicating growing disenchantment with the government and the wider political system. This damaging trend, and the drift of voters towards radical parties, will continue in the absence of economic revival. The ANC therefore faces a stiff test at municipal elections in 2021, and could lose its national majority for the first time in 2024.
Political outlook: International relations
South Africa-the most advanced economy in Africa-will play an important role in regional and global affairs, facilitated by a third stint on the UN Security Council in 2019-20. The country will remain deeply engaged in Africa, particularly Southern Africa, and will continue to support peacekeeping operations in the continent's conflict zones. Mr Ramaphosa will be the next chair of the African Union in 2020. South Africa will also seek to build closer "South-South" ties, especially within the BRICS (Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa) grouping and with other African trade blocs, including the under-negotiation African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA). The prioritisation of African ties partly explains South Africa's decision in 2016 to withdraw from the International Criminal Court (ICC), which some observers argue targets the continent unfairly. However, the country's High Court ruled in 2017 that departing the ICC would require fresh legislation, leaving South Africa's membership in the balance.

Opportunities will be mixed with uncertainties
South Africa's business environment ranking for 2019-23 declines (to 56th) at the global level, but does not change at the regional level. As a key emerging market (and the most advanced economy in Africa), with vast mineral reserves, sound banks and a broad commitment to free markets, the country will remain an important business centre. However, improvements in some areas, such as infrastructure and market opportunities, will be offset by declines in the macroeconomic environment and taxes, because of subdued growth and higher tax levels, respectively.
Business also confronts a wide range of policy uncertainties, aggravated by divisions within the ruling African National Congress (ANC). One key controversy is the ANC's decision to embrace expropriation without compensation, to speed up land reform, although The Economist Intelligence Unit expects any such moves to apply in limited circumstances only, thereby limiting the threat to property rights. Uncertainties also surround an improved but still flawed mining charter, as well as a new investment law that requires any disputes to be settled in the local courts, rather than via international arbitration.
An election win for the ANC in May 2019 and Cyril Ramaphosa's installation as president for a full five-year term have positive policy implications. However, room for manoeuvre is limited by divisions in the party between reformers and resisters on the one hand, and between centrists and left-wingers on the other. Mr Ramaphosa's successes to date include cracking down on corruption, strengthening institutions and restarting a private-sector renewable energy programme. Political sensitivities preclude labour market deregulation or outright privatisation. Despite the obstacles-and the damage caused by years of mismanagement under the former president, Jacob Zuma-we believe that reform will gather pace as Mr Ramaphosa increasingly asserts his authority.

Business environment outlook: South Africa's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Policy is broadly pro-business, but favourable moves, such as new special economic zones offering tax incentives, are accompanied by tighter competition laws and stricter black economic empowerment (BEE) rules.
2021-23: Expropriation without compensation, to speed up land reform, applies in limited circumstances only, reducing the threat to property rights. Investment incentives in selected industries (such as automotive manufacturing) remain in place.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: A reworked mining charter offers some concessions to business. A new foreign investment law limits access to international arbitration by giving local courts the primary responsibility for handling disputes.
2021-23: The government continues to encourage foreign investment and public-private partnerships, but resists the full privatisation of state assets in most cases.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: The government implements a modest relaxation of capital controls on outward investment.
2021-23: Progress towards regional economic integration in Southern Africa makes some advances, but barriers persist.
Taxes
2019-20: Tough fiscal conditions lead to higher direct and indirect taxes, but a further rise in VAT is avoided.
2021-23: Efforts to streamline and modernise the tax system and expand the tax base continue.
Financing
2019-20: South Africa's commitment to fiscal discipline and parastatal reforms forestalls a further downgrade by ratings agencies. Local banks remain sound and profitable on aggregate, and a key source of corporate financing.
2021-23: The central bank's continued independence helps to preserve the stability of the financial system. Monetary policy remains prudent and interest rates are broadly stable. The proposed nationalisation of the central bank is symbolic.
The labour market
2019-20: Labour laws stay inflexible, despite the negative impact on employment, because of trade unions' political power.
2021-23: The labour market remains tough, owing to skills shortages and BEE targets.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Investment in transport and electricity, by both the state and private firms, boosts capacity.
2021-23: Private-sector-led investment in renewable energy gathers momentum under the government's long-term energy plan, adding diversity to power supplies and cutting reliance on coal. Rising power tariffs drive energy efficiency.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The roll-out of domestic fibre-optic cables boosts capacity and cuts costs. Investment in digital technology gathers momentum, including in cloud computing and high-end data analysis. The allocation of new spectrum faces delays.
2021-23: Work advances on the Square Kilometre Array, a powerful radio telescope with multinational support, giving a wider boost to science and the information and communications technology (ICT) sector.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.6 6.1 53 65 6 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The macroeconomic environment score declines in the forecast period, pushing down South Africa's global ranking to 65th (from 53rd) and its regional ranking to ninth (from sixth). Real GDP growth will remain sluggish, averaging just 2.3% a year in 2019-23, but will show an upward trend, from 0.8% in 2019 to 3.4% in 2023, driven by consumption and investment. However, growth will remain vulnerable to adverse global developments-such as an escalating US-China trade war and a disorderly Brexit-and to domestic policy uncertainties. Growth will also be insufficient to bring down the high unemployment rate, which hit 29% in June 2019. The possible loss of South Africa's remaining investment-grade credit rating in 2020, because of fiscal slippage, would also have a negative impact via higher borrowing costs, but a downgrade may be avoided.
An interest rate cut in July will have a mildly positive impact, especially if followed by another cut in 2019/20, although South Africa's weak growth mainly reflects structural, not monetary, constraints. The current-account deficit will remain a source of vulnerability, but it will move within a fairly narrow 4-4.5% of GDP range in 2019-22, and will decline after 2020, dropping to 3.7% in 2023. The rand-a widely traded and market-determined currency-will maintain a weakening trend, albeit with high levels of volatility, although the pace of depreciation will taper off towards the end of the forecast period. Annual inflation will stay comfortably within the 3-6% target range set by the South Africa Reserve Bank (the central bank) in 2019-23, despite temporary breaches, underpinned by prudent monetary policy and weak growth in demand.
The challenge of black economic empowerment
A unique, challenging and controversial aspect of South Africa's policy environment is black economic empowerment (BEE), which aims to redress the iniquities of the apartheid era-whereby most wealth and assets ended up in the hands of the white minority-by gradually transferring economic power to the black majority. Legislation governing BEE includes sector-specific charters and broader codes of conduct, both of which set targets for ownership and other variables. Broadly speaking, BEE requires firms to have 25% black ownership, although the precise figure varies by sector (and foreign subsidiaries are largely exempt from equity transfer rules). Revised codes of practice, which came into force in 2015, cut the number of elements on a company's BEE scorecard from seven to five-ownership, enterprise and supplier development, skills development, management control, and socioeconomic development-and reweighted the components. Alongside other changes, this will make it harder for firms to earn (or retain) a BEE-compliant rating: non-compliant firms will be at a competitive disadvantage when bidding for government contracts or negotiating public-private partnerships.
Apart from the problems posed by changes to the rules, two key questions remain unanswered after nearly two decades of BEE: how long will the policy remain in force, and is a once-empowered company always empowered? The reworked mining charter in 2018 partly answers the latter question, by allowing BEE deals that have lapsed (because of new black owners selling their shares) to count towards a firm's equity transfer target, although the concession requires certain conditions to be met and does not necessarily apply outside of mining. Less positively, the new charter plans to lift the ownership threshold in mining to 30%. With regard to wealth transfer, the record of BEE has been mixed: the initial benefits were spread fairly narrowly (helping to create a new, black elite), although a drive towards more broad-based empowerment (by including workers and suppliers, for example), is distributing the rewards more evenly. Some company BEE schemes yield higher benefits than others, however, depending on several variables, such as share price movements
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.0 5.3 51 56 5 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Policy towards private enterprise will remain broadly accommodating, but several policy-related challenges will persist, leading to a small decline in South Africa's global and regional rankings. Public-private partnerships (PPPs) will become more commonplace, but obstacles such as strict labour laws, elevated strike risks and skills shortages will persist. In addition, taxes are trending higher because of fiscal pressures. Key areas of uncertainty are the reworked mining charter-which eases BEE requirements in some areas while tightening them in others-and government plans to embrace expropriation without compensation to speed land reform. Proposals to phase in a new National Health Insurance system are a particular concern for large private-sector providers. Mr Ramaphosa's installation as president in May for a full five-year term heralds faster reforms, but the challenge facing the government of reconciling the imperatives of growth with those of socioeconomic transformation will persist.
Powerful parastatals (such as the power generator, Eskom, and the port and rail operator, Transnet) will continue to play a key role, despite suffering from weak management, political interference and financial indiscipline. Parastatal overreach and the government's resistance to outright privatisation imposes limits on private opportunity, although openings for PPPs-including the possible injection of private capital into ailing state-owned firms-and independent initiatives will increase, especially in the energy sector, given the proposed unbundling of Eskom into generation, distribution and transmission arms. Industrial policy will continue to offer incentives in some sectors, especially for vehicle manufacturing, incentives for which have now been extended beyond 2020. Tax concessions are on offer to investors in new special economic zones (SEZs), of which six have been designated, although some restrictions apply. Existing industrial development zones will switch to the SEZ format.
Expropriation without compensation unsettles investors
The ANC's decision to embrace expropriation without compensation, in order to speed up land reform-which has so far taken place mostly on a "willing buyer, willing seller" basis-could pose a threat to property rights, depending on the rules adopted. However, we believe that expropriation, if any, will apply in limited, clearly defined circumstances only, and will not extend beyond land. As a first step, the government plans to amend the constitution to specifically allow for expropriation without compensation, but this will require a two-thirds majority in parliament, which is by no means guaranteed. The failure of the land reform programme to meet targets has little to do with the constitution, however, and largely reflects weaknesses in land-related policies and institutions. Plans for expropriation without compensation, even with clear limits, will weigh on sentiment until the details are clarified.
Competition policy is becoming stricter
Policy towards anti-competitive practices will become stricter, as the competition authorities (comprising a commission and a tribunal)-under the newly-expanded Department of Trade and Industry-intensify their battle against cartels, overpricing and barriers to entry, which are relatively high in South Africa, given the entrenched positions of several large local firms. An amended competition act, signed into law in February 2019, gives the competition authorities (and the relevant minister, Ebrahim Patel) additional powers, allowing them to launch inquiries into sectors with a high degree of concentration and intervene in mergers on public-interest grounds. There are legitimate concerns about competition policy being increasingly used as a tool to promote wider socio-economic objectives (such as black economic empowerment-BEE), although rulings made by the competition authorities, including recent determinations, are more practical than ideological. Conditions imposed on takeovers and mergers mainly relate to developing local suppliers and retaining workers (for a set period), which are not typically deal-breakers. Gaining competition authority approval can be time consuming, however, and the stricter new act could see more stringent remedies applied in some cases.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.0 6.4 55 52 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Policy uncertainties could hamper FDI inflows
South Africa will remain a key destination for non-oil foreign direct investment (FDI) in Africa during the forecast period, in a wide range of sectors, driven by market opportunities and the country's role as a gateway to the rest of the continent, especially Southern Africa. This will facilitate a small improvement in South Africa's global ranking during the forecast period, despite the persistence of policy uncertainties. Foreign investors, for the most part, face the same challenges as domestic firms, including strict labour and competition laws, the dominant position of parastatals and concern about future property rights. Conversely, foreign (and local) investors, will be drawn by opportunities for PPPs, notably in renewable energy. A reworked mining charter, issued in 2018, could buoy investment, but some aspects need clarification. In a key concession to business, the revised charter allows previous BEE deals that were subsequently unwound to count towards the 26% equity threshold, but also imposes new restrictions, such as lifting the threshold to 30%. The courts may be asked to rule on the remaining areas of contention. Foreign investors seeking domestic acquisitions can face scrutiny from the competition authorities, as happened during Walmart's purchase of a majority stake in Massmart in 2011, although the conditions attached to deals, such as supplier development, are typically not too onerous. Pepsi's US$1.7bn bid for Pioneer, a consumer goods firm), in July will provide the next major challenge for the competition authorities.
A new Protection of Investment Act, sometimes referred to as the FDI Act, which came into force in July 2018 following lengthy delays, is creating new uncertainties. The law aims to provide a more streamlined environment for FDI (compared with previous ad hoc arrangements) and is based on treating local and foreign investors more equally. However, the act also limits investor access to international arbitration and instead requires all legal disputes to be first dealt with by local courts. Investors may be assuaged by South Africa's respected constitution and independent judiciary, but changing the rules generates inevitable uncertainty. South Africa's termination (or failure to extend) around a dozen bilateral investment treaties with EU countries, in the belief that they have little impact on actual investment flows, is a similar concern. More positively, the new law appears not to be harming FDI, which picked up strongly in 2018. FDI will be driven in part by opportunities for PPPs, as well as private-led initiatives, especially in the field of infrastructure provision. For example, private firms, both foreign and local, are playing a leading role in the rollout of renewable energy (especially solar and wind), having invested almost US$14bn to date, with more projects in the pipeline.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.9 7.3 55 57 6 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Exchange controls will gradually be liberalised
South Africa maintains some controls on outbound capital flows (although not on inflows), but is loosening the rules, in stages, and moving from centralised directives towards prudential self-regulation. Liberalisation stalled during the 2008-09 global financial crisis (as controls offered some protection, by constraining capital flight), but then regained momentum, driven by Treasury-led reforms. These include removing the ceiling for outward investment; lowering the ceiling on advance payments for imports; allowing South African companies to open foreign bank accounts without prior approval; permitting banks to invest 25% of their liabilities in offshore portfolio instruments; and offering concessions to foreign firms that set up headquarters in South Africa. Other changes have loosened the rules for outward investment in Africa. Additional reforms are probable during the forecast period, but some restrictions will remain in place, especially given the risks that US-led protectionism-and consequent trade wars-pose to the global financial system.
Sluggish growth, combined with an activist industrial policy, will lead to protective measures in some cases (in the form of higher tariffs and anti-dumping duties)-such as for steel-although South Africa will seek to remain compliant with World Trade Organisation (WTO) rules. The Southern African Development Community (SADC) will progressively implement a free-trade area, but the initiative is running behind schedule because of wide economic and policy divergences between member states. Loftier ambitions for a customs union, a common market and monetary union will not be realised during the outlook period. Other free trade plans are advancing, including the proposed merger of SADC, the Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa and the East African Community into a Tripartite Free-Trade Area (TFTA), and a more recent initiative-the African Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA)-which formally launched in July. However, both the TFTA and the AfCFTA still require lengthy negotiations, and it may be impractical for them to co-exist. Non-tariff barriers and poor infrastructure links are other serious obstacles.
South Africa (and other members of the Southern Africa Customs Union-SACU) successfully negotiated a new economic partnership agreement with the EU in 2014. The deal will facilitate deeper trade and investment ties, and provides improved access to the EU for South African agricultural exports. The UK's intended departure from the EU poses risks: negotiations on a standalone SACU-UK deal are ongoing. South Africa will also retain trade preferences in the US under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), which has been extended by ten years to 2025. Nonetheless, South Africa's AGOA status will remain conditional on its policies towards trade liberalisation and investment protection. A dispute about South African restrictions on US meat imports, for example, threatened South Africa's AGOA eligibility before the issue was settled in 2016. US tariffs on steel and aluminium imports from most countries, including South Africa, imposed in 2018, violate the spirit of AGOA, but South Africa is unlikely to retaliate. US protectionism poses clear risks to AGOA and to South Africa-US trade and investment relations.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.4 6.1 32 57 7 9
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Tight fiscal conditions lead to higher taxes
South Africa's score and global ranking for taxes decline in 2019-23, as revenue shortfalls combine with spending pressures to push the tax burden higher. The budget for fiscal year 2018/19 (April-March), for example, lifted the value-added tax (VAT) rate to 15%, from 14%, the first adjustment for 25 years, and also increased fuel duties. This follows hikes in capital gains tax and income tax, including a new top rate of 45%, in fiscal-year 2016/17. However, the corporation tax rate remains unchanged, at 28%, and is unlikely to be raised, given pressures on corporate finances. Other levies include property and labour-related taxes, such as a skills development levy and contributions towards unemployment insurance.
Additional tax increases are probable during the forecast period, given spending pressures, although the government's room for manoeuvre is now more limited: another VAT hike would be politically damaging and there is limited scope for higher income-tax rates (which could lead to increased evasion). Other forms of wealth tax will be considered, but South Africa already relies too heavily on a small number of rich individuals and firms, and instead needs to broaden the tax base. Efforts to streamline taxation, boost compliance and seal loopholes will continue during the forecast period, informed by the findings of the Davis Tax Committee, which produced a string of reports during its five-year probe, ending in April 2018. South Africa's revenue shortfalls also reflect mismanagement at the South African Revenue Service (SARS) under the former commissioner, Tom Moyane, appointed by Mr Zuma in 2014 and sacked by Mr Ramaphosa in 2018 after a legal probe. With the experienced Edward Kieswetter now leading the SARS, revenue collection will improve, reducing the urgency of tax rises.
Tax incentives will continue to apply in some cases, including for small firms, which have enjoyed reduced corporation tax rates since 2013. A youth employment subsidy (via tax concessions) dating from 2014 will now remain in place until 2029, following a ten-year extension. A discounted 15% rate of corporate tax also applies to investors in new SEZs; the first six SEZs were formally designated in August 2018. The 2018/19 budget allocated R350m to cover tax incentives in SEZs. New environmental and health-related taxes will be introduced during the forecast period, as highlighted by a new sugar tax on soft drinks imposed on April 1st 2018, alongside a higher levy on plastic bags. In addition, a long-mooted carbon tax finally came into force in June 2019, geared towards curbing emissions. Criticised by the green lobby for being too low, and by business for being too high, the impact will be relatively small in the initial phase, until end-2022, because of exemptions available. A major review will precede phase two, running from 2023-30, making the outcome uncertain. The carbon tax will pose risks to profit, but will also encourage innovation.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.3 6.3 37 46 5 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Banks remain sound and well-capitalised
The banking system remains sound and well-capitalised, with a long-term reputation for stability, underpinned by an effective regulatory and supervisory framework, overseen by the SARB. Key challenges are slow GDP growth (and hence demand for credit) and a range of regulatory uncertainties. Banks' capital-adequacy ratios remain comfortably above prescribed minimums, and profitability (as measured by return on equity) remains satisfactory despite dipping to 15.3% in June 2019, down from 16.3% in June 2018. Credit growth to households has regained buoyancy in 2019, rising to 6.5% year on year in June, a multi-year high. Credit growth to firms is higher, but more volatile. Economic strains pushed up the bad-debt ratio to 3.7% in June 2019, but it will remain comfortably below the critical 5% threshold in 2019-23, barring shocks. Interest rates will remain broadly stable during the forecast period, with small hikes interspersed by small cuts. Local banks will remain a key source of funds for private investment projects, as illustrated by their participation in financing renewable energy projects. Other key sources of financing are the Johannesburg Stock Exchange and, to an increasing extent, local development finance institutions such as the Industrial Development Corporation.
The four dominant banks-ABSA (formerly Barclays Africa), Nedbank, Standard and First Rand-are world-class players with strong international links. They are also, to varying degrees, expanding their presence in the rest of Africa, thereby cementing South Africa's role as a gateway to the rest of the continent. The withdrawal of Barclays from Africa, largely completed in 2017, poses no threat to the local banking system; the bank's African operation has now been rebranded as ABSA (its former name). The implementation of an amended Financial Intelligence Centre Act in June 2017, meeting a deadline set by the Financial Action Task Force, removes a threat to the credibility and integrity of local banks and will help to tackle money-laundering. However, the phased implementation of more stringent Basel III regulatory standards ahead of the extended 2022 deadline, alongside a new financial sector regulation bill based on a Twin Peaks model, may impose additional costs.
A key policy challenge is a possible change to BEE rules in the financial sector, which are comparatively loose at present. A new credit-relief act, signed into law in August 2019, is causing some concern because of a potential debt write-off for poor borrowers. But the impact may be small, especially for large banks, which have little exposure to the low-income segment. Poor borrowers could suffer, however, because lenders will struggle to price risk correctly. Government plans to embrace land expropriation without compensation represent a fundamental threat to banks (given the amount of land used as loan collateral), although we expect the government to set clear limits on expropriation. Another danger is the exposure of banks to heavily indebted parastatals. The possible nationalisation of the SARB-a rare privately owned central bank-is unsettling, but would be of symbolic value only, provided its mandate was left untouched. Banks raised no objection to a new law passed in March 2019 allowing for a state-owned bank, provided all banks are treated equally.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.9 5.1 75 71 13 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The labour market will remain characterised by strict regulations, partly owing to the political power of the trade unions, despite the negative impact on job creation. The official unemployment rate hit a new high of 29% in the second quarter of 2019-rising to 36.6% with the inclusion of discouraged job seekers-partly because of slow GDP growth, but also because of tight labour laws. The employment equity requirements of BEE, for example, and the limits imposed on casual, temporary employment deter firms from hiring, as does the high risk of strike action. A labour movement split in 2017 saw many unions break away from the Congress of South African Trade Unions (Cosatu, an ANC ally) to found the more radical South African Federation of Trade Unions (Saftu). This partly weakened the labour voice but brings new challenges for firms, as most unionised workers in the private sector are now Saftu members, leaving Cosatu as the dominant force in the public sector.
The introduction of a national minimum wage on January 1st 2019 will have an uncertain impact on the labour market. By setting the initial rate at a relatively low level of R20 (US$13.50) an hour-with a discounted rate applying to domestic service and agriculture for a temporary period-and by allowing for exemptions, the government hopes that any associated job losses will be minimal, but the evidence to date is unclear. The national minimum wage could create new jobs, by boosting the spending power of up to 5m low-paid workers (a third of the total), but could also lead to retrenchments in some cases, leaving the net result uncertain. The existing system of sector-based minimum wages will be retained, despite its complexity, to protect workers earning more than the national minimum. A Minimum Wage Commission will monitor the impact and make recommendations on future increments (to account for inflation). In return for agreeing to the national minimum wage, business secured commitments from mainstream trade unions to increase the use of pre-strike balloting, via an amendment to the Labour Relations Act, which may reduce the incidence of industrial action.
Shortages of skilled workers will remain a key constraint
One the biggest labour-market challenges is a shortage of skills, stemming from weaknesses in the education system at all levels, exacerbated by the HIV/AIDS pandemic. Skills shortages will remain prevalent in most sectors, pushing up the premium required to attract skilled workers and leading to the poaching of capable staff. South Africa's top universities have a good reputation but are failing to alleviate the shortage, especially of technical and engineering skills. The deficit is being aggravated by outward migration of skilled workers and overly restrictive rules on immigration. We expect a relaxation of immigration rules to help tackle the problem.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.8 6.5 44 40 5 5
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Parastatals restrict opportunities in transport
South Africa's transport network is well-developed by African standards, despite some bottlenecks, although the strong parastatal presence, including Transnet (for most freight railways and ports), Prasa (for passenger railways) and Sanral (for roads), limits opportunities for private providers. Moreover, weak parastatal governance can lead to cost overruns, project delays and workforce bloat. Privatisation is politically sensitive, but PPPs are, nonetheless, playing an important role, as illustrated by the Gauteng mass-transit railway, which opened, in phases, in 2010-12 and may be extended. The partnership between the privately-owned Richards Bay Coal Terminal, Africa's largest, and Transnet, which operates the railway serving the terminal, represents a different form of PPP. The government's bid to finance Gauteng's highways via a tolling system continues to face resistance from drivers, however, leading to revenue shortfalls at Sanral and underspending on maintenance. End-user pricing models clearly work better for railways (such as Gautrain) than roads.
South Africa's energy scene in 2019-23 will be characterised by a gradual decline in the dominant role of debt-laden Eskom, brisk growth in renewables (led by the private sector), and slow growth in electricity demand (because of sluggish economic growth and improvements in energy efficiency). The government's flagship renewable procurement programme, launched in 2011, has attracted investment of about US$14bn to date, mainly in solar and wind, which cut Eskom's share of the power mix from 95.9% in 2012 to 90.3% in 2018. The programme stalled in 2016 (partly because of Eskom's resistance), leaving several projects in limbo, but was revived by Mr Ramaphosa in 2018, leading the energy department to conclude new contracts worth US$4.7bn (for projects initially approved in 2014-15). Further bidding rounds are planned. The forecast period will see Eskom unbundled into separate distribution, transmission and generation arms, accompanied by the possible injection of private capital, provided trade union resistance can be overcome.
The draft update in 2018 to South Africa's Integrated Resource Plan (IRP), which runs to 2030, confirms the commitment to renewables but makes no provision for additional nuclear power. Eskom's coal-fired plants will continue to supply the bulk of base-load power, although the phased opening of new and hugely costly mega-plants at Medupi and Kusile (in 2017-23) will be see the closure of some ageing and less-efficient facilities. The final IRP update is still awaited, highlighting the political sensitivities surrounding energy policy. The risk of power shortages, which re-emerged in early 2019, will dissipate, but rising tariffs will burden end-users, while also driving energy efficiency.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.8 6.3 47 43 6 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
South Africa's ICT sector is a leader in Africa
South Africa's information and computer technology (ICT) market is among the most advanced in Africa in terms of technology and service provision, highlighted by the opening of two cloud-computing centres by Microsoft (in Johannesburg and Cape Town) in March 2019, the first by any operator on the continent. Local data centres will reduce problems with latency (delays) and provide new options for firms, such as banks, which are obliged to hold data locally for privacy reasons. Amazon, the world's leading cloud-computing firm, is investing in new projects in Cape Town (where the firm's local HQ is located) focussing on cloud computing, machine learning and data analysis, ahead of the planned opening of its first local data centre in 2020. China's Huawei also plans a local data centre, and Google may follow after it lays a proprietary high-speed cable from Portugal to South Africa in 2021. Cape Town is emerging as a key ICT hub, helped by having one of Africa's largest public fibre-optic networks. Key challenges are relatively high end-user charges (although these are falling over time), an increase in cybercrimes-marked by a number of serious data breaches in the private sector-and skills shortages.
Spectrum allocation faces delay
The allocation of new spectrum (freed by the switch from analogue to digital) could give a major boost to ICT capacity, including the roll-out of 5G, but a delay seems likely, based on draft plans in July. These call for 20% of the new spectrum to be allocated to a wholesale open-access network (WOAN)-to benefit small players-with the rest being auctioned. However, a WOAN could take up to two years to implement, thereby delaying the spectrum boost, unless the plans are amended. South Africa's 5G roll-out could also be hampered by the US clampdown on Huawei-a market leader in network equipment-as part of the ongoing US-China trade war.
In a significant boost to ICT and science, South Africa will host the majority portion of the US$2bn Square Kilometre Array (SKA) complex, a powerful radio telescope in Northern Cape. The first portion of the SKA, a 64-dish radio telescope, known as MeerKAT, opened in July 2018 to scientific acclaim, following investment of US$332m, mainly from public sources, including from international partners in the SKA consortium. MeerKAT is also at the cutting edge of high-performance data processing, which bodes well for technological progress and digital skills building. MeerKAT will be the central component of the SKA, which will include additional dishes and arrays in South Africa and several other African countries. Parts of the SKA will also be situated in Australia, bringing the total number of dishes to about 3,000. MeerKAT will operate independently until it is linked to the SKA in 2023, although the entire project may not be finished until later in the decade. The SKA could offer clues to black holes, dark energy and the origin of the universe.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Boosting economic growth and job creation amid global uncertainty, while avoiding macroeconomic imbalances, will remain the main task facing policymakers. There is little scope for fiscal stimulus in view of the high costs of bailing out dysfunctional parastatals and the need to raise taxes in order to keep debt under control and forestall additional credit downgrades. The main medium-term challenge is to overcome structural obstacles to faster growth, such as infrastructure bottlenecks and skills shortages. Targeted industrial incentives will therefore stay in place, and infrastructure investment will remain a priority, despite being constrained by funding shortfalls. Other challenges include persistent labour market rigidities and the progressively stricter application of rules against anti-competitive behaviour.
The May 2019 election win for the ANC will add impetus to Mr Ramaphosa's agenda, although internal party dynamics will continue to impose constraints, especially with regard to labour law, parastatal reform and privatisation. Prospective wins for Mr Ramaphosa include restarting the private sector-led renewable energy programme and producing a more business-friendly mining charter. Opportunities for public-private partnerships will arise, including in the power sector. Land rights will remain subject to uncertainty, however, given the ANC's backing for expropriation without compensation in some circumstances. Corporates face the additional challenge of complying with black economic empowerment targets, exacerbated by ongoing changes to the legal framework. A plan published by the Treasury in August recommends several growth-boosting reforms (such as relaxing visa rules), but vested interests, including organised labour, are an obstacle. Many policy conundrums facing the government stem from the difficulty in reconciling the imperatives of growth with those of socioeconomic transformation.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)

Government expenditure 30.6 30.3 30.3 30.3 30.5 30.3
Government revenue 25.8 25.5 25.5 26.3 26.8 27.1
Budget balance -4.7 -4.8 -4.8 -4.0 -3.7 -3.2
The fiscal outlook is deteriorating, largely because of unbudgeted bail-out funding of R59bn (US$4.1bn) in July for Eskom-the struggling, heavily indebted power parastatal-including R26bn in fiscal-year 2019/20 (April-March) and R33bn in 2020/21. Combined with constraints on revenue stemming from slack GDP growth, restructuring of the tax agency and the demands of other weak parastatals, the government will struggle to meet is budget deficit targets, set in February, of 4.5% of GDP in 2019/20 and 4.3% of GDP in 2020/21. Adding in the bail-out funds while leaving other parameters unchanged would produce deficits of 4.9% of GDP in both years. The government's target of a deficit reduction to 4% of GDP in 2021/22 is also at risk. Fiscal consolidation will therefore advance more slowly than envisaged in the 2019/20 budget, with The Economist Intelligence Unit's budget deficit forecasts (as a proportion of GDP) rising to 4.8% in 2019/20 (up from 4.2%) and 4.8% in 2020/21 (up from 3.9%). Our subsequent projections are unchanged, with the deficit falling to 3.2% of GDP by 2023/24 as economic growth picks up. Larger deficits imply higher public debt (and debt-servicing costs) although most borrowing will be sourced from local markets, which limits exchange-rate risks.
The impact of the Eskom bailouts (and other post-budget developments) on the fiscal accounts will become clearer with the release of the medium-term budget policy statement in October. A significant upward adjustment in the projected deficits (and borrowing requirements) could imperil South Africa's remaining investment-grade rating. A revision of South Africa's outlook by Moody's in November (from stable to negative) could presage a full downgrade in 2020, thereby pushing up borrowing costs across the economy. A downgrade may be avoided, however, if fiscal and growth indicators improve.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Commercial banks' prime rate (av) 10.1 10.0 9.8 9.8 10.0 10.3
The South African Reserve Bank (SARB, the central bank) cut the benchmark rate by 25 basis points to 6.5% in July, reversing a rise of the same magnitude in November 2018. The rate cut primarily stems from moderate inflation, which has stayed close to 4.5%-the midway point of the SARB's 3-6% target range-since December. Inflation at current levels also meets the informal target set by the SARB governor, Lesetja Kganyago, who was reappointed for a second, five-year term in July, heralding policy continuity. The start of an easing cycle in the US with a rate cut by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) in late July, after the SARB acted, could lead to another domestic rate reduction later in 2019 or early 2020, depending on inflation and exchange-rate trends. Barring shocks, we expect South African rates to move within a fairly narrow range in 2019-23. The SARB will retain its inflation-targeting mandate and its independence, even if the government takes the institution into public ownership.

Domestic and global headwinds inform our GDP growth forecast of 0.8% in 2019, unchanged from 2018. Growth picked up mildly in the second quarter, to 0.9% year on year, from zero in the first quarter-when the economy suffered from widespread power cuts-but it remains sluggish, amounting to 0.4% in the first half. Agriculture, mining and construction all shrank in January-June, respectively because of poor rainfall, strikes and power cuts, and weak investment, although services kept the economy afloat, led by transport and financial services. On the demand side, consumption growth quickened in the second quarter and investment growth turned positive, but net exports made a negative contribution.
The rebound, albeit mild, will continue in the second half, barring fresh power cuts, helped by a pick-up in private-sector credit extension to households, and to a lesser extent, corporates. Recovery will be constrained, however, by a double-digit rise in power tariffs in 2019 and higher unemployment, which climbed to a near-record rate of 29% in the second quarter, thereby denting aggregate demand. The government's tight finances leave little room for fiscal stimulus, although another small interest-rate cut is possible, following a reduction in July, which will support demand and credit uptake.
Economic activity will benefit from the re-election of Mr Ramaphosa in May, which gives him a mandate to implement policy reforms geared towards job creation and investment. This will potentially buoy private-sector confidence, although investors will remain cautious because of policy divisions within the ruling ANC over several key issues, such as land reform and the overhaul of Eskom, which need further clarification. Global developments will remain a key variable in 2019 because of threats posed by US-led protectionism, trade wars and the UK's potentially disruptive departure from the EU.
Assuming that reforms gather momentum (instead of stalling)-and that global tensions dissipate rather than escalate-real GDP growth will quicken to 1.6% in 2020, before heading higher, to 3% a year on average in 2021-23. Action to overhaul dysfunctional parastatals will facilitate investment from both public and private sources, although resistance to change from trade unions and vested interests will impede progress. More buoyant consumption, underpinned by an expanding black middle class, will also drive the economy, as will the spread of digital technologies, but growth will be too slow to have a significant impact on unemployment. Structural constraints, such as skills shortages and infrastructure bottlenecks, will persist. A negative external balance will weigh on economic growth throughout most of the forecast period.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
On the supply side, services will remain the largest sector (69.7% of factor-cost GDP in 2018) and will continue to be a key growth source. Activity will remain subdued in 2019, in line with the wider economy, before gaining momentum in 2020-23, to grow by 2.4% a year. The large banking segment (22.4% of GDP, including real estate and business services) will remain a leading segment and a key source of job creation, bolstered by rising rates of financial inclusion. Growth in retailing and wholesaling (15.1% of GDP) will be sluggish in 2019, held back by wholesale-and the impact of high unemployment on aggregate demand-but will benefit from a July rate cut and faster credit growth to households. Medium-term prospects are favourable, spurred by urbanisation. Transport and communications (9.6% of GDP) will gain from new investment in infrastructure, including in railways, ports and fibre-optic cable networks. The mobile-phone market is largely saturated, with a penetration rate of about 155 subscriptions per 100 people in 2018, but a transition to high-end services and increased data usage will underpin expansion. Tourism has considerable potential-based on South Africa's varied natural attractions and favourable climate-and is also labour-intensive, although high crime levels remain a deterrent. Tourism will benefit from the ongoing relaxation of tighter visa restrictions, misguidedly imposed in 2014-15, which led to a temporary downturn.
Industry (27.7% of factor-cost GDP in 2018, including mining) is struggling, held back by weak construction, utilities and mining, but is poised to regain ground in 2020-23, to remain a key part of the economy. Manufacturing (13.5% of GDP) is broad-based by Sub-Saharan African standards, being a key employer and source of exports, although growth will remain fairly sluggish, given subdued domestic demand and competition from imports. The key vehicle segment will benefit from new investment, spurred by incentives offered under the Automotive Production and Development Programme (APDP), which has now been extended beyond 2020, as part of the government's activist industrial policy. The risk of power shortages will persist, especially in the short term, owing to Eskom's financial and technical woes, but will diminish over time as new capacity, both private and public, comes onstream. Manufacturing will continue to face an elevated risk of strikes.
Mining makes a modest and declining contribution to GDP (8.1% in 2018), but accounts, directly and indirectly, for about 50% of export earnings. This leaves South Africa vulnerable to commodity price fluctuations and to a slowdown in China. Mining also suffers from labour militancy and a high-level of regulatory uncertainty, leading to a paucity of new investment. A reworked mining charter is more business-friendly, but some aspects still require clarification. Despite South Africa's rich mineral reserves, faster growth will require a more conducive policy environment. The small agricultural sector (2.6% of GDP in 2018) is vulnerable to drought, but it will continue to make an important contribution to exports (including fruit and wine), agro-industry and employment. However, erratic rainfall poses a high degree of risk: agriculture contracted in 2015, 2016 and 2018 because of drought, interspersed by a strong rebound in 2017. Future performance is dependent on both the climate and the government's land-reform policies, which remain in flux.

Our inflation projection for 2019 stays at 4.6%, helped by softer oil prices. Rand depreciation and a double-digit increase in electricity tariffs will be the main inflationary drivers in 2019, along with tax rises. Dry weather poses some risk to food prices, but the main maize harvest should be sufficient to avoid imports. Lower global oil prices in 2019 (on an annual basis) will mute inflation, as will slack demand and spare industrial capacity. An oil price spike, although not our central forecast, would threaten the forecast, especially in conjunction with rand weakness. We expect inflation to average 4.9% a year in 2020-23, staying within the SARB's 3-6% target range (temporary breaches aside). Oil prices will rise in 2021-23, but prudent monetary policy, stricter competition laws and efficiency gains will help to mute price growth.

The rand depreciated to R15.16:US$1 in August (from R14.04:US$1 in July), the weakest monthly rate-and the sharpest monthly decline-for more than three years. A US rate cut in late-July, which reversed a tightening trend, was potentially positive for the rand and other emerging-market currencies, but the impact has been overshadowed by growing concerns about escalating US-China trade wars and the consequent threat to the global economy. Domestic developments are adding to the pressure on the rand, especially sluggish GDP growth and the dire financial straits of Eskom, which threaten both the fiscal accounts and South Africa's remaining investment-grade credit rating. A downgrade, possibly in 2020, would have a negative impact on the value of the rand, but it may be avoided, depending on interim fiscal and macroeconomic developments. The rand will remain highly volatile, underlining its widely-traded status, although South Africa's modest level of external debt (denominated in foreign currency), offers some protection. We expect the rand to make a mild recovery from August levels, thereby leaving our forecasts are unchanged, at R14.48:US$1 in 2019 and R15.50:US$1 in 2020. The pace of depreciation will ease thereafter, helped by an improvement in several economic variables, taking the exchange rate to R17.80:US$1 in 2023.

The current-account deficit will fluctuate within a narrow range of 4-4.5% of GDP in 2019-22, before dropping to 3.7% of GDP in 2023. The structure of the deficit, comprising a merchandise trade surplus and a larger invisible trade deficit (on services, income and current transfers) will remain unchanged. Exports will grow at a modest pace in 2019-20, in line with non-oil commodity price trends and South Africa's heavy reliance on mineral sales. Non-mineral exports (such as cars) will benefit from a weaker rand and from South Africa's probable retention of trade preferences under the US African Growth and Opportunity Act, although US-led protectionism poses risks. Imports will be constrained by a slow pick-up in GDP growth and lower oil prices in 2019-20, keeping the merchandise trade balance in surplus. However, the shortfall on invisible trade will show a broad rising trend, underpinned by income payments to foreign investors and transfers to fellow members of the Southern African Customs Union. The current-account deficit will peak in 2020, at 4.5% of GDP, as world trade growth slows, before retreating slightly to an annual average of 4% of GDP in 2021-23, helped by stronger earnings.t

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in South Africa
Stocks and flows
South Africa is a prime destination for non-oil foreign direct investment (FDI) in Sub-Saharan Africa. Inflows averaged US$4bn a year in 2013-17, before rising to a four-year high of US$5.5bn in 2018, according to central bank figures, returning South Africa to top spot in the Sub-Saharan Africa investment league. Annual figures can vary substantially, however, because of the discontinuous nature of FDI, as well as the sensitivity of investment to commodity price trends (especially in mining) and changes in the policy environment. Inflows peaked at a record of US$9.9bn in 2008, boosted by the US$5.2bn purchase of a 20% stake in Standard Bank by China's state-run Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC)-the second-biggest FDI deal to date-behind the acquisition of 56% of ABSA by Barclays (UK) in 2005. Eight years later, in 2013, Barclays brought together most of its African operations, including ABSA, under the Barclays Africa banner, before subsequently announcing its withdrawal from Africa in 2016 as part of a global restructuring exercise. The sale of Barclays' majority stake in Barclays Africa, primarily to local investors, was completed in 2017. FDI regained momentum after the 2009 recession, rising to US$4.6bn in 2012, buoyed by the purchase by Walmart (US) of 51% of Massmart, for US$2.4bn. Inflows climbed higher, to US$8.2bn in 2013, the second highest on record, and remained strong at US$5.8bn in 2014, but weaker inflows in 2015 (US$1.5bn), 2016 (US$2.2bn) and 2017 (US$2.1bn) illustrate heightened investor concerns about domestic and global prospects. The rebound in 2018 suggests a recovery in confidence. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI to be fairly buoyant during the forecast period, averaging US$6.3bn a year in 2019-23 (and rising towards the end of the period), helped in part by South Africa's status as a gateway to Sub-Saharan Africa. South Africa is also a major outward investor, especially in Africa, where local firms are present in a wide range of sectors, including services and infrastructure, as well as in more traditional natural resource exploitation. Outward FDI averaged US$6.3bn annually in 2013-17, surpassing inward FDI in all four years, but higher inflows and lower outflows in 2018 reversed the pattern.
Origin and distribution
Most major investors are represented in South Africa, including the UK (Vodafone and, formerly, Barclays), Germany (Mercedes-Benz and BMW) and the US (Coca-Cola, Ford and Walmart). Pepsi may join the list after launching a US$1.7bn takeover bid for Pioneer, a local consumer goods firm, in July 2019. Investment from non-traditional sources, especially China (ICBC) and India (Tata and Cipla), is growing strongly. Financial services, information and computer technology (ICT), tourism, real estate, mining, and manufacturing are among the most attractive sectors, helped in some cases by investment incentives (such as for vehicles). FDI in South Africa includes greenfield projects-in motor vehicles, pharmaceuticals, food-processing, ICT and beverages-and buy-outs of existing firms (such as Massmart). The economically powerful Gauteng province receives the bulk of inward FDI, Eastern Cape benefits from investment in the Coega industrial zone and Western Cape is the main ICT hub. KwaZulu-Natal and North West respectively gain from investment in transport and mining, while Northern Cape is hosting the Square Kilometre Array telescope. New special economic zones will facilitate a more even spatial distribution of investment.
Determinants
Several factors drive inward investment, including South Africa's status as the most advanced economy in Sub-Saharan Africa (with close links to several other regional markets), a sizeable domestic market of 58.8m people (in mid-2019), strong tourism potential and world-class mineral wealth. South Africa's preferential access to the EU market, via a new economic partnership agreement concluded in 2014, and to the US market, under the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA), which has been extended by ten years, to 2025, also helps to support investment. Set against these factors are a number of deterrents, including a high degree of policy uncertainty, labour-market rigidity (and strikes), skills shortages, widespread crime and the dominant position of parastatals in several sectors. Contentious policy areas include a new FDI law that limits recourse to international arbitration, as well as proposals to allow for expropriation without compensation, which could damage property rights. Privatisation prospects are limited, although openings will arise for independent operators and public-private partnerships, mainly in energy and transport.
Impact
FDI has a strong positive impact in South Africa, especially in key sectors such as automotives, ICT, banking and mining, and has played a key role in boosting exports, facilitating growth and lifting employment. FDI provides capital, allows for the transfer of technology and skills, and binds South Africa more closely to the global economy.
Potential
We expect inflows to rise steadily during the forecast period, from US$5.5bn in 2018 to US$7.4bn in 2023, helped by a pick-up in local growth, but global and domestic risks are significant. The impact of the US-China trade war on global trade and growth, a slowdown in China, and a disorderly Brexit all have the potential to impede investment flows. Policy uncertainty will also inhibit investment, although the government's commitment to reforms is buoying confidence, despite periodic setbacks. Inflows will benefit from South Africa's activist industrial policy, especially in the automotive segment, and from private-sector investment in renewable energy. The retention of South Africa's AGOA status will also facilitate inflows (barring fresh disputes with the US over South Africa's eligibility), as will closer regional integration within the Southern African Development Community (SADC), and between the SADC and other African trade blocs. A new Africa Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) will give an additional boost if negotiations are conclusive. The rollout of a domestic cable network and the pending allocation of new spectrum will increase bandwidth and cut costs, facilitating investment in ICT, including in cloud computing and data analysis. Business-process outsourcing (given an English-speaking workforce in a similar time zone to the EU) has potential, but is underdeveloped. South Africa will remain a key base for companies with pan-African operations by offering a range of services, including banking, capital-raising and trade-related functions.
Demographic assumptions

South Africa's population is projected to grow at a relatively modest rate of 1.2% per year in 2019-23, partly because of the ongoing impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic. As a result, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the population to rise from an estimated 57.8m in 2018, to 61.5m in 2023, including positive net migration, mainly from neighbouring states. The latest official estimates for mid-2019 show that almost 8m people are living with HIV/AIDS-more than in any other country, and equivalent to 13.5% of the population. The number of victims and the prevalence rate therefore continues to rise; however, on other key metrics, such as deaths attributable to AIDS and the incidence rate of new infections, South Africa is making significant progress. AIDS-related deaths fell to 126,805 (23.4% of all fatalities) in the year to mid-2019-the lowest since the series began in 2002-from a peak of 286,588 in 2006, helped by the mass roll-out of anti-retroviral drugs. Most of those in need now receive treatment, enabling them to live longer and more productive lives, although the costs are substantial, amounting to about US$2bn a year. South Africa's incidence rate has also fallen sharply, from a peak of 2.5% in 2002 to just 0.7% in 2018 and 2019. With the incidence rate having fallen below the critical 1% mark, the prevalence rate is now increasing more slowly than the overall population growth rate and will start to decline during the forecast period.
The disease will remain a significant source of mortality into the medium term, imposing costs at the household, corporate and national levels. The loss of trained workers, either through death or extended absenteeism, is particularly damaging in a country so short of skills. Organisations therefore need to adopt coping strategies, such as increased expenditure on training. Despite positive data trends, any complacency with regards to AIDS is misplaced; instead, the government, in partnership with the private sector, should consider fresh policy initiatives.
Life expectancy will rise steadily
The fall in AIDS-related deaths is being accompanied by a rise in average life expectancy, which reached 64.7 years in mid-2019, up from a recent low of just 54.4 years in 2005. The improvement moves South Africa closer to the average for upper-middle-income countries, and further gains can be expected during the forecast period. South African demographic statistics, including age profiles, growth rates and life expectancy also display large race-based variations stemming from the apartheid era. The white population-typically wealthier, older and more educated-declined by 0.4%, to 4.7m, in the year to mid-2019 (7.9% of the total), thereby maintaining a long-term downward trend, driven by outward migration. By contrast, in the year to mid-2019, the Indian/Asian population grew by 1.5%, to 1.5m (2.6% of the total), the coloured/mixed-race population by 1.2%, to 5.2m (8.8% of the total), and the black population by 1.7%, to 47.4m (80.7% of the total). The black share of the total population will continue rising over time, based on current trends.
National Health Insurance advances
Healthcare, which is marked by costly private-sector provision for the rich and second-rate public provision for the poor majority, will face a shake-up over the next decade because of the government's decision to implement a National Health Insurance (NHI) system after lengthy delays. An NHI bill in July 2019 outlines the new framework, based on the centralised procurement of services from both public and private providers, but many key details have still to be settled, including funding and the precise role of private sector. Reforms are clearly needed, given a steady rise in overall healthcare costs to about 9% of GDP (of which half is accounted for by private operators), but whether the NHI will have an adverse or beneficial outcome depends on a host of uncertainties. Risks include damaging private healthcare and putting more pressure on overstretched public facilities and the fiscal accounts. The target date for full NHI implementation is 2026, beyond the forecast period, and additional delays are probable.
Rapid urbanisation will strain social services
South Africa is one of Sub-Saharan Africa's most urbanised societies, with an estimated 66.4% of the population living in urban centres in 2018, principally in the main metropolitan areas of Gauteng, namely Pretoria and Johannesburg, and the coastal cities of Cape Town and Durban. Urbanisation will continue throughout the forecast period, lifting the proportion living in cities (and associated slums) to 69.1% by 2023. Urbanisation is boosting market potential but also poses challenges for policymakers, in terms of strengthening service delivery at a municipal level.

South Africa's consumer market will continue transforming as the poor black majority is increasingly drawn into the mainstream economy, accompanied by an expansion of the black middle class. The transition is happening less rapidly than previously expected, given several years of sluggish growth and high unemployment (which constrains aggregate demand). Transformation will gain momentum during the forecast period, helped by faster growth and government initiatives to address poverty and inequality, such as generous welfare payments, black economic empowerment (BEE) and a national minimum wage. Despite significant changes since the apartheid era, South Africa remains one of the world's most unequal societies-with a Gini co-efficient of 0.63 (on a scale of 0-1; the higher the number, the higher the level of income inequality)-largely because of persistent racial disparities. Spending by black households is rising much faster than for white households in real terms, but the absolute gap remains large. We expect policy actions, demographic changes and faster growth to erode race-based distinctions over time as more blacks enter the middle class, which currently accounts for about 35% of households.
Consumer spending will show a broad upward trend
Household spending growth in real terms retreated from 4.2% a year in 2010-12, when the economy rebounded from the 2009 recession, to just 1.5% a year in 2013-18, reflecting an overall growth slowdown, weak job creation, rising interest rates (in 2014-16), household indebtedness and wages lost to strikes. Spending growth sank to just 0.6% in 2016, owing to a severe drought, but recovered to 2.1% in 2017, helped by better rains and a first rate cut in five years. An ebb to 1.8% in 2018 partly stemmed from higher taxes. Spending growth will remain muted in 2019, but is poised to quicken, underpinned by a July rate cut and a pick-up in credit allocation to households, which grew by a multi-year high of 6.5% year on year in June. Moreover, household debt (as a proportion of disposable income) is on downward trend, falling to 72% in 2018. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a steady rise in household consumption during the forecast period, in line with wider economic expansion. More generous welfare payments, rising real wages (for those in work), higher levels of financial inclusion and the expansion of the black middle class will support the improving trend.
Consumer spending will also benefit from the expansion of low-cost housing and electrification-boosting demand for ancillary goods and services-and from a broader-based approach to BEE. The benefits of BEE have been spread narrowly to date, helping to create a new black elite (the so-called black diamonds, who generally display similar consumption patterns to rich whites). However, the drive towards more broad-based BEE, including employee share-ownership schemes and a focus on suppliers, will potentially spread the gains more widely, boosting both the black middle class and poorer market segments.
The introduction of a national minimum wage on January 1st 2019 may buoy market potential but also carries risks, in terms of weaker job creation. The overall impact may be small, however, as the minimum wage is set fairly low and some exemptions apply. "Demonstration effect" purchasing by new middle-class entrants and blue-collar workers-and easier access to and greater reliance on credit-will buoy markets for more expensive retail goods such as electrical appliances. The spread of modern shopping malls will reinforce the trend, as will competition between the leading retailers, Pick n Pay, Shoprite, Woolworths and Massmart, the latter of which Walmart (US) took a majority stake in 2012 for US$2.4bn.

Consumer expenditure will show a broad upward trend over the forecast period, in both rand and US-dollar terms, although the composition of consumption will not change radically. In line with conventional patterns, the proportion spent on foodstuffs will decline over time, although it will remain the largest single category of expenditure, underpinned by the entry of subsistence-level rural dwellers into the commercial economy and the rise in the spending power of lower-income groups (which typically spend more of their money on food).
