From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: Growth will revive gradually in 2019-23, helped by a rise in confidence under Cyril Ramaphosa's presidency, accompanied by greater policy clarity and a crackdown on corruption, which will encourage investment. However, global headwinds (including trade wars) and fiscal consolidation in South Africa, alongside lingering policy uncertainty-especially about land reform-mean that growth, despite quickening, will remain sluggish, averaging 2.3% a year in 2019-23. Lower interest rates will provide a mild stimulus, although monetary policy will remain strongly determined by global trends. Growth will therefore be too slow to make a significant dent in the high unemployment rate (currently 29%), which continues to dampen aggregate demand. Structural constraints such as labour market rigidity and skills shortages will persist, although electricity supplies will improve, helped by private-sector investment in renewable energy.
The impact of HIV/AIDS will gradually dissipate in 2031-50
Demographic trends: South Africa's population will continue to grow at a slow pace, held back by the impact of the HIV/AIDS pandemic, which may persist for another generation. However, the downward trend in new infections and deaths attributable to AIDS, and the ongoing rollout of treatment programmes, will reduce the impact of the disease in 2031-50. Life expectancy will consequently rise, although population growth will remain relatively muted, as rising disposable incomes and urbanisation lead to smaller families. The working-age population and the labour force will grow slightly faster than the overall population, given the high proportion of young people and inward migration from other African states, adding to the difficulty of bringing down the unemployment rate. Demographic trends also point to a rise in the proportion of urban dwellers, from 66.4% in 2018 to 80% in 2050.
External conditions: South Africa's performance, as a relatively small and open economy that is strongly reliant on mineral exports, will remain closely tied to world trends. This leaves South Africa vulnerable to disruptions stemming from US-led protectionism (under the presidency of Donald Trump), Brexit and a Chinese slowdown. Multilateral trade liberalisation under the auspices of the World Trade Organisation may fall victim to trade wars, although trade will benefit from bilateral and regional initiatives, including plans for a single African market. The Africa Continental Free Trade Area (AfCFTA) was formally launched in July 2019, but will require lengthy negotiations before coming into effect. The Southern African Development Community will continue pressing for freer trade, although ambitions for a customs union, a common market and monetary union may not be realised until after 2030, because of economic and policy divergences between members. Intra-African trade will be held back by non-tariff barriers and weak infrastructure in 2015-30, but these constraints will ease in 2031-50. Ties with the EU will continue to deepen, following agreement on a new economic partnership agreement in 2014. South Africa will retain preferential access to the US market-given the extension of the African Growth and Opportunity Act until 2025-although its eligibility will be subject to periodic reviews. Trade and investment ties with non-OECD states, especially fellow BRICS members (Brazil, Russia, India and China) will deepen over the long term, at the expense of traditional links with OECD partners.
The quality of institutions will improve
Institutions and policy trends: The quality of institutions will improve, boosting transparency and accountability, but capacity constraints will persist, especially at provincial and municipal levels. Key institutions, such as the South African Reserve Bank (the central bank) and the judiciary, will retain their independence, even if the former moves into public ownership. The wider policy framework-which is based on a partnership between private business and the "developmental state"-will remain intact. In broad terms, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects moderate, centrist voices to prevail in the policy debate in the longer term, at the expense of pro-patronage forces and the interventionist left. The process will be helped by political realignments that could see the fragmentation of the ruling tripartite alliance-comprising the African National Congress (ANC), the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the South African Communist Party-and the emergence of a new coalition between moderates in the ANC and the opposition. Challenges such as skills shortages, high unemployment and land reform will persist, although investment will alleviate infrastructure constraints.
Productivity gains will boost growth in the longer term
Long-term performance: We forecast that real GDP growth will average 4% a year in 2019-50, helped by rising life expectancy, improved healthcare, investment in infrastructure, regional integration and global demand for commodities. Technological advances, such as cloud computing and additive printing, will also drive growth and boost productivity. Growth will quicken to 4.3% a year in 2031-50 as the ICT revolution gathers momentum and African integration deepens. Growth in capital stocks will outpace growth in labour productivity throughout the period, owing to a combination of skills shortages and investment in new technology.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
The threat of climate change continues to rise up the national agenda, driven by water deficits, which could worsen as weather patterns become more extreme. A three-season drought in Western Cape, after the failure of winter rains in 2015-17, leading to strict water rationing, highlights the challenge, although rainfall was better in 2018-19. The government is developing a comprehensive climate change policy, in the form of a draft National Climate Change Bill, unveiled in mid-2018, and is also a signatory to the Paris Agreement (2015), which aims to secure cuts in greenhouse gas emissions on a global basis. The introduction of a carbon tax in July 2019 is a key step, but faces criticism from the green lobby for being too low, and from business for being too high, thereby threatening competitiveness. The carbon tax's impact will be fairly small in the first phase, in 2019-22, given a raft of exemptions and concessions, although rules will become tighter in 2023-30, depending on the outcome of a proposed first-phase review. The carbon tax poses some inevitable challenges but will also encourage innovation. The government's long-term energy plan, running to 2030 and close to being finalised, will have a major impact on emissions, because of increased reliance on renewable energy at the expense of coal-fired power. Coal's share of installed generating capacity is expected to fall to 45% in 2030, down from 72% in 2018. Major reforms in water policy and management are also required, to stem the risk of ever more severe droughts.
Technological developments
South Africa, with the most advanced information and computer technology (ICT) environment in Africa, is well-placed to benefit from future technological progress. The continent's first cloud-computing data centres, under the Microsoft banner, opened in March 2019 in Johannesburg and Cape Town-the two domestic ICT hubs-and Amazon is similarly investing in cloud computing and advanced data processing. In terms of start-up numbers and financing, South Africa leads the pack in Africa, according to the GSMA, a trade body that represents the interests of mobile network operators worldwide. This reflects the dynamic business environment, especially by African standards, as well as South Africa's reputable legal system, strong banks and adequate power supplies. Skills shortages will nonetheless remain a challenge, although the probable loosening of restrictions on inward migration for skilled workers may address some of the deficit. Other obstacles include comparatively high end-user tariffs (although these will trend downwards) and the global problem of cybercrime and data security.
South Africa's central role in the multi-national Square Kilometre Array (SKA), a powerful radio telescope, will make a significant contribution to technological progress. SKA's first portion opened in July 2018 to scientific acclaim, and will be followed by new arrays in South Africa, other African countries and Australia over the next decade, at a total cost of at least US$2bn. SKA's high-performance data-processing requirements will help to drive technological development. The roll-out of 5G will benefit from the allocation of new spectrum, although this may be delayed until 2021 because of plans to hand 20% to an open-access network. South Africa will also benefit from space-based technology (helped by ongoing satellite launches) and the local development of 3D-printing using platinum. Digital innovation has the potential to transform almost all economic sectors.
Migration and urbanisation
South Africa is a net recipient of cross-border migration, unlike most African countries, driven by inflows from poorer parts of the continent, which will continue into the long term. The latest mid-year estimates for 2019 show that net inward migration accounted for about 24% of the total population increase (of 836,000) during the preceding 12 months. From another perspective, inward migration was responsible for 0.3 of a percentage point of the overall 1.4% annual increase. This replicates the broad pattern over the past decade, although the relative contribution of net inward migration will ease over time because of faster economic growth in other African states than in South Africa and a rise in South Africa's natural population growth rate as the impact of HIV/AIDS diminishes.
South Africa's white population (4.7m in 2019; 7.9% of the total) continues to shrink (by 20,000 in the year to mid-2019, a multi-year high) because of outward migration, leading to a loss of skills. However, migrant inflows are far larger and will also make a positive skills contribution, helped, for example, by Zimbabwe having better schools than South Africa. Inward migration will continue to pose social challenges, given South Africa's high unemployment rate, leading to periodic bouts of xenophobia-tinged unrest. Net inward migration means that remittance outflows exceed remittance inflows, contrary to the African pattern. Internal migration within South Africa from poorer provinces to the economic hubs of Gauteng and Western Cape will also drive population movement and urbanisation, although the proliferation of informal settlements and deficits in service provision will remain pressing issues.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historic data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US & OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US & OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: Dated Brent Blend
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Dollar effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Population: Based on UN data for both the historical and the forecast periods
Balance of payments: IMF, IFS
Inflation: Statistics South Africa. Based on CPIX (consumer price inflation less mortgage costs)
Exchange rate: IMF, IFS; principal rate expressed as R:US$
Real effective exchange rate index: based on consumer price index; trade partner weighted index with base period 2000=100
Interest rate: IMF, IFS; average lending rate
US$ GDP: SARB, Quarterly Bulletin; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US$ GDP divided by population
Foreign direct investment: IMF, IFS; UNCTAD, World Investment Report
Total external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; sum of long-term debt, short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity in excess of one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
Total debt service: principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges paid against total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
SARB: South African Reserve Bank
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Country Forecast Europe September 2019

Abstract: A total of 19 EU members share the euro as their currency and are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank. During the euro zone debt crisis, several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) received financial support from the EU and the IMF in return for fiscal and economic reforms. At its September 2019 meeting, the European Central Bank (ECB) announced a stimulus package that was more dovish than many had expected, sending a strong signal that ultra-loose monetary policy will persist in the medium term and at least into 2021. Background: The political geography of Europe has been defined by two world wars. The EU's creation dates back to the Rome Treaty of 1957, which created the European Economic Community between the six founding EU member states (France, Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg). After four enlargements in 1973 (UK, Denmark, Ireland), 1981 (Greece), 1986 (Spain and Portugal) and 1995 (Austria, Finland and Sweden), the EU counted 15 members. The collapse in 1991 of the Soviet Union provided an opportunity to expand the EU eastwards. Ten new member states (eight from the former communist bloc) were admitted to the EU in 2004, followed by a further two in 2007, and Croatia in 2013. In June 2016 the UK electorate voted in a referendum to withdraw from the EU; UK-EU negotiations on the UK's exit from the EU have so far been difficult. The economic transition of the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) has proceeded more smoothly than those of other east European countries. The effects of war in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s and a slower pace of reform have shaped developments in south-eastern Europe. In the Commonwealth of Independent States, many countries continue to have deep economic and political ties with Russia.
Political structure: All 28 EU member states are parliamentary democracies, although in some of the newer, former communist members in particular, the substance of democracy-including a political culture based on trust and political participation-is often absent. The communist period lasted much longer in the former Soviet Union, and political developments in most parts of that region have been characterised by a drift towards authoritarianism.
Policy issues: Many aspects of domestic policy for EU member states-notably those relating to the single market-are decided collectively at EU level. A total of 19 EU members share the euro as their currency and are subject to a single monetary policy administered by the European Central Bank. They are supposed to comply with common fiscal rules, although these have sometimes been ignored. During the euro zone debt crisis, several member states (Cyprus, Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain) received financial support from the EU and the IMF in return for fiscal and economic reforms. Outside the EU, the speed and extent of reform, and institutional change, vary widely. Countries with proximity to Western markets and with stable political outlooks have proceeded faster-and more successfully-with economic stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation. Institutional problems, such as weakness in the rule of law and widespread corruption, plague much of non-EU Europe.
Taxation: Individual tax regimes operate in all countries. All EU member states must operate a system of value-added tax (VAT), with a minimum of 15% as the standard rate.
Foreign trade: If intra-EU trade is included, the EU accounts for about half of all global trade. About 60% of trade conducted by EU member states is intra-regional.

Summary
Political stability
Popular disaffection with traditional mainstream parties will persist during the forecast period (2019-23), leading to greater success for populist and insurgent parties in elections; difficulties in government formation; and the creation of unusual (and in some cases unstable) coalitions.
The May 2019 European Parliament elections resulted in a more fragmented political landscape. The centre-right European People's Party (EPP) and centre-left Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) remain the two largest parliamentary groups, but they lost their majority for the first time.
The New European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, has nominated her commissioners and put forward an ambitious policy agenda, but the geopolitical and policy divisions in the EU will stymie progress, including on budgets, foreign policy and security, migration and trade.
The UK remains in political deadlock over Brexit. The British parliament has rejected the Withdrawal Agreement Bill and a "no-deal" Brexit. The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that a general election is the most likely way out of the current impasse. A no-deal Brexit remains a risk.
Economic policy
We expect the euro zone to resist steps towards full fiscal integration, but the Franco-German axis will drive forward some reforms in the coming years.
Some countries will continue to push back against EU and euro zone rules. However, a confrontation between the Italian government and the European Commission over the country's fiscal plans looks to have been averted following the departure of the Lega and the formation of a new coalition in August.
At its September 2019 meeting, the European Central Bank (ECB) announced a stimulus package that was more dovish than many had expected, sending a strong signal that ultra-loose monetary policy will persist in the medium term and at least into 2021.
Economic growth
The euro zone's economic recovery was broad-based and sustained in 2017, but growth slowed in 2018. This loss of momentum has carried through into 2019 and we expect a substantial slowdown in growth rates across the bloc this year and next, before growth picks up again from 2021.
The main reason for the slowdown is a deterioration of the external environment, with softer global trade and high geopolitical uncertainty, reflecting US-China trade tensions, the threat of a US tariff increase on EU automotive exports and the risk of a no-deal Brexit in the UK.
However, domestic demand has remained firm, with private consumption supported by widespread labour market improvements, and investment growth fuelled by high capacity-utilisation rates and favourable lending conditions.
Business environment rankings
The business environment has improved in most European countries, as the post-crisis economic recovery has gathered pace, and this will continue.

Political outlook: Political stability
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects political risk to remain high in Europe throughout the forecast period (2019-23). The negative political fallout from the global financial crisis and euro zone crisis, coming on top of the long-term erosion of the traditional political party system, is proving to be electorally disruptive. The fragmentation of the political landscape is leading to delays in forming governments after elections and an increase in unstable coalition governments. The rise of populism has hampered reform efforts at both the national and regional levels, and a meaningful overhaul of the European institutional framework is unlikely.
Challenges for the EU include Brexit and migration
Threats to European political stability over the medium term include the damaging impact of the UK's decision to leave the EU; disagreement over how to manage migration policy and over the proper balance between national sovereignty and "pooled sovereignty"; and the impact of an economic growth slowdown on support for the mainstream political parties.
The UK's vote in June 2016 to leave the EU represents a challenge for the bloc, and the departure of one of the EU's largest members will continue to reverberate after the UK leaves (in 2019 or 2020). The country's departure will leave a hole in the EU budget, which will be difficult to overcome without generating antagonism within the bloc. However, so far Brexit has resulted in increased European solidarity rather than tensions between member states. This is because leading member states such as France and Germany are keen to send a strong political message that a departure from the bloc will be more damaging for the exiting member state than for the EU.
In the wake of the European Parliament elections on May 23rd-26th, which resulted in a more fragmented parliament (compared with the 2014 Parliament elections), the process of appointing candidates to the top jobs was protracted. On July 2nd, EU heads of state announced their candidate choices, after reaching a compromise on Ursula von der Leyen, the German defence minister, as their nominee for president of the next European Commission. The package of nominations also included Christine Lagarde, the managing director of the IMF, as the president of the European Central Bank (ECB); Charles Michel, the Belgian prime minister, as president of the European Council; and Josep Borrell, the Spanish foreign affairs minister, as high representative for foreign affairs and security policy. The nominations bolster the political strength of the core EU member states and can be viewed as a win for Emmanuel Macron, the French president.
Ms von der Leyen formally presented her team of commissioners on September 10th. Confirmation hearings will be held in late October in the European Parliament, before the line-up (or a revised version, should any changes be required) is confirmed in office on November 1st. Ms von der Leyen stated the need to "address the changes in climate, technology and demography", and then presented three executive vice-president roles (out of eight vice-president positions in total) that correspond to these areas. We expect a hawkish stance on competition policy, energetic efforts to push for a carbon-neutral economy and some easy wins in social policy. Other policy areas-notably trade negotiations, budget discipline and migration-will be more controversial. Ms von der Leyen would like Europe to be seen as an alternative model to the US or China, emphasising multilateralism, fair trade and the rules-based order, rather than protectionism or authoritarianism. However, achieving her goals will depend on building consensus on difficult issues within a fragmented European Parliament.
The political scene in Germany will be less stable than in the recent past
Germany is a leading example of a country where support for the traditionally dominant mainstream parties has declined sharply as the landscape of voter support has become more fragmented. The government installed in Germany in March 2018 is another grand coalition comprising the centre-right Christian Democratic Union (CDU) with the Christian Social Union (CSU, its Bavarian sister party) and the centre-left Social Democratic Party (SPD). However, the seat share of these two parties has declined from almost three-quarters of parliament in 2005 to 56% now. Parties that take a clear line on migration and openness have benefited most from this-notably the far-right, anti-immigrant Alternative for Germany (AfD), which is now the largest opposition party, and the centre-left Greens, who stand for an open Germany.
The fall in support for the SPD has been particularly extreme. The party is approaching a leadership contest, which could result in calls from within the party to quit the grand coalition and re-establish itself in opposition. Nonetheless, we expect the government to serve its full term, as forcing a snap election would probably cost the SPD most of its parliamentary representation. The chancellor, Angela Merkel, will stand down at the end of her term in 2021, which will be a significant change after 16 years in office.
Germany has played an important role on the EU stage in recent years, and its economic dominance within the euro zone means that this will continue. The German position on questions of reform-a consensus against further fiscal transfers within the bloc, lukewarm support for euro zone reform, and stronger support for a redesign of security and refugee policy-are unlikely to change. Relations with Mr Macron will be important in the debate about the future of Europe.
In France political stability has returned, for now
In France Mr Macron enjoys the support of a solid majority of deputies in the National Assembly (the lower house of parliament), which has enabled him to make substantial progress on his ambitious legislative agenda since taking office in May 2017. He came to power determined not to give in to the sort of street protests that had derailed so many of his predecessors' plans, and front-loaded difficult structural reform efforts in the hope that the results would materialise before the end of his term in 2022.
However, weekly protests by the "Gilets Jaunes" in late 2018 and early 2019 forced him to rethink his plans. These protests began in response to a proposed tax rise on fuel, but struck a chord more generally with people frustrated by stagnant wages, who view Mr Macron as the "president of the rich". In response, Mr Macron pledged EUR10bn in concessions to the protesters in December 2018 and held a national debate in January-March 2019. This resulted in a new package of reforms that will make up "Act II" of his presidency.
The debate was in part a way of calming the social unrest, and in part a way of reconnecting with voters who had grievances to express. More than 2m people took part, and the protests eased in intensity, with Mr Macron's approval ratings stabilising at about 30%. Although there has been no overall change in the government's policy direction, a range of new legislative measures has been announced, including an easing of the tax burden, a rise in pensions and a boost to public service provision. Mr Macron will continue to face vocal opposition, but the risks to political stability have fallen.
Political stability will improve in Spain, but the Catalan issue is still unresolved
In Spain politics has become increasingly unsettled in recent years. Parliamentary fragmentation, a litany of political graft scandals and rising regional nationalism in Catalonia pose serious challenges to governance. Against this backdrop, in April 2019 Spain held its third general election since December 2015. The snap vote was triggered by the rejection at the hands of two Catalan pro-independence parties of the 2019 budget proposal made by the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party (PSOE) government. The PSOE, led by Mr Sánchez, won a decisive victory at the election, raising its vote share from 22.6% in 2016 to nearly 29%. The nationalist, far-right Vox entered the national parliament for the first time after surging to 10.3% of the vote. Having failed to obtain the confidence of parliament to form a government in July, Mr Sánchez had until September 23rd to obtain sufficient support. Because he failed to do that, a repeat election will take place on November 10th 2019.
In September, after months of negotiations, the PSOE was unable to reach an agreement with the far-left Unidas Podemos (UP) on the framework of a left-wing government. The PSOE accepted only a common policy programme with UP, whereas UP remained intent on a coalition government. Both parties were unwilling to make further concessions, leaving a repeat general election scheduled for November 10th as the only remaining option to break the deadlock. Several opinion polls released in mid-September projected gains for the PSOE, but had the party falling at least 30 seats short of an absolute majority. The prospect of gaining more seats and freeing itself from a reliance on smaller parties-such as the separatists in Catalonia-could have been one incentive for the PSOE to face a fresh poll.
We expect that the election will again deliver a fragmented parliament, but to a slightly lesser degree than following the April election. We believe that the PSOE will still fall short of an absolute majority, but it will increase its representation in parliament and therefore negotiating power. The most likely scenario is a minority PSOE-led government with the external support of UP and the liberal Ciudadanos (Citizens). Such a government would probably have a simple majority in a second-round investiture vote. Two other possible scenarios are the PSOE reaching a coalition agreement with either the UP and the support of small regionalist parties (preferably without Catalan separatists), or with Ciudadanos. There is a risk that centre-right parties (especially the PP) perform better that expected in the polls, although we do not think the PP, Ciudadanos and the nationalist, far-right Vox will be able to obtain a majority of seats. We expect the Catalan issue to persist, with no clear solution in sight.
Brexit is likely to be delayed owing to a political deadlock in the UK
The UK is currently in a political deadlock over Brexit. Upon becoming prime minister on July 24th, Boris Johnson promised that the UK would leave the EU, with or without a deal, on the current Brexit deadline of October 31st. However, in September, opposition members of parliament (MPs) successfully passed the so-called Benn-Burt bill into law. This bill requires the prime minister to request an extension of Article 50 until January 31st, if no withdrawal agreement has passed by October 19th, and to accept within two days any counter-offer given by the EU, unless parliament explicitly overrules this. Some 21 Conservative MPs rebelled against the Conservative whip to support the bill, and were subsequently expelled from the Parliamentary Conservative Party. This expulsion, combined with additional defections, leaves the government 43 seats short of a majority. As the legal default option is now for the UK to request an extension and with Mr Johnson now far short of a majority needed to change this law, we believe that this is by far the most likely outcome
However, having lost its majority, the government is likely to fall once the imminent threat of no deal is postponed. The EU is also likely to insist on some material change, such as an election, as a justification for an extension. Therefore, it is likely that there will be an election in November or December. We expect that Mr Johnson will use parliament's role in blocking him as a rallying cry for an election-seeking a mandate to deliver Brexit on the new deadline, while the opposition parties will campaign on ways to further delay, soften or revoke the Brexit process. The outcome of the election is highly uncertain with current polling suggesting another hung parliament as a likely outcome, leaving both no deal and no Brexit as possible outcomes, as well as a potentially divisive second referendum.
The Italian government will be unstable and will not last long
The general election in Italy in 2018 produced a highly fragmented parliament. Following prolonged negotiations, the anti-establishment Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S), which won 33% of the vote, and the Eurosceptic far-right Lega, which secured 17% agreed to form a coalition government. In early August 2019 Matteo Salvini, the leader of the Lega, called a vote of no confidence in the Lega-M5S coalition, in the hope of forcing a general election to capitalise on the Lega's growing popularity. A shared desire to prevent the Lega from forming a hard-right government pushed the M5S and centre-left Partito Democratico (PD) to agree to form a new coalition together. This is still led by Giuseppe Conte, an independent.
We believe that the new Conte government is unlikely to last until the end of the parliamentary term in 2023, but it will hold together for 12-18 months. Much will depend on whether electoral support for the Lega remains high.
Turkey has completed its transition towards one-man rule
In Turkey Recep Tayyip Erdogan was re-elected in June 2018 as president of Turkey for a second term in the first round of a snap election, while the conservative Justice and Development Party (AKP) secured a parliamentary coalition majority with its right-wing ally, the Nationalist Action Party (MHP), in an election that was mostly free, but largely unfair.
Mr Erdogan's re-election concludes Turkey's shift from a parliamentary to a presidential republic. This move was initiated with a constitutional referendum in April 2017, which the government narrowly won. The new system grants the president wide-ranging executive powers with little oversight (including in the selection of most of the officials in the judiciary) and has abolished the role of prime minister. This greatly curtails the role of parliament.
We expect the AKP and Mr Erdogan, who came close to being overthrown in an attempted coup by parts of the military in mid-2016, to remain in power until 2023. Mr Erdogan and the AKP suffered a clear blow to their credibility when the opposition candidate, Ekrem Imamoglu, increased his margin of victory over Binali Yildirim of the ruling coalition in the Istanbul mayoral election rerun at the end of June 2019. However, Mr Erdogan will continue to clamp down on political dissent to maintain his dominance of Turkish politics in the coming years.
Terrorist attacks by Islamic State (IS) and the independence conflict being waged by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) pose a constant security risk. Neither the government nor the PKK is interested in reviving peace negotiations that collapsed in mid-2015, raising the risk that violence will return to 1990s levels.
The transition to a post-Putin Russia has led to greater political jockeying
The president of Russia, Vladimir Putin, won a comfortable victory in the March 2018 presidential election. Although Mr Putin's re-election itself was a non-event, given his high approval ratings and the absence of credible opposition candidates, it has ushered in a period of political uncertainty as various factions of the elite jockey to secure their positions in the post-Putin political order-assuming that the president stands down at the end of his term in 2024 (our core forecast). The transition will result in great uncertainty owing to the weakness of most political and legal institutions, as well as the personalised and opaque governance system around Mr Putin.
Mr Putin's fourth term will be characterised by broad continuity in his policy agenda, which focuses on "conservative cultural values", an authoritarian political culture and overt anti-Westernism. We also expect a renewed focus on domestic policy in an effort to arrest the current decline in living standards and bolster growth following the 2015-16 recession. Despite occasional pro-market rhetoric, economic policy will remain statist, nationalist and protectionist. Economic sovereignty-understood as insulating the economy from external shocks-will remain a priority.
On the international stage, Russia will continue to pursue a muscular foreign policy, with the aim of asserting its status as a major global player. Its influence will be strengthened by the conclusion of international deals in strategic sectors such as oil and gas, nuclear power plants and military equipment.
The CIS region will be mostly stable
We do not expect political or economic upheaval in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) in the near term. The exceptions to this are Uzbekistan, where the new president will continue to pursue a reformist course, and Armenia and Georgia, where street protests in 2018 led to a change in government, and where economic growth will outpace that of most other countries in the region. Kazakhstan will undergo a successful managed political transition, with Kasym-Jomart Tokayev (the chosen successor to Nursultan Nazarbayev) winning a landslide victory in the June 2019 presidential election. We believe that no significant political or economic change will take place in the other central Asian countries (the Kyrgyz Republic, Turkmenistan and Tajikistan).
Political outlook: Election watch
General elections across Europe since 2017 have confirmed rising disaffection with the political establishment, which has been reflected in the decline of the two-party system and the rise of insurgent populist parties. Increasing political fragmentation across the region has resulted in a more complicated policymaking outlook, but has also made forming governments more difficult and given rise to some unusual coalitions.
The shift on migration under the ÖVP will help it into government
Austria provides one example. Following the expulsion in May 2019 of the far-right Freedom Party (FPÖ), the then chancellor and leader of the centre-right People's Party (ÖVP), Sebastian Kurz, lost a vote of no confidence, supported by the Social Democrats (SPÖ) and the FPÖ. This led to the appointment of a placeholder government until elections are held on September 29th. We expect the ÖVP to emerge as the largest party from the election, after campaigning on a more hardline policy towards migration and integration. However, we do not expect the party to win enough support to govern alone, requiring another coalition. We expect the FPÖ to re-enter government as the ÖVP's coalition partner, owing to the considerable policy overlap between the two parties, although the position of controversial FPÖ politicians could impede any new coalition deal.
European Parliament elections result in a more fragmented EU political scene
The European Parliament elections, held on May 23rd-26th, reflected similar trends to those since 2017 at the national level. There were significant gains for the liberal, centrist Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE) and for the Greens/European Free Alliance, alongside a continued rise in support for nationalist, populist and Eurosceptic parties (most notably the single-issue Brexit Party in the UK). The traditional mainstream parties struggled in comparison, with the centre-left Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) and the centre-right European People's Party (EPP) losing their majority for the first time.
Nonetheless, the results from May 2019 do not pose a threat to the European project, as some had feared before the event. We expect the balance of power within the European Parliament to remain largely pro-EU-even more so once the UK leaves the bloc and its members of European Parliament (MEPs) stand down. We do not expect the hardline Eurosceptic parties, which are highly heterogeneous, to be able to form a cohesive, united front.
Recent Ukraine elections hinge on question of corruption
Another significant election in the third quarter of 2019 was the parliamentary election in Ukraine in July. In April Volodymyr Zelenskyi, a comedian and television celebrity with no political experience, won a decisive victory in a second-round vote against the incumbent, Petro Poroshenko. This victory was the result of a widespread popular rejection of political elites in general and of Mr Poroshenko in particular, as well as a perception that the changes promised after the 2014 revolution had not materialised. Following the July parliamentary polls, Servant of the People, a new political party created to support the candidacy of Mr Zelenskyi in the presidential race, commands an absolute majority of seats in parliament. This has given Mr Zelenskyi has a strong mandate to tackle corruption and speed up an ambitious set of reforms that he laid out in the first weeks of his presidency. These include changes to the political system to ensure more accountability (which includes removing the immunity of the president and deputies), a new deal with the IMF and the revival of an anti-corruption campaign that stalled in the last months of Mr Poroshenko's presidency.
In Greece a snap general election was held on July 7th, three months before the end of the parliamentary term. The main centre-right opposition party, New Democracy (ND), led by Kyriakos Mitsotakis, recorded a comfortable victory over the ruling Syriza Coalition of the Radical Left (Syriza). The Syriza leader and prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, called the election after losing heavily to ND in the European Parliament and local elections on May 26th. At the general election, ND obtained 39.85% of the national vote, which, along with a 50-seat bonus awarded to the party with the most votes, gave Mr Mitsotakis's party 158 seats in the 300-seat parliament. This makes his government the first single-party government since the start of the Greek crisis nearly a decade ago. Despite its solid majority, the new government faces formidable policy challenges, not least to implementing its programme of spending and tax cuts.
Fine Gael minority coalition government will not survive a full term
The Fine Gael-led minority coalition government in Ireland does not have the capacity or cohesion to address the mounting economic and political challenges in the country effectively, and our view remains that the government will not survive a full term to February 2021. We currently expect a snap election to take place in early 2020-although we do not expect this to produce a government any more stable or effective than the current coalition. This existing administration, led by Leo Varadkar, relies on the support of a disparate group of independent MPs, and a three-year "confidence and supply" agreement between Fine Gael and the main opposition party, Fianna Fail. The agreement with Fianna Fail was extended in December, as neither Mr Varadkar nor Micheal Martin, the leader of Fianna Fail, was willing to trigger an early election while there was still great uncertainty regarding Brexit. However, opinion polls have recently shifted towards Fianna Fail, and we expect them to withdraw their support for the current government as soon as the threat of a no-deal Brexit in the UK is no longer imminent.

Political outlook: Intra-regional tensions
Policy-related tensions remain high within the euro zone, but the risk that they will prompt rows between EU members has fallen sharply since 2016, in the context of an economic recovery across the bloc in 2016-18. The ECB has overcome objections in a number of countries-notably Germany-to its use of unconventional policy instruments. However, the breathing space created by the ECB's programme of sovereign quantitative easing (QE) has not been used by political leaders to bolster the economic recovery with a strong united position on fiscal policy and structural reform.
Huge political capital has been invested in keeping the euro zone together in recent years. There were fears that one or some euro zone countries might exit the bloc during the financial crisis. However, this scenario now seems unlikely, and the financial stability of the bloc looks strong despite the high public debt levels of some south European countries (such as Greece, which existed its bail-out programme in August 2018, and Italy).
Italian government is testing the limits of the EU's patience on fiscal rules
The trend toward "sovereigntist" and Eurosceptic politics has played out dra-matically over the past year. In Italy, the previous government, composed of the anti-establishment M5S and the anti-immigration Lega, tested the limits of EU rules, particularly on fiscal policy and immigration. Following a protracted dispute with the European Commission over its draft 2019 budget plan, the previous administration narrowly avoided the launch of an excessive-deficit procedure in early July.
We expect the new government coalition comprising the pro-European PD and the M5S to be less confrontational towards EU rules on migration and fiscal policy than the previous administration. It remains to be seen what Mr Conte can realistically achieve regarding his government's demands for a revision of the EU's Stability and Growth Pact in favour of economic growth-friendly policies, and a review of the Dublin Regulation to ensure burden-sharing among member states in dealing with migrants seeking asylum in the EU. The prospect of obtaining some concessions on the fiscal front appears to be better than the chance of concessions on the highly divisive migration issue.
Hungary and Poland will continue to clash with the EU over illiberal policies
The nationalist, socially conservative governments in Hungary and Poland have come into conflict with the EU over the EU's refugee-relocation policy and also over the creation of what the Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, has called-in reference to his own country-an "illiberal" state. In addition to refusing to take their allocation of refugees, the Hungarian and Polish govern-ments have curbed the independence of the judiciary, imposed government control over the public-service media and clamped down on civil-society groups. The Commission has referred several of these measures to the European Court of Justice (ECJ), but it has so far struggled to find an effective response. Steps taken by the Commission and the European Parliament since December 2017 to invoke Article 7 of the Treaty on European Union, possibly resulting in the suspension of a member country's voting rights, are unlikely to succeed; they require the unanimous vote of all members, and Hungary and Poland have made clear that they would support one another in such an event.
Turkey's foreign policy with the EU and US will be increasingly confrontational
Turkey's relationships with the EU and the US have shifted under the AKP since the early 2000s. Declining trust in the US and the EU and an ambition to make Turkey a regional power have all incentivised the AKP to pursue a "Turkey first" approach to foreign policy. By putting its interests first, the country has started to establish transactional co-operation with countries with which it was previously a rival or had limited relations, such as Russia and China. On the downside, Turkey's foreign policy will leave the country strategically isolated, and Turkey's relationship with the US will become increasingly transactional. Many factors have contributed to the deterioration in relations between Turkey and its Western partners. The watershed moment was the failed military coup by part of the Turkish military in 2016 and a perceived lack of Western solidarity in its aftermath. The subsequent resistance of the US to extradite a self-exiled Turkish imam, Fethullah Gulen, from the US for his alleged role in the failed coup further fanned the flames of anti-US sentiment in Turkey. Prior to the coup attempt both countries had already clashed on several issues, including the collaboration of the US with Iraqi and Syrian Kurds.
Turkey-US relations have reached fresh lows following Turkey's purchase in 2019 of the Russian-made S-400 air-defence system, which has resulted in the US blocking Turkey's purchase of US-made F-35 fighter jets and Turkey's suspension from the F-35 production programme. We expect that Turkey will activate the missile-defence system in April 2020. This is likely to result in US sanctions on Turkey under the Countering America's Adversaries through Sanctions Act. We believe that sanctions will lean towards the less onerous side to avoid pushing Turkey completely into Russia's orbit and to ensure a degree of collaboration on other issues, including migrant, and refugee, inflows from Syria and Iraq.
Russia-West tensions are at their highest level since the cold war
Political tensions between Russia and the West are at their highest since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. Western countries have accused Russia of financing extremist opposition parties in western Europe, employing cyber-warfare against Western targets and engaging in a propaganda war through media outlets that it controls in the West. Meanwhile, Russia is seeking to reassert its role on the global stage and is dismantling the security and arms control agreements that were put in place at the end of the cold war. Russia's opposition to the post-cold war security architecture was evident in its decision to withdraw from the Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe in 2015, and its subsequent breach of the 1987 Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty, which bans short- and medium-range ballistic missiles.
Russia's illegal annexation of Crimea in 2014 and backing of separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine, resulting in a conflict in this region, has led to a further deterioration in Russia's relations with the West. The Minsk II agreement, signed in 2015, is unlikely to resolve the conflict. The current status quo of a regularly breached ceasefire with contained levels of fighting seems likely to endure for several years. This serves Russia's interests, as a frozen conflict prevents closer Ukrainian integration with the EU and NATO, which Russia would view as a direct threat to its national interests. In response to Russia's actions regarding Ukraine, the EU and the US have imposed sanctions on Russian officials, as well as on the Russian financial, energy and defence sectors. On August 3rd the US State Department announced a fresh round of sanctions on Russia preventing it from issuing new US dollar-denominated debt on international markets. We expect these mutual sanctions to remain in place over the medium term, and it is likely that they will be expanded further.
The EU has labelled China a systemic rival. The BRI divides opinions
The EU has labelled China a "systemic rival" and has adopted a regulation setting up a framework to scrutinise foreign investments from non-EU countries, a move that is widely understood to be directed towards foreign direct investment from China. Although the EU supports improving connectivity between Europe and Asia (as pointed out in the EU Connectivity Strategy), it has not formally come out in support of the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI)-China's flagship foreign policy initiative that aims to create a "New Silk Road" of trading routes, and to expand China's economic and diplomatic ties. However, despite the EU's reluctance to support the BRI, several European countries have signed up to it, including Italy, Portugal, Greece and several countries in the western Balkans.
One of the points of concern for the EU regarding the BRI is the near monopoly that Chinese companies enjoy in implementing these projects. Until transparency regarding the terms of BRI funding improves and the procurement processes are made more inclusive and competitive (allowing for participation from European companies), the EU is unlikely to change its stance on the BRI.
Macroeconomic policy
The Franco-German axis will drive foward some euro zone reform plans
The commitment in 2012 by the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Mario Draghi, to do "whatever it takes" to preserve the euro represented a turning-point for the bloc. In 2017 EU leaders renewed their push for further integration of the economic and monetary union to boost the bloc's resilience to future shocks, and in June 2018 Germany and France presented a shared set of proposals. However, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects progress to remain patchy.
We do not expect the emergence of the type of full fiscal integration that the French president, Emmanuel Macron, has been pushing for, but the strength of the Franco-German axis, with support from a number of southern member states, is likely to be sufficient to lead to a relatively ambitious set of reforms, which will nevertheless take several years to implement fully. These would include reform of the current bail-out fund, the European Stability Mechanism (ESM), which could be turned into something akin to a version of the IMF. Such a move could shift the responsibility for fiscal and economic monitoring of member states away from the European Commission to the revised ESM, and include restructuring of sovereign debt as a strict conditionality in any bail-out. One of the three pillars of the banking union, the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS), which has yet to be implemented, will continue to meet political resistance from several north European member states. The planned EDIS would increase the responsibility of healthy economies for bad debts in others.
France and Germany believe that a new EU industrial strategy is a priority
France and Germany have taken the lead in pushing for a new industrial strategy for the bloc, and also a potential revamp of EU competition policy, in the wake of the Commission's decision to block the planned merger between two train manufacturers, Alstom (France) and Siemens (Germany). Both coun-tries' ministers of the economy are pushing for a revision to EU competition law to enable such mega-mergers in the future, in order to build European champions capable of competing with the largest of their US and Chinese rivals. Their manifesto also argues for greater funding for innovation, and a European strategy to become a world leader in artificial intelligence, among other areas. They are also emphasising the need to develop more robust rules for screening inward foreign direct investment (FDI), especially from China. We expect continued French-German co-operation on these issues, with the aim of developing a more protectionist stance for the bloc.
Talks over the EU's next seven-year budgetary framework will be tough
Tensions arising from negotiations over the EU's seven-year budget framework for 2021-27 will start to emerge in the second half of 2019. The most contentious issue is the European Commission's proposal to increase member states' financial contributions to meet the shortfall created by the withdrawal of the UK, a major net contributor. Although some southern member states and Germany are willing to contribute more, fiscally hawkish countries such as Austria and the Netherlands oppose this. Another point of controversy is the Commission's proposed introduction of conditionality in the next budget cycle, linking the transfer of funds to rule-of-law compliance. This emerged in response to the illiberal drift in countries like Poland and Hungary. The idea has created an east-west split, but we expect that a version of the proposal will be approved.
The 2021-27 budget will also include a new, small euro zone budget, after a compromise was reached between France and Germany. Far from providing a fiscal stabilisation function-as favoured by Mr Macron-the euro zone budget will instead be channelled to countries looking to improve competitiveness and convergence. The topic has proved contentious among the so-called New Hanseatic League, a group of fiscally hawkish Nordic and Baltic countries led by the Netherlands.
Macroeconomic policy: Fiscal policy
