Consensus on fiscal restraint is eroding, but we do not expect a substantial shift
A conservative fiscal bias has prevailed across most of the region since the global crisis in 2008-09, leaving policymakers to rely on low interest rates and unconventional monetary policy tools as the main levers with which to manage their economies. Monetary policy looks set to remain as the main macroeconomic policy tool, not least after the ECB presented a substantial easing package on September 12th. This includes a cut to the deposit rate (to -0.5%, from -0.4% previously), enhanced forward guidance, another round of quantitative easing (QE2) and the introduction of a deposit tiered system.
Almost all European countries improved their fiscal position in 2009-18, and there has now been a widespread repositioning towards a looser stance. Although fiscal policy in the euro zone has become slightly accommodative in 2019 and will remain so next year, significant fiscal loosening remains off the agenda for most countries, especially for those with high public debt loads, owing to the rigidity of the rules agreed by EU members at the height of the euro zone crisis.
Nevertheless, there may be a greater appetite for some fiscal initiative in the coming period. Several factors make this more likely. First, Germany's economic slowdown is undermining the political opposition to balanced budgets-reforming the debt-brake rule embedded in the constitution is no longer a taboo. Second, a new Commission will take office on November 1st, and a discussion has started over revising the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) framework. Third, the ECB's most recent meeting gave a strong signal to governments that policy would remain ultra-loose until at least 2021, which will increase their fiscal space.
Some national governments are pushing back against EU fiscal rules
A major shift on this front remains unlikely in our view however. The average euro zone government debt/GDP ratio was 87.2% at end-2018, but Belgium, Greece, Italy, Cyprus and Portugal all had ratios in excess of 100%, and those for France and Spain were only slightly below 100%. Hefty debt loads will remain a challenge for much of the zone for many years. In addition, member states have strong disagreements over fiscal policy. Some have already pushed back against centralised fiscal constraints, which are significantly more rigorous as a result of changes introduced in response to the crisis.
The previous Italian government comprising the Eurosceptic far-right Lega had mounted a serious challenge to euro area fiscal rules, proposing an expansionary 2019 budget that the Commission regarded as violating the debt-reduction criterion of the SGP. The administration eventually reached a compromise with the EU institutions on a deficit target of 2% of GDP in 2019. We believe that the new pro-EU Movimento 5 Stelle (M5S)-Partito Democratico (PD) administration has greater chances of obtaining some concessions from the EU on the fiscal front than the previous coalition, and that it will reach an agreement with the Commission on a 2.2% of GDP fiscal deficit target for 2020.
This will be achievable through lower interest payments on government debt (owing to a reduced risk premium and more accommodative policy by the ECB), some cuts in spending and an overhaul of the tax system. The removal of the flagship flat-tax extension of Matteo Salvini (the leader of the Lega)-with estimated revenue losses of about EUR15bn (0.9% of GDP)-will help to avoid a 3-percentage-point increase in the value-added tax (VAT) rate (worth 1.3% of GDP). The deficit is then expected to average about 2.1% in 2021-23. Public debt, at 132.2% of GDP at end-2018, will remain near this level for the next five years.
The UK government has shifted towards a looser fiscal stance
The UK's fiscal position improved in 2016-18, but the government has relaxed policy modestly in 2019 and is likely to continue to do so. Lower than anticipated public borrowing in 2018 has increased the "fiscal headroom" that the previous chancellor, Philip Hammond, banked, to £26.6bn (US$34.8bn), from £15.4bn. The current chancellor, Sajid Javid has promised over £13.8bn in additional expenditure, although this is probably continengent on the Conser-vatives being returned to power with a majority in the next election. The Labour Party is also expected to pursue a much looser fiscal policy.
The fiscal easing already planned for 2019, combined with a slowdown in economic growth, should cause a slight widening of the deficit this year, to 1.8% of GDP, from 1.5% in 2018. We expect a further expansion in 2020, to 2.3% of GDP, following from large one-off investments delivered by the Conservatives or Labour after the election, but we expect a gradual contraction to 1.5% by the end of the forecast period. We expect public debt to decline from about 87% of GDP in 2018 to less than 82% by 2023.
Fiscal performance has improved markedly across central Europe
As a result of robust economic growth and tighter controls on spending, fiscal performance has improved markedly across the central European countries in recent years, with the Czech Republic posting a budget surplus in 2018, and Poland and Slovakia both having deficits narrower than 1% of GDP. In Hungary, in contrast, fiscal loosening ahead of the April 2018 parliamentary election led to a widening of the budget deficit, to 2.2% of GDP in 2017 and in 2018. We expect narrow deficits of less than 1% in Slovakia in the 2019-23 forecast period and narrow deficits in the Czech Republic after 2020. However, the fiscal deficits in Poland and Hungary will widen over the forecast period, to 2% of GDP. We forecast that public debt, which is equivalent to 50% or less of GDP in the Czech Republic, Poland and Slovakia-but is 71% of GDP in Hungary at end-2018-will continue to decline in all these countries. Given Hungary's high public debt, the country's fiscal position and currency will remain vulnerable to volatility on world markets.
Higher oil prices are easing fiscal constraints in Russia
The tight budget constraints facing Russia's government are abating owing to higher global oil prices. We expect international oil prices to average US$69/barrel in 2019-23, up from an average of about US$50/b in 2015-17. However, the Ministry of Finance intends to relax fiscal policy only slightly in 2019-21, and the government will maintain a fiscal surplus. Spending related to the "National Projects"-the government's plans for infrastructure modern-isation-will push up expenditure. Military spending will remain high as well, but some spending will be redirected towards health and education, as recently promised by the president, Vladimir Putin. Meanwhile higher global oil prices-and the government's conservative oil price forecasts (retaining a US$40/b oil price assumption)-almost guarantee that revenue will outperform expec-tations. We expect the budget, which returned to surplus in 2018, will not dip to less than 1% of GDP throughout 2019-23.
Turkey's fiscal position looks relatively solid
The public finances have traditionally been one of Turkey's most reassuring economic features. Low budget deficit/GDP and public debt/GDP ratios reflect the positive impact of cautious fiscal policy in the past. Higher government spending on defence, security, infrastructure, public employment and social benefits widened the deficit to about 2% of GDP in 2018, from 1.5% in 2017.
In 2019-after substantial fiscal stimulus-we expect the budget deficit to widen to 2.8% of GDP. In 2020-21 we expect a cautious approach to on-balance-sheet fiscal policy (concerns about off-balance-sheet trends will persist). This, alongside a recovering economy, will cause the deficit to narrow gradually, to 1.4% of GDP in 2021. We expect a widening of the deficit in 2022-23, with the shortfall reaching about 2.2% of GDP in 2023, owing to the presidential and parliam-entary elections that year. The central government debt/GDP ratio deteriorated slightly in 2018, rising to 28.7% of GDP in 2018 (from 28.3% in 2017). The ratio will decline slightly, to about 27% by end-2023, as macroeconomic conditions normalise.
Macroeconomic policy: Monetary policy and exchange rates
Interest rates (av; %) 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Euribor -0.3 -0.3 -0.4 -0.2 0.1 0.2
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate 2.0 2.4 1.7 1.7 2.2 2.5
US 10-year government bond yield 2.9 2.3 1.8 2.0 2.6 3.4
10-year German government bond yield 0.4 -0.2 0.0 0.8 1.2 1.5
The ECB adopted a loose monetary policy in response to the European sovereign debt crisis that began in 2011. Interest rate cuts were followed by the introduction of an asset-purchase programme, QE, in 2015. The programme ran until December 2018. Growth in the euro zone had accelerated significantly in 2017 and headline inflation was picking up. However, economic momentum softened substantially in 2018 and the underlying growth trend remained weak during the first half of 2019. Inflationary pressures have remained subdued, and the risk of deflation increased (market long-term inflation expectations have fallen significantly below the 2% target). This, together with a more subdued economic outlook for the bloc, has prompted the ECB to ease policy further.
The ECB will maintain a dovish stance
On September 12th the bank announced a substantial stimulus package, involving a small cut to the deposit rate; enhanced forward guidance; the restart of QE2; the introduction of a deposit tiered system, whereby some of commercial banks' excess reserves at the ECB are exempted from paying the -0.5% deposit rate; and more favourable terms for the third-round of cheap loans granted by the ECB, known as targeted longer-term refinancing operations (TLTROs-III). Crucially, the ECB decided not to put a specific time limit for QE2, and opted for an open-ended programme instead. This, together with its decision to link forward guidance to its mandate of "close to, but below, 2%" inflation-effectively showing that rates will remain low until inflation converges towards the ECB's target-have sent a strong signal to markets and governments that policy will remain ultra-loose until at least 2021.
The ECB's decision is part of a more general process of easing monetary policy that is occurring at the global level as central banks elsewhere also struggle with persistent geopolitical uncertainty and subdued inflation.
The BoE has paused its tightening cycle
The Bank of England (BoE, the UK central bank) raised its policy rate for the first time in a decade in November 2017 and again in August 2018. However, this year it has adopted a more dovish stance. The BoE revised down its forecasts for economic growth and inflation in August 2019, citing a weaker global environment and Brexit-related uncertainty, and voted to leave policy interest rates unchanged, at 0.75%. The bank still expects domestically driven price pressure to build gradually in the forecast period, but the timing of future rate rises will depend on the nature and outcome of Brexit. We expect the BoE to delay the next increase in the policy rate until the fourth quarter of 2020.
In the event of a disorderly UK withdrawal from the EU at end-October (not our baseline forecast), we expect the bank to make whatever policy changes are required to support economic activity. The BoE has emphasised that it is prepared for such an outcome; a worst-case scenario used in the bank's stress tests for the banking system involves a decline in the pound's value, higher unemployment and inflation, an increase in borrowing costs and a decrease in property prices. However, the UK's banking system has sufficient capital, and monetary policy would be loosened, unless the decline in sterling were especially sharp relative to the overall macro-economic shock.
Turkey still faces the risk of another sharp depreciation of the lira
Turkey's currency crisis in 2018 and the ensuing recession have put severe pressure on the government's finances, business sector solvency and banks' balance sheets. After the lira's sharp depreciation against the US dollar in August 2018, the Central Bank of Turkey raised its main policy rate to 24%, from 17.75% previously. Since then annual consumer price inflation has started to ease, and the MPC reduced its main policy rate to 19.75% in July. We expect rates to be cut again at the September MPC meeting as consumer price inflation eased in August, to 15% year on year, from 16.7% in July. By the October MPC meeting the central bank will have inflation data for September, which are likely to be slightly less than 10% year on year because of base effects. At this meeting we expect another decline in the main policy rate, which will bring it down by about 300 basis points in total with these two cuts.
We expect a gradual appreciation in the lira in the second half of 2019. This forecast assumes that the Turkey-US dispute will not result in damaging sectoral sanctions; that government policy will be credibly reoriented; and that the central bank will maintain a tight monetary policy stance, lowering interest rates only as price pressures fade. However, there are large risks to this forecast, with another sharp lira depreciation still a possibility. In 2020-23 we expect the lira rate to depreciate gradually against the US dollar as the current-account deficit widens and central banks in advanced economies re-embark on a path of monetary policy tightening.
We expect one or two rate cuts in Russia in 2019
In Russia in December 2018 the Central Bank of Russia (CBR, the central bank) increased its policy rate by 25 basis points, to 7.75%, in anticipation of the inflationary pressures expected in 2019, driven by an increase of the VAT rate and the resumption of foreign-currency purchases from January 2019. This pre-emptive rate increase in December 2018 was sufficient to offset this one-off price rise, and the CBR cut its policy rate by 25 basis points three times since then, to 7%. The CBR projects an annual inflation rate of 4-4.5% for 2019, which is broadly in line with our inflation forecasts. We expect the CBR to keep its policy rate unchanged for the remainder of 2019. However, any downward shock to global oil prices or new stringent sanctions on Russia would prompt the CBR to tighten policy quickly to soften the resulting depreciation of the Russian currency against the US dollar.
Many currencies in eastern Europe remain pegged to the euro
For central and east European countries with currencies pegged to, or managed, against the euro (mostly in the western Balkans), risks of volatility have moved in line with expectations of the Federal Reserve's and the ECB's policy trajectory. However, we do not believe that there are significant risks to the currency boards in Bosnia and Hercegovina (BiH) or Bulgaria, or to the peg in North Macedonia. Croatia had been more of a cause for concern, in the light of the 2015 legislation to force banks to convert Swiss franc-denominated loans into the euro. However, the country's improved external and fiscal positions, and increased demand for the kuna as a result of a strong tourism performance, have driven appreciation, which we forecast will continue in 2019.
We expect broadly accommodative monetary policy stances in Central Asia
Currencies across the former Soviet Union depreciated sharply in 2015 as a result of the weakening of the rouble and lower oil prices, which hit commodity exporters. Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan officially abandoned their US dollar pegs in 2015. In practice, only Kazakhstan has allowed its currency to float. Given Kazakhstan's trade ties to the Russian economy, it would lose competitiveness if the tenge appreciated significantly against the rouble. Azerbaijan appears to have returned to a US dollar peg since April 2017. The monetary policy stances of oil-exporting countries, such as Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, are closely linked to oil price fluctuations, as the exchange-rate movements of these countries are closely linked to global oil prices (which determine export earnings). With global oil prices expected to remain firm in our forecast period, these countries will maintain an accommodative monetary policy, which will also support domestic economic growth.

Economic growth in the euro zone will lose momentum, but remain firm
The recovery of the euro zone economy from the global financial crisis of 2008-10 began in 2013, after the president of the European Central Bank (ECB), Mario Draghi, committed to doing "whatever it takes" to restore confidence in the euro. The recovery strengthened once this commitment was backed by a large-scale quantitative easing (QE) programme. By 2017 the euro zone's expan-sion had gathered sustained and broad-based momentum, and this, in turn, benefited neighbouring economies that receive EU funding and rely on EU trade. However, growth in the euro zone eased in 2018, and will moderate further in 2019. In the second half of last year the German economy stagnated and momentum softened in France, and Italy entered a technical recession.
Some of the reasons for the slowdown were temporary: adverse weather conditions, rail strikes and protests weighed on growth in France in 2018, and Germany's manufacturing sector was hit by changes to European car-emissions regulations and disruptions to freight transport. However, there has also been a marked deterioration in the external environment from 2018 and into 2019, with softer global trade and high geopolitical uncertainty, reflecting rising US-China trade tensions, the threat of a US tariff increase on EU automotive exports and the risk of a "no-deal" Brexit. Concerns about these issues, and a softening of demand across Asia, the euro zone, the UK and (to a lesser extent) the US, have fed into a decline in manufacturing data and sentiment indicators.
Against this less supportive external environment, domestic demand has remained firm, driving quarterly growth in the euro zone to 0.4% in the first quarter of 2019-stronger than in the three previous quarters. High-frequency indicators such as consumer confidence, employment data and retail sales are robust, supporting private consumption, and a buoyant housing market, high capacity-utilisation levels and favourable funding conditions are fuelling investment. Across most of the bloc recovering labour markets, accommodative monetary policy and gradual fiscal loosening are supporting growth.
Nonetheless, the risks to The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast remain skewed to the downside. The most immediate risk is the US administration's threat to raise tariffs on imported European autos and auto parts (from 2.5% at present). Our core view is that the US will refrain from raising these tariffs. There is significant opposition to doing so in the US market, and with the next presidential election in November 2020, opening yet another front in the trade war would be a risky move. However, should the current dispute over subsidies at Airbus and Boeing, two aerospace companies, result in mutual tariff imposition, this would change the calcu-lation. The German economy is particularly exposed to this threat, given its dominant role in the European automotive industry and highly open economy.
We expect a mild technical recession in Germany this year
Real GDP growth peaked in Germany in 2017, at 2.8%, alongside a pick-up in global trade volumes. Growth slowed in 2018 as the external environment became less supportive, and we expect a technical recession this year, with two consecutive quarters of mild contraction, and annual growth averaging 0.5%.
The main driver of the German slowdown has been external, and we see three main aspects to this. First, there has been a noticeable slowdown in German exports to China, in line with slowing Chinese economic growth and the intensifying US-China trade war. Together, these have fed into slower global trade growth and weighed on euro zone business sentiment. Second, German exports to the UK have been hit by Brexit uncertainty. Third, the automotive sector is facing a number of challenges. Global car sales declined for the first time in a decade in 2018, reflecting slowing demand from China and structural shifts in the industry towards electric cars, car-sharing and strict emissions tests. All of these changes are disrupting the heavily diesel-focused German automotive sector.
That said, the country's domestic economic fundamentals remain strong, and the main driver of growth over the medium term will be private consumption, with investment also contributing robustly. The government has agreed on a more expansionary fiscal policy until 2021, and we expect further spending increases given the loss of momentum in economic growth this year. There is still strong commitment to keeping the budget in balance, but discussion about whether this remains appropriate has intensified significantly.
Growth will remain comparatively strong in France, in a European context
France's recovery from its slump in 2012 was slow by European standards, with growth recovering to its 2008 rate only in 2017, supported by a cyclical upswing in the euro zone. After real GDP growth of 2.4% in 2017, growth eased to 1.7% in 2018. We forecast a sharper slowdown, to 1.2% in 2019-although this figure is relatively robust in compared with Germany and Italy, and well above what we are expecting for Germany or Italy. In 2020-23 we expect annual average growth of 1.6% as recent reforms to the business environment start to bear fruit and (from 2021) external demand picks up. However, structural rigidities-especially regarding the tax system and the labour market-will not disappear entirely, and the country will continue to struggle to improve its competitiveness over the medium term, with often negative investor perceptions of the country likely to prove slow to change.
Italy's economy entered a recession in the second half of 2018
The Italian economy has softened since about mid-2018, contracting on a sequential basis in the second half of last year. Momentum has remained weak in 2019, dampened by domestic political and economic uncertainty, as well as global trade tensions. We expect that the economy will expand by a marginal 0.1% in full-year 2019, on the back of slower growth in private consumption and fixed investment, and less favourable external conditions. In 2020 the euro area's third-largest economy will fare little better, expanding by a modest 0.4% in real terms, as cooling external demand in the euro area and the weight of global trade tensions, as well as a slowdown in the US, continue to hold back an economic recovery. From 2021 to 2023 growth should return to closer to 1% per year on average, a respectable performance by Italian standards, but still weak in the context of euro area economies, as structural rigidities, a high level of sovereign debt, clogged credit channels and policy uncertainty continue to exert a drag on growth.
Structural reforms have improved the context for growth in Spain
In Spain, a combination of reform and austerity has given rise to a marked economic improvement since 2014. The financial sector is now in a better position, owing to reforms undertaken as part of Spain's EUR41.3bn bank bail-out process, and we believe that further episodes of instability-particularly at instit-utions of systemic importance-are unlikely. Meanwhile a landmark labour market reform implemented in 2012 lowered dismissal costs, clarified and narrowed the definition of unfair dismissal, reduced the collective bargaining power of trade unions, and made it easier for companies to cut wages and working hours. Further structural reform would improve the economy's medium-term prospects, but will probably proceed at a more gradual pace in 2019-23 compared with the reform-intense period under the absolute majority of the People's Party (PP) in 2011-15. Real GDP growth decelerated from 3% in 2017 to 2.6% in 2018 as private consumption growth slowed slightly and external demand softened more significantly. In 2019 growth will slow further, to 2.2%, before cooling to about 1.9% on average in 2020-23 as euro area growth remains lacklustre and the global economy cools, owing to the lasting effects of the US China trade war and weaker growth in the US economy in 2020.
The recovery in Greece remains fragile, with political instability a central risk
Greece exited its third bail-out programme in August 2018, but we are sceptical that the country will experience rapid and sustained growth. Greece's economy has been in almost permanent recession since 2008. Compared with 2007 levels, real GDP has shrunk by more than one-quarter, government consumption by almost one-quarter, household consumption by one-fifth and gross fixed investment by almost two-thirds. The recovery, which began at the start of 2017, is fragile, and vulnerable to domestic and external developments. Real GDP accelerated in 2018, but the economy lost momentum in the final quarter of the year. We expect real GDP growth to remain constrained, at about 2% in 2019-23. The risks to our forecast are balanced: upside risks include continued strong tourism performance if capacity constraints are addressed and competitiveness gains are not eroded; downside risks include the frailty of the banking sector and political and financial market instability.
The UK economy is suffering from the uncertainty stemming from Brexit
The UK economy was relatively resilient in the aftermath of the Brexit vote in 2016, but has lost momentum since 2018. In 2018 full-year growth was 1.4%, and the economy has continued to slow through 2019, contracting by -0.2% quarter on quarter in April-June. In line with our forecast that the current political impasse will lead to a delayed Brexit and a snap election, economic uncertainty will continue to weigh heavily on activity in 2019 and 2020, when we expect real GDP growth to slow to 1.1% for both years, with significant downside risks stemming from the possibility of a disorganised withdrawal from the EU.

The Visegrad countries will continue to post above-average growth rates
Much of central Europe faces a challenging environment in the longer term. However, countries that benefit from EU funding, such as the Visegrad countries (the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia) in particular, will register real GDP growth well above the EU average in 2019-23. Funding inflows for projects under the 2014-20 funding period were slow to begin in 2016, holding back activity in that year, but funds began to flow again in 2017-18, contributing to stronger economic activity, and projects are in progress that will support economic growth rates during 2019-23. Increased employment and soaring wages in the Visegrads-driven in part by a tight labour market-have fuelled private consum-ption since 2017, and this will continue in the forecast period. The slowdown in global trade growth, and in particular growth in Germany-a major market for these countries-along with the upcoming structural challenges facing the automotive sector, will weigh on growth in central Europe in 2019-20. However, still robust German investment spending and private consumption in Germany will help to sustain export demand.
Economic activity accelerated in south-eastern Europe, but is now moderating
In south-eastern Europe the economic recoveries are continuing, although growth has generally lost momentum. In the region's largest economy, Romania, the economy grew by 4.1% in 2018 after growth of 7% in in 2017, driven by private consumption, exports and a significant increase in inventories. We expect growth to decelerate to about 3.7% in 2019-20 owing to a weaker global environment and the consumption-led growth model reaching its limit. In Bulgaria, a recovery in domestic credit growth, a strengthening labour market and firmer real wage growth have underpinned the acceleration of economic growth in recent years. We forecast that real GDP growth in this country will average 3.2% in 2019, compared with 3.3% in 2018, before slowing to an average of 2.8% per year in 2020-23, reflecting less favourable global conditions and labour capacity constraints.
Structural imbalances in the western Balkans have been largely corrected
Economic activity in the western Balkans (Albania, Bosnia and Hercegovina, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia) broadly picked up in 2015-18, reflecting a combination of favourable base effects and externally driven cyclical factors, such as low oil prices in 2015-16 and a strong pick-up in demand from the euro zone in 2017. In 2018 the Serbian economy accelerated, bringing up the regional average after a decade of uneven growth. The region has undergone a significant economic adjustment in the years since the 2008-09 global financial crisis, largely correcting fiscal and current-account imbalances (with some exceptions, such as Montenegro). Inflation has fallen to historical lows for the region, allowing a more accommodative monetary policy that has supported growth. The revival of investment is set to continue, and over the medium and long term the western Balkans should benefit from the structural reforms that are now in rpgress in most countries. On the downside, high public and/or private debt loads, and (in some cases) continued large fiscal deficits remain impediments to faster growth. Political cronyism, corruption, vested interests and a poor demographic profile are also a drag on growth across the region. We forecast average real GDP growth in the western Balkans of about 3.3% in 2019-23.
Exchange-rate volatility has pushed Turkey into a recession
In Turkey government stimulus measures, government credit guarantees, political pressure on banks to extend credit, improved export competitiveness and a pick-up in global demand caused real GDP growth to accelerate to 7.3% in 2017 (from 3.3% in 2016), but this surge exacerbated internal and external discrepancies. These imbalances-coupled with heightened policy unpredict-ability, foreign investors' concerns regarding the independence of the central bank, reliance on short--term capital inflows, tighter global liquidity and a diplomatic spat with the US-contributed to the lira depreciating by about 24% on average against the US dollar in 2018.
The sharp depreciation of the lira caused consumer price inflation to accelerate from already high rates, increased input costs for corporations and raised the debt-servicing costs of large foreign-currency-denominated liabilities. Higher domestic interest rates and rising risk premiums further dented the economic outlook. The crisis pushed the Turkish economy into recession in the second half of 2018. We expect the lira to remain volatile in 2019-23.
Growth in Russia will slacken this year
According to Russia's Federal State Statistics Service (Rosstat), Russian real GDP grew by a surprisingly strong 2.2% in 2018-the fastest growth rate since 2012. The strong growth rate was largely driven by the inclusion in output data of investment in construction work at the third phase of the Yamal gasfield, as well as high levels of exports. This is unlikely to be sustained in 2019 owing to weaker growth in external demand, a new deal with OPEC to constrain oil production, and a lower projected grain harvest. Domestic demand is also likely to slacken this year owing to higher interest rates and an increase in value-added tax (VAT). International sanctions-and broader political and business uncertainty-will remain significant constraints on investment, as will the lack of a "culture of failure" (the absence of entrepreneurial spirit weighs heavily on innovation and investment). We forecast that economic growth will ease to 1.3% in 2019. In the medium term outdated capital stock, a declining workforce, dependence on natural-resource sectors, institutional weaknesses, low prod-uctivity growth, a difficult business environment and statist policies will limit real GDP growth, to an annual average of 1.6% in 2019-23.
The possible end of Russian gas transit represents a large risk for Ukraine
Real GDP decreased by a cumulative 16.4% in Ukraine in 2014-15 amid conflict and a chaotic political situation. The disruption of these years accentuated a structural change in the Ukrainian economy away from heavy industry and towards agriculture. The economy has been recovering since 2016, driven by vigorous growth in private investment and private consumption. Real GDP growth stood at 3.3% in full-year 2018. Household spending continued to increase (supported by solid wage growth and high inflows of remittances) and investment remained robust.
In 2019-23 we expect average annual average real GDP growth of about 2.7% per year, with household consumption making the largest contribution to GDP growth in each year. However, soft global steel prices, rising production costs and a worsening external environment will weigh on growth, especially in 2019-20. The probable end of Russian gas transit in 2020-when the current transit contract expires and the Nord Stream 2 pipeline connecting Russia to the EU is supposed to begin operations-represents a significant risk.
Growth rates in the CIS will be similar in 2019 to those recorded in 2018
Growth and exchange-rate movements in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) are highly correlated to movements in global oil prices, especially in large oil exporters such as Russia, Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan. Owing to important trade links and high levels of remittance flows, the performance of the Russian economy has an impact on that of smaller countries in Central Asia (the Kyrgyz Republic and Tajikistan) and the South Caucasus (Armenia and Georgia, not CIS members). We forecast growth of 1.3% in Russia, 2.3% in Azerbaijan, 3.9% in Kazakhstan and 3% in Ukraine in 2019. Given our forecast for an oil price corridor of about US$60-75/barrel in 2019-23, the growth outlook for most countries is unlikely to diverge significantly from their 2018 final outturn.

Price pressures have eased again in the euro zone, after rebounding in 2017 and 2018-inflation accelerated to 1.5% in 2017 and 1.7% in 2018. In 2019 we expect inflation to slow to 1.4%, even as domestic price pressures-stemming from tighter labour markets and firmer wage growth-sustains relatively decent price growth. Inflation will remain low in 2020, at just 1.5%, reflecting still subdued momentum and low global oil prices. From 2021-23 we expect prices to pick up.

Business environment rankings cover 82 countries
The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings model seeks to measure the attractiveness of a country's business environment and its major components. The model's assessment of the business environment-based on the opportunities for and hindrances to the conduct of business-enables us to rank each of the 82 countries covered on its overall position and in each of 11 categories on a global and a regional basis. The model uses quantitative data and expert assessments to measure the attractiveness of countries' business environments. The framework has been designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies in formulating their global business strategies and investment location decisions. The overall scores (on a 1-10 scale) and rankings are based on scores for 91 indicators, grouped into 11 categories.
There is a moderate improvement in Europe's aggregate regional scores between the historical period (2014-18) and the forecast period (2019-23), reflecting the transition from the post-crisis period to one in which recovery and repair are, in most countries, well under way. Western Europe is ranked second globally out of six regions, after North America, and eastern Europe is ranked fourth, after North America, western Europe, and Asia and Australasia, but a better performance than Latin America, or the Middle East and Africa.
EU countries and Nordics score particularly well in our rankings
EU countries remain well represented in the top 20 of our global rankings. Two non-EU countries, Switzerland and Norway, also occupy leading positions. The large number of west European countries in the top 20 reflects the high degree of political stability in the region (a post-crisis rise in social and political tension notwithstanding), large and competitive domestic markets and a strong degree of openness to world trade. Although we continue to highlight the risks of political fragmentation and rising anti-establishment sentiment, we do not forecast a marked anti-market backlash in policy choices.
Business environment in eastern Europe has improved since 1990s
The investment climate of central and eastern Europe has improved consid-erably in recent years. The early reformers among the countries of central Europe led the way in the early 1990s in adopting far-reaching stabilisation, liberalisation and privatisation programmes. Reform in the Balkans has been much more uneven and subject to periodic reversals, but significant progress has been made even there. Factors such as a low-cost, but well-qualified, labour force, proximity to developed markets, and, in some cases, ample natural-resource endowments have attracted considerable foreign direct investment to the region over the past decade. However, many east European countries still face fundamental reform challenges; meeting those challenges will test already fraying relations between governments and electorates, and heighten the risk of political instability and social unrest.
The outlook for the business environment in the countries of the former Soviet Union is mixed. Throughout the region, the barriers to enacting wide-ranging reform remain formidable. In Russia, the business environment has suffered as a result of Western sanctions and a rise in tariff and non-tariff barriers. There is little evidence that the Russian government intends to undertake disruptive structural reform to improve the dynamism of the economy. However, low energy prices have prompted some regional commodity exporters, notably Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, to seek to open up and diversify their economies.
Data sources and definitions
Methodology
The forecast tables have been constructed from the individual data series available in the respective Economist Intelligence Unit Country Forecasts. In addition, The Economist Intelligence Unit runs the National Institute's Global Econometric Model (NIGEM), which is developed and maintained by the London Business School at the National Institute of Economic and Social Research.
Sources
GDP/GNP: IMF, IFS (line 99 b/c) for local currency data, converted into dollars by the relevant year average exchange rate, also available in IFS
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS (line rf)
Population: national statistical offices and IMF, IFS (line 99z)
GDP growth and inflation: relevant central banks or national statistical offices, also available in OECD, National Accounts
Abbreviations
CEECs: Central and east European countries (excludes Russia and other members of the Commonwealth of Independent States)
ECB: European Central Bank
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Canada--highlights: Political outlook
The Liberal Party, led by the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, has shifted Canadian politics to the left since it won the election in October 2015. Its then surprise parliamentary majority has made the passage of legislation straight-forward, allowing the government to implement much of its policy agenda. The October 2019 federal election will nevertheless be a close contest. Mr Trudeau and his party enter the campaign with plenty of baggage, including some broken promises, and face a rejuvenated Conservative Party. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberal Party to remain in power, but there is a risk that it will lose its current parliamentary majority. This raises the prospect of periodic legislative gridlock in 2020-23, and diminished government effectiveness. Canada benefits from solid institutional stability and capability. The bureaucracy is efficient, but some functions are duplicated between the federal and provincial levels.
Canada--highlights: Business environment outlook

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
Canada rises to ninth place (out of 82) in our global business environment ranking in 2019-23, and into first place in the regional rank of G7 countries. The increase in Canada's overall score reflects improvements in areas such as infrastructure, technological readiness, and policy towards private enterprise and competition. These gains will more than offset modest declines in market opportunities and the labour market. As a centrist party, the Liberals are supportive of business and are unlikely to pass laws that would significantly hinder the business environment. Continued trade protectionism in the US will create uncertainty for business in Canada, which relies heavily on the US economy, but recent trade deals will help Canadian exporters to build markets elsewhere. The country's openness to trade will remain the most attractive feature of the business environment.

We expect that real GDP growth will slow to 1.6% in 2019, dampened by slower private consumption growth and an economic slowdown in the US. Sluggish demand will keep growth below its long-term trend at 1.7% in 2020. Real GDP growth is expected to pick up again in 2021, and will average 2.4% per year in 2022-23. It will be supported by public investment in infrastructure and stronger export growth, driven by recovering demand in the US. High household indebtedness will remain a major vulnerability.

Canada's population totals 37.1m and is expected to increase at a rate of just under 1% per year, to 38.7m, by 2023. Growth in the working-age population is slowing, and the number of pensioners is starting to rise sharply as the post-war baby boomers (those born between 1946 and 1965) move into retirement. This will increase pressure on the country's health and pension systems in the forecast period (2019-23). Immigration will continue to drive population growth, as the fertility rate is well below the replacement level. However, immigration will not fully offset the shift in the demographic age structure.

Canada is an attractive market because of its high income levels, but it is small compared with other, more populous countries such as the US. Households' high levels of debt will limit their spending power, as will rising interest rates towards the end of the forecast period. A generally stable operating environment will continue to make Canada an attractive destination for investment, skilled workers, cutting-edge research, science and innovation.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
The Canadian economy is forecast to expand by an average of 2% per year in real terms in 2019-50. This is slightly slower than the 2.1% annual average growth achieved in 2000-18. Canadian exporters will seek new opportunities in Asia and Latin America, and trade agreements with the EU and Pacific countries will have tangible effects in the coming years. Successive governments will seek to address the slow pace of productivity growth. Enhancements to infrastructure and a focus on innovation, science and technology will lead to modest improvement in this area.

Background: The Canadian economy was the tenth-largest in the world in 2018 (measured in US dollars at market exchange rates). It is highly integrated with the US economy, which absorbs 75% of its goods exports and is the source of 51% of its imported goods. The US exerts a powerful economic and cultural influence on Canada. Fifty-eight per cent of Canadians say that English is their mother tongue; just over 21% say French and just under 21% have another language as their first. The majority of French speakers live in Quebec, Canada's second most populous province. Canada's unity is sometimes called into question, but support for independence is currently muted in Quebec. Neither of the two leading political parties in the province is seeking an independence referendum.
Political structure: Canada is formally a constitutional monarchy, with the governor-general (always of Canadian nationality and appointed in Ottawa) acting as the representative of the British crown. In practice, the Canadian House of Commons (the lower house of parliament and main legislative body) is sovereign. Canada is a federation of ten provinces (Alberta, British Columbia, Manitoba, New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia, Ontario, Prince Edward Island, Quebec and Saskatchewan), each with substantial powers, and three territories (Nunavut, Northwest Territories and Yukon). At the federal level are the Commons, the main seat of legislative power, and the non-elected Senate (the upper house), which plays only a marginal role. The Liberal Party has led a majority government since 2015; the next general election will be held on October 21st 2019.
Policy issues: The current federal government is attempting to balance the assistance that it is providing to the fossil fuel industry through approving new oil pipelines with maintaining its green credentials. The government will increase its spending on infrastructure significantly, including through its Canada Infrastructure Bank.
Taxation: The federal corporate income tax rate is 15%. Provincial governments charge corporate tax at rates between 2% and 16%. In 2016 the government introduced a new top marginal rate of personal income tax of 33%, which applies to taxable income higher than C$210,371 (US$159,200) in 2019.
Foreign trade: The US absorbs about three-quarters of Canadian exports, so the health of its economy is crucial for Canada. Canada's trade deficit was US$17bn in 2018, and the current-account deficit was US$45.3bn (2.6% of GDP).

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: The 42nd parliament was dissolved on September 11th 2019 ahead of the federal election, which will take place on October 21st. Four years after the prime minister, Justin Trudeau, led the governing Liberal Party to a surprise majority in the 2015 federal election, ending a decade of government by the Conservative Party, Mr Trudeau is seeking a second term. The Liberal Party had 177 of the 338 seats in the House of Commons (the lower house of parliament and main legislative body), at the time of dissolution, while the Conservatives had 95. The New Democratic Party had 39 seats. The Senate (the upper house) is in the midst of a broad transformation that will make all 105 senators non-partisan. There are currently 29 Conservative senators, 58 independents, nine Liberals, seven non-affiliated senators and two vacancies.
Political outlook: Political stability
The 42nd parliament has been dissolved ahead of the federal election, which will take place on October 21st. The Liberal Party government, led by Mr Trudeau, won a majority at the previous federal election, in 2015, ending a decade of Conservative Party rule. The government has made progress on much of its agenda, but controversy over political interference in a criminal corruption case has tarnished Mr Trudeau's political brand. The Liberals have regained most of the ground lost in opinion polls at the peak of the affair earlier this year, and are virtually tied with the Conservatives. The election results will be tight, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Liberals to remain in government after the election. However, the party's parliamentary majority is at risk. This raises the prospect of periodic legislative gridlock, and a modest deterioration in political stability in 2020-23.
Mr Trudeau contends that his government has reduced poverty and unemployment and has fulfilled promises by cutting income taxes for the middle class and legalising cannabis. However, other pledges have been broken, such as reforming Canada's first-past-the-post voting system. Mr Trudeau is also burdened by the recent findings of the parliamentary ethics commissioner that he attempted to obstruct the course of justice in the criminal prosecution for alleged bribery of SNC-Lavalin, a large Quebec-based engineering firm (which denies the charges). The Conservatives promise to make life more affordable by ending the national carbon tax, removing value-added tax from home-heating fuel, and embracing "nation-building projects", such as oil pipelines, to create more jobs. Mr Trudeau argues that a Conservative government would cut public spending and revive policies of Stephen Harper, the former, Conservative prime minister.
Opposition parties strongly opposed to the federal Liberal government's environmental legislation have taken control of provincial governments in Ontario and Alberta in the past 15 months, setting the stage for policy battles at the federal election and beyond. The Alberta premier, Jason Kenney, whose United Conservative Party defeated the left-leaning New Democratic Party (NDP) government at the provincial election in April, claims that the federal government's environmental policies have harmed Alberta's resource-based economy. He has repealed the carbon tax in the province, which was introduced by the former NDP government. As a result, the Liberal government plans to introduce (in January 2020) the same national carbon tax in Alberta that it imposed in April on four other provinces-Saskatchewan, Manitoba, Ontario and New Brunswick-that did not have pricing plans that met federal standards. The provincial governments in Ontario, Saskatchewan and Alberta contend that the national carbon tax is unconstitutional, and the Supreme Court of Canada will ultimately rule on the matter later this year.
The nationalisation in 2018 of the Trans Mountain oil pipeline and expansion project has also raised questions regarding federal jurisdiction. The expansion, designed to carry additional crude oil from Alberta to a port in British Columbia (BC), is opposed by the NDP provincial government in BC and by environmentalists. The federal cabinet's decision in June to proceed with the project is controversial and will be a central election issue. The Conservative leader, Andrew Scheer, who backs the project, claims that Mr Trudeau is not committed to the pipeline expansion.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The quality of the bureaucracy in Canada is exceptionally high, and the incidence of corruption low. The legal system is highly efficient and transparent. The political system will remain effective. The Liberal majority in the House of Commons since 2015 has meant that opposition parties have been unable to block government legislation. More than 100 bills were passed through both chambers and received royal assent since the Liberals formed the government. Key legislation included bills ratifying the Canada-EU Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement and an act to make recreational cannabis legal in Canada. We expect the Liberals to be re-elected on October 21st-only two majority governments have failed to be re-elected for a second term. However, a minority government is the likeliest possibility, which would force either a Liberal or Conservative-led administration to negotiate with other parties to pass legislation, reducing overall political effectiveness.
The Liberals have failed to overhaul the first-past-the-post system
Mr Trudeau had major plans to revamp Canada's political institutions when he won office in 2015. He has been partly successful. The Liberals had pledged that the 2015 election would be the last to use the first-past-the-post system, but after national consultations on a replacement, the government decided to stay with the current system. The issue is unlikely to be revisited over the forecast period (2019-23). In December 2018 legislation changing some parts of the election process was passed, including limiting the length of election campaigns to 50 days and making spending by political parties and third parties more transparent. The legislation also allows Canadian citizens living abroad to vote regardless of how long they have been overseas. The government also proposed a series of changes to how the House of Commons conducts its business. The watered-down version that passed in mid-2017 puts an obligation on the government to explain why it has delayed the House of Commons from meeting, when that has occurred, and gives the speaker of the Commons the power to divide omnibus bills into smaller sections.
Canada is a decentralised federation, with the provinces exercising jurisdiction in many areas, including natural resources, health and education, and securities regulation. This can be a source of strength, in that each of the ten provinces and three territories is free to experiment with policies, allowing the others to watch and then adopt proven practices. However, it is also a source of weakness, because it makes the setting of national policy in areas of shared jurisdiction difficult and sometimes impossible. Tensions arise in areas of shared jurisdiction, such as environmental policy. Governments can, and have, appealed to the courts to sort out jurisdictional battles. The NDP government in British Columbia (BC), which opposes the Trans Mountain expansion pipeline, intends to appeal to the Supreme Court of Canada after the BC Court of Appeal ruled in May 2019 that proposed provincial legislation restricting the increased flow of oil into BC conflicted with federal jurisdiction over interprovincial pipelines. Governments generally abide by court decisions, either abandoning their proposed course of action or addressing flaws that judges have identified.
Political outlook: Election watch
Following the SNC-Lavalin affair, the Conservative Party overtook the Liberals in opinion surveys in February 2019, but support for the Liberals has since recovered. According to an aggregate poll published on September 12th, 34% of respondents supported the Conservatives, compared with 33.7% for the Liberals. The NDP was well behind, backed by 12.6% of those surveyed, followed by the Greens on 10.8%.
We expect the Liberal Party to remain in government after the federal election on October 21st, although it could fall short of an absolute majority. The Liberals have the advantage of incumbency, and will highlight their record on middle-class income tax cuts, raising the child benefit, and climate-change policy. However, the contest will be tight. The Conservatives will focus on the Liberal government's perceived vulnerabilities, namely higher government spending, the cost of its environmental policies and the rising cost of living. The opposition will also highlight the issue of trust, given the Liberal government's broken pledge on electoral reform, its failure to balance the budget by 2019 as stated in the 2015 election campaign, and the SNC-Lavalin affair. The Conservatives also contend that the Liberals have lost control of the border by allowing more than 45,000 people to walk across from the US over the past two years and claim asylum.
Political outlook: International relations
The Liberal government's foreign policy will continue to emphasise multilateralism, mitigating the effects of climate change and upholding human rights. The contrast with policies pursued by the US president, Donald Trump, will continue to strain bilateral relations during the remainder of Mr Trump's administration. Canada will nonetheless seek to preserve relations with the US, by far its most important diplomatic and economic partner. Canada will also increase efforts to diversify trade.
The signing in November 2018 of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) and preserve the trilateral arrangement, has mitigated some trade risk for Canada. The revised deal maintains most of the substance of the earlier one; in particular, the USMCA retains the Chapter 19 dispute-resolution mechanism, on which Canada relies to protect some of its industries (primarily lumber) from potential US anti-dumping measures. Canada also negotiated an exemption from any future tariffs that the US might impose on automotive imports, and the US has been granted greater access to the Canadian market for dairy, poultry and eggs (these sectors are managed by the government to ensure sufficiently high prices for farmers). Mexico has already ratified the deal, but political hurdles in the US, and Canada's parliamentary recess until November 2019, mean that full ratification will probably be delayed until 2020.
China is a major target for exporters, but relations are fraught
China was a major target for the government's trade diversification policy until December, when Meng Wanzhou, a senior executive of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, was detained in Canada at the request of US authorities on fraud charges (that she denies). Bitter exchanges between Canada and China since her arrest have cast a chill on bilateral relations. In response, China has detained two Canadians on charges of spying, sentenced two others convicted of drug crimes to death, and has used non-tariff barriers to impede agricultural imports from Canada. In early September the government requested bilateral consultations with the country at the WTO, the first step towards launching a formal complaint on China's blocking of Canadian canola (rapeseed) imports. Bilateral relations will remain tense for as long as Ms Meng faces the threat of extradition to the US.
The implementation of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) is expected to provide enhanced access to major Asian markets over the 2019-23 forecast period. A trade deal signed with the EU in 2016 has removed 98% of the EU tariff lines; when the deal is fully implemented, that figure will rise to 99%.

Canada rises to ninth place in The Economist Intelligence Unit's global business environment rankings in 2019-23 (the forecast period) and moves into first place in the regional rank of G7 countries. The increase in Canada's overall score reflects improvements in areas such as infrastructure, technological readiness, and policy towards private enterprise and competition. These gains will more than offset slight declines in market opportunities and the labour market. Taxes and labour will remain the least favourable aspects of the business environment.
Canada performs best in the foreign trade category. Most of the Canada-EU Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) came into effect in September 2017. In 2018 Canada ratified the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP), which is in force for six of the 11 signatories. Full implementation will provide enhanced access to major Asian markets. The signing in November 2018 of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), has eliminated much of the uncertainty surrounding the US-instigated renegotiation of the deal. Despite complications over timing, we continue to expect that ratification of USMCA will be completed in 2020.
We expect the Liberal government to remain in power after the federal election due in October 2019. However, it lost a major ally in Ontario, Canada's most populous province, after the Liberal government there was defeated in June 2018. This was followed by the return to provincial government in Alberta of the United Conservative Party in April 2019. In Canada's decentralised feder-ation, where provincial leaders can be powerful adversaries, this will make national policymaking more challenging. As a centrist party, the Liberals are generally supportive of business and are unlikely to pass any laws that would significantly hinder the business environment.
