Business environment outlook: Canada's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Canada's dairy, egg and poultry markets are partially opened up as a result of trade agreements. Intellectual property rules are tightened.
2021-23: A controversial new regulatory process for approving major projects is implemented. The government works towards introducing a national pharmacare plan.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: The government continues to welcome foreign investment but will sometimes reject foreign takeovers owing to national security considerations. Chinese investment and takeover bids come under particular scrutiny.
2021-23: Foreign ownership restrictions in broadcasting and telecommunications could be relaxed. Foreign investment rise in value terms.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Canada, Mexico and the US ratify the revised North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), now called the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which retains the essence of the original treaty.
2021-23: Canada continues to diversify its trade ties. Free-trade talks with China resume.
Taxes
2019-20: The federal corporate tax rate for small businesses is reduced to 9% (from 10%). The government provides benefits and tax breaks to help to maintain business competitiveness compared with the US.
2021-23: The federal carbon tax is increased under a Liberal government. A Conservative government would repeal the tax.
Financing
2019-20: Enhancements to corporate governance, business conduct and customer redress systems in the banking sector take effect. Changes to the deposit insurance system are implemented.
2021-23: The government completes its update of financial legislation. The Toronto Stock Exchange will continue to face competitive pressure from the larger markets in the US.
The labour market
2019-20: Employment reforms reduce labour flexibility and push up costs for federally regulated industries.
2021-23: The government further encourages the entry of skilled workers and professionals by raising its immigration target.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Work begins on the Trans Mountain Expansion project, which will pipe additional crude oil from Alberta, although further legal challenges could slow progress.
2021-23: After years of uncertainty, pipelines to carry more energy resources from Alberta begin to come on stream.
Technological readiness
2019-20: The federal government auctions spectrum necessary for fifth-generation (5G) technology services.
2021-23: Expertise in artificial intelligence takes root, particularly in the academic centres of Toronto and Montreal.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.8 7.8 21 35 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
Household debt and exposure to the US will remain vulnerabilities
Canada's score in the macroeconomic environment category is unchanged in 2019-23, but the country slips 14 places in the global rankings to 35th as economic prospects in other countries improve. We expect real GDP growth to slow, at a below-trend 1.6% in 2019 and an average 1.7% in 2020, reflecting slower domestic demand and the negative effect on the US economy (and hence Canadian exports) of the escalating US-China trade war. Growth will return to an average of about 2.3% per year in the latter years of the forecast. A central area of vulnerability in the economy is household indebtedness, which remains near record-high levels. A series of government measures have helped to cool the overstretched housing market, reducing the risk of a major correction, but prices remain inflated. Another vulnerability is Canada's economic dependence on the US, its main trading partner, which purchases about 76% of Canadian goods exports and supplies 51% of goods imports. The high level of regional integration between the US and Canada and complex crossborder supply chains mean that the Canadian economy is heavily exposed to an economic downturn in the US, as well as increased trade protectionism and other policy changes pursued by its neighbour. Some Canadian firms have redirected investments to the US after its corporate tax reform in 2018. The government will continue efforts to diversify Canada's export markets.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.8 9.0 5 5 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
Canada will remain one of the most favourable environments for private enterprises. The country's score rises to 9, from 8.8 previously, although its global and regional (G7) rankings are unchanged at fifth and second respectively. In 2018 the federal government nationalised the Trans Mountain oil pipeline and expansion project, which had been undermined by environ-mental protests and obstruction by the provincial government in British Columbia (BC). The federal government gave final approval for the expansion project in June 2019, although construction work could be delayed further by legal challenges. Assuming that it goes ahead, the pipeline will greatly increase capacity to transport crude oil from Alberta and allow oil producers to diversify their markets. There are 45 Crown Corporations (state-owned enterprises) at the federal level. Only a few compete directly with the private sector, and they are subject to the Competition Act to prevent abuse of dominance. Foreign investors can also challenge them under the rules of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) or NAFTA (and will also be able to do so under its successor, the USMCA, once it is ratified).
Intellectual property rules will be tighter under the USMCA
In April 2019 the US removed Canada from the high-priority watch list of countries that it believes do not adequately protect intellectual property (IP). However, Canada remains on the lower-level watch list, owing to ongoing concerns about pharmaceutical patents, online piracy and counterfeit goods. The US attributes Canada's removal from the priority list to expanded IP provisions in the USMCA and harsher penalties in recent Canadian court cases.
Canada's supply management system for dairy, egg and poultry production controls prices and restricts imports through high tariffs. These markets will be partially opened up under CETA, the CPTPP and the USMCA, although the overall impact on domestic producers is expected to be small. For example, it is estimated that Canadian dairy farmers will lose a total market share of 8% once all the agreements are fully phased in.
The other major area of federal government price control is patented medicines, for which Canadians pay among the highest prices in the world. New regulations aimed at reducing the price of patented medicines will take effect in July 2020. The Liberal government is expected to firm up its commitment to a national pharmacare plan at the October 2019 general election, although it will take several years to implement. Under a national plan, the federal government would have more clout negotiating prices with pharmaceutical companies, resulting in lower prices.
In March 2019 the Competition Bureau released new abuse of dominance enforcement guidelines. The main changes include the removal of the 35% "safe harbour" threshold, under which firms with a market share of below this level would generally not be subject to examination by the bureau. The market share threshold for further investigation has, in effect, been lifted to 50%, unless there is other evidence of a substantial degree of market power.
The impact of the new project approval process is uncertain
In June 2019 parliament passed legislation (Bill C-69) aimed at giving investors greater clarity on the regulatory process for approving major projects (including resource projects), ensuring that affected communities and indigenous groups are fully consulted, and reducing the possibility of project approvals being challenged in court. However, critics of the legislation contend that it will create more red tape and deter investors.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.7 8.7 10 10 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
Canada remains in tenth place in the global rankings for this category, and in first place among the regional (G7) economies. The two main political parties will maintain a welcoming policy towards foreign investment. Two large divestments by foreign oil companies of operations in Canada's oil sands contributed to a sharp drop in foreign direct investment (FDI) in Canada in 2017, but FDI rose to a three-year high in 2018 (at US$45.4bn, or 2.7% of GDP). Further progress will be hampered by global economic headwinds, volatility in oil prices, and uncertainty caused by the US administration's trade policies.
The US is by far the largest source of FDI in Canada, accounting for almost half of the FDI stock in 2018, although this share has declined over the past decade. Trade and tax policy in the US will nevertheless continue to affect foreign investment in Canada. For example, the reduction in the US corporate tax rate as part of that country's tax reforms in 2018 increased the relative attractiveness for US firms of investing at home rather than in Canada. The Liberal government has introduced some mitigating measures, such as enhanced tax breaks on capital expenditure.
Regulations governing broadcasting and telecoms will be modernised
Canada maintains foreign ownership restrictions in a few industries, although some were loosened in 2018, and further relaxation is possible in the forecast period. In mid-2018 the government raised the limit on foreign ownership of Canadian air carriers that provide passenger and cargo services to 49% (from 25% previously). A final report and recommendations on modernising the legislative framework governing broadcasting and telecommunications will be published in January 2020. Non-Canadians cannot currently hold a broad-casting licence and are restricted to 20% ownership of a telecommunications common carrier. Canada also reviews foreign investments above certain thresholds, set at C$1.05bn (US$0.8bn) in 2019 for private firms from WTO members and C$1.57bn (US$1.19bn) for firms in countries covered by a trade agreement. In May 2018 the government blocked the US$1.2bn purchase of Aecon, a construction company, by a Chinese state-owned firm, on grounds of national security. Successive governments will be open to most foreign invest-ments in the forecast period, but those proposed by state-owned firms will come under increasing scrutiny.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
10.0 10.0 1 1 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
Foreign trade and exchange controls are the best-rated feature of Canada's business environment, and the country maintains its top global ranking in this category. In the WTO's rankings for 2018, Canada was the 13th-biggest exporter, with a 2.3% share of global exports, and the 13th-biggest importer, with a 2.4% share of imports.
Given the openness of the Canadian economy, in which one in five jobs are linked directly or indirectly to exports, free trade will continue to be supported strongly by the two major political parties in the forecast period. However, policies in this area will be constrained in part by the need to maintain close relations with the US, which absorbs the vast majority of Canada's exports. The renegotiation of NAFTA in November 2018 will help to ease short-term concerns about trade policy. We expect the US and Canada to ratify the USMCA, the treaty that will replace NAFTA, in 2020, although political obstacles on the US side could affect this timeline. Mexico ratified the new agreement in June 2019.
Canada has made some compromises that will further open its markets in order to reach agreement on the USMCA. Central among these are a 16-year sunset clause, greater access for the US to Canada's dairy and poultry industries and modification of the investor-state dispute settlement mechanism. However, the new agreement preserves another dispute-resolution mechanism (Chapter 19 of NAFTA), on which Canada relies to protect some of its industries, notably lumber, from potential US anti-dumping measures. The USMCA also includes tighter rules of origin in the auto industry, an important sector for Canada, and tougher rules on IP and digital trade. Tariffs imposed by the US on Canadian steel and aluminium imports in June 2018, on the grounds that they represented a threat to national security, were lifted in May 2019, but the US government has warned that the tariffs could be re-imposed if steel and aluminium shipments from Canada were to surge in the future.
The CPTPP will provide greater access to major Asian markets
Trade tensions with the US have revived efforts to diversify trade. Much of the CETA with the EU came into force in 2017, and the CPTPP, an agreement between 11 Pacific countries, is currently in effect for six of the signatories. However, the Liberal government's attempts at strengthening trade ties with China have stalled. China has little interest in including non-economic areas considered crucial by Canada, such as the environment and IP protection, in a trade agreement. Moreover, relations with China have soured following the arrest and detention by Canada of a senior executive of Huawei, a Chinese telecommunications firm, on charges that she denies, and the blocking by China of some agricultural imports from Canada in retaliation. Although the spat will eventually blow over, formidable barriers need to be overcome before a trade deal can be agreed. Progress on a proposed comprehensive economic partner-ship agreement with India has been slow and a deal is unlikely to come into force in the forecast period.
Canada's accession to the UN Arms Trade Treaty in September 2019 will entail new regulations on arms brokering, formal assessment criteria for export permits and increased transparency in the reporting of arms exports. Textiles and clothing are also subject to export controls, as are nuclear goods and technology, and softwood lumber. Canada will maintain import controls on some agricultural products, especially dairy and poultry products where domestic output is tightly controlled, although the full implementation of recent trade deals will lead to a partial opening-up of these markets.
Canada has sanctions and related measures in place against 19 countries, including Russia, North Korea and Iran. In 2017 parliament passed legislation to impose sanctions and take other restrictive measures against foreign officials who violate human rights, the so-called Magnitsky law.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.0 7.1 21 25 1 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
The tax category has traditionally been one of Canada's weakest, largely because of the complexity of the tax system, which is a mixture of federal and provincial tax regimes. Canada's score edges up to 7.1 in the forecast period. However, the country slips to 25th in the global ranking for this component and to second position in the regional (G7) ranking.
Permanent reductions in corporate tax rates are unlikely
US tax reform in 2018 removed the tax advantage held by Canada for more than a decade by reducing the US average combined federal-state corporate tax rate to 26%, slightly below the average combined federal-provincial rate in Canada of 27%. Businesses in Canada will continue to press the federal government to reduce the corporate tax burden. However, persistent budget deficits will limit the ability of the federal government, and some provincial governments, to implement permanent reductions in corporate tax rates.
Canada has a separate corporate tax rate for small businesses, the federal component of which was reduced to 9% from January 2019, from 10% previously. Small businesses fiercely resisted plans by the Liberal government to make tax avoidance more difficult. The government was targeting wealthy individuals who used the tax system to reduce their tax, but many legitimate enterprises were caught in its proposed net. The government made significant changes before implementing the final measures, which reduce access to the small business rate and a refundable tax. The Liberals reduced personal income tax rates for the middle class and raised them for high-income earners soon after they won the 2015 election. We do not anticipate further major changes to personal tax rates in the forecast period.
A Conservative government would repeal the federal carbon tax
The federal carbon tax will remain controversial. In April 2019 the federal government introduced a carbon tax of C$20 (US$15)/tonne in the four provinces without their own carbon pricing programmes: Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan and New Brunswick. The tax will rise by C$10 each year, to C$50 per tonne by 2022. The Liberal government plans to introduce the same tax in energy-rich Alberta from January 2020, after the new United Conservative Party government in that province dumped the existing carbon tax in May 2019. The federal Conservative Party will repeal the federal carbon tax if elected in October. Assuming that the Liberal government is returned to power, provincial governments are likely to seek a ruling from the Supreme Court of Canada on whether the federal carbon tax is constitutional.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.5 8.5 3 9 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
Tight regulation, cautious lending policies and continued improvements to oversight will maintain the soundness of the banking sector in 2019-23. Canada maintains its score of 8.5 in this category and remains in first place in the regional (G7) rankings. The federal government regulates banks and federally incorporated institutions in the trust and loan, life insurance, and property and casualty insurance subsectors. Credit unions, caisses populaires (co-operatives), securities dealers and exchanges are mostly regulated by the provinces. The government is in the process of updating legislation governing financial institutions to reflect new technologies and to factor in demographic changes that are changing business models and consumer relationships.
The government is undertaking a financial systems update
Amendments to the Bank Act legislated in December 2018 include enhancements to corporate governance, responsible business conduct, disclosure and transparency, and customer redress systems. Changes to the deposit insurance system that will come into effect in 2020-21 include extending coverage to foreign-currency deposits, removing term limits on guaranteed investment certificates, and adding new deposit categories, to ensure that every registered product is covered up to the same C$100,000 (US$76,000) limit.
As part of the update to the financial system, the government is modernising the structure of three payment systems. The 1999 large value transfer system (LVTS) will be replaced by newer infrastructure called Lynx by 2021, and the 1984 automated clearing settlement system (ACSS) will also be replaced by a more efficient retail system. The third change involves a new real-time retail payment system. The Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) does not own the payments systems but provides settlement accounts to the participants of all three systems. We expect these changes to be completed within the forecast period.
The Toronto Stock Exchange (TSX) has sophisticated trading and settlement systems, but will continue to face competitive pressure from the larger markets in the US and from electronic share-trading networks. More than 100 Canadian companies, including almost all of the major ones, have shares listed on foreign stock exchanges, most commonly the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) and Nasdaq. At end-July 2019 there were 1,566 issuers on the TSX, and the TSX Venture Exchange (TSXV) had 1,700 issuers. Energy and mining companies account for more than 40% of issuers on the TSX/TSXV. Aequitas NEO, an exchange backed by a number of banks, asset managers and pension funds, began trading in March 2015 as a rival to the TSX. In July 2019 it had more than 90 corporate and exchange-traded fund listings.
The six major Canadian banks will remain profitable, reflecting in part the oligopolistic nature of the market. Canada's banking sector, especially retail banking, is among the least competitive and most profitable in the OECD. This has allowed domestic banks to charge high fees for basic services such as cash withdrawals and debit-card payments. The banks' pricing power is a recurring source of political controversy. However, growth in mobile payment and other online services will gradually force the banks to become more competitive. The banks' capital position is solid and will provide a buffer against losses. The banks currently maintain capital and leverage ratios above regulatory requirements.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.9 6.8 16 24 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
Canada's score for this category slips to 6.8 in the forecast period, reducing its global ranking to 24th, although it remains in second place in the regional (G7) ranking. Canada's labour market is robust. The unemployment rate of 5.7% in July 2019 remains close to a 40-year low, although it varies greatly across the country. Using US statistical methods, the unemployment rate in Canada was 4.6% in July, compared with 3.7% in the US. Wage growth, which had been subdued since the 2014 commodity price drop, has picked up in 2019, with year-on-year growth in hourly wages averaging 3.5% in April-August. However, with the labour market expected to soften in 2020-21, we do not anticipate a breakout in wage growth over the forecast period.
The Liberals will lift annual permanent resident admissions
According to the latest quarterly business outlook survey published by the BoC in June 2019, reports of labour shortages have increased from a low level in the previous survey, but are not widespread. To address a shortage of skilled workers, the federal government launched a global skills strategy in 2017 to make it easier and quicker for firms to bring skilled workers to Canada. A start-up visa programme, which began in 2013 as a pilot project, became a permanent pathway for immigration to Canada in 2018. Just over 321,000 permanent residents were admitted to Canada in 2018, which was the highest number since the current data series began in 1972. The government's latest three-year immigration plan commits to increasing annual permanent resident admissions to 350,000 in 2021, which will be equal to nearly 1% of the population. The major political parties will continue to support immigration.
Labour rigidity will increase under federal employment reforms
Employment reforms being phased in from September 2019 will reduce labour flexibility and push up costs for federally regulated industries such as banking and transport. The changes include enhanced leave entitlements and a relaxation of minimum length-of-service requirements for eligibility, mandatory notice periods for changing employee shifts, tighter rules on breaks and new pay equity rules.
Sluggish productivity will remain a problem, defying efforts by the government to boost innovation, encourage investment in machinery and equipment, and increase FDI flows. Successive governments will attempt to tackle the problem through infrastructure investments, innovation programmes and investing in skills training.
About 4.8m Canadian workers belong to a union, 2.8m of whom are in the public sector and the rest in the private sector. The unionisation rate, which dropped steeply in the 1980s and 1990s before assuming a more moderate decline, was 28.1% in 2018. There were 80 major work stoppages in Canada in 2018, down from 175 in 2017 and well below the average for the previous seven years.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.3 8.8 9 5 1 1
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 7 countries: Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the UK and the US.
Canada performs well in the infrastructure category. Its score rises to 8.8 in the forecast period, lifting it to fifth place in the global rankings, and retaining first place in the regional (G7) rankings. The Liberal government is investing C$180bn (US$137bn) over 12 years to improve infrastructure. Owing to its large geographic size, Canada has an extensive road and highways network. A survey by Statistics Canada published in 2018 indicated that the country had more than 765,000 km of publicly owned roads in 2016. One of the newer additions is a 120-km, all-weather road from Inuvik to Tuktoyaktuk in the Northwest Territories, which opened in 2017. The link between Canada's Arctic Coast and and the areas south of this region is important for northern inhabitants and resource development in the territory.
More than half of the highways (59%), local roads (52%) and arterial roads (52%) in Canada were in very good or good condition, according to the Statistics Canada survey. There were 47,279 publicly owned bridges and 351 publicly owned tunnels. Only about one-tenth of bridges and one-tenth of tunnels were in poor or very poor condition. The federal government spent C$4.2bn replacing the Champlain Bridge linking the island of Montreal to the south shore, and about C$5.7bn will be spent constructing the Gordie Howe Bridge linking Windsor, Ontario, to Detroit, Michigan. The new Champlain Bridge opened in July 2019 and the Gordie Howe Bridge (replacing the Ambassador Bridge) is due to open in 2024.
Trans Mountain Expansion pipeline gets the green light
The oil industry and the provincial government in Alberta have been calling for the construction of more pipelines to bring additional crude oil to global markets. Existing pipelines to the US are also near capacity, forcing exporters to move an increasing amount of crude oil by rail. The proposed Trans Mountain Expansion project will almost triple the capacity of the existing oil pipeline and allow shipments to markets beyond the US, the current destination of most oil exports from Alberta. The project, now owned by the federal government, received the final go-ahead in June 2019. Construction is scheduled to begin later this year, although further legal challenges could delay completion, currently scheduled for 2022. Legal challenges and opposition from environ-mentalists have further delayed construction of the proposed Keystone XL pipeline from Alberta to Nebraska. Following a decision by the Nebraska Supreme Court in August 2019 affirming approval for the route, construction could get under way in 2020. The Liberal government rejected the proposed Northern Gateway pipeline from Alberta to the British Columbia (BC) coast in 2016.
Businesses complain about lengthy approval processes for pipelines
Complaints about lengthy, expensive and redundant approval processes for major projects, including pipelines, have led the federal government to revamp the process. Legislation passed in June 2019 is meant to streamline approvals for major projects, give investors greater clarity on the regulatory process, ensure full consultation with indigenous groups and reduce the risk of project approvals being delayed by court challenges. However, critics of the legislation claim that it will actually make it harder to get new pipeline and resource projects approved. Canada generates more electricity than it needs, exporting 9% of the 652.3 terawatt-hours (TWh) generated in 2017 to the US. About 60% of the electricity consumed in Canada is generated by hydro, 15% by nuclear, 10% by gas or oil, 9% by coal and 7% by non-hydro renewables.
The Canadian Radio-television and Telecommunications Commission (CRTC), a government agency, has set a goal that by 2021 90% of Canadian homes and small businesses will have access to fixed broadband that offers internet speeds of up to 50 megabits per second (Mbps) in downloads, with an unlimited data allowance. According to the CRTC's 2019 Communications Monitoring Report, 84.1% of Canadians have access that meets these targets, although the proportion falls to 37.2% for rural areas. The agency says that 99% of Canadians have access to Long-Term Evolution (LTE) mobile wireless services (commonly referred to as fourth-generation, or 4G, technology), but the service is limited or non-existent in some rural and remote areas. About 86% of major transport roads and highways have access to LTE. The 2019 federal budget earmarked C$1.7bn in new funding towards achieving a new target that 95% of Canadian homes and businesses have access to internet speeds of at least 50 Mbps in downloads by 2026.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness

8.6 8.9 18 19 2 2

Canada has a solid performance in this newly created category, which shows how future-oriented the business environment is, including the extent to which it is digitally connected, open to innovation and prepared for technological disruption. Canada scores 8.9 in the forecast period. It ranks 19th in the global rankings and is in second place in the regional (G7) rankings.
Internet access is almost universal
The most recent data published by the International Telecommunication Union, in mid-2019, show that 87% of households had internet access at home-well above the global average. The percentage of people with fixed broadband subscriptions was 39%, and the percentage with mobile-phone subscriptions was 89%. Households will continue to drop landline telephone services in favour of mobile-only service, with almost a third having already done so, according to the CRTC. In mid-2019 4G availability from the three major mobile operators ranged from 88% to 90%, and operators have begun testing for fifth-generation (5G) technology services. The federal government intends to hold an auction in 2020 for the 3,500-megahertz spectrum necessary for 5G services.
At least 87% of individuals and virtually all businesses make some purchases online in Canada. Credit cards dominate e-commerce payments in Canada, accounting for about 90% of such purchases. One reason for this is security, as nearly two-thirds of users find a credit card safer, although reward schemes are also a factor. This dominance is likely to continue as the popularity of mobile online and in-app transactions continues to rise. Almost one in two Canadians use a mobile device to purchase products or services online, and this proportion will grow during the forecast period.
Canada ranked 23rd out of 193 countries in the UN's 2018 e-governance survey, doing well in the provision of online services and content, and in having the human resources to promote and use information and communications technology (ICT), but lagging in the adequacy of the telecommunications infrastructure. The Liberal government announced a new cyber-security strategy in 2018, and established the Canadian Centre for Cyber-Security to centralise units previously dispersed across the government and co-ordinate government responses to cyber threats.
Canada's reputation as a hotspot for artificial intelligence research will grow
Canada is among the top ten countries with the largest volume of top-cited scientific publications. A study by the Council of Canadian Academies in 2018 of Canada's research and development (R&D) found that the country's international standing was at risk because of a sustained slide in private and public investment in R&D (which stands at 1.7% of GDP, according to UNESCO). However, the study found pockets of R&D strength across several industries. One area is artificial intelligence (AI), where Canada is in the top ten countries filing AI patents. In 2017 the Liberal government set up and invested in the Pan-Canadian Artificial Intelligence Strategy. This was followed in December 2018 by the announcement of C$230m (US$174m) in funding for a Quebec-based AI-Powered Supply Chains Supercluster, a collaborative venture to build intelligent supply chains through AI and robotics. In 2018 Samsung (of Korea) opened AI research facilities in Toronto and Montreal-the main hubs for AI research in Canada. Google (of the US) also has AI research facilities in both cities.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
The government will seek to support domestic industries that are adversely affected by US trade protectionism and Canada's trade issues with China. Measures to boost the competitiveness of Canadian businesses following tax cuts in the US last year included a tax break on capital expenditure in manufacturing. However, the government will struggle to balance environ-mental policy with support for the fossil fuel industry. It has rolled out a national carbon tax of C$20 (US$15)/tonne in provinces that did not have an equivalent carbon pricing programme in place. This tax will rise to C$50/tonne by 2022. However, the government has also approved the controversial expansion of the Trans Mountain pipeline, which it now owns. To ease concerns about the apparent contradiction, the government has pledged to recycle all profits into clean-energy projects. The pipeline expansion could be delayed further by legal challenges.
Policymakers will continue to monitor the residential property market, which will remain a risk owing to overleveraged Canadian households. Measures introduced by the federal government and provincial governments in Ontario and BC in recent years have helped to cool the tight housing market. In Vancouver and Toronto foreign buyers are subject to an additional tax on property purchases, and the federal government has tightened mortgage requirements nationwide, which has improved the quality of new mortgage lending. According to the monthly Teranet-National Bank National Composite House Price Index, prices softened in September 2018-April 2019 but edged up in May-July. Despite falling mortgage interest rates, The Economist Intelligence Unit still expects the housing market to remain sluggish in 2019, reflecting a combination of tighter lending standards and continued affordability pressures. However, the risk of a major correction appears to have eased for now.

The government is committed to a programme of infrastructure and other spending that will entail a series of budget deficits, but these will be partially offset by increased receipts due to the introduction of the carbon tax and greater tax income as a result of cannabis legalisation. However, lower average oil prices in 2019-20 compared with 2018, and a slower pace of economic expansion, mean that government receipts are likely to undershoot official projections overall, weighing on plans to reduce the fiscal deficit.
According to the federal budget for fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March) handed down in March, the budget deficit for 2019/20 will be C$19.8bn (US$14.9bn)-equivalent to 0.9% of GDP. Official projections show the budget deficit contracting to C$9.8bn (equivalent to 0.4% of GDP) by 2023/24. We project that the fiscal deficit will expand from 0.4% of GDP in 2018 (our fiscal forecasts are calendar-year based) to 0.9% of GDP in 2019 and 1% of GDP in 2020. The government will seek to reduce the shortfall in the longer term, and we expect the deficit to contract gradually, to 0.7% of GDP by 2023. The deficit would be likely to fall more quickly under a Conservative government.
Economic forecast: Monetary policy

It has been almost a year since the Bank of Canada (BoC, the central bank) last changed its policy rate, the overnight rate, lifting it by 25 basis points to 1.75% in October 2018. A solid improvement in the economy during the second quarter of this year and the return of consumer price inflation to around the mid-point of the central bank's 1-3% target range have allowed the BoC to buck the recent trend of some other central banks in cutting rates-at least for now. However, at its latest interest rate announcement, on September 4th, the BoC warned that the escalating US-China trade conflict had caused world trade and business invest-ment to soften, and indicated that it would pay close attention to global develop-ments and their impact on the outlook for Canadian growth and inflation.
We forecast that the Federal Reserve (Fed, the US central bank) will follow up the cut to its policy rate in July with three more 25-basis-point cuts in September and December this year, and in March 2020. On balance, we continue to expect the BoC to keep its policy rate unchanged until January 2020, when we expect it to sanction a 25-basis-point cut amid a further weakening in US growth; because of the linkages between the two countries, this will weigh on economic growth in Canada. However, the chances of an earlier rate cut in Canada are increasing. The BoC will begin to tighten monetary policy gradually again from 2021, as economic growth picks up.

Real GDP growth slowed to 1.9% in 2018, from 3% in 2017, and we expect the pace of economic expansion to soften further in 2019, to an average of 1.6%. High household debt levels and the subdued housing market will weigh on private consumption growth this year, although solid growth in government spending will help to cushion the impact. A fall in gross fixed investment in the second quarter has led us to revise our forecast for this component, which we now expect will contract by 1.3% this year (we previously forecast a 1.5% expansion). The impact of this and other minor tweaks on our overall real GDP forecast has been offset by an upgrade to our projection for export growth. However, export growth will still moderate this year, as a result of weaker economic expansion in the US, Canada's main export market.
The renegotiation of North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) reduces one of the major downside risks to our forecast, although the timeline for the ratification of the successor agreement, the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), will be extended into 2020. Canadian producers and manufac-turers will benefit from the removal in May of US tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminium imports, and the end of the retaliatory import tariffs that Canada imposed, but are feeling the pinch from trade restrictions imposed by China on some Canadian farm exports, such as canola. Global trade uncertainty remains a major downside risk to our forecast. Other risks to the economic outlook include a sharp drop in global oil prices, which would act as a drag on economic activity.
At 1.7%, real GDP growth will remain well below its long-term trend next year as economic growth in the US continues to slow and domestic demand in Canada remains sluggish. Real GDP growth is expected to pick up again in 2021, and will average 2.4% per year in 2022-23. This will be supported by continued public investment in infrastructure and stronger export growth, driven by recovering demand in the US and enhanced trade ties with the EU and CPTPP members.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
The primary sector has begun to recover from the precipitous fall in oil prices in mid-2014. As the fourth-largest oil exporter in the world, Canada has been highly exposed to what proved to be a structural shift in the oil industry. The partial recovery of global oil prices since 2018 will spur renewed interest in investments in the oil-producing provinces of Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Newfoundland and Labrador in the coming years. However, the rapid expansion of the US shale sector complicates the outlook for the Canadian fossil fuel industry. The US is by far Canada's largest market for energy products, which makes greater US energy independence a challenge for Canadian drillers. This will encourage the sector to pursue its plans to diversify its sales to include Asian markets through the development of additional pipeline capacity, although environmental concerns will remain a challenge. Canada also has large deposits of various metals, including copper, metal and silver. Coal is becoming less popular, but is still extracted, mainly for use in power stations.
The agriculture, forestry and fishing sector's share of nominal GDP has remained stable at about 2.1% in recent years. The Canadian agricultural sector benefits from abundant land, high productivity and a strong export tradition. This has enabled it to avoid the declining trend evident in many other OECD economies. We expect the sector to maintain its share of GDP in the forecast period (2019-23). The US will gain greater access to the Canadian poultry and dairy markets as a result of the NAFTA renegotiation, although the supply-management system for these sectors will remain in place. The federal govern-ment will offer compensation to Canadian dairy farmers to help to mitigate the loss of market share. In August 2019 the government announced a compen-sation package worth C$1.8bn over eight years to compensate Canadian dairy farmers for increased dairy imports as a result of the EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade-Agreement (CETA) and the CPTPP.
Currency developments have a sizeable impact on the manufacturing sector
The manufacturing sector enjoyed several years of modest recovery following the 2008-09 global financial crisis, although its vitality was constrained by the strength of the Canadian dollar (against the US dollar and other major currencies). The local currency has depreciated against the US dollar since 2015, and we forecast that it will remain at around this lower level in the forecast period. However, the Canadian manufacturing sector has so far struggled to take full advantage of this, owing to uncertainty in the past couple of years over the NAFTA renegotiation and the application of multiple tariffs on Canadian exports to the US. One of the largest manufacturing sectors, motor vehicles and parts production, faced the possibility of significant disruptions on both the supply and demand sides from an end to NAFTA. The removal in May 2019 of US tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminium imports, and the successful negotiation of NAFTA's successor, the USMCA, in late 2018 has removed much of the risk. However, the US and Canada have yet to ratify the agreement, and the current US administration's unpredictable trade policies will remain a source of uncertainty.
We expect the services sector, which accounts for about 70% of nominal GDP, to experience decent, but not stellar, growth in the forecast period. The sector expanded by an average of 2.3% per year in 2016-18, and is forecast to grow by 2.2% per year on average in 2019-23. Flat house prices will weigh on the real estate sector in 2019-20, and high household debt will dampen consumer credit growth. The services sector will also be affected in 2019-20 by slower growth in the US, reflecting the close ties between the economies. The transport and distribution segments will, however, benefit from Canada's ongoing economic expansion and a reduction in internal tariffs due to the Canadian Free-Trade Agreement signed in April 2017. The deal will also provide a boost to retail and wholesale services. Furthermore, support services for the oil and gas industry will be boosted by construction of new infrastructure to increase transport capacity for crude oil from Alberta.

Consumer price inflation fell back to 1.6% year on year in the first quarter of 2019, owing to lower petrol prices and the impact of previous monetary tightening by the central bank. However, it picked up to 2.2% in the second quarter, underpinned by higher food and energy costs. Subdued economic growth and generally lower oil prices will keep inflation at about 2%, the mid-point of the BoC's 1-3% target rate, overall in 2019-20. We forecast that the inflation rate will pick up from 2021 as the economy regains momentum and the unemployment rate starts to fall again.

The exchange rate, commodity prices and the health of the US economy will continue to shape the outlook for the current account, which will remain in deficit in 2019-23. The impact of softer global oil prices and export growth in 2019-20 will be more than offset by slower domestic demand and, therefore, import growth, compared with 2018, causing the merchandise trade deficit to narrow. As a result, we expect the shortfall on the current account to ease to an average of 2.2% of GDP in 2019-20. The CPTPP, the effects of which will begin to be felt from 2020, will result in higher trade volumes between Canada and Pacific nations. This will help to narrow the current-account deficit to a forecast 2.1% of GDP by 2023.
Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Canada
Stocks and flows
Foreign direct investment (FDI) plays an important role in the Canadian economy. According to IMF data, FDI inflows fell from US$59.6bn in 2015 to US$27.5bn in 2017, but rebounded to US$45.4bn (equivalent to 2.7% of annual GDP) in 2018. This was despite uncertainty surrounding the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) negotiations, increased US protectionism and a reduction in the US corporate tax rate, which eroded the decade-long tax advantage enjoyed by Canada. Inward FDI has held up well in the first half of 2019. The stock of FDI in Canada stood at US$973bn in 2018, equivalent to 56.8% of annual GDP.
Origin and distribution
The US is the biggest source of direct investment in Canada, with US companies owning 46% of the stock of FDI in 2018, according to Statistics Canada. However, the ratio has generally been on a downward trend since 2004, when the share was 64%. European nations are another major direct investor. The Netherlands was the largest single source among European countries, accounting for 12% in 2018 (probably for tax reasons); Luxembourg was second, with 6% (also for tax reasons), followed by the UK and Switzerland, with shares of 6% and 5% respectively. The combined share held by European countries has risen by nearly 5 percentage points since 2008, to reach 38% in 2018. Among Asian nations, China's share of the FDI stock (excluding Hong Kong Special Administrative Region) was on a long-term upward trend, albeit from a low base, but its share slipped back slightly, to 1.9% in 2018. Japan accounts for a slightly larger share, at 3.3%, but will eventually be overtaken by China. There are high levels of foreign ownership in many sectors of the economy, particularly in manufacturing, which accounted for 23% of investment holdings at the end of 2018. However, the share of manufacturing has fallen from about 33% in 2008. Mining, oil and gas accounted for the next biggest slice, at 20% of the total stock of FDI in 2018.
Determinants
Close physical proximity has been the driving force behind US foreign investment in Canada and has encouraged the integration of the two economies. Canada's attraction as a destination for US investment was enhanced when the free-trade agreement (FTA) between the two countries came into effect in 1989. Under the FTA, almost all tariffs on trade in goods were abolished, and many US companies restructured their operations to treat the US and Canada as a single market. FDI projects in Canada are vetted by a federal ministry, Innovation, Science and Economic Development Canada, but few are rejected. Under NAFTA, which superseded the FTA in 1994, less restrictive conditions exist for investments by US and Mexican firms. This will continue under NAFTA's successor, the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). Similar conditions were granted for private-sector firms from the EU as part of the Canada-EU free-trade agreement (CETA). Canada has an attractive business environment for foreign investors and scores highly in most categories of The Economist Intelligence Unit's business environment rankings.
Impact
FDI inflows make up a significant share of overall fixed investment spending. FDI inflows from the US have been a catalyst for improving efficiency, raising productivity and promoting diversification of the Canadian economy. They have also helped to generate strong trade flows between the US and Canada, create new jobs and raise living standards. However, there is a risk of foreign acquisitions "hollowing out" the Canadian economy and turning domestic manufacturing into a part of the US supply chain.
Potential
Although the stock of inward FDI as a percentage of GDP in Canada is fairly high compared with other developed countries, there is still potential for large-scale inflows in the medium term, and FDI stocks are expected to remain strong in the forecast period (2019-23). Successive Canadian governments have introduced measures to promote inward investment, including low-cost financing, increased skills training for workers and reductions in business taxes. The current federal government is also keen to promote inward investment, and has raised thresholds above which proposed investments must be reviewed to ensure that they are of net economic benefit to Canada.

Immigration will drive population growth
Canada's population was an estimated 37.1m in 2018; it expanded by 1% per year on average in 2014-18. Population growth has been steady at around this rate for the past two decades. The slow rate of growth in the working-age population has caused this cohort to shrink as a ratio of the overall population. This, combined with a growing number of retirees, will increase pressure on the country's health and pension systems in the Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast period (2019-23). The Canadian population is younger than those of most other G7 countries (with the exception of the US), and it will age more rapidly than its neighbour to the south. Like most other industrialised countries, Canada experienced a post-war baby boom (1946-65). The number of seniors as a percentage of the population in Canada has exceeded the proportion of children since 2015, revealing an ageing population. For most of the last century natural increase through birth has been the main driver of population growth in Canada. However, migration has taken over (and will remain) the major driver of growth as fertility rates remain unchanged. According to Statistics Canada, migration accounted for over three-quarters of population growth in 2017/18, the highest proportion on record, with natural increase accounting for the remainder. This trend will continue as the superior quality of life and the accommodative environment continue to attract skilled human capital, refugees and asylum-seekers.
Young immigrants will slow, but not stop, Canada's ageing trend
Immigration will dilute, but not reverse, ageing trends in Canada. It has been the main driver of population growth since the late 1990s. According to the 2016 census, 22% of the population are foreign-born individuals residing in Canada after going through the immigration process, which is among the highest proportion in the G7. It is projected that this share could reach up to 30% by 2036. The government will come under periodic pressure to reduce the number of foreign workers in order to encourage employers to hire more Canadians. The temporary foreign worker (TFW) programme is meant to help employers who cannot find workers owing to labour or skills shortages.
An unflattering report by the auditor-general, Michael Ferguson, in mid-2017 suggested that the programme was widely abused by employers and that government oversight was poor. As a result, the government has tightened compliance arrangements, including checks that potential employers have fulfilled requirements to ensure that no Canadian citizen is available to fill the position, and to ensure that potential employees understand their rights.
The percentage of Canadians of working age is forecast to fall progressively from 69% in 2013 to 65% in 2023 and 62% by 2030. By this point the baby boomers will have largely retired. It would take sustained high levels of immigration during this period to prevent the labour force from shrinking. Life expectancy in Canada has been rising in line with other industrialised countries over the past three decades, and will continue to do so. In 2012 the Conservative government announced a gradual rise in the official retirement age from 65 to 67, but this was undone by the Liberal government in 2016, which announced that it would remain at 65.

Canada will continue to provide the market opportunities consistent with a rich, mid-sized economy. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects that GDP per head will reach US$54,847 by 2023, measured at purchasing power parity (PPP) exchange rates. Household consumption per head is forecast to reach US$31,790 by 2023. We expect the economy to grow at a weaker pace in 2019-20, when US economic activity slows owing to the effects of the escalating bilateral US-China trade war. Generally, however, a stable operating environment should make Canada an attractive destination for investment, skilled workers, cutting-edge research, science and innovation. There could also be some profitable opportunities in banking, telecommunications, the media and airlines, especially as restrictions on ownership in these sectors will be gradually eased.
High income levels will continue to compensate for a mid-sized population
Canada is an attractive market on the basis of its high income levels, but market opportunities will be limited by the small size of the population, which, at about 37m in 2018, is only one-ninth the size of the US. Size could act as a deterrent to market entry for some businesses, which would prefer to establish a direct presence in the US or concentrate on other countries offering greater market scale. Uncertainty about the timeline for full ratification of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA), which will replace the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA), adds a source of risk. However, NAFTA will remain in place until the USMCA takes effect, and it is unlikely that the US government will decide not to proceed with the new deal.
Income levels tend to vary across provinces in Canada. More than 60% of the population live in Quebec and Ontario provinces, where the majority of the major urban centres are located. Rural provinces tend to have lower average incomes and are much more sparsely populated.

Canada remains one of the most developed countries in the world
Canadian social indicators rank the country among the most advanced in the world. Average life expectancy, at about 82 years, is one of the highest in the world, and the infant mortality rate stands at fewer than five deaths per 1,000 live births. After occupying the top position during most of the 1990s, Canada's ranking in the UN Development Programme's Human Development Index has dropped in recent years, and the country ranked 12th in 2018. The widely admired Canadian healthcare system (a mixture of public provision and private top-up opportunities) has led to some of the lowest mortality and illness rates in the Western world. The mortality rate per 1,000 of the population stood at 7.5 across all age groups in 2018. Yet, at 10.7% of GDP in 2018, healthcare spending was below the G7 average of 14.2%.
An ageing population will put a strain on the healthcare system
As in most developed countries, the Canadian population is ageing. This trend will drive gradually increasing demand for more healthcare, personal care and old-age care services. Other services aimed at the retired, such as leisure activities, could also get a boost. A consensus exists in Canadian society on the necessity for high spending on social services. This is being reinforced by the Liberal government, which has introduced a more generous child benefit programme. Spending initiatives announced under past governments proved popular, and Canada's social welfare system is politically secure. Canada is a world leader in all levels of education, and continued spending in this sector should allow it to retain its lead over the US and many other OECD countries.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the Canadian economy to expand by an average of 2% per year in real terms in 2019-50. This is slower than the 2.1% annual average growth achieved in 2000-18, which was supported by an increase in household debt and Canada's close economic ties with the expanding US economy, but it remains a solid pace of growth for an advanced economy. Overstretched Canadian households will be cautious about accumulating more debt, and the US economy is forecast to grow at a more moderate pace. Nonetheless, the US will remain among the more vibrant developed economies in the long term, which means that Canada will continue to benefit from the bilateral relationship. Canada will also seek to diversify its trade and economic ties in response to the wave of protectionist sentiment in the US. Developing economic ties with the EU and Asian economies will ensure alternative sources of export growth in the long term.
Initial conditions. Canada already has many of the foundations of long-term prosperity. The most important is its bilateral relationship with the US, which we do not expect to be unduly affected by the replacement of the North American Free-Trade Agreement (NAFTA) by the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). Canada also benefits from one of the best business environments in the world. It rates especially highly for openness to foreign trade, policies towards private enterprise and competition, a wide range of market opportunities and the widespread availability of corporate financing. Even in areas where it scores less highly, such as the labour market and taxes, it still fares well compared with its peers in the G7. The Canadian workforce is highly skilled, with average years of schooling per worker among the highest in the G7 countries.
Canada's productivity lags that of the US
However, Canada also faces a productivity challenge, as output per worker has lagged behind the US. Owing to the government's commitment to a swathe of infrastructure enhancements and a focus on innovation, we expect labour productivity growth to accelerate from an average of 0.8% a year in 2000-18 to 1.5% in 2019-50. Excessive wage regulation could also be addressed by the federal government to increase labour market flexibility. Despite the deregulation of most domestic consumer markets, liberalisation in several industries remains a politically contentious issue, particularly in financial services.
Demographic trends. Like many other developed nations, Canada faces the problem of an ageing population and falling birth rates. Inflows of migrant workers, and increased participation of women and older people in the workforce, will ensure that the labour force continues to expand. Nevertheless, the size of the labour force in relation to the total population will shrink over the long term.
The first baby boomers-the large number of Canadians born between 1946 and 1965-reached the retirement age of 65 in 2011, and this is triggering a jump in the proportion of retirees in the population. The share of the population over the age of 65 stood at 17.2% in 2018, and this proportion will reach 25% by 2050. This has implications for healthcare spending and other assistance to the elderly, such as homecare and institutional care, and the partially funded public pension system.
An ageing workforce weighs on productivity growth
The number of Canadian workers aged 55 or over has increased significantly in the past two decades, and the average retirement age in 2017 was 64, up from 61 in the late 1990s, according to Statistics Canada. The government will continue to encourage greater participation in the workforce among pensioners, women and discouraged workers, and to permit higher immigration. Although these measures will support continued modest growth in the workforce, improving labour productivity will be crucial for the country to maintain its high standard of living. Technological development and innovation are a major consideration in driving productivity and growth.
External conditions. The share of Canada's output that is internationally traded is high. Exports of goods and services account for nearly a third of GDP, with about 75% of exported goods sold to the US market. Canadian exporters have long hoped to reduce their reliance on the US economy. The government signed a Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA) with the EU in 2017, and has ratified the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). In the longer term, Canadian firms will increasingly try to tap the Chinese market while remaining more receptive than their US counterparts to flows of Chinese capital into the domestic economy.
Canada's institutions are strong and credible
Institutions and policy trends. Canada has strong political institutions and a reputation for sound policy. This could be tested by the Liberal government's decision to break with Canada's adherence to fiscal surpluses. We forecast that the government will run wider deficits for longer than it has promised voters. However, we also believe that the government appreciates the areas on which Canada needs to focus to improve its long-term performance. These include the need for investment in public infrastructure, and targeting education and skills training to support a largely knowledge-based workforce. Given the efforts of previous administrations to reduce the stock of public debt, the country will continue to enjoy cheap access to financing, as its debt burden will remain low.
Our long-term projections assume that the confederation remains intact. This is an important assumption, as the threat of Quebec breaking away is never absent. Support for independence is well below the levels last seen in the mid-1990s, but it could rise again if demands for greater autonomy are not fulfilled.
Long-term performance: Real GDP growth per head is forecast to average 1.3% per year in 2019-50. This is a respectable result by historical standards, with average growth in the past two decades standing at the same level. This forecast assumes rising labour productivity gains, aided by government initiatives, to mitigate the effects of an ageing population. The growth rate in the US will also play a role, given the importance of the US market for Canadian exporters, until a point when Canada is able to diversify trade relations and is less reliant on the performance of the US economy.
Our base case assumes only a modest improvement in a few select categories of an already attractive business environment, but there is still room for further gains. If the government tackles the issue of over-regulation in the labour market while committing extensive funding to improving infrastructure and skills training, long-term growth could accelerate. On the downside, the economy is vulnerable to a prolonged period of weak growth or recession should household debt burdens become impossible to service as interest rates rise, the US slip into a long recession, or the Chinese economy suffer a disorderly debt-driven downturn. Each of these scenarios would require a recovery that would reduce our long-term growth forecasts.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
This year The Economist Intelligence Unit has developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and finds that the economy will be 1% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth. As a developed economy and strong proponent of combatting climate change, Canada will enjoy a strong capacity to manage the effects of climate change through government intervention, as well as through action by consumers and businesses. Nevertheless, changes in climate will have important repercussions, particularly for the economy, owing to a significant reliance on oil and gas exports. The development of alternative resources will require heavy investment, and would mark a painful transition as labour mobility issues arise in provinces that rely on fossil fuels for employment and growth. Furthermore, changes in global temperatures will have a bearing on the agricultural sector. Prolonged winters and higher average temperatures during summer are likely to disrupt established cropping patterns, affect agricultural productivity and yields, and necessitate innovation to sustain productivity. This would put government spending under pressure, as investment would be needed to shield the country against such changes, provide assistance to affected sectors and create a better social net to protect labour markets during the phase of transition. Changing consumer tastes and preferences towards responsibly and sustainably sourced products will also drive multiple changes, such as motivating businesses to innovate supply chains and prompting elected officials to have robust climate change agendas and, consequently, more stringent environmental regulatory requirements.
Technological developments
Canada's growth prospects in the long term will rely on increased investment in science, technology and continued innovation. This will be necessary, as increased mechanisation and an ageing population will reduce the contribution that conventional factors of production, labour and capital command in determining productivity. In order to boost total factor productivity and to promote efficiency between how labour and capital resources interact, the state will play a greater role in integrating the public sphere and private organisations to drive innovation. This has been reiterated in Canada's long-term science and technology strategy. High levels of technological development would allow Canada to digitise public services in order to improve the quality and administration of services offered. Investment in advanced technology will also allow Canada to mitigate against likely labour shortages arising from the ageing population. The government is also bolstering efforts to attract investment in core research and technology areas, where the country holds a leading edge.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.
