Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US, Japanese, EU and OECD growth and inflation: OECD
World trade growth: total world exports, quantum index, UN
Oil prices: dated Brent
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
US$ effective exchange rate: IMF, IFS; nominal weighted index, 2000=100
Domestic data
GDP growth: Statistics Canada; at chained 2012 prices
Growth in expenditure components of GDP: Statistics Canada; chained 2012 prices
Sectoral GDP: Statistics Canada; chained 2012 prices
US$ GDP: Statistics Canada; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
Population: Statistics Canada
Average hourly earnings in manufacturing: Statistics Canada
Consumer prices: Statistics Canada; all items, annual % change
Exchange rates: IMF, IFS; Bloomberg; average market rates
3-month market rate: IMF, IFS; Bank of Canada Review
Current-account balance: IMF, IFS (figures may differ slightly from national source)
Abbreviations
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UN: United Nations
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Peru--highlights: Political outlook
The president, Martín Vizcarra of the centre-right Peruanos Por el Kambio, assumed office in March 2018 after his predecessor, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski (2016-18), resigned amid corruption allegations. Mr Vizcarra made anti-graft reform a centrepiece of his policy agenda. However, given that progress on passing institutional reform has almost always been precipitated by a major stand-off between the executive and the opposition-controlled legislature, Mr Vizcarra has proposed a constitutional reform to bring the general election forward by one year to April 2020, as a way of giving Peru a fresh start. Although The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that elections will advance and that a centrist government will come to power, there are significant risks to both assumptions.
Peru--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.94 6.61 49 43 4 3
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru's business environment score rises in the 2019-23 forecast period, mostly owing to improvements in the political environment and government policy towards private investment, moving Peru up to 43rd place in the global ranking, and third in the regional ranking. Peru's strengths are its openness to foreign trade-secured by multiple free-trade agreements-and its prudent macroeconomic management. The business-friendly approach that existed during the historical period (2014-18) will be deepened by the current and the prospective government. Infrastructure will expand, although significant gaps will persist. Peru's labour market, albeit improving, will remain the weakest aspect of the business environment in terms of the global and regional rankings.
Peru--highlights: Economic outlook

Exchange rate S:US$ (av) 3.3 3.3 3.4 3.3 3.2 3.2
GDP growth will average 3.7% in 2019-23, driven by a recovery in private investment. In the longer term, growth will hinge more on productivity improvements, as commodity prices will be lower than during the 2000s boom. Social and political pressure for higher public spending will persist, but the fiscal accounts will remain prudently managed and characterised by one of the lowest debt stocks in the region. The stable macroeconomic outlook will also be underpinned by low inflation and a manageable current-account deficit.
Peru--highlights: Demographic outlook

The labour force will expand more quickly than the overall population in 2019-23, contributing to a demographic bonus over the next two decades. The formal economy, despite having expanded relatively firmly in recent years, will struggle to absorb new entrants to the labour market. As a result, the level of informal employment will remain high. Underdevelopment in rural areas will encourage the trend towards urbanisation, which stands at close to 80%. There should be further improvements in education and health indicators, in line with lower levels of poverty (which has more than halved since 2000). However, high levels of deprivation will persist in rural and indigenous communities.

Peru is a fairly small market and opportunities will remain restricted by low purchasing power measured in terms of GDP per head, as well as by high levels of poverty and inequality. However, two decades of strong economic growth have gradually led to the emergence of a growing middle class, notably in the capital, Lima. Rising demand from lower-income districts has led to a transformation in consumer patterns. Although progress will be gradual, we expect this trend to continue in 2019-23. Public investment in infrastructure will support greater integration of outlying regions.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Growth in Peru's real GDP per head is forecast to be roughly stable, at around 2.4% in 2019-50. The demographic bonus will have run its course by the early 2030s, weighing on growth. Education levels will remain low, with only modest progress forecast. Low inflation and a stable currency will contribute to macroeconomic stability. Abundant opportunities in energy, mining and infrastructure will continue to attract investment. Nevertheless, Peru will remain vulnerable to fluctuations in external demand and the prices of commodities.

Background: More than 12 years of military rule ended in 1980. Following a decade of economic and social instability, the government of Alberto Fujimori (1990-2000) ended hyperinflation, advanced reforms to liberalise the economy and defeated the Maoist Sendero Luminoso insurgency. However, Mr Fujimori also subverted Peru's democratic institutions and committed grave human rights abuses, and his government collapsed over a corruption scandal. Subsequent governments have been successful in consolidating macroeconomic stability, but have largely overlooked the structural reforms required to raise productivity levels. The current president, Martín Vizcarra, has used much of his political capital to undertake political reform in order to address Peru's vast institutional deficiencies.
Political structure: The 1993 constitution established a presidential regime, elected for five years. Consecutive re-election is not permitted. A 130-member unicameral legislature-elected at the same time as the president-also sits for five years. The government is decentralising revenue and responsibility to the 25 regions, including the constitutional province of Callao.
Policy issues: The Economist Intelligence Unit assumes that there will be a continuity of orthodox economic policies and that the business environment will remain attractive. Policymaking will be guided for the foreseeable future by the competitiveness and productivity plan developed by the Vizcarra administration, which focuses on strategic policy areas, such as infrastructure, human capital development and financial inclusion. Comprehensive labour reform, however, will remain elusive. Bilateral free-trade agreements with Peru's main trading partners-including the US, China and the EU-as well as initiatives within Latin America, will help to keep investment and trade flows strong in 2019-23.
Taxation: The corporate income tax rate is 29.5% (mining companies that do not benefit from tax-stability contracts pay additional taxes). Dividends and other profit-distribution schemes are taxed at 5%. Branch-profit tax is levied at 30% and remittance tax at 10%. Interest paid abroad stands at 5%.
Foreign trade: Tariffs are levied on imports at 0%, 6% or 11%. The World Bank's calculation of the average effective tariff was 1.4% in 2014. Most non-tariff barriers have been eliminated. In 2018 merchandise export earnings increased by 8% to US$49.1bn, while the import bill grew by 8.1%, to US$41.9bn.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
The president, Martín Vizcarra of the centre-right Peruanos Por el Kambio (PPK), took office in March 2018 after his predecessor, Pedro Pablo Kuczynski (2016-18), resigned after being implicated in a corruption scandal. Mr Vizcarra is governing from a precarious position, with a series of defections from PPK in the aftermath of Mr Kuczynski's resignation leaving the ruling party with just five legislators in the 130-member Congress. However, it is not just PPK that has seen its position diminished in recent months. Political instability and high-level corruption scandals have led to the weakening of multiple legislative caucuses, including that of the dominant opposition party, Fuerza Popular (FP). Mr Vizcarra has not sought to build a multiparty governing coalition, choosing instead to use very high levels of public support for his reform agenda to pressure lawmakers into passing legislation. Consequently, relations between the executive and legislative branches have been fraught with conflict.

Political outlook: Political stability
Despite taking office under strained circumstances, Mr Vizcarra has made significant progress in enacting an agenda of institutional reform. However, as a political outsider without a governing coalition, he has been forced into employing political brinkmanship in order to get his legislative agenda passed. On multiple occasions, Mr Vizcarra has made political reforms the subject of a vote of confidence in his administration in order to force legislative debate on those issues. Under Peru's constitution, the president may dissolve Congress and call for new legislative elections if lawmakers fail to support a vote of confidence in the government on two distinct occasions. Given that the FP-dominated Congress had already not supported a vote of confidence in Mr Kuczynski's government in September 2017, a failure to address Mr Vizcarra's reform proposals could potentially have allowed him to dissolve the legislature. The tacit threat of dissolution forced lawmakers to acquiesce with the executive branch and expedite debate on political reforms.
Political frictions, however, persisted between the two branches of government. Lawmakers accused Mr Vizcarra of trying to muscle his bills through Congress, and the president accused lawmakers of diluting his reform proposals. Viewing this relationship as fundamentally unsustainable, on July 28th the president announced that he would present Congress with a constitutional reform bill to bring forward legislative and presidential elections by one year, to April 2020.
Mr Vizcarra's proposal for an early election is now dominating the political scene. Lawmakers are divided on whether or not it is the best way out of Peru's perpetual political stalemate. Irrespective of the merits of the proposal, The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that lawmakers will ultimately agree to bring forward the general election. As in previous occasions, Mr Vizcarra may use a vote of confidence to force a debate on his proposal. The president could also threaten his resignation, along with that of the vice-president, which would also trigger fresh elections. In this context, there are few political incentives for lawmakers to obstruct debate on the early-election proposal.
There are substantial risks to our assumptions. Given that lawmakers are barred from consecutive re-election, they may be unwilling to yield power in the short term, even if this stance has negative implications in the medium term for their party or their political future. As a result, they may continue to delay debate on the proposal, or threaten legal action if the president attempts to make an early election the subject of a vote of confidence. The recent resignation of the vice­president-Mercedes Aráoz (also a sitting lawmaker)-from the PPK congressional caucus, citing "a lack of internal democracy", also complicates matters. The rift between Mr Vizcarra and Ms Aráoz could significantly weaken the president's negotiating hand with Congress. (The latter could ascend to the presidency if Mr Vizcarra is impeached or resigns, assuming that she does not resign in solidarity with him.) However, we think that costs of derailing the early-election proposal-which has the support of more than two-thirds of the population-outweigh the benefits, and so lawmakers should allow its passage.
Under our baseline forecast, we expect a centrist candidate to win the presidency in 2020. Despite the increased disillusionment with the political establishment, voter appetite for a radical candidate from the left has not particularly increased. This was made evident in the 2018 local elections, when a plurality of regional governorships and district mayoralties were won by centrist, business-friendly candidates. However, the left believes that it can capitalise on the political weakness of established right-wing parties such as FP; the two left-wing parties in Congress, Frente Amplio and Nuevo Perú, have voiced support for Mr Vizcarra's proposal to advance the general election. Although we do not believe that a left-wing candidate is likely to gain sufficient traction to win the presidency, a stronger representation of the left in the next Congress could present its own set of political challenges for the next administration.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
The Vizcarra government and its successor will face the governability challenges that accompany a high level of political fragmentation. Reflecting the nature of Peru's proportional representation electoral system, no government since 2000 has come to power with a working majority in the legislature. Although this has been part of the reason that Peru's largely orthodox economic framework has held steady for multiple decades, it has also prevented successive administrations from undertaking ambitious structural reforms, such as to the labour market.
Some of the political reforms passed by the Vizcarra administration will help to address institutional deficiencies. The reform of the judicial appointment board, for instance, should help to improve the selection and functioning of the judiciary, which should translate into increased efficiency and objectivity in institutional and judicial processes, and thus greater transparency for investors. Similarly, measures to bolster political participation, regulate campaign finance and increase gender parity in Congress should also help to improve the diversity of lawmakers. Nonetheless, there will continue to be several challenges to government effectiveness, including a less than robust political culture, an ineffective bureaucracy and pervasive corruption across all levels of government.
A process of decentralising the central government's resources and powers-initiated in 2001 but largely abandoned by following governments-has been partly revived by the Vizcarra administration. Mr Vizcarra pledged increased budgetary support from the central government, as well as a reform of the mining canon (a mechanism to redistribute mining royalties to local governments), to fast-track disbursements to local social development funds. However, these measures failed to address the underlying reason that mining wealth has failed to trickle down to local communities, notably a high level of administrative corruption, and a lack of technical capacity at regional and municipal levels. Consequently, the deepening divide between national and local politics could add to the myriad existing challenges of governability.
Political outlook: Election watch
Under our baseline assumption that Mr Vizcarra's early-election bill is passed, the next presidential and legislative polls (currently scheduled for April 2021) will be held in mid-2020. Parties have yet to begin declaring their candidates for the presidency and for Congress. However, we continue to assume that a centrist candidate will be best placed to win the presidency in 2020. Despite recent disillusionment with the political establishment, the plurality of regional governorships and district mayoralties in local elections in 2018 were won by candidates who espoused pragmatic, business-friendly policies. In our view, a candidate such as Julio Guzmán, of the centrist Partido Morado, could fit the bill. Mr Guzmán was a leading contender in the 2016 presidential election until his candidacy was disqualified over a technical error in registration. However, it is still early and the lack of strong party structures facilitates the rapid ascent of personalities and political outsiders, who could yet emerge. Legislative elections are likely to produce a politically fragmented Congress, as historically has been the case in Peru. Policymaking under the prospective government will therefore still require a significant degree of cross-party consensus building.
Political outlook: International relations
Peru's major foreign-policy challenge will centre on its relationship with Venezuela. On the one hand, Peru will seek to lead the Lima Group (a transnational regional body, of which it is a founding member) in its efforts to develop a region-wide response to the rapidly growing spillover effects of the socioeconomic crisis in Venezuela. On the other hand, Peru's ability to absorb Venezuelan refugees will be limited by growing domestic concerns over the economic and security implications of mass Venezuelan immigration.
Peru will continue to support regional integration efforts, such as the Pacific Alliance (a trade pact that also includes Chile, Colombia and Mexico). Talks are ongoing to incorporate Australia, Canada, New Zealand, Singapore and Ecuador as associate members of the bloc. Members of Mercosur (the Southern Cone customs union, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay) have also stated a desire for greater integration with the Pacific Alliance, but we do not currently forecast any progress in 2019-23. Peru is also a member of the Andean Community, a customs union that includes Bolivia, Colombia and Ecuador.
Trade policy will remain a vital component of Peru's foreign policy during the forecast period. Peru already has 17 bilateral trade deals in place, covering nearly all of the world's largest economies, including Australia, Canada, China, the EU, Japan, South Korea and the US. Peru is expected to complete domestic ratification of the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (an 11-nation trade pact) by 2020.

Peru will be open to trade and will have a stable macroeconomic environment
The Economist Intelligence Unit's global business rankings measure the quality and attractiveness of the investment environment in 82 of the world's largest economies, including 12 in Latin America. Peru's business environment ranking improves slightly for the 2019-23 forecast period; the country rises to 43rd globally (from 49th in 2014-18), and moves up one place, to third in the regional rankings. Peru's improved rankings owe in part to its continued macroeconomic stability, stronger policies for competition and investment, and continued strides towards expanding international trade agreements. Since the 1990s Peru has developed a solid record of macroeconomic management, which will be strengthened over the forecast period. We assume further progress in other key areas of the business environment, including policy towards enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, market opportunities and tax policy. We expect the administration of the president, Martín Vizcarra, to continue the implementation of orthodox macroeconomic policy and rules-based fiscal management. Furthermore, despite indications of rising global protectionism, Peru will maintain its openness to foreign trade and foreign investment.
However, Peru's overall improvement in both the global and regional rankings will be constrained by categories in which improvements are generally difficult and take longer to bear fruit. This is particularly the case with the labour market, where Peru remains in 11th in the regional rankings. The Vizcarra government's plan for heavy investment in infrastructure and plans for an overhaul of labour laws will be hampered by a contentious political environment, sweeping corruption probes and burdensome bureaucracy.

Business environment outlook: Peru's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Further reforms are introduced to reduce bureaucracy and improve transparency. State launches national policies to increase productivity and boost competition.
2021-23: Government will refocus efforts to formalise small and medium-sized enterprises. Pro-competitive policies required for OECD accession are adopted.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Changes made to hydrocarbons legislation (modifying royalties and the length of contracts) to attract investment. Extension of value-added tax (VAT) rebates during the construction phase of extractive projects to secure mining investment.
2020-23: The concession process is upgraded, guaranteeing that projects are construction-ready when tendered.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Ratification of the 11-nation Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). Implementation of a bilateral trade agreement with Australia.
2021-23: A free-trade agreement with India is signed and implemented.
Taxes
2019-20: Changes to deductions for income tax are approved, as well as new requirements for companies to report beneficial ownership in tax filings.
2021-23: Tax code will be changed to close loopholes and eliminate exemptions, including those for investment in jungle regions. Government will review and maintain suspension of 5% capital-gains tax.
Financing
2019-20: Changes made to legislation for capital markets, including easing conditions for infrastructure and real-estate funds.
2021-23: New rules for investment through Pacific Alliance (Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru) so that investment mechanisms can act swiftly to finance projects. More options for financing via CPTPP and China's Belt and Road Initiative.
The labour market
2019-20: The monthly minimum wage will rise in 2020, but labour costs will not be significantly affected, owing to high rates of non-compliance with the minimum wage law. Little progress made in addressing labour rigidity.
2021-23: Government will enact modest changes to labour laws as part of its OECD accession efforts.
Infrastructure
2019-20: "Public works for taxes" mechanism expands to waterworks and other infrastructure sectors, including tourism.
2021-23: State concessions for light railway construction near Lima, the capital, and along northern coast. New Cusco airport work under way and Lima airport expansion nearing completion. Work on new mega-port on the southern coast to begin.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Continued expansion of broadband service nationally, with a new concession for broadband service for five northern regions. Government rolls out single digital platform for the state to promote electronic government.
2021-23: Government to offer over 20 regional fibre-optic projects, worth US$1.5bn, in tenders. Government services will become electronically accessible. Implementation of electronic "single window" systems to reduce state bureaucracy.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment

a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Macroeconomic environment will remain attractive to investors
Peru's macroeconomic performance will continue to underpin the business environment in 2019-23. Although economic growth will slow early in the forecast period amid domestic and external headwinds, at an average of 3.2% in 2019-20, it will remain above the regional average. Improved economic conditions in the latter half of the forecast period will help to produce GDP growth of 3.7% in 2019-23 on average. Inflation will average 2.6% in 2019-23, squarely within the 1-3% target band set by the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (BCRP, the central bank). The fiscal deficit will continue to fall, moving towards the 1% legal limit set for 2021, after which we assume that countercyclical policy will produce continued fiscal consolidation. Exports will remain strong-as will the trade surplus-as a gradual build-up of production capacity boosts mineral output, and external demand for Peru's agricultural exports remains strong. The government undertook another round of tax reform in late 2018, complemented by tax avoidance legislation in 2019, which will help to boost tax collection as a percentage of GDP. The public debt/GDP ratio will remain manageable throughout the forecast period, below the legal ceiling of 30%. Peru's reliance on raw-material exports, however, opens it to the potential for external shocks, as does its geography, which exposes it to cyclical flooding and the threat of major earthquakes. Corruption scandals and political gridlock could also impact the forecast. A proposed constitutional reform to bring forward the general election by a year, to April 2020, could also dampen investor sentiment in the near term.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.8 7.0 43 26 4 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Government looks to streamline regulation and promote competition
The score for policy towards private enterprise and competition improves during the outlook period, with Peru moving up in both the global and regional rankings. The government further strengthened the Instituto Nacional de Defensa de la Competencia y la Protección de la Propiedad Intelectual (Indecopi, the competition and intellectual property rights institute), which oversees policies to foster competition and ensure intellectual property rights. The Vizcarra administration has also continued to refine concession procedures, strengthen rules for public-private partnership (PPP) projects, and introduce new policy mechanisms, such as the co-financing of private works and the establishment of project management offices (PMOs) to improve execution. Price controls were virtually eliminated in the 1990s, and it is extremely unlikely that they will be reinstated in the forecast period. The risk from distortions, created by state ownership of enterprises, is mitigated by a strict adherence to legally binding fiscal targets.
The Vizcarra administration, as well as its successor, will not make substantial changes to the approach to public companies adopted by the previous four administrations. The government will, nevertheless, move to address problematic issues in some public enterprises. In December 2018 the government published legislation to reform the indebted Banco Agropecuario (Agrobanco, one of four public financial institutions), to establish new vehicles for small farmers to restructure debts. The government will also consider options for Petroleos del Perú (Petroperú, the state oil company) to establish partnerships with the private sector to manage its faltering 100,000-barrels/day northern oil pipeline. The pipeline has become a target of protests and was disrupted six times in the first seven months of 2019.
The government will also focus on administrative simplification during the forecast period as Peru ramps up efforts for OECD accession. Legislation was approved in July 2018 to streamline the process to obtain construction certificates and register property. As a result, the average time to obtain a building permit in Peru has dropped to 122 days, compared with an average of 153.1 days in the OECD, according to the World Bank's Doing Business 2019 report. However, reducing other regulatory hurdles will take time. It currently takes 24.5 days to start a business in Peru, compared with just 9.3 days in OECD countries, according to the Doing Business report.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.3 8.2 30 21 3 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Peru will improve the rules for foreign investment
Peru's score for policy towards foreign investment improves considerably in 2019-23, with the country moving up nine places to 21st in the global ranking, and up one place to second regionally. The improvement reflects ongoing efforts to deepen domestic capital markets, which will help to draw in foreign portfolio investment, as well as efforts to make policy towards foreign direct investment (FDI) more transparent, clear and predictable. The government will maintain the broad macroeconomic policies since the early 1990s, while making changes to encourage foreign investment, especially in infrastructure and the extractive sectors. Foreign investment is protected under the constitution, as well as through a network of 15 free-trade agreements (FTAs), and 36 bilateral investment-protection and promotion agreements. Foreign investors receive the same treatment as local investors, and can enjoy most of the tax exemptions and financing options as their domestic counterparts. Risk of expropriation of foreign assets is low, and is expected to reduce further, owing to changes in regulatory standards.
The Vizcarra administration announced major new plans for several extractive sectors. In June it created a commission that will have two years to review and propose a new electricity law that will include changes to concessions, investments and power-purchasing agreements. In July the administration announced the start of a similar process to update the 1992 General Mining Law. It also announced a new effort to work with Congress to approve changes to the organic hydrocarbons law proposed in 2017, with the aim of having the reforms in place by the start of 2020. Although ongoing congressional gridlock puts these timelines in doubt, the Vizcarra administration has also taken unilateral executive action to improve regulation in some areas. In January it approved new rules for public consultations of oil and gas concessions, and in June it revamped regulations for environmental protection for projects in the electricity sector.
The Vizcarra administration plans to focus attention on the development of industrial parks and special development zones. It published implementing legislation for special development zones in August and included industrial park development in its umbrella national competition and productivity plan, which was released in July. The national strategy for industrial parks should be in place by 2020, with the first parks operating before 2025.
The investment promotion agency (ProInversión) plans to offer (through PPPs and co-financed private initiatives) 51 projects between 2019 and 2022. These projects are expected to draw in about US$9.2bn in investment. The first of these projects, a US$269m sewage-treatment system in towns around Lake Titicaca, in the south-eastern highlands, was awarded in the first half of 2019, to a Mexican consortium, Fypasa.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
8.2 8.2 37 39 3 4
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The score for foreign trade and exchange controls is unchanged during the forecast period, but Peru falls two places globally, to 39th, and by one place regionally, to 4th, owing to improvements in other countries. Peru will retain its commitment to trade openness; more than 90% of its trade is now covered by FTAs with most of the world's largest economies. Transactions on the current and capital accounts will remain free from restrictions and the structural strength of the external position virtually eliminates the threat of exchange controls being imposed. The BCRP will continue to ease requirements on US-dollar deposits and credit from abroad, as well as intervening intermittently in the currency markets to manage liquidity and foreign-exchange inflows. The currency has been fully convertible since 1990. Peru has a tripartite tariff structure, with 70.4% of items entering tariff-free, and the remaining items paying a tariff of either 6% (20.8% of goods) or 11% (8.8% of goods).
Trade liberalisation will remain a priority in 2019-23
Trade liberalisation has remained a pillar of Peru's economic strategy since the implementation of a watershed FTA with the US in February 2009. Peru had 15 FTAs in place as of August 2018, and has signed (but not yet implemented) bilateral agreements with Australia and Guatemala. Peru also signed in March 2018 the 11-nation Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, and is expected to ratify it in 2020. Peru has ongoing trade negotiations with India, holding five rounds of talks as of August 2019; however, given the Indian government's relatively protectionist stance, there is a high risk that the FTA could be diluted to a preferential trade agreement. Peru also began negotiations with China in early 2019 to strengthen the existing trade agreement. New chapters covering intellectual property and e-commerce will be added to the existing agreement. Peru also remains engaged in the Trade in Services Agreement, one of the world's largest potential agreements, which involves more than 50 World Trade Organisation members.
The Vizcarra administration wants Peru to become a trade hub through the development of a national logistics system that would be completed by 2030. The first phase, through to 2025, will include upgrading infrastructure to allow for the integration of the existing Callao Port with a new US$3bn port in Chancay, 100 km to the north. The plan also proposes the building of a railroad between Lima (the capital) and Ica (a port city 255 km to the south).
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
6.6 7.3 27 22 3 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Reforms to the tax code will aim to reduce evasion and promote investment
Peru's score in this category improves moderately during the forecast period, moving up one place to second in the regional rankings, and up five places to 22nd in the global ranking. The improvement to the score is explained largely by changes to the tax code aimed at promoting investment, particularly through the expansion of the OxI mechanism, which allows companies to invest a percentage of their tax bill directly in infrastructure. Policies to improve the consistency and fairness of the tax system will also come into effect during the forecast period. The tax burden in Peru is not a deterrent to doing business in the country. The corporate income tax rate stands at 29.5%, while the highest marginal income tax rate is 30%-both of which are low by regional and global standards. Peru also offers investors tax-stability agreements to stimulate private investment. The government guarantees that the statutes on income tax in effect at the time of the investment contract will remain unchanged for that investment for ten years. This scheme is applicable for investments of more than US$10m in the mining and hydrocarbons sector (or US$5m in all other sectors). The tax system also offers entities a number of income tax credits and exemptions (for instance, on pre-operating expenses, interest payments and employees' health insurance premiums). Peru's score improvement is curbed by a relatively high value-added tax (VAT) rate, which stands at 18% and is unlikely to change in the forecast period. The government will continue to adjust other taxes and implement policies to eliminate exonerations and curb tax evasion and avoidance. The overall tax system will remain complex, with the time taken to prepare, file and pay taxes averaging 260 hours in Peru, compared with 159.4 hours in OECD countries, according to the World Bank's Doing Business 2019 report.
The government will regularly assess and modify the tax code to improve efficiency and to minimise economic distortions. In December 2018 the Vizcarra administration eliminated long-standing rebates on VAT and import duties for companies working in the Amazon basin, owing to criticisms that the tax breaks did not contribute to investment or development, and that the exemptions for import duties were not passed on to consumers. The government will seek to review hundreds of similar tax exonerations, which could ease its fiscal burden by as much as 2% of GDP annually.
In May the Vizcarra administration published new regulations aimed at mitigating tax avoidance. The new legislation sheds light on what uses of tax benefits-tax deductions, tax payment deferrals and tax credits-would be considered "improper". The regulations outline seven criteria that would meet such a definition. The regulations also mandate the Superintendencia Nacional de Aduanas y la Administración Tributaria (Sunat, the tax agency) to create a three-member committee to determine when a review of a tax-evasion offence is required.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
7.0 7.0 22 33 2 2
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Prudential indicators show that the banking sector remains solid
Peru's score in the financing category is unchanged during the forecast period. Its regional ranking remains the same (in second place), while its global ranking falls 11 positions to 33rd, owing to improvements in the regulatory environment in more developed countries. The regulatory framework that governs the financial sector is solid, and is likely to be strengthened in line with the Basel III framework. Although the financial sector is highly concentrated, some of the smaller banks have developed niche positions in specific types of lending. The financial sector balance sheet is strong-the non-performing loan ratio has remained relatively stable in recent years, at between 1.5% and 3%. The capital adequacy ratio is well above the legal minimum, and liquidity levels are adequate. Bank profitability is also high, with the average return on equity of the 15 banks in the financial system remaining above 18% in the past three years. We expect greater penetration of the banking sector in the forecast period, with legislation enacted in August 2018 requiring all purchases with a value greater than three tax units (one tax unit is equivalent to about US$1,250) to go through the financial system. Capital markets are shallow, but are slated to expand on the back of recent and forthcoming legislation aimed at promoting capital-market development. Peru enjoys an investment-grade credit rating, providing the state and private companies with ample channels to access financing.
The government will unveil a series of financing mechanisms for small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), as well as for small-scale farmers, to increase their presence in the financial sector and deepen financial inclusion. The state-run development bank, Cofide, will be in charge of three funds: Crecer (for SMEs), Fondo de Capital Emprendedor (for start-up capital) and Fondo para la Inclusión Financiera del Pequeño Productor Agropecuario (for small-scale farmers). The Crecer fund for SMEs is expected to start operating in December, while the other two will begin in 2021. New legislation to regulate the fintech (financial technology) sector-planned for the fourth quarter of 2019-will help to expand the financial system.
Large domestic corporations currently enjoy captive demand for their securities from three main institutional investors: the Administradoras de Fondos de Pensiones (AFPs, private-pension funds), insurance companies and mutual funds. A wider range of Peruvian companies (including medium-sized firms) have issued bonds, and equity financing will become more common during the forecast period. However, a weak corporate governance culture and concerns over public information disclosure will remain the major restriction to issuance of shares.
Further progress expected on stockmarket integration
The Bolsa de Valores de Lima (BVL, the Lima stock exchange) is small, albeit expanding. The BVL will continue its integration into the Mercado Integrado Latinoamericano (the Latin American Integrated Market)-a joint initiative of the bourses of Peru, Colombia, Chile and Mexico-to become a single unified equity and securities exchange. Harmonisation of rules has been slow, but a new "funds passport" will allow easier investment in mutual funds.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 4.9 78 77 11 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
The rigid labour market will remain an area of weakness for Peru
Peru's score in the labour category improves slightly in the forecast period, but it is the weakest indicator, keeping Peru near the bottom of both the regional and global rankings for this category. Labour rigidity will continue to hamper job creation and the low quality of education has resulted in a poorly trained workforce and low productivity. As of June, around 70% of the economically active population worked in the informal sector and only a minority of workers have access to health insurance or pensions, or pay taxes. According to the Instituto Nacional de Estadística e Informática (INEI, the national statistics institute), 34% of workers in Lima did not have access to healthcare or pensions as of June. Regional differences in employment quality and productivity levels are stark. In addition, labour market mismatch is high in Peru, with around 50% of workers either underqualified or overqualified for their job, according to OECD estimates. However, given the lack of active labour market policies, this is likely to remain a concern over the forecast period. One of the positives for Peru is that wages are largely market-determined; although a minimum wage is in place, it suffers from high rates of non-compliance. However, as a result, despite low rates of unionisation, there is a high incidence of strikes-the majority of which are over wages and working conditions.
The Vizcarra administration presented a two-pronged approach to labour market reform in its competitiveness and productivity plan, published in July. In order to address issues of labour market mismatch, the government will create a unique graduate monitoring system, aimed at better matching high-skilled labour market entrants with employers. The government will also create institutes of higher technical and vocational training for low-skilled labour market entrants. By contrast, the government will be much more cautious in pursuing legislation to reduce labour market rigidity. Successive governments have attempted labour reform since the early 2000s, but have had their efforts thwarted by popular protests. In this context, changes to labour regulation will focus on reducing non-wage hiring costs and formalising part-time work and work from home.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.3 5.3 65 59 9 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Infrastructure is set to improve but large gaps will remain
Peru's score for infrastructure improves considerably during the forecast period, moving the country up three places in the regional rankings to sixth, and six places in the global rankings, to 59th. In 2018 the Vizcarra administration managed to unlock several projects that had previously been stalled by red tape, including the US$1.3bn expansion of Lima's international airport, the US$5.4bn construction of Line 2 of the Lima Metro, and the US$600m construction of a new airport in Cusco, the principal tourist area. These projects will not be finished until nearer the latter part of the forecast period. Others will continue to be stalled for longer, including the US$7.3bn construction of a second natural-gas pipeline in the south of the country, as well as two large-scale irrigation projects: the final stage of the Chavimochic project in the north and construction of the Majes-Siguas II project in the southern Arequipa region.
Bureaucracy, corruption scandals and weak institutional capacity continue to hamper improvements in infrastructure. At end-2018 the three levels of government-municipal, regional and national-had utilised 21% of the S25.6bn (US$7.7bn) budgeted for reconstruction in 13 regions, after mass flooding during the first quarter of 2017. The inauguration of newly elected mayors and governors in January 2019 has also slowed public investment in infrastructure. Public investment was down by 6.4% from January-July 2019, compared with the same period last year; including a near-40% drop at the municipal level. Although public investment will gather pace over the forecast period, budget under-execution will remain a perennial problem, reflecting low technical capacity in the public sector and persistent mismanagement of public projects.
The government will use new models to develop infrastructure projects
The administration unveiled its new national infrastructure plan in July. This prioritises 52 projects with a combined investment value of approximately US$28bn. It is intended to help to close an infrastructure gap, which the government estimates at around US$110bn. The projects will cover six large geographical zones, but 50% of the total investment will be focused on Lima, given its population density and its importance as a commercial centre. Meeting the targets relies heavily on several different models, including PPPs and the use of PMOs. The latter was first employed in Peru for the construction of venues for the Pan American Games (a sporting competition held in Lima from the end of July through to the end of August). A British firm was hired to manage the US$1.2bn investment. The PMO model is also being used for construction of the Cusco airport. A South Korean consortium, led by Korea Airports Corporation, was selected in June to oversee the US$660m construction effort.
ProInversión announced a list of 51 infrastructure projects that it will offer in the 2019-22 period, to draw in investment of approximately US$9.2bn. Of these projects, 36% are in transport, 25% in water and sanitation, 11% in mining and energy and 10% in hospitals. The agency has concluded one process-a co-financed private investment US$269mn for a sewage treatment network in the Puno region. The government is also considering another review of its OxI mechanism, which allows companies to invest a percentage their tax bill in infrastructure. The mechanism was responsible for financing 370 projects (valued at S4bn) since its launch in 2009, to July 2019.
Railway infrastructure is set to improve during the forecast period. The government has announced plans for a light rail system connecting Lima to intermediary cities to the north and south, and another to link the northern cities of Trujillo and Piura. Peru is also working with the governments of neighbouring countries-including Bolivia, Brazil and Paraguay-to begin the construction of a cargo railway that would connect Peru's southern coast with the port of Santos in Brazil. However, the project remains in the incipient stage, and construction is unlikely to finish within the forecast period.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.3 4.7 72 67 8 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 12 countries: Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Venezuela.
Mobile-phone penetration will increase, but digital infrastructure will be lacking
Peru's score over forecast period improves, moving up five places in the global rankings, to 67th position, and one place in the regional rankings, to seventh. Penetration of information technology remains unequal: although 91.5% of the population has a mobile-phone connection, only 34% of households have at least one computer and a mere 36.7% of households have access to internet, according to the national statistics institute. Although the penetration of e-commerce is improving (more than doubling to 13% in the year leading up to March), it remains below the regional average.
In 2018 the state took steps to foster digital governance in the coming years. In particular, it created the new Secretaría de Gobierno Digital (Segdi, digital government office) to direct the digital affairs strategy of public institutions. The government also established regulations in December 2018, mandating that all state agencies and all levels of governments submit plans to provide e-government services by January 2020. The central government is also in the process of migrating to a single-state portal-an approach adopted by Argentina, Mexico and Uruguay-to drive economies of scale, to facilitate access to information and government services, and to improve data sharing between public institutions. Full migration to a single-state portal is expected by 2021.
Through the national competiveness and productivity plan, the Vizcarra administration will launch strategies to close Peru's wide gaps in research and development (R&D). According to statistics from UNESCO, Peru invests around 0.15% of GDP in R&D, compared with 0.36% in Chile, 0.24% in Colombia and 0.49% in Mexico, (the three countries that Peru is partnered with in the Pacific Alliance-a regional trade bloc). To address this deficiency, the administration plans to extend in 2019 a tax credit that allows companies to deduct up to 175% of investment in R&D from their tax bill. The state will also establish a new programme for researchers and a "science space" innovation centre before end-2021. Parallel to these efforts, the state is also focused on improving education at all levels, including university education. A three-year moratorium on the creation of new universities and satellite campuses began in 2018, so that spending on higher education is focused on improving existing capacity.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
Policy priorities will be broadly similar under the current and prospective governments, centring on anti-graft reform, pro-competition policy, infrastructure development, modernisation of the state and fiscal consolidation. The president, Martín Vizcarra, has sought to complement institutional reform efforts with legislation to promote transparency in the public sector (through the publication of visitor records for public officials) and the private sector (by strengthening protections for whistle-blowers).
The government also seeks to improve the business environment and promote growth through the implementation of a "national competitiveness plan"-aiming to raise potential GDP growth to 4.5% by 2022-but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects only modest progress on this front. Reforms will include improvements to the framework for public-private partnerships, the strengthening of skills-building programmes, digital-capacity building and the incentivisation of economic diversification. The government will also look to pass legislation to reduce high non-wage labour costs, but will make little progress on comprehensive labour reform, which is politically very sensitive.
The government will make modest advances in incentivising infrastructure investment to narrow Peru's large infrastructure gap, through legislation that expands the scope of a programme allowing companies to invest part of their tax bill in public works projects. Other policy undertakings include adapting the country's regulatory framework to OECD standards, the development of domestic financial markets and investment in digital government.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators
(% of GDP)

Budget balance -2.3 -2.0 -1.6 -1.0 -0.7 -0.5

The non-financial public-sector deficit will narrow from 2% of GDP in 2019 to 0.5% of GDP by 2023, as the government gradually dials down fiscal stimulus and recent tax reforms bolster public revenue. We expect that the public debt/GDP ratio will rise from 26.4% in 2019, to a high of 26.6% in 2020, before easing to 23.1% in 2023 as the fiscal deficit narrows. This level is low by regional and global standards.
Early in our forecast period, fiscal adjustment will come more from the expenditure side. The Vizcarra administration has established spending limits for ministries and state-owned agencies in a number of areas, to improve the efficiency of public expenditure. Current expenditure growth will also be contained by lower subsidies to the Fondo de Establización de Precios de Combustibles, a fuel-price stabilisation fund, owing to weaker oil prices in 2019-20. Capital spending will fall moderately as newly elected authorities in regional and municipal governments-who took office in January-take time to get up to speed on current and planned projects; a problem exacerbated by weak institutional capacity. This will take public expenditure as a percentage of GDP from 30.5% in 2019 to 30.1% in 2020. Assuming that prudent countercyclical fiscal policy is maintained, we expect public expenditure to stabilise at 30% of GDP in 2021-23.
Meanwhile, public revenue is expected to be roughly stable as a share of GDP in the initial part of our forecast period, at 28.5% in 2019-20, as a slight deceleration in economic growth offsets improved tax enforcement. Thereafter, we expect public revenue to rise incrementally to 29.5% of GDP by 2023, owing to a confluence of factors. These include: a more rapid expansion of formal-sector employment as economic growth accelerates once again; the gradual elimination of costly tax breaks, such as to companies based in Peru's Amazon regions; and other reforms undertaken by the Vizcarra administration to reduce tax avoidance, increase oversight by the tax authority and broaden the tax base.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy
Interest rates
(%)
  2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Short-term lending rate (av; %) 14.5 14.6 14.8 15.4 15.5 16.4
The Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (BCRP, the central bank) operates a well-established inflation-targeting regime that has been instrumental in maintaining macroeconomic stability by increasing confidence in policymaking, containing inflation expectations and reducing pass-through from price shocks. We expect there to be strong confidence in the inflation target throughout the forecast period. The BCRP has, in recent months, maintained fairly accommodative monetary policy to support economic growth. In August it cut the policy rate by 25 basis points, to 2.5%. We expect the monetary authorities to keep the policy rate on hold at this level until 2021, given our forecast for tepid growth and weak inflationary pressures in 2019-20. Thereafter, in 2021-23 the Peruvian economy will once again be on an upswing, leading to a renewed tightening cycle. Real interest rates will remain positive throughout the forecast period, but will nonetheless remain supportive of credit growth.

Economic growth so far in 2019 has been lacklustre as a result of low public investment, output disruptions in the primary sector and subdued external demand. Although we expect sequential improvements towards the end of 2019, annual growth will nonetheless be weak at 3% (relative to its historical ten-year growth rate, averaging 4.4%). The outlook for 2020 is slightly better-owing to improved global trade growth, higher copper prices and easier global financial conditions-but political uncertainty will weigh on the investment climate, restricting growth to 3.4% in 2020. The medium-term outlook remains favourable, owing to Peru's solid macroeconomic fundamentals and gradual improvements to the business climate.
On the expenditure side, private consumption will be bolstered by improved job creation, a rise in real wages and growth in consumer credit. Private investment will grow strongly throughout most of the forecast period, but the greatest gains will come from the mining sector; non-mining investment will be slower to expand. Public investment will falter at the beginning of the forecast period, owing to delays in project execution by newly elected local governments. However, it will gradually increase as authorities get up to speed and as improvements to the public-private partnership framework helps to spur investment in construction, transport and irrigation infrastructure. The rise in fixed investment will have a multiplier effect on growth through its knock-on effects on consumption. Historically, there has been evidence to support the existence of a virtuous investment-employment-consumption cycle in Peru. The contribution of the external sector to growth will be muted throughout the forecast period as increased import demand offsets higher export volumes.
A key risk to our forecast stems from weaker than expected investment in the extractives sector. This could materialise through a number of channels. For instance, an increase in trade protectionism worldwide could dampen commodities prices, reducing the profitability of mining companies. Another risk stems from disruptions to mining activity as a result of social conflict. Despite steps by the Vizcarra administration to improve dialogue between local communities and mining companies, we do not rule out the possibility of protracted anti-mining protests.
On the supply side, although the economy will remain dominated by the mining sector, the main productivity gains will come from the agro-industrial sector, which has grown rapidly in recent years. Manufacturing will continue to face constraints related to external competition, fluctuations in global demand and a lack of skilled labour. Services growth will be supported by advances in the retail, finance, tourism and transport sectors. The continued expansion of an emerging middle class will boost the services sector.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
Industry will grow by an annual average of 4.4% in 2019-23, supported by strong prices for Peru's key metals exports-particularly copper. Although copper prices have softened so far this year, amid rising trade tensions between China and the US, they will resume an upward trajectory later in our forecast period as copper stocks fall. China, which accounts for almost half of global copper consumption and is Peru's largest trade partner, will be pivotal in sustaining a tighter copper market. China's electric-vehicle market and significant investments in renewable energy infrastructure-as officials work to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions-will further help to increase copper demand. The outlook for copper consumption in India (one of Peru's fastest-growing export markets), is also broadly positive, owing to investment-led growth in that country. Although the copper-price environment will not match up with the 2006-13 boom years, it will nonetheless be supportive of investment in the extractives industry. The government calculates that mining projects, principally in copper, gold, iron ore and silver, could bring in as much as US$38bn in new investment in 2019-23. Furthermore, feasibility and engineering studies have been completed for around half of the mining projects on offer, which should consolidate the development of a new mining cycle. We expect more modest investment, as a number of projects that the government is counting on are expected to face issues related to financing or face opposition from local communities. Community groups oppose the arrival of mining investment, citing concerns over damage to the environment and the fact that not enough locals are hired to work at the mines. Anti-mining protests often turn violent and mining projects suffer delays. Nevertheless, Peru will preserve its place as a pre-eminent copper producer (it is currently the second-largest producer in the world, behind Chile) and mining output will show consistent growth.
Manufacturing will also remain fairly dynamic, despite its vulnerability to fluctuations in demand from the US and China-given their trade war-and competitiveness issues brought on by the combination of low productivity and myriad free-trade agreements (FTAs). As such, the areas that will see the most growth will be extractive or non-tradeable in nature. Significant investments in 2019-23, including in the expanding petrochemicals sector and gas-pipeline infrastructure, will boost industrial capacity in the latter part of the forecast period. Successive administrations have moved towards the medium- to long-term goal of developing industrial centres that will take advantage of the high quantity of ethane in Peruvian gas to produce polyethylene and other petrochemicals. The construction of large hydroelectric plants in the Amazon region will also boost growth in the energy sector. Construction, which has boomed in recent years, will continue to expand during the forecast period, although at a slower rate. This will be driven by the government's plans for public infrastructure projects (electrification, sanitation, housing, roads and new transport facilities in major cities), and private projects, including large retail investments in secondary cities and industrial schemes (such as a natural-gas pipeline, hydroelectric plants and mining projects).
Agriculture will record average annual growth of 4.2% in 2019-23, although the figure masks some volatility across the forecast period. Peru is carving out a niche in international markets for agro-exports, taking advantage of growing conditions at home and new opportunities created by Peru's numerous FTAs. The rapid growth of agricultural and agro-industrial activity in recent years has also led to sustained growth in formal employment; the number of new formal sector jobs created in agribusiness surged by 24% in 2018, to close to 100,000. Considerable investment in irrigation and export capacity has gone into the sector in recent years, and output will be lifted in the latter part of the forecast period by the completion of large irrigation projects in the southern and northern coastal areas. The fishing sector is expected to grow modestly, focusing largely on traditional fishmeal and fish-oil exports, as the government regulates fishing for human consumption to ensure the sustainability of fish stocks.
Services are expected to grow by an annual average of 3.5% in 2019-23, supported by an expansion in retail, finance, tourism and transport. Planned expansion of large retail chains across the capital, Lima, and in smaller cities will respond to the changing consumer patterns of a growing middle class. Tourism will gain in importance as infrastructure, such as the construction of a modern airport in Cusco that will better access to the country's main tourism destinations, improves gradually. The continued emergence of a growing middle class will boost the services sector and will gradually contribute more to Peru's GDP growth as the latest wave of investment comes to an end.

Inflationary pressures remain modest, with 12-month inflation at 2.1% in July. An expansion of the labour supply has contained wage growth, keeping demand-side pressures in check. Supply-side pressures will also be muted, owing to expected lower oil prices in 2019-20. As economic growth gathers pace in 2021-23, we expect inflation to pick up once again. We expect it to stay within the BCRP's 1-3% target range on average throughout the forecast period.

After mild depreciation in 2019-related to a general weakness of emerging-market currencies-we expect the sol to appreciate in nominal terms in 2020-23, owing to strong capital inflows. The relative attractiveness of Peruvian assets will support foreign-portfolio inflows, despite an uncertain investment climate. Foreign direct investment (FDI) will slacken slightly in 2019-20 as non-mining FDI is dampened by a challenging international environment, but we expect it to pick up in 2021-23. On this basis, we project average annual real currency appreciation of 0.7% during the forecast period, taking the sol from S3.37:US$1 at end-2018 to S3.22:US$1 at end-2023. Our forecasts assume a modicum of central bank intervention in currency markets to maintain sol competitiveness. The BCRP made purchases of US$405m in January-June to reduce appreciation pressures on the sol. Although we expect ad hoc interventions to continue, this will not produce serious currency misalignment.
The BCRP will continue to support the ongoing process of de-dollarisation and the protection of the financial sector, which is moderately exposed to currency risk. Although Peru's capital market has advanced in recent years, it remains relatively shallow, limiting the sol's exposure to emerging-market asset sell-offs.

After widening to 1.9% of GDP in 2019, the current-account deficit will narrow to 1.6% of GDP in 2020, and again to 1.4% of GDP in 2021 (at which it will stabilise for the rest of the forecast period). Commodity price shocks remain the key risk to our forecast. The trade surplus will remain large, averaging 2.6% of GDP in 2019-23. Export revenue will be supported by high copper prices and gradual improvements to productive capacities, as well as greater export-market diversification. The import bill will grow slowly in 2019-23, owing to weaker prices of oil and other intermediate goods. However, import values will grow faster from 2021 onwards, amid resurgent oil prices and greater import demand. The primary income deficit will remain large, averaging 4.7% of GDP in 2019-23, owing to profit repatriation by multinational firms in Peru. The services deficit will be roughly stable, at an average of 1% of GDP. The secondary income account (mostly inward workers' remittances) will register an average surplus of 1.5% of GDP. The current-account deficit will be more than adequately financed by inward flows of FDI, which will average 3% of GDP in 2019-23.
Foreign reserves stood at US$68.1bn on August 23rd (equivalent to about 16 months of import cover). Although reserves will rise further in nominal terms, coverage will fall to 14.5 months by 2023. Nonetheless, this will provide more than adequate protection against external shocks.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Peru
Stocks and flows
Foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows peaked in 2012 at a historic high of US$13.6bn (7.1% of GDP). FDI flows have since ebbed, reaching US$6.5bn in 2018 (2.9% of GDP). The initial decline in FDI was a result of weaker commodities prices, which dampened foreign investment in the mining sector. However, with metal prices up significantly from their 2015-16 lows, mining FDI has begun to recover. In this context, the sustained decline in FDI in 2017-18 related largely to the stagnation of non-mining investment, as corruption scandals and political crises put major infrastructure projects on hold during those years. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects FDI inflows to increase moderately, in nominal terms, over the forecast period, owing to resurgent prices for Peru's traditional exports, especially copper. At the same time, strong opportunities will open up in the energy, manufacturing, retail and infrastructure sectors. However, FDI inflows will stabilise at around 3% of GDP in 2019-23, considerably below the average of 5.6% of GDP at the height of the commodities boom in 2007-12. The stock of inward FDI totalled US$106bn at end-2018, or 47.2% of GDP. Peru does not have significant outflows of FDI; these totalled only US$19m in 2018, resulting in a stock of just US$8.8bn. Despite its small size, this stock has increased sharply over the past decade.
Origin and distribution
According to the government's investment-promotion agency, ProInversión, in 2018 Spain, the UK and Chile respectively accounted for 18%, 17% and 13% of the accumulated FDI stock in Peru, followed by the US (12%), the Netherlands (6%) and Brazil (5%). The stock of FDI was dominated by the mining sector, with 22% of the total, ahead of telecommunications (19%), finance (18%), energy (13%) and industry (12%); all other sectors had low single-digit shares. This suggests that there is considerable potential outside the traditional recipient sectors, with retail, transport, and tourism considerably underrepresented compared with their shares of FDI in similar economies. One notable investment in the past resulted from the sale of the national telephone company to Telefónica (Spain), which partly explains that country's (and the telecoms sector's) large share of the FDI stock.
Determinants
Macroeconomic stability and liberalisation in the 1990s allowed for large increases in FDI inflows, following a period of sharp economic recession in the late 1980s. Annual average inflows rose from the negligible amounts of the 1980s to US$1.7bn (3.5% of GDP) in the 1990s. During the first half of the 1990s in particular, the government aggressively pursued foreign investment in privatisation, above all in communications and financial services, and the development of abundant mining and energy resources. The implementation of business-friendly policies in the early 2000s, coupled with political stability-in addition to an ongoing rise in commodity prices throughout most of the last decade-helped to boost FDI inflows to an average of US$3.7bn in 2000-10, and to an average of US$8.3bn in 2011-15. During 2019-23 the government will continue to seek to attract private investment into mining, hydroelectricity, hydrocarbons exploration and infrastructure projects. However, risks to commodities prices will persist throughout the forecast period, especially given a recent increase in protectionist sentiment across the globe, and efforts to diversify into other sectors (such as services) could prove increasingly lucrative.
Impact
Increases in FDI during the mid-1990s funded a growing share of gross fixed investment. The impact of FDI on the wider economy in terms of technology transfer has been confined mainly to the spillover effects from a much-improved telecoms sector and a more efficient financial services sector, with investment in mining having only limited links to the rest of the economy. This is changing, as foreign investment in natural gas and hydroelectricity is improving sources of energy. The award of infrastructure concessions will also promote economic development across various regions (some of which are relatively poor). An estimated US$110bn shortfall in infrastructure and communications investment will also be a driver for increased public-private partnerships (PPPs).
Potential
In the short term, increased FDI will be driven by reinvestment of profits of foreign companies amid relatively firm economic growth, as well as robust demand for Peru's mining exports. However, attracting new investment outside the mining sector will prove more challenging. Notwithstanding ongoing efforts to streamline regulation on public tenders, PPPs in infrastructure will frequently be subject to delays, given the difficulties involved in managing various stakeholders. Regardless, Peru's improving track record of prudent policymaking, free-trade agreements with the US and the EU (which include FDI clauses), and Peru's rich hydrocarbons and minerals resources will continue to pique interest during the forecast period. Nonetheless, there are numerous risks associated with foreign investment in the mining sector including bureaucratic delays, local opposition, governability concerns, difficulty with environmental licences and uncertainty associated with metals prices. Other areas that will receive investment include hydrocarbons exploration, transport infrastructure, water and sanitation, petrochemicals, and telecoms. Non-capital investment will be led by the financial and tourism sectors.
