Working-age population will outstrip overall population growth
Population growth slowed to 1.1% per year in 2014-18, from 2.3% in the 1980s and 1.8% in the 1990s, owing to migration abroad and a declining birth rate. Population growth will tick up marginally in 2019-23-keeping it above the global average-reflecting high birth rates among lower-income households and advances in healthcare (leading to outcomes such as lower infant mortality). The population will remain younger than in most industrialised countries. A modest rise in the old-age dependency ratio-the proportion of the population above working age-will be partly offset by a decline in the young-age dependency ratio in the medium term. Dependency ratios have also been supported by the recent influx of Venezuelan migrants into Peru. According to official estimates, more than 800,000 Venezuelan refugees have settled in Peru since end-2015, with about 92% being of working age. The number of people of working age will therefore continue to rise faster than the growth of the population as a whole, providing a demographic dividend to the economy.
As with many countries in Latin America, Peru has experienced rapid urbanisation in recent decades. According to the latest estimates from the national statistics institute, 79% of the total population lived in cities in 2017, with about two-fifths of those living in Lima, the capital. Urbanisation will continue to rise during the forecast period as Peruvians seek better living and employment conditions. Informal employment, which is estimated to account for over three-quarters of the economically active population, will remain high, notably in the construction and retail sectors. Informal unemployment is expected to decline only gradually, aided by government efforts to ease labour costs for businesses via tax simplification and subsidies, but it will remain high by international standards. The unemployment rate reached a record low of 5.9% in 2014, but has been slowly creeping up as economic growth has cooled, relative to the years of the commodities boom. Although the unemployment rate has stabilised at around 6.7% over the last three years, this masks high levels of underemployment, which affects as much as one-third of those employed, and is tied to a mismatch between labour market demands and the focus and quality of education.
Demographic indicators to improve, but from a low base
Peru's demographic indicators will make progress in the next decade-as education standards rise, nutrition improves, and access to safe water and sanitation is expanded-but they will remain relatively poor. Poverty levels have declined significantly over the last decade. The proportion of the population living in poverty fell from around 37% in 2008 to 20.5% in 2018. However, there are marked regional disparities; 42% of the population in rural areas was still living below the poverty line in 2018 (down from 68.8% in 2008). According to official figures for 2018, 85% of the urban population had access to potable water through the public network (a further 10% are served, but water is not deemed potable). Meanwhile, only 75% of the rural population is reached by the public network, and a mere 9% of those served receive potable water. The extension of the water and sanitation network will remain one of the highest public healthcare priorities, and will continue to receive substantial investment in the forecast period as the government plans significant expenditure in this area in 2019-22 through ProInversión (the state investment promotion agency).
Health status indicators have improved significantly in recent decades, although regional variations in infant and maternal mortality rates are pronounced. Average life expectancy has risen to 75.9 years, according to the World Health Organisation (WHO); its figures differ from the local-source data on which The Economist Intelligence Unit's current forecasts are based. According to the World Health Statistics 2018 report published by the WHO (which for Peru contains 2015 data), maternal mortality rates have more than halved over the past 15 years (from 160 to 68 per 100,000 births), but are still above the regional average of 52. The mortality rate of children under five has been on a declining trend, reaching 15.3 per 1,000 births in 2015 (down from 40 in 2000), although it remains a serious problem, especially in the more remote rural districts. The latest cause-of-death data (2014) show that malignant tumours are the single highest cause of mortality, followed by influenza and pneumonia. Cardiovascular diseases and diabetes also rank high among the main sources of mortality. Our projections assume that there will be some progress in health statistics in 2019-23, but that Peru will continue to lag behind most other countries in the region.

The emerging middle class will expand, but remain concentrated in urban areas
Although the Peruvian consumer market will remain characterised largely by inequality, two decades of strong economic growth have gradually led to the emergence of a growing middle class. Over the past decade, the capital, Lima-where most affluent consumers are concentrated-has seen a rapid transformation in consumer patterns. Retail and entertainment chains have expanded from the traditional wealthy areas, owing to increasing demand from lower-income districts and emerging neighbourhoods (former slums) located in the periphery of the metropolitan area. This new consumer demand is also evident in secondary cities, such as Arequipa, Trujillo, Chiclayo, Cusco, Piura, Iquitos and Ica, where economic growth has had a wider impact. However, the growth of market opportunities will remain limited to urban areas, and the majority of the population (particularly in rural areas) will continue to have low disposable income during the forecast period.
The Economist Intelligence Unit expects average annual GDP growth of 3.7% in 2019-23; solid in historical terms, and an improvement over the average growth of 3.2% in 2014-18, when the economy was adjusting to the end of the last commodities supercycle. This will contribute to the continued gradual expansion of the middle class as the number of formal-sector jobs grows, albeit from a low base. The economy is expected to generate jobs for unskilled and skilled workers alike. However, those who remain in rural areas, or are confined to the informal sector by a lack of skills (where underemployment will keep the supply of labour high and crimp income), will continue to see fewer benefits.
The government's efforts to reduce labour costs-especially at small firms-could help to increase formal job creation, but despite efforts to improve educational outcomes, raising skill levels will prove challenging. Although a strengthening of existing conditional cash transfer programmes will increase purchasing power for lower-income groups, their access to consumer goods and services will remain limited. Despite a sharp reduction in overall poverty levels (from more than half the population in 2000 to less than a quarter today), indigenous communities in the Andes and the Amazon areas will remain isolated and high levels of illiteracy will persist.

Poverty and social inequality will remain barriers to market growth
Owing to still high levels of poverty and vast social inequalities, the total size of the population is a poor guide to market opportunities in Peru. The World Bank estimates the country's Gini coefficient (a widely used indicator of inequality, with zero equalling complete equality and 1 maximal inequality) at 0.433 in 2017, lower than in some other regional economies, but high by global standards. Low inflation, steady growth of real incomes and targeted poverty-alleviation programmes will gradually lift more families out of poverty, allowing the share of food in overall household expenditure to decline slowly, although it will remain high by international standards. Increased household incomes will bring about a shift in consumption patterns, with food and beverages losing ground to expenses in healthcare and telecommunications. Over time, growth of credit will encourage increased expenditure on durable consumer goods by a greater proportion of the overall population and those living outside Lima.
The market is geographically skewed, with metropolitan Lima accounting for about one-third of the population, well over 50% of all economic activity and 75% of consumer bank credit. Although Lima will continue to be the focus for investors, they will increasingly tap demand in areas outside the capital. Indeed, the last few years have seen a rapid expansion of retailers in the larger cities along the coast and in the Andes, and an expected pick-up in growth in 2019-23 will mean that this trend is likely to continue in the medium term. Greater market integration is also expected as the government continues to increase spending on infrastructure. Growth, macroeconomic stability, low tariffs and a plentiful supply of foreign exchange should allow Peru to become a more significant importer of consumer goods. This trend will be accelerated by greater access to US, Chinese and European markets under free-trade agreements. Although Peru's population is ageing, it will remain much younger than in developed markets, and the ongoing demographic boom will make consumption patterns more dynamic.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: Peru's real GDP growth averaged 3.2% between 1982 and 2015, and growth of real GDP per head averaged 1.1%. However, these figures disguise a marked improvement in economic performance during the 1990s, when the policy environment was transformed, and the economy was liberalised after a period of macroeconomic instability in the 1980s, characterised by a debt crisis and hyperinflation later in the decade. These policy improvements spurred economic growth in the 2000s and helped the economy to withstand the 2008-09 global financial crisis fairly well. Although rapid GDP growth over the past two decades has enabled Peru to catch up with the Latin American median in terms of GDP per head, it is still well below that of developed countries. Weaker external conditions and slow progress in pushing the reform agenda forwards to tackle long-standing structural issues means that Peru will continue to lag behind developed economies by 2030. Peru is well endowed with natural resources-ranging from metals and natural gas to productive agricultural land. Its main weaknesses are the poor quality of its institutions, coupled with widespread income and regional inequalities. Education levels will remain low overall, and the slow pace of institutional improvement, together with lower investment in capital spending, will be the main factors behind a slowdown in average annual growth in the second half of the long-term outlook period. Opportunities in energy and mining will continue to foster investment. Nevertheless, with export-orientated industries the mainstay of the economy, Peru will remain vulnerable to fluctuations in external demand and commodities prices.
Demographic trends: The Economist Intelligence Unit expects population growth to average 1% annually in 2019-30, before slowing to 0.57% per year in 2031-50. Fertility will decline in line with continued urbanisation, but the birth rate will remain relatively high (even by Latin American standards), and well above developed-country norms. Declining fertility and increasing life expectancy point to an ageing population. However, even by the end of the long-term forecast period, the proportion of the population aged 65 and over, at around 19%, will remain much lower than in OECD countries. Lower birth rates and the current low numbers of pensioners means that the dependency ratio (the ratio of children and elderly to the working-age population) will bottom out at 50.2% in 2020, before beginning a steady upward trend. Emigration is substantial enough to have an impact on population growth; each year, around 300,000 individuals are estimated to leave Peru to seek work abroad, although significant numbers have returned in recent years, as the economy has expanded rapidly and opportunities in traditional migrant destinations, such as Spain, have been limited. However, economic growth, by increasing disposable income for those in work, will put the option of emigration within reach of a greater proportion of the population, and the gap in economic opportunities between Peru and a variety of countries, including the US and neighbouring Chile, will remain wide. Internal migration will also have a decisive influence on the development of the economy. The level of urbanisation will rise from its present level of 79%, but it is already high by global standards, so the increase will be modest.
External conditions: The export-orientated sectors of the economy, ranging from mining to agriculture, have long been the most dynamic. Peru is expected to continue to benefit from free-trade agreements (FTAs) with the US (the main market for non-traditional exports) and China, which in 2014 replaced the US as the recipient of the largest proportion of total exports. FTAs with the EU and other Asian economies will provide similar benefits. Integration efforts within Latin America are also gaining pace, particularly under the auspices of the Pacific Alliance (an integration pact comprising Peru, Chile, Colombia and Mexico), which focuses not only on trade in goods, but also on services, capital and free movement of people. Global trade flows will outpace world output growth over the long term, and Peru's increasing integration with the world economy should allow the country to benefit from global demand. Although the Peruvian economy is highly exposed to world commodity prices, its vulnerability to external shocks will be partly mitigated by greater export-market diversification, as well as investments in supply expansion of non-traditional exports (where prices have played only a marginal role).
Institutions and policy trends: Peru's institutions were weakened during the 1990s under the rule of the then president, Alberto Fujimori (1990-2000). The media and forces in Congress became co-opted by the executive, and the political system became more authoritarian. The transition from Mr Fujimori's regime highlighted popular demands for a greater degree of effective democracy and decentralisation, made evident by rising protests in Peru's regions. Nevertheless, the quality of institutions remains weak, characterised by a politicised judiciary, widespread corruption and the lack of a strong party system, which leads to legislative fragmentation. The current president, Martín Vizcarra, who has devoted much of his efforts to overhauling the political system, succeeded in passing three major constitutional reforms in 2018: a reform of the judicial appointment board, a ban on immediate re-election of lawmakers and a reform of campaign finance. Mr Vizcarra built upon these efforts in July 2019, enacting additional political reform laws addressing issues including gender parity in the legislature, the establishment of mandatory open primary elections, and the reduction of barriers to party registration. Subsequent improvements in the selection and functioning of the legislature and the judiciary should improve confidence in Peru's democratic institutions over time. Our long-term forecast assumes that improvements in the conduct of economic policy and in the policy environment will largely be sustained. We expect the public finances to be prudently managed, characterised by low debt levels. Bureaucracy will gradually be reduced and the business environment, which in some respects remains non-conducive to entrepreneurship, will improve. Increased spending on healthcare and education will gradually have productivity-enhancing effects. Private investment will lead to improvements in infrastructure. Furthermore, a continued commitment to inflation targeting by the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank), along with responsible fiscal management and a low debt stock, will help to maintain macroeconomic stability, while a flexible exchange rate will help the economy to cope with external shocks.
Long-term performance: We forecast average real GDP growth of 3.4% per year in 2021-30, easing to an average of 3% in 2031-50; this is strong by regional standards. Past reforms-in particular the establishment of private pension funds-will continue to bear fruit, helping to deepen capital markets and raise the savings rate. Nevertheless, growth is likely to be focused on resource-intensive areas, export agriculture and specialised areas of manufacturing, such as textiles. Relatively low levels of education for the majority, coupled with low spending on research and development-at less than 1% of GDP-will constrain the economy from moving into higher value-added areas, despite frequent attempts by governments to improve domestic productive capacity. Economic performance will become more dependent on productivity gains as growth in the labour force slows and the economy remains reliant on the extractive sectors. Reflecting investments made in previous years and slow but sustained institutional improvements, labour productivity will rise by an average of 2.6% in 2019-50. We expect GDP per head, measured at purchasing-power parity levels, to increase to 28% of the US level by 2050, up from 20% in 2018.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Peru's long coastline and diverse topography leave it disproportionately exposed to the effects of climate change. It is already a warm country, given its tropical latitude, and is therefore subject to droughts and extreme weather events. Peru is further disadvantaged by the fact that more than two-thirds of the population, and most of its economic activity, is concentrated along the Pacific coast. These risks are exacerbated by Peru's economic structure; although the agricultural sector makes up only 7.5% of GDP, it accounts for nearly 30% of total employment. Furthermore, Peru is heavily reliant on agro-industrial production for its export economy, which is crucial to the health of its external accounts. Therefore, even though Peru is responsible for close to 0.1% of global carbon-dioxide emissions, it will be one of the most responsive countries in terms of implementing policy for climate change adaptation.
In April 2018 Peru became the fourth country in the Latin American and Caribbean region to institute a legal framework for climate change mitigation, in line with the commitments of the Paris Agreement (ratified by Peru in mid-2016). One of the key implications of the law is that it makes Peru's commitment to reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions by 30% by 2030, legally binding. These efforts will largely be focused on reducing emissions from deforestation and forest degradation in the Amazon region, which is responsible for the majority of greenhouse-gas emissions in Peru. The framework also seeks to promote research in climate change management, by making it a priority area for public spending. Climate financing rose exponentially, from US$400,000 in 2005 to US$426m in 2015, and will continue on a positive trajectory over the long term. This year we have developed a model to calculate the impact of climate change on long-term growth, and we find that the Peruvian economy will be 4.2% smaller in 2050 than it would have been without this hit to growth.
Technological developments
Peru's government is seeking to promote the development of new technology, both by introducing it into government services and by encouraging partnerships with the private sector. The government is working on developing a comprehensive regulatory framework aimed at encouraging investment into the growing industry by reducing regulatory uncertainty for investors. This should therefore reduce the risk of bringing new technological developments to market.
In 2012 the Peruvian government approved law 29985, on electronic money (e-money), which proved to be one of the fundamental pieces of legislation for enabling the growth of electronic-commerce (e-commerce) and mobile-commerce (m-commerce). The law allows banks and non-banking financial institutions to issue and clearly define e-money, and facilitate its use by existing companies and new start-ups.
As a result, overall e-commerce usage is increasing, driven by rising internet use by the young population, with an internet usage rate of 83% among persons aged 19-24 years. The m-commerce sector is developing particularly quickly, owing largely to greater mobile-internet coverage than wired-internet coverage, particularly in remote and rural areas. Mobile-phone penetration in Peru is high, at 91.5% in early-2019, and this is expected to increase further in the coming years. The expanding availability of third-generation (3G) and fourth-generation (4G) services will also be supportive of m-commerce expansion.
An example of innovative products using the new technology is mobile-money wallets, which have facilitated the growth of m-commerce. The government has led innovation in this space by partnering with financial institutions, telecommunications companies, microfinance institutions and other providers to offer Billetera Móvil (BiM)-the country's first fully operational national mobile-money system. This has encouraged private investors to join the scheme and offer their own m-commerce services.
Nonetheless, despite relatively low transaction costs for services such as BiM, the cost of buying a mobile phone handset is still high for some sectors, acting as a barrier to entry. For instance, mobile ownership costs 12% of total income for the poorest 40% of Peru's population, well above the industry target of 5% of total income. In addition, efforts to broaden financial inclusion will be impeded by high levels of financial illiteracy and a lack of confidence in the financial system (related to inadequate consumer-protection requirements). For logistical reasons such as these, e-commerce and m-commerce services are likely to expand most rapidly in urban areas, with take-up of new tech services being slower in Peru's most remote areas.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; The Economist Intelligence Unit is the source for all forecast data unless otherwise stated
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: dated Brent
Non-oil commodity prices: IMF, IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IMF, IFS
Domestic data
GDP, public finances, inflation, exchange rate, trade data, population, foreign direct investment (FDI): BCRP http://www.bcrp.gob.pe
US$ GDP, interest rates, balance of payments: IMF, IFS, various issues
External debt: World Bank, Global Development Finance
IMF debt stocks, flows and interest: IMF, IFS, various issues
Public finances: non-financial public sector (NFPS), excluding privatisation revenue, unless otherwise stated
PPP: purchasing power parity, average ratio of prices in Peru to prices in the US
Inflation: based on index of consumer prices for metropolitan Lima, 2009=100
Terms of trade index: World Bank, Global Development Finance; based on merchandise trade price indices, 1985=100
Exchange rate: average of bank buying and selling rate, end-period; S:US$1
Bank deposit rate: average rate offered by commercial banks on 31-to-179-day deposits
Bank lending rate: average rate charged by commercial banks on loans of 360 days or fewer
Real exchange rate: ratio of estimated annual average purchasing power parity for tradeable goods to annual average exchange rate
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
BCRP: Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (the central bank)
IFS: International Financial Statistics
Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.

Full text: Egypt--highlights: Political outlook
Egypt's political sphere will remain tightly controlled during the forecast period, reflecting the government's wariness of dissent in the delicate security and economic environment. Nevertheless, the president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, will maintain internal stability during his second term, which has been extended to 2024 as part of a package of constitutional amendments that were approved in early 2019. There is also a special dispensation for Mr Sisi to stand for a third term. All forms of protest activity will continue to be heavily repressed. The security forces will face persistent challenges from armed Islamist groups, both in northern Sinai, as part of an ongoing insurgency, and also in the form of sporadic terrorist incidents elsewhere in the country.
Egypt--highlights: Business environment outlook
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.48 5.55 73 66 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Egypt's business environment score improves in the forecast period, with its regional and global rankings rising by one and seven places, respectively, owing largely to better macroeconomic conditions and efforts to enhance the business environment. The government passed a new investment law in 2017 with further refinements in 2019 and a new law on industrial licensing, in an effort to ease crippling levels of red tape and to boost incentives for private enterprise. Consequently, there is a leap in the score for policy towards private enterprise and competition. Nonetheless, progress will be slow in certain areas owing to resistance from vested interest groups in the government and military.

Although it was formally concluded in mid-2019, Egypt remains broadly committed to the strictures of the economic reform agreement concluded with the IMF in 2016, which helped to secure significant external funding, including a US$12bn loan from the Fund. Economic reform will remain focused on fiscal and structural deficiencies, with a view to consolidating the state finances, shoring up foreign reserves and enhancing the business environment. The Economist Intelligence Unit, therefore, expects the fiscal and current-account deficits to narrow, albeit gradually. The most severe macroeconomic imbalance precipitated by the (managed) flotation of the pound in 2016 is high inflation, although this is now returning to the Central Bank of Egypt's (CBE) comfort zone of single digits. More broadly, macroeconomic stability will be achieved slowly over 2019-23, spreading to the private sector gradually, reflecting weak institutional capacity.
Egypt--highlights: Demographic outlook

Egypt will enjoy a structural demographic bonus in 2019-23, when it will experience an increase in its working-age population, and the country will retain its standing as host to the largest population in the Middle East. This will present both a demographic opportunity, owing to the presence of a sizeable, youthful workforce, and a demographic challenge if the current downwards trend in unemployment is not sustained (not our central forecast). Regardless, the spike in the cost of living since the currency flotation means that many young Egyptians will continue to seek employment in the Gulf states and elsewhere. Egypt is highly urbanised, with nearly one-tenth of the population living in Cairo.

In population terms, Egypt boasts the largest consumer market in the Middle East and North Africa. However, the potential of this market will be severely constrained in the first half of the forecast period by weak purchasing power, reflecting low wage growth amid high (albeit easing) inflation, with consumers wary of spending amid subsidy reform and recent economic instability. GDP per head figures mask deep income disparities between the rich and the poor, with most of the population in the latter category. Nevertheless, per-capita income will begin to pick up steadily in 2019-23, including in US dollar terms.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Egypt has started to address long-standing market distortions, and there is significant potential for strong real economic growth in the long term. However, success will also depend on a commitment to structural reform, as well as on major improvements to institutional effectiveness. We forecast that real GDP growth will average 3.5% a year in 2019-30 and 2.9% in 2019-50, with labour productivity growth being a significant contributor.

Background: In 1952 an army coup brought an end to the monarchy in Egypt. Two years later Gamal Abdel Nasser (1954-70), a former military officer, assumed the presidency and introduced nationalist policies. Under his successor, Anwar Sadat (1970-81), Egypt's political stance shifted towards the west and its economic policies became more liberal. Mr Sadat's signing in 1979 of a peace treaty with Israel eventually led to his assassination and the appointment of his deputy, Hosni Mubarak, as president in 1981. However, Mr Mubarak grew increasingly unpopular among Egyptians as official corruption became rampant during his three-decade tenure, and a popular uprising, backed by the military, forced his resignation in early 2011. The Muslim Brotherhood, which had been banned since 1954, won parliamentary and presidential elections in 2012. However, in the wake of mass protests, it was ousted by the military in July 2013, and the former army chief, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, was elected president by a landslide less than a year later and re-elected in 2018.
Political structure: Egypt's semi-presidential system is based on the 2014 constitution, which granted parliament wider powers, including the right to withdraw confidence from the president. However, the current parliament-elected in late 2015-lacks an effective opposition bloc. In April 2019 the constitution was amended to extend the presidential term and strengthen the powers of the office-including over parliament, the judiciary and military. Cabinet ministers are often subjected to scrutiny, which can result in their dismissal and, in some cases, court action.
Policy issues: Weak institutional capacity and stiff opposition from interest groups-chiefly employees in the state bureaucracy-often prevent economic reforms. Nonetheless, the Sisi regime is keen to enhance the business environment and consolidate the public finances through fiscal reforms.
Taxation: After multiple revisions, a presidential decree was passed in August 2015 reducing the top tax rate on companies and individuals from 25% to 22.5% on incomes of E£200,000 (US$22,523 at the pre-flotation official rate) or above. The decree also suspended a 10% capital gains tax for two years, to boost competitiveness. However, it retained a 10% tax on stock dividends. Value-added tax (VAT) of 13% was approved by parliament in August 2016 and raised to 14% in 2017/18.
Foreign trade: Egypt has a large structural trade deficit, which widened in 2018, to US$37.8bn. Despite declining hydrocarbons output, oil and gas remain the country's leading export earners. Suez Canal transit fees provide more than US$5bn a year in foreign-currency inflow, and the current account fluctuates between modest deficits and surpluses.

Political outlook: Political forces at a glance
Present government: The president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, won a second four-year term in March 2018; the present government took office in June that year, with Mustafa Madbouly replacing Sherif Ismail as prime minister. The only significant change during the following 12 months after the presidential election was the replacement of the transport minister following a train disaster in February. Domestic policy will remain largely focused on economic and social reform, but in the context of tightly controlled political process. Among the key ministers is Sahar Nasr, whose portfolio has expanded over time to include investment as well as international co-operation. (Ms Nasr was instrumental in securing a three-year US$12bn loan from the IMF in August 2016 and further funding from the World Bank.) Other key figures include the finance minister, Mohamed Maait, the foreign minister, Sameh Shoukry, and the defence minister, Mohammed Zaki.
The cabinet is largely technocratic in nature, which partly reflects the embryonic status of most political parties in Egypt and Mr Sisi's desire to contain alternative power bases. This may also reflect Mr Sisi's desire to remain neutral towards all political forces that are currently represented in parliament. Many cabinet ministers are Western-educated, and most are private-sector veterans without affiliations to political parties. The president has taken steps to boost the representation of Copts and women in the cabinet (evidenced by the rise of Ms Nasr), with some holding key posts. Although former members of the now defunct National Democratic Party are rarely selected for ministerial posts, many of the lower-ranking officials in the government served under the ousted regime of Hosni Mubarak (1981-2011).
The armed forces and their various affiliates have assumed an increasingly important role in the economy during Mr Sisi's rule, and particularly in infrastructure projects. This trend is likely to be reinforced during the forecast period. One of the most important figures in the cabinet is the new transport minister, Kamel el-Wazir, who was head of the Egyptian Armed Forces Engineering Agency prior to his appointment in March 2019. Mr el-Wazir has been given a mandate to effect a major upgrade to the railway system.
Parliamentary forces: Elections to the 596-member unicameral legislature concluded in December 2015, with pro-state parties claiming the lion's share of parliamentary seats. These include the Free Egyptians party (65 seats), the Nation's Future party (53 seats) and the decades-old Wafd party (36 seats), all of which have secular and nationalist inclinations. Mr Sisi did not form his own party to contest the election, but most of the represented factions are broadly supportive of his domestic political and economic policies. Many of the Mubarak-era loyalists who ran as independents or under the Egyptian Front coalition failed to win seats, although the success of a sizeable number of businessmen will give lobby groups a powerful voice inside the assembly. Similarly, the Salafi Nour party suffered a heavy defeat with only 11 seats, in an indication of dwindling public support for Islamists. Almost all of Egypt's existing political parties are newly founded, and all of them lack a popular and nationwide base of support. With the notable exception of the Egyptian Social Democratic Party, most of the other parties represented in parliament backed the candidacy of Mr Sisi in the 2018 presidential election. It is worth noting that Mr Sisi is not a member of a political party himself. The 2019 constitutional amendments will reduce the number of seats in the lower house to 450 from 596, and one-quarter of its seats will be reserved for women. An upper house, the Senate, will be created, with 180 members, of whom two-thirds will be elected and the remainder appointed by the president. The Senate will be consulted on a wide range of policy matters. The move is clearly aimed at further tightening the president's oversight of the legislative branch.
Political outlook: Political stability
The president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, will remain in power over the 2019-23 forecast period and beyond. Constitutional amendments ratified in April 2019 extend his current, second term from four to six years, to 2024. They also allow him to stand for a further six-year term, until 2030, and tighten his control over other branches of power in several key ways: the creation of the office of vice-president; changes to the structure of parliament-including establishing an upper house (Senate), in which one-third of members will be appointed by the president; direct presidential oversight of judicial appointments; and an expanded role for the military. Although Mr Sisi will keep a tight grip on power, crack down on public dissent and contain social instability, the centralisation of the president's authority and the extension of his term pose risks to political stability beyond 2019-23, especially if the public do not begin to see substantial benefits from economic reform. The overthrow of the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, during the 2011 Arab Spring, and the recent ousting of the presidents of Sudan and Algeria, illustrate the potential risks to long-serving authoritarian regimes. Mr Sisi, formerly the head of the armed forces, will ensure that he continues to retain the support of the military, including by allowing it to expand its business interests as a means by which to ensure regime stability in the medium term.
The risk of occasional protests will continue, especially as tough economic reforms have only recently started to translate into broader economic growth and lower unemployment. Public distaste for further instability is likely to keep such pressures muted, but continued political repression could undermine Mr Sisi's rule in the longer term. Domestic policies will focus on economic development, particularly in the restive Sinai and other deprived areas, and security. Mr Sisi will exert even tighter control over the military and internal security, taking a tough line on dissent, media freedoms and security threats, with ongoing harsh crackdowns on Islamist militants.
Although he has made some concessions under international pressure on the rights of non-governmental organisations (NGOs), Mr Sisi will retain tight control over political discourse and civil society groups. Parliament-dominated by the Support Egypt bloc-is subservient and will be further kept in check by presidential appointees to the new Senate. The most active opposition to the government will remain Sinai-based jihadi groups, as well as the deposed Muslim Brotherhood and its militant offshoots Hassm and Liwa al-Thawra. The last two groups have carried out attacks on state and security officials and on tourist sites since the removal in July 2013 of the Islamist president, Mohammed Morsi. Public sympathy for the Brotherhood has ebbed, however, amid concerns over the instability that forceful regime change would entail and the prospect of a robust security response.
The sweeping anti-terrorism offensive launched in February 2018 has inflicted severe damage on terrorist infrastructure and has helped to restore the fortunes of Egypt's vital tourism sector, but sporadic attacks will remain a threat. Although eradicating terrorism is unrealistic, given broader regional turmoil, The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the military operation will help contain the number and size of attacks. Nonetheless, there is still a considerable risk from jihadi groups, which will carry out attacks intermittently on tourist areas, as well as on military and minority religious targets.
Political outlook: Political and institutional effectiveness
Egypt's bureaucracy is arguably the largest in the region-and among the most bloated globally-with nearly 6m workers employed by the central government, according to official data. (This excludes around 3m additional workers who are employed by the state on temporary contracts.) As a result, low efficiency is particularly endemic in the government sector. This over-staffing has placed a heavy burden on the public finances and left few funds for improving public services and upgrading systems. Domestic reform is sometimes held back by the populist bent of the parliament, although it has co-operated strongly with the state on a raft of austerity measures that have helped to unlock significant multilateral financial support, such as a US$12bn credit facility from the IMF.
Mr Sisi has professed his determination to make the government more efficient and to crack down on corruption. In the 2018 Corruption Perceptions Index compiled by Transparency International, Egypt's score and rank improved, placing it 105th out of the 180 countries surveyed. The main grounds for the rise in the ranking appeared to be the anti-corruption mission assigned to the Administrative Control Authority. This body is closely tied to the presidency, and, according to a law passed in 2017, its scope is restricted to the civilian bureaucracy, which means that there is no institutional structure for scrutinising the expanding military role in the economy.
However, one of the main means of achieving this has been to enhance the role of the armed forces and the intelligence services in managing important projects and in controlling services such as the media. The prerogatives of the military were strengthened in the constitutional amendments that were approved in April 2019. These amendments also reinforced the presidency's control over the judiciary (and over military appointments). Moreover, Transparency International qualified this rise in the ranking by observing that very few improvements were evident on the ground. The tightening of restrictions on public expression has also hit civil society organisations, which are heavily constrained. The increasing centralisation of power within the presidential office and among senior military and intelligence figures is likely to yield some improvements in the efficiency of government operations, but at the expense of accountability and at the risk of fostering corruption within these privileged echelons of the state.
Another important development during the forecast period will be the transfer of government operations from Cairo to the new administrative capital, to the east. Ministries are scheduled to commence this process during 2020. The move provides an opportunity to streamline government operations through having a dedicated zone for them, with modern infrastructure and information technology services. However, there will inevitably be some disruption during the transfer.
Political outlook: Election watch
Mr Sisi has not allowed alternative political leadership to emerge-only one pro-Sisi candidate was allowed to stand in the March 2018 election-and recent constitutional and other legal changes are intended to quell the development of rival power bases. This carries a risk of sudden and volatile regime change beyond the forecast period. In the medium term, however, Mr Sisi will maintain a tight grip, with parliamentary elections (due in late 2020) likely once again to see low voter turnout. The constitutional changes also extend Mr Sisi's second presidential term from four to six years, until 2024, and allow him to stand for an additional six-year term (after which the presidential mandate will be limited to two six-year terms). Mr Sisi-who is 64 and appears to be in relatively good health-is therefore likely to remain in power until 2030. Repeatedly delayed municipal elections (due in July) are likely to take place in early 2020 instead. These are particularly important for companies, as local councils will implement Egypt's new, streamlined investment regulations at municipal level. We expect the central government to ensure that only candidates who are broadly supportive of the president's agenda are allowed to contest the elections.
Political outlook: International relations
The government's priorities will remain centred on maintaining cordial ties with the US and the EU, and building a broadening range of international links, including deepening relationships with Russia and China. It will also seek to secure maximum economic support from the Gulf Arab states and build economic ties with regional allies. We expect Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia to maintain close ties and increase joint efforts against security threats from Islamist groups and in the Red Sea, and over Libya, although regional policy priorities will not always match exactly. In mid-2017 Egypt joined its Gulf Arab allies-Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Bahrain-in a diplomatic and economic boycott of Qatar, in protest at Qatar's support for Islamists and its close relations with Iran. The boycott will remain in place, and relations between Egypt and Qatar will remain tense throughout 2019-23, although there will be some co-ordination over Gaza, where both governments are involved in peace and reconstruction efforts.
Relations with European and Asian suppliers of military hardware will remain a priority in the context of Egypt's security campaigns and geopolitical tensions in the gas-rich Eastern Mediterranean region, where Egypt is taking an increasingly central role in developing the resource. Since the discovery of major offshore natural gas reserves in 2015, Egypt has procured European defence systems and submarines to guard its gas infrastructure and to deter incursions by Turkey, which does not recognise the 2003 maritime border demarcation agreement between Egypt and Cyprus. Co-ordination with both Cyprus and Israel over gas resources will continue to build.
The development of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam by Ethiopia will severely constrain the flow of water from the Blue Nile to Egypt. Although efforts to find a negotiated solution will intensify, tensions between Egypt and Ethiopia could flare up and affect ties between Egypt and other African nations that are politically aligned with Ethiopia. However, we expect Egypt to press its case through diplomacy and do not expect a military escalation. More broadly, Egypt will seek to strengthen diplomatic and commercial ties in Africa.

Policy reforms will continue to enhance Egypt's business environment
Egypt's overall score improves in the forecast period (2019-23), and its regional and global rankings rise by one and seven places, respectively, owing to more stable political conditions, improved macroeconomic indicators and efforts to enhance the business environment as part of reforms that have been undertaken with the support of the IMF and the World Bank. The government of Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi will build on the stabilisation of the economy achieved during his first term. His current term has been extended to a six-year mandate, and he can now stand for a third term in 2024. The economy is set to grow at a faster rate in 2019-23, and business will also welcome indications that inflation is set to stabilise at a single-digit rate, which will open the way for lower interest rates and a revival of consumer demand in the latter half of the forecast period. Structural reforms will include efforts to upgrade the education system so as to equip the new generation of workers with the kind of skills that employers are seeking.
Egypt's score for taxation improves significantly, as businesses stand to benefit from the government's enhanced management of tax affairs. The Ministry of Finance is proceeding with plans to achieve full digitisation of its tax accounts, which should improve the efficiency of tax affairs and provide greater transparency. The top rate of corporate income tax is likely to remain at 22.5%, although there is a chance that it could be lowered in the second half of the forecast period. Value-added tax (VAT) was introduced at 13% in mid-2016 (rising to 14% in July 2017), replacing the 10% sales tax. Stamp duty on share transactions was introduced in July 2017 as an interim measure until the law on capital gains tax is put into effect in 2020. Businesses setting up projects on the basis of the 2017 investment law are entitled to income tax discounts of 30-50%. Following an amendment to this law in 2019, these discounts will now be available for extensions of existing projects.
The restoration of such tax incentives, which were withdrawn in 2005, will improve Egypt's competitiveness in relation to other regional investment destinations. Access to finance will be much improved, as companies will have much less difficulty in securing foreign exchange, and the increase in the government's external borrowing will free up more domestic bank liquidity for lending to the private sector. As inflation started to ease in early 2018, the Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) started an easing cycle, with four rate cuts totalling 450 basis points by August 2019. Further rate cuts are likely during the first past of the forecast period.

Business environment outlook: Egypt's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Share offerings from five state entities in the downstream petroleum sector and in 23 other state-run firms proceed. The public-private partnership (PPP) programme is revived.
2021-23: Stockmarket listing of stakes in state-run firms continues, including remaining shares in banks, although the National Bank of Egypt is kept in full public ownership.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Following the passage (and further refinement in 2019-20) of the 2017 investment law and the industrial licensing, the government actively courts foreign investment through a series of roadshows and conferences.
2021-23: The investment law is amended after complaints from foreign companies about delays and bureaucratic obstacles.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: The Central Bank of Egypt relaxes remaining capital controls that were imposed prior to the flotation of the Egyptian pound in November 2016 and ensures that banks comply with regulations regarding foreign-exchange operations.
2021-23: Remaining restrictions on imports, including tariff surcharges on goods deemed to be luxuries, are lifted.
Taxes
2019-20: The government keeps corporate income tax at 22.5%. The tax-collection system is fully digitised. Attempts to introduce new taxes face challenges but stamp duty on stockmarket transactions edges up.
2021-23: Corporate income tax is lowered, but the value-added tax (VAT) rate is increased. Capital gains tax is finally introduced in 2020, after two postponements of two and three years, respectively.
Financing
2019-20: Lending to the private sector increases as inflation and interest rates ease further.
2021-23: Foreign banks increase their direct lending to Egyptian projects, and leading Egyptian banks receive enhanced ratings from international agencies.
The labour market
2019-20: The official unemployment rate stays below 10% as economic growth accelerates, but workers push for wage increases to compensate for the erosion of real wages since 2016.
2021-23: The government faces trade union resistance to pension reforms that will push the retirement age up to 65.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Further thermal electricity-generation projects on hold until 2023 after a massive build-out ensures excess power capacity. Major new rail projects get underway, including monorail serving the new administrative capital. Work starts on a second container terminal at East Port Said. Suez development continues. New cities, slum clearance and development projects in the Sinai are prioritised.
2021-23: Road and rail connections to the 14 new satellite cities are completed. Investment in seawater desalination increases.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Firms expand their presence on e-commerce platforms, although low internet penetration remains a hindrance.
2021-23: E-government portals are put into general use to automate processes of business licensing applications.
Business environment outlook: Macroeconomic environment
