Private consumption growth is set to recover strongly in the forecast period
The macroeconomic category was one of the weakest areas of Egypt's business environment in 2014-18, but has strengthened markedly. This reflects improvements in most key indicators, including real GDP growth, fiscal deficit, external balance and inflation, as a result of reforms enacted since 2016. Set against this are a number of challenges and risk factors, in particular weak consumer demand and high levels of both domestic and external debt.
Real GDP growth has been supported by increased investment, stronger trade performance and a substantial rise in natural gas production. However, private consumption growth has been constrained by the surge in inflation in the wake of the late-2016 flotation of the local currency, which has dampened household spending. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects further moderation in inflation and the exchange rate appears set for a period of stability.
In 2017/18 the government achieved its first primary fiscal surplus in more than a decade, which will help to bring down public debt towards the government's medium-term target of below 80% of GDP.
The flotation of the currency at the end of 2016 was a shock to the country's financial system, but it has contributed to a turnaround in Egypt's balance-of-payments position. The inflow of capital in the form of loans from international institutions, sovereign bond issues and a revival in direct and indirect foreign investment has enabled the central bank to rebuild its foreign-exchange reserves to a comfortable level, and to relax capital controls. Businesses are benefiting from much-improved access to foreign exchange.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards private enterprise and competition
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.5 5.0 70 63 12 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Egypt's policy towards private enterprise and competition is likely to improve considerably over the forecast period, as the government seeks to streamline the regulatory system for investment and licensing. The country's score improves markedly and its global and regional rank both rise as a result. Most areas will see improvement. However, private businesses will have to contend with the growing involvement of the armed forces and their various commercial arms in a wide range of economic sectors.
Broadening role of military in economy could pose challenges
Efforts to promote private investment stretch back decades, but businesses still encounter a host of obstacles arising from inconsistencies in the legislation and inefficiency and corruption in the bureaucracy. The new licensing and investment laws are likely to result in some improvements, but much will depend on how they are implemented. One of the most important factors is the active role that military agencies play in business. The army frequently acts in the guise of a regulatory agency itself, by requiring permission for companies to operate in areas deemed to have a national security dimension, and military companies often compete with civilian firms, but with the advantage of being able to use cheap military assets, including land and labour. The IMF noted in its January 2018 review of its loan programme that "private-sector development may be hindered by involvement of entities under the Ministry of Defence".
Law 15 on industrial licensing and Law 72 on investment, both passed in 2017, aspire to speed up the approval processes for private companies carrying out new projects and to enhance the authority of the quasi-autonomous agencies operating under the law: the Industrial Development Agency and the General Authority for Investment.
New legislation to encourage both new and existing projects attract investment
A revision in 2019 to Law 72 now enables the expansion of existing investment projects to qualify for incentives. In the original law, these incentives were only available for new projects. The incentives include corporate tax discounts of 50% for projects in designated priority areas and 30% for projects in other areas. Another adjustment specifies that the fee for certifying signatures for contracts to set up a new project should be 0.25% of the paid-up capital, with an upper limit of E£10,000 (US$570; there was no upper limit previously).
The establishment at the end of 2015 of SCZone, an agency responsible for the Suez Canal Economic Zone, was also intended as a signal to private business that the government was serious about creating a more user-friendly regulatory environment, but it has since become more closely tied to the state sector and the armed forces
The retirement of Vice-Admiral Mohab Mamish as chairman of the Suez Canal Authority (SCA), the public-sector agency in charge of overseeing the canal, has paved the way for the agency responsible for economic development in the canal zone to regain its autonomy. Yehia Zaki, the former head of an engineering consultancy that has worked closely with the military, has been appointed chairman of SCZone The appointment of Mr Zaki is likely to be welcomed by investors, as it should enable the agency to operate more smoothly, now that its head will not have to combine this task with that of running the Suez Canal
The government has previously sought to assist domestic steel and cotton producers in the face of global pressures. Despite changes to reform competition policy, loopholes and other impediments to competition remain in certain sectors, such as telecommunications and utilities, and corruption is still a problem, especially at local government level.
Business environment outlook: Policy towards foreign investment
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.2 5.5 72 65 14 11
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Wider hard-currency availability should facilitate foreign direct investment
Egypt's score for its foreign investment policies improves for the forecast period and its global and regional rankings rise by seven and three places, respectively to 65th and 11th. The government is actively courting foreign investment through revamping the regulatory framework, including the restoration of tax incentives, and through the intensive promotion of new project proposals and zones. Foreign investors have also been encouraged by the reforms to the exchange-rate system, which have helped to ease blockages in access to foreign exchange needed to finance imports of equipment and materials and to allow for repatriation of dividends. Inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) decreased slightly in both 2017 and 2018, but this was in the context of a general global slowdown in FDI, and the government claims that Egypt's share of global FDI has increased by 4% per year over this period.
The new investment law of 2017 and the subsequent amendments in 2019 have given new powers to the General Authority for Investment, with the provision for electronic approval of project proposals. The main issues the new law has sought to address are inconsistencies in the approval process and the demand from investors for the restoration of tax incentives, which were removed in 2005 on the grounds that they led to manipulative behaviour by businesses and that they deprived the Treasury of revenue.
The efficacy of a new investments approval system will now be put to the test, and businesses setting up new projects or expanding existing ones will be entitled to claim discounts of 30-50% on their tax bills, up to the equivalent of 85% of their paid-in capital. The higher discounts will be available for projects established in areas classified as deprived and for labour-intensive projects. At the insistence of parliament, the new law allows for the creation of new special investment zones (SEZs).
New legislation allows foreign acquisitions to be included in FDI figures
The investment law was amended in 2019 to enable extensions to existing projects and the development of new product lines to benefit from the tax exemptions. The amendments also included changes to the accounting system for FDI, through giving the General Authority for Investment full authority to record inflows. The definition of FDI has been broadened to reflect international practices, including allowing foreign acquisitions of stakes of less than 10% in Egyptian entities to be recorded as FDI-a notable example is the 9% foreign shareholding in Commercial International Bank, Egypt's largest private bank. Foreign oil companies will be able to retain profits for reinvestment. Regularising the recording of flows with international norms will improve transparency, and the authorities hope that it will make for a more amenable FDI environment, especially outside of the hydrocarbons sector.
The government has provided assurances that the new investment law will bring an end to conflicts with the industrial licensing law, which also includes a streamlined approvals process. It remains doubtful whether such conflicts can be avoided in practice.
Business environment outlook: Foreign trade and exchange controls
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.2 6.0 74 72 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Foreign trade and exchange controls will ease in 2018-22
Egypt's score in this category improves, and its global and regional rankings rise by two places and one place, respectively. This reflects the positive impact of the easing of foreign-exchange controls, which is offset by the persistent difficulties that companies face in dealing with Egypt's import and export procedures. Since 1994 there have been no explicit exchange controls in Egypt, with no officially declared restrictions on foreign investors converting currency or remitting profits and capital. Egypt has also accepted the obligations of sections 2, 3 and 4 of Article VIII of the IMF's Articles of Agreement. These oblige the authorities to refrain from imposing any restrictions on payments and transfers for current-account transactions or from engaging in discriminatory currency arrangements or multiple-currency practices without the IMF's approval. Nevertheless, the authorities did impose a series of restrictions on foreign-exchange transfers after the rapid depletion of net international reserves in the wake of the 2011 revolution, and companies found it increasingly difficult to secure access to foreign exchange to finance imports and for the repatriation of dividends. The situation has improved dramatically following the flotation of the Egyptian pound in November 2016. Restrictions on cash deposits to finance imports were relaxed, and in June 2017 the central bank said that henceforth banks would be free to provide clients with foreign currency to transfer abroad, with no limit on the amount or the timeframe, removing previous restrictions placed in early 2011 and only partially relaxed in 2014 that still limited banks to one transfer per year of up to US$100,000 on behalf of individual clients.
The net international reserves of the central bank reached a record level of U$44bn in July 2018, having more than doubled since the currency's flotation in 2016, and they have since stabilised at around this level. The exchange-rate system is now operated by commercial banks, with the central bank playing no formal role in the market. The rate averaged about E£17.8:US$1 during 2017, compared with the pre-flotation official rate of E£8.88:US$1. The rate weakened slightly in the second half of 2018, amid heavy divestment by portfolio investors, but the Egyptian pound has rallied strongly in 2019 in response to renewed portfolio inflows. The currency was trading at about E£16.55:US$1 in August.
The new open foreign-exchange regime was tested in 2018 as higher interest rates in the US limited the appetite of portfolio investors for emerging markets, including Egypt. The market coped well with this test, and the CBE now has more leeway to ease monetary policy as the US authorities are poised to cut rates. The government is due to pay back about US$17bn in deposits, placed by Saudi Arabia, the UAE and Kuwait, over the next three to four years, but these facilities could be rolled over. The first repayments of the US$12bn IMF extended facility are scheduled to start in 2021, with the final repayment due in 2026. These repayments could put additional pressure on external financing capacity if positive financial market sentiment reverses and portfolio inflows come under strain, placing pressure on the currency.
Business environment outlook: Taxes
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
5.8 6.8 50 36 9 7
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Tax policy will improve but an element of unpredictability remains
Tax policy is likely to see some improvement during the forecast period, although the scale of change will not be at the rate seen in the historical period. Egypt's global and regional rankings improve by 14 and two places, respectively. The basic rate of income tax for companies was lowered to 22.5% from 25% in 2015. The government is unlikely to increase this rate during the forecast period, and there is a chance that it could lower it to 20%, the rate it applied between 2004 and 2011, in response to lobbying from the business community, which is strongly represented in parliament. Any cut in the VAT rate is unlikely, and the government may decide to increase it from 14% to 15% as a means by which to derive more tax revenue. Withholding tax is likely to remain at its current level of 20%. Following the flotation of the local currency, international banks resumed investments in Egyptian Treasury bills as the high returns and reduced foreign-exchange risk offset reservations about the withholding tax. These inflows turned into outflows in 2018 amid a cooling of international investor sentiment towards emerging markets, but recovered strongly in 2019.
The new investment law includes a provision for tax discounts of 50% for projects in priority areas and 30% for all other projects. The law was amended in 2019 to extend these exemptions to expansions of existing projects and the launch of new product lines.
Some tax measures have been deferred
A 10% capital gains tax and a similar level of tax on annual portfolio profits, passed in 2014, have been deferred several times. The tax was supposed to be applied in May 2015, but the government granted a deferral of two years. In early 2017 the government granted a further three-year deferral but decided to introduce stamp duty on listed and unlisted securities in the interim. The duty has been set at 0.125% for the first year, rising to 0.15% in the second and to 0.175% in the third year. A charge of 0.3% will be levied from both sides in acquisitions in which one-third or more of a company's equity is sold.
The new property tax law finally came into effect in 2014/15, but the first payments did not start until 2017/18. The 10% tax is charged on properties with a market value of E£2m (US$118,000) or more. The amendments include exemptions for clubs, tourist facilities and property owned by the armed forces. Valuations are to be reassessed every five years. The first reassessment has been put back to 2020 in light of the delays in collecting the tax.
Business environment outlook: Financing
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.4 6.3 68 46 12 6
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Confidence in the financial system has grown strongly
The turnaround in Egypt's balance of payments that followed the signing of a US$12bn three-year extended fund facility (EFF) with the IMF in November 2016 is the main factor behind the dramatic improvement in the score and ranking for the country in the financing category. The global rank for financing rises to 46th place, and compares with a previous ranking of 68th, which reflected the acute financial constraints with which the government and business had to grapple before the IMF deal. The regional rank moves up to 6th from 12th.
The increased confidence in the international financial system in Egypt has been reflected in the series of successful sovereign debt issues undertaken by the finance ministry since January 2017, which have raised a total of US$19.7bn. The most recent were issues of US$4bn and EUR2bn (US$2.2bn), respectively, in January and April 2019. This borrowing and the loans secured from the IMF are being used predominantly to finance the fiscal deficit, and they have also played an important part in bolstering the central bank's foreign-exchange reserves. Previously, the government had relied almost exclusively on issuing securities to local banks to finance the deficit. The shift to external deficit financing, and the steady lowering of the deficit itself, will make more liquidity available in the banking system for lending to the private sector.
Borrowing costs set to fall for Egyptian businesses in the medium term
Lending to the private sector is likely to grow during the forecast period as the CBE progressively loosens monetary policy in response to falling inflation. The surge in inflation in the wake of the November 2016 flotation prompted the CBE to push up interest rates by 700 basis points in a series of hikes, the last of which was in July 2017. Inflation started to ease at the end of 2017, and the CBE cut rates by a total of 200 basis points in 2018, bringing its main operation rate down to 17.25%. Further cuts of 100 basis points in February 2019 and 150 bps in August have brought the rate down to 14.75%. With inflation continuing to ease, and with US and European monetary authorities also on an easing cycle, businesses in Egypt can look forward to a steady lowering of their borrowing costs during the first half of the forecast period.
According to the CBE, non-performing loans (NPLs) accounted for 4.1% of total loans in March 2019, significantly lower than in 2015, when NPLs made up 7.1% of total loans. However, this improvement in loan quality has come about partly because of the preference of banks to lend to the government rather than to private businesses. As lending to business revives, we expect that the NPL ratio will also increase, but from a relatively low base.
The stockmarket attracted strong inflows of foreign portfolio invest-ment following the flotation of the pound, but there was a slowdown in 2018 amid wider concerns among international investors about emerging-market risk. The market has rallied in 2019, amid the general recovery of portfolio investment inflows. We expect Egypt to continue to attract significant levels of inward investment into equities, as a stream of initial public offerings (IPOs) by both private and partly state-owned companies come to the market, mostly from 2021. The government has announced plans for stockmarket flotation of some state assets. The EGX30 index fell by 13.3% in 2018, despite a bullish start to the year; in the first eight months of 2019, the index rose by about 10%.
According to a draft banking law that is currently under consideration by parliament, the minimum capital for commercial banks is set to rise tenfold to E£5bn (US$300m). Banks will be given three years to comply. The new capital levels have been set with a view to complying with Basel III and Basel IV regulations, and to take account of devaluation since the previous level was established in 2003. Several smaller banks are likely to merge in order to comply with the new capital requirements.
Business environment outlook: The labour market
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 5.1 77 75 14 12
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
The labour market score and ranking rise for the forecast period, in line with the general improvement in macroeconomic conditions. From a business perspective, the Egyptian labour market offers an abundance of young workers, with graduates, post-graduates and skilled and semi-skilled technicians available at very competitive rates. There are several drawbacks, however, notably the rigidity of labour market laws-which are set to become more restrictive-and regulations that make it difficult to fire workers (partly because it is an extremely costly exercise). Employers are likely to face increased pressure from workers for pay increases to compensate for the fall in real wages in recent years and the rise in the poverty rate over the past few years. Real earnings were hit hard during the surge in inflation following the 2016 devaluation, and the official poverty rate reached 32.5% in the 2017/18 fiscal year, compared with 27.8% at the time of the previous assessment, for 2014/15. Workers' bargaining power is likely to be enhanced by the recent fall in unemployment.
Unemployment is falling
After reaching almost 13% in 2016, the unemployment rate has fallen steadily over the past three years, reaching 7.5% in mid-2019. We expect unemployment to stabilise at lower levels as increased private-sector activity and an increase in job opportunities associated with major infrastructure projects, such as the Suez Canal development zone and the establishment of a new capital city provide employment. However, the fall in the official unemployment rate is partly attributable to the steady decline in the labour participation rate to 43.3% in 2018 from a recent peak of 49% in 2010, suggesting many disaffected Egyptians are no longer searching for work.
The government has sought to lessen the risk of labour unrest by announcing a significant increase in the minimum wage for all workers in the state sector, to E£2,000 (US$120) per month, with effect from July 2019. The minimum wage was previously increased to E£1,200 per month in 2014. The government also increased the basic state pension by E£150 per month to E£900. Proposed reforms to the pension system, entailing a gradual increase in the retirement age to 65 from 60 and a shift to a hybrid defined benefit/defined contribution scheme tied to average lifetime earnings, rather than final salary, could also prompt opposition from workers.
Focus on private-sector employment
The government will try to shift the burden of creating jobs back to the private sector once economic growth starts to accelerate. In 2018 it also launched education reforms tailored to improving the skills of the future labour force.
Business environment outlook: Infrastructure
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
4.8 5.3 55 59 11 10
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Egypt's score for the quality of its infrastructure improves during the forecast period, and its regional ranking rises by one place to tenth, although the global ranking slips by four positions. This reflects heavy and ongoing investment in upgrading infrastructure, with a particular focus on energy and transportation, but even with the implementation of these major projects significant gaps remain in infrastructure. The military will take a pre-eminent role in many infrastructure projects, particularly for transport
Big power capacity push
The principal focus of the investment drive in the past few years has been the energy sector. Between June 2014 and June 2018 installed electricity-generating capacity rose from 32 GW to 55 GW, as a result of a 3.6-GW emergency gas turbine installation plan, the completion of delayed projects, and the start-up of three 4.8-GW combined-cycle plants built by Siemens of Germany. The power sector has also benefited from an improvement in natural gas supply, initially through imports of liquefied natural gas (LNG), and more recently owing to a rapid rise in domestic production. There is now a comfortable surplus of more than 20 GW of capacity over peak load.
The contribution of renewable energy to total power capacity will increase over the forecast period, with the recent start-up of 1.5 GW of solar capacity developed under a feed-in tariff programme and the development of a series of large-scale wind farms and solar installations.
Work will start during the forecast period on a 4.8-GW nuclear power station at El Dabaa, west of Alexandria. The project is to be carried out by Rosatom of Russia through a directly negotiated contract, including the supply of fuel and the disposal of waste. Contracts have also been negotiated with Chinese and UAE developers for two large-scale coal-fired power stations, but there is some doubt as to whether these will go ahead.
The government is investing heavily in energy and transport infrastructure
The completion of a new 72-km channel in the Suez Canal has improved services for international shipping. A new channel has also been dredged at the northern end of the canal to upgrade access to the East Port Said container terminal and to allow for its expansion. A second terminal is likely to be built, although contract negotiations for this have so far failed to progress.
Major rail transport projects will make progress during the forecast period. These include a monorail system serving the new administrative capital and the new 6th of October City, for which a contract was signed in mid-2019 with Canada-based Bombardier. The government is also pressing ahead with upgrades to the existing rail system, which has a poor safety record. The government has invited bids for a railway linking Sokhna, on the Gulf of Suez, to the Mediterranean. Further sections of the Cairo metro will be completed during the forecast period. The road network will continue to be expanded under the supervision of the Egyptian Armed Forces Engineering Agency. These will include the completion of the Rod el-Farag axis across northern Cairo.
Business environment outlook: Technological readiness
               
Value of index a   Global rank b   Regional rank c  
2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23 2014-18 2019-23
3.5 3.3 69 74 13 13
a Out of 10. b Out of 82 countries. c  Out of 17 countries: Algeria, Bahrain, Egypt, Iran, Israel, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, Morocco, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, UAE, Angola, Kenya, Nigeria and South Africa.
Egypt is not keeping pace with technological developments
We assess Egypt's technological readiness for business as one of the country's weaknesses, based on patent applications, quality of e-commerce infrastructure, the scope of e-government and internet usage, among other criteria. Egypt's score for technological readiness falls marginally for the forecast period as it fails to keep up fully with the pace of technological change, and the country's global ranking slips owing to improvements elsewhere in that area. The Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (MCIT) was established by the government in 1999 to support and promote a national information and communications technology (ICT) sector. The main areas of focus for the ministry are telecommunications, digital citizenship, human capacity, industry development and innovation. To date, progress has been slow, as indicated by Egypt's low (albeit improving) ranking on the World Intellectual Property Organisation's 2019 Global Innovation Index at 92nd out of 129 ranked countries. The main weakness for Egypt appears to be in ICT infrastructure, while slow progress is being made in institutional capacity and market sophistication, as well as business complexity.
The ICT sector is gaining increasing attention from the government
The government envisages the technology sector as being one of the main drivers of economic growth over the next five years, including the development of new ICT investment clusters-for example, a proposed technology valley in the Suez Canal Economic Zone. However, there is a long way to go before Egypt's technological infrastructure will be ready.
According to the Ministry of Planning, Monitoring and Administrative Reform, the telecoms sector grew by 16.6% year on year in real terms in the first three-quarters of 2018/19 and the ICT sector grew by 3.8%. The telecoms sector is also growing rapidly, with the rollout of 4G and improved data provision helping to support growth in e-commerce and in the use of data services.
Egypt tested 5G mobile data during the Africa Cup of Nations in 2019 but a broader buildout will take some years, with those firms using hardware from the Chinese company, Huawei, likely to face political pressure from the US.
Economic forecast: Policy trends
A pro-business policy direction will be maintained under Mr Sisi, providing consistency during the ongoing economic transition. In the short term, economic policy will continue to be shaped by IMF-agreed conditions. In November 2016 the IMF approved a three-year US$12bn extended fund facility (EFF) for Egypt, with the final US$2bn tranche disbursed in August. Egypt is now able to raise funds elsewhere. It is therefore unlikely to seek a new funded IMF programme once the current one expires, but it has indicated interest in a looser, unfunded arrangement. Since 2016 the government has pushed through major reforms, including the introduction of value-added tax (VAT); the initial 13% rate was raised to 14% in fiscal year 2018/19 (July-June). The government has pushed through a series of cuts to fuel subsidies, most recently in April 2019, although implementation of further subsidy reforms could well be delayed by political considerations. A more flexible exchange-rate policy will stay in place.
These measures have been accompanied by structural reforms to address deficiencies in the business environment. The 2017 investment law has eased considerably the process of establishing companies and obtaining licences, with further changes planned to improve investment incentives and regularise data. Reforms have brought in significant new foreign investment, but some hurdles remain, making exporting industries uncompetitive. Moreover, the influence of powerful interest groups within government, especially the extensive and growing business interests of the military, will limit the effectiveness of the reform process. The Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) has relaxed most capital controls (introduced in 2011), owing to the growing availability of hard currency and improved access to foreign capital markets, although rollover risks remain.
The government has also resumed its sale of state assets but will proceed cautiously due to political considerations. Concerned at restoring his popularity after three years of tough economic reforms and ongoing subsidy tightening, public-sector wage and pension increases have been introduced and social safety-net programmes improved with World Bank assistance. Water and rail infrastructure and addressing rural underdevelopment-especially in the restive Sinai region-will be prioritised, as will slum clearance, although fiscal constraints will limit these efforts.
Egypt will also seek to advance its role as a regional energy hub for the Eastern Mediterranean and as a gas exporter. The 30-trn-cu-ft Zohr gasfield off the Egyptian coast-production from which began in late 2017-is the largest gasfield so far discovered in the Mediterranean and is potentially large enough to meet Egypt's entire domestic gas needs for a decade. Other gas-resource development projects have been initiated, although some have suffered setbacks. Egypt has also signed export deals with Jordan, effective from 2020, and with Israel for gas transport and processing, probably for onward export, again from 2020.
Economic forecast: Fiscal policy
Fiscal indicators

Budget balance -9.5 -6.8 -6.3 -6.0 -5.9 -5.6
Government debt 89.5 82.4 79.6 76.7 74.3 72.4
Government policy will seek to balance the goal of achieving fiscal sustainability-as illustrated by the continued reduction of the budget deficit as a share of GDP since the start of the IMF-backed reform programme-with containing public discontent over the ramifications of economic reform through supportive transfer payments for the less well-off. The decision to increase minimum levels for public-sector wages and pensions will add to the fiscal burden and slow the pace of consolidation. However, the public finances will still be strengthened in 2019-23 by rising tax revenue, in tandem with continued robust GDP growth. The government will gradually divert spending away from subsidies towards public services such as healthcare and education. The government will rely primarily on VAT to generate tax revenue. It is likely to leave the corporate tax rate unchanged at 22.5% in the early part of the forecast period in order to encourage investment. The narrowing (albeit still large) deficit will reduce crowding-out and should allow local interest-rate cuts, reducing the cost of companies' borrowing from domestic banks. The latest round of fuel-subsidy cuts, which began in April, with additional cuts in July for more widely used fuels, will increase firms' production costs, although lower global oil prices in 2019-20 and rising natural gas production from the Zohr field should help to stabilise domestic energy prices. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the fiscal deficit to narrow in 2018/19, to 6.8% of GDP, from 9.5% of GDP in 2017/18. Thereafter, the pace of decline will ease, with the deficit narrowing to 5.6% of GDP in 2022/23. International sovereign bonds will finance the bulk of the deficits, with multilateral and bilateral borrowing likely to cover the remainder.

Economic forecast: Monetary policy

Monetary policy will be used mainly to target inflation, which averaged almost 30% in 2017-after the Egyptian pound's flotation-but eased to 14.4% in 2018. This allowed the CBE to cut policy rates by 200 basis points in 2018, with a further 100-basis-point cut in February 2019. With inflation falling further, even with a fresh round of subsidy cuts pushing up local prices and interest rates moving down globally, the CBE announced an additional 150-basis-point cut in August, leaving the key policy rate at 14.25%. The CBE will be wary of the risk of currency volatility, although concerns about capital outflows are easing. Continued declines in inflation and real currency appreciation (as gas exports rise), should encourage further monetary easing and lead to improved credit conditions.

Real GDP growth reached 5.6% in 2018/19, but we expect it to slow to 5% in 2019/20 as global demand weakens. Egypt's economy will nevertheless grow strongly, expanding at an annual average rate of 5.6% in 2019-23. Lower unemployment and the improved investment climate will boost private consumption, although widespread poverty and high inflation will remain a constraint on consumer demand growth. The construction and energy sectors are the main engines of growth. In partnership with private contractors, the government is pursuing various low-income housing schemes, as well as the construction of a new (administrative) capital city, to the east of Cairo, to be completed in 2020. Production from the Zohr gasfield, which came on stream at end-2017, will sharply reduce (but not eliminate) the need for fuel imports, but capital imports will remain high to support the country's infrastructure projects. The slowdown in Europe, Egypt's main export market, will affect tourism and other sectors.
Growing confidence in the availability of hard currency will provide a much-needed boost to business sentiment and will help to attract foreign investors, especially in the latter years of the forecast period. With growth becoming increasingly broad-based and unemployment falling, consumer spending should pick up from 2020. The development of hydrocarbons resources and processing capabilities could further boost growth in the longer term.

Enlarge this image.
Economic forecast: Sectoral trends
The manufacturing sector, which includes oil refining, accounts for nearly one-tenth of real GDP, but the challenges facing the sector are numerous. Local manufacturing suffers from quality issues and is often unable to match competition from imported goods. Egyptian exports are likely to benefit in the coming years from the impact of the November 2016 currency flotation, but, so far, the competitiveness of manufactured goods has been undermined by a spike in the costs of imported intermediate goods and raw materials. Weak global demand in recent years has also been a hindrance for the sector and will also slow growth in 2019-20 as global trade performance weakens. On top of this, many factories have been forced to curtail production significantly (or even shut down) in recent years, as hard-currency shortages and central bank-imposed import controls meant that local manufacturers could not procure the necessary imports of intermediate goods and raw materials, although this has become less of a problem more recently.
The outlook for the oil and gas sector continues to improve, owing to substantial investments coming on stream from international oil companies (IOCs). Because of political instability, production in both sectors declined, and government debt owed to IOCs has built up in the aftermath of the 2011 uprising. However, the oil industtry is currently experiencing an upturn in its fortunes-aided by a modest recovery in oil prices in 2017-18-with BP advancing the development of the US$12bn West Nile Delta project to develop fields that have proven reserves of 5trn cu ft of natural gas and 55m barrels of condensates, with considerable further potential. The scheme aims to reach plateau output of 1.4bn cu ft/day from late 2019, which would be a significant addition to Egypt's current output of about 5bn cu ft/day. Of even greater significance, Italy's Eni revealed in August 2015 that it had made a historic discovery of a supergiant gasfield, the largest ever in the Mediterranean. Known as Zohr, it holds around 30trn cu ft of gas and is potentially big enough to meet Egypt's entire domestic needs and restart exports. Eni has embarked on a fast-track development of Zohr, with production beginning in late 2017, and set to reach its plateau level of 3.2bn cu ft/day in 2020; it had reached 2.7bn cu ft/day by mid-2019.
The services sector-another major employer and traditionally a significant component of the economy-has experienced unprecedented setbacks, notably the downing of a Russian airliner over Sinai by militants in October 2015 and the loss of an EgyptAir flight, which crashed into the Mediterranean in March 2016. After the Sinai crash, tourist arrivals fell to an average of about 400,000 a month (with a modest uptick in arrivals in 2017), from 900,000 on average in the six months preceding that incident. Nevertheless, the outlook for services remains positive over the long term, as shown by the strong recovery in tourist arrivals since early 2018. In 2018 there were 11.4m visitors, the highest annual total since 2012, and up by 36.8%; foreign visitor arrivals were up by a further 4% year on year in the first quarter of 2019, which suggests the pace of recovery is beginning to level off. The government has revealed an ambitious plan of boosting tourism revenue to US$26bn by 2020, but this will also depend on the level of investment in the sector and the impact of global economic conditions on tourist spending. Other important components of services, including the financial services and information and communications technology (ICT) sectors, which have been strong drivers of growth in recent years, will also continue to expand.
Construction and transport are likely to continue to be among the fastest-growing sectors. Projects such as the new administrative capital and 13 other satellite cities under development will underpin strong growth in the construction and building materials sectors. The first phase of the new capital is nearing completion, and private developers are preparing to embark on building new residential and commercial areas. The main foreign participant is China State Construction and Engineering Corporation, which is building the central business district. The new capital has generated a number of major transport schemes, notably a new monorail system that will link it to Cairo, and which will include a line from Cairo to the 6th of October City industrial and residential area to the south-west. The government is also promoting investment in logistics, including a series of inland dry ports to be carried out on a public-private partnership (PPP) basis.
Economic forecast: Inflation
% 2018 2019 2020 2021 2022 2023
Consumer prices 14.4 9.1 7.8 8.3 7.8 7.0
Despite an uptick earlier in the year and strong monthly price rises in the wake of further subsidy cuts in July, inflation fell to a four-year low that month. In 2019-20 we expect inflation to decline to an average of 8.5% a year. The effects of fuel-subsidy cuts and continued growth in non-oil commodity prices (except in 2019) will be contained by lower international oil prices. Thereafter, we expect inflation to remain close to these levels, with currency appreciation helping to offset the impact of higher international prices, but stronger domestic demand limiting falls in inflation. Overall, average annual inflation should remain in single digits, falling to 7% in 2023.

Having weakened from E£8.88:US$1, following the currency flotation in late 2016, to E£17.91:US$1 at end-2018, the pound has experienced a marked appreciation, which will be broadly sustained during the forecast period. The pound eased only slightly in the wake of the August interest-rate cut, owing to rising confidence in the CBE's management of exchange-rate policy and stronger capital inflows. In the short term, some of the recent sharp gains in the pound are likely to be reversed, but, in the longer term, there is potential for more real exchange-rate appreciation, reflecting a growing natural-resource endowment and a downwards trend in inflation. The flotation has eliminated the black market and helped to restore confidence in the pound, while allowing the banking system to capture much of the US dollar liquidity in unofficial circulation. The pound will come under renewed pressure, with the CBE or state banks selling foreign exchange in a bid to support the currency, although the level of intervention will fall, with the CBE reducing the banking sector's powers to influence the market directly. We expect sporadic volatility, but, overall, the pound will strengthen to an average of E£16.35:US$1 in 2023.

Economic forecast: Foreign direct investment in Egypt
Stocks and flows
Despite uncertainty about Egypt's political transition, foreign direct investment (FDI) rose steadily between 2012 and 2016, reaching US$8.1bn, reflecting strong global market conditions. Inflows have declined since then, to US$7.4bn in 2017 and US$6.8bn in 2018, although the government maintains that Egypt's share of global investment flows has increased. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects a recovery-initially fairly slow, reflecting global economic weakness--during the forecast period, reflecting improvements in the business environment and a wider availability of hard currency to meet business needs. We also forecast that outward direct investment will increase during the forecast period as healthier liquidity levels and easing foreign-exchange shortages enable companies to expand their overseas operations.
Origin and distribution
EU-based investors, the majority of which are British firms, have accounted for about two-thirds of total inward FDI flows to Egypt during the past five years, and the US and Arab countries have supplied most of the remainder. The UAE has been the largest source of investment among Arab countries, by a significant margin, followed by Saudi Arabia and Qatar. Chinese companies have shown increasing interest in investing in Egypt, but, according to the most recent central bank data, China only accounted for about 1% of gross FDI inflows in 2016/17 and 2017/18. A slowing Chinese economy, as well as the US-China trade and technology disputes, are likely to hamper further growth in investment from China. FDI inflows are heavily skewed towards the oil and gas sector, reflecting the major ongoing investment in developing new natural gas fields. In the first three-quarters of 2018/19, oil and gas accounted for 62% of total new FDI inflows, compared with 19% for greenfield projects and 16% for real estate.
Determinants
Besides market size and the availability of cheap labour, the main determinants of FDI include the business and legal environment and the availability of foreign exchange for imports and profit repatriation. Under the current regime, the government is seeking to resolve a number of long-running disputes with Gulf Arab (and other foreign) investors, as part of a broader effort to encourage regional players to increase their activity in Egypt. The former investment minister, Dalia Khorshid, and her successor, Sahar Nasr, have both devoted fresh energy into settling these disputes. Efforts to establish new free zones-such as the Suez Canal Development Zone-may help court investments, Downside risks to FDI will persist. These include business environment deficiencies, weak lending by domestic banks and the economic slowdown in Europe, a major source of FDI. Other potential sources of hindrance include the spillover effects of the bilateral trade dispute between the US and China.
Impact
Increased FDI has helped to transform Egypt into a more modern market economy. Foreign firms are aiding economic diversification, improving the quality of human capital through better managerial and technical skills, increasing employment opportunities and assisting the transfer of technology. Leading petroleum firms are helping the government to exploit its rich oil and gas endowment and generating budget revenue.

Egypt's population will exceed 100m by the end of the forecast period
Egypt's growing population provides opportunities but is also among the biggest challenges facing the govern-ment, as it places additional strains on the labour market and public services such as healthcare and education. The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts that the population will rise from 97.1m in 2018 to around 107.4m by 2023, an annual growth rate of 2%-nearly double the average for most developing countries-with rural areas experiencing higher growth rates than urban centres. The growth rate is likely to be different from the recent historical trend, reflecting our expectation that recently launched family-planning campaigns and the high cost of living since the 2016 currency flotation will reduce fertility rates.
Labour force to expand even faster than overall population
It is worth noting, however, that the labour force will continue to expand at a faster pace than the overall population, at about 3.7% a year in 2019-23, owing to a youthful demographic bulge. Egypt is the most populous Arab country, and even modest growth rates will result in a large increase in the population; the population increased by over 10m in 2014-18 alone.
Almost one-third of the population is below the age of 15, and more than half is below 24. About 700,000 new entrants join the labour market annually, and unemployment rose in the wake of the 2011 uprising, as real GDP growth averaged well below the 6-7% required to absorb the growing labour force. The situation was aggravated in 2011, when hundreds of thousands of migrant workers fled back to the country to escape fighting in Libya. With the economy failing to provide sufficient jobs, many Egyptians have turned to the informal sector in search of employ-ment, although they tend to be lower paid and less secure. Official data suggest that unemployment has recently been on a sharp downwards trend-falling from 12.6% in the second quarter of 2016 to 7.5% by the second quarter of 2019-the lowest level since the 2011 uprising.
Outward migration to the Gulf states, Europe and North America will continue
Outward migration from Egypt to neighbouring Gulf Arab states, Europe and North America will continue as a by-product of slow economic growth. According to CAPMAS, 9.4m Egyptians lived abroad at end-2017, and expatriate remittances are among the major sources of foreign-exchange receipts for the country. However, migrating to the oil-rich Gulf Arab states is now becoming increasingly difficult, as these countries have stepped up their programmes to increase the proportion of their own nationals in the workforce. Similarly, public opinion in Europe and North America is turning increasingly against economic migrants, which is likely to be reflected in tighter immigration rules and restrictions on foreign labour inflows.
Poverty rate continues to rise
Other consequences of Egypt's recent political and economic turbulence include a rise in the rate of poverty since 2011. According to the results of a household survey published by CAPMAS in July 2019, the poverty rate (calculated at an income below E£735.7 per head per month, equivalent to US$41 monthly or US$1.4 a day, and lower in US dollar terms then the level set in 2014/15) reached 32.5% in the 2017/18 fiscal year. This was 4.7 percentage points higher than in the previous published survey, for 2014/15, and reflected the impact of economic reforms enacted since 2016 with the support of the IMF, which have squeezed household spending power. The prime minister, Mustafa Madbouly, said that the rise in the poverty rate was relatively small in the context of the scale of the fiscal adjustment that the government had been obliged to make, and that effects had been mitigated by social protection programmes, but consumer spending has been hit. The absolute poverty rate in 2017/18 was 6.2%, according to a line set at E£490.8 per month, compared with a rate of 5.3% in 2014/15, based on income of E£322 per month.
Egypt has a highly urbanised population, with nearly 10m people living in Cairo alone. With this in mind, the government of Abdel Fattah el-Sisi has taken steps to promote internal migration from the overcrowded Nile Valley into unpopulated tracts of desert. These include a demarcation plan to create three new governorates-Central Sinai, Al Alamein and Al Wahat-bringing the total to 30. The government is also undertaking a number of major industrial projects outside urban centres, such as the Suez Canal Development Zone, with the aim of boosting employ-ment opportunities in the long-neglected rural areas. The government has embarked on the construction of 14 new satellite cities. The largest of these is the new administrative capital, which is envisaged as eventually housing 6m people.

High inflation will undermine household purchasing power in the near term
Purchasing power was eroded in the immediate aftermath of the November 2016 currency flotation, which led to severe inflationary effects. Amid this challenging backdrop, retail sales declined in 2017 in US-dollar terms-although there was some recovery in 2018 as inflation started to fall. Nonetheless, as the most populous country in the Middle East and North Africa, Egypt's size makes it an important market in the region, with huge potential (particularly in the second half of the forecast period) that will continue to grow over the long term. The population is easily accessible, not least because it is located in an extremely concentrated geographical area. That said, GDP per head remains low compared with many other countries in the region, and the headline figures mask wide disparities in income between the rich and the poor. After the flotation-induced contraction in 2017, Egypt's GDP per head is now expected to climb rapidly, reaching US$4,940 by 2023, although this will remain low by regional standards.
Nevertheless, the spending power of a sizeable minority of the population, who reside mainly in newly built cities and neighbourhoods such as New Cairo and 6th of October, is comparable to that of consumers in the industrialised world. Even with the currency-policy changes, this segment retains substantial disposable income and is prepared to spend it on consumer goods. A government survey published in July 2016 showed that the richest 10% of the population accounted for one-quarter of total spending by Egyptians. This indicates the extent of the inequality between rich and poor households in the country, with recent increases in the poverty rate likely to have intensified this polarisation. Later in the forecast period, as the economy experiences several years of broader growth and more manageable price growth, and as lower unemployment helps to boost private consumption, purchasing power will improve across a wider swathe of the population although large disparities will still remain.
In any case, despite the large population, Egypt's retail markets have seen little investment since 2011, which means that the market is undersaturated and assets are underpriced. This could provide opportunities for foreign companies seeking to establish a foothold in the country, but much will depend on the government's commitment to policy reform. Importantly, import-control measures imposed by the Central Bank of Egypt (CBE) and the government have led to supply bottlenecks for many goods, which has created a need to boost output by local manufacturers in order to fill the growing gap between supply and demand.

In common with the rest of the region, spending on food, beverages and tobacco accounts for the largest share of total consumer expenditure, and this will remain the case throughout the forecast period. Despite The Economist Intelligence Unit's forecast of recovering household incomes, mass-consumer expenditure in Egypt is likely to remain dominated by spending on basic household items, primarily food and beverages, as well as housing, although their share of spending will start to dip toward the end of the forecast period. This is because a substantial chunk of the population will remain at or just above the poverty line, which means that a large proportion of disposable income is spent on subsistence; poverty rates have risen over the historical period although they are likely to begin to edge down in the forecast period, translating into a slow shift in spending patterns among some groups.
In the long run, demand for higher-end consumer goods will be underpinned by rising incomes, employment and population growth. Demand for more sophisticated, foreign-produced electrical goods is certain to grow, not least because of mistrust of the quality of locally produced goods. Other markets will increase in importance as the forecast period progresses, however, notably transport and communications. As car ownership rises and demand for mobile and internet technology takes off, a rising proportion of household income will be spent on these items.

From May 2019 The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term growth forecasts have been revised to take into account the economic impact of climate change.
Initial conditions: Egypt began addressing decades-old market distortions in 2016, backed by significant external financial support. The government of the prime minister, Mostafa Madbouly, has retained the policies of the previous cabinet-centred around economic liberalisation, but progress has been slow at times. Moreover, the public finances are stretched, and the government continues to labour under a large (but gradually declining) fiscal deficit. Nevertheless, agreement reached with the IMF in 2016 and the subsequent economic policy changes have helped to shore up investor confidence in the economy. The economy is well diversified, and the abundance of cheap labour, coupled with its large market size, means that Egypt still has huge potential over the long term.
Demographic trends: Egypt's high population density has some advantages: access to consumers is relatively easy, especially in the two urban centres, Cairo and Alexandria. Demographic trends are broadly favourable to growth prospects, in that the working-age population will continue to rise more rapidly than the overall population throughout the forecast period owing to the youthful demographic bulge. However, this will also add to the burden on public services such as education and healthcare. The government will press ahead with projects to develop areas of the desert beyond the Nile Valley to alleviate pressure on infrastructure. This will be supported by the government's efforts to reclaim 1.5m feddans (630,000 ha) of land. With most of the land surface uninhabited, the government will push ahead with long-awaited plans to create a number of new governorates, an idea that was first mooted in 2005 and later revived by the president, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, in late 2014, who has since pushed forward with major urban construction projects, including a new administrative capital.
External conditions: External conditions will remain dependent on demand from key export markets in North America and the EU-Egypt's largest trading partner. The broader region is also embroiled in political and security turmoil, which will continue to dampen investment sentiment across the Middle East as a whole. However, over the longer term, economic recovery in Europe and the US should translate into higher inflows of foreign direct investment (FDI) as well as growing exports. Similarly, reliance on financial assistance should decline gradually as structural reforms put the economy back on a sustainable footing.
Institutions and policy trends: The present and future governments will work to streamline the bureaucracy and boost the accountability of public officials. They will also look to downsize the bloated public sector, which means that private-sector participation in the economy and attracting FDI will be key to developing the country's infrastructure and improving public services. However, such reforms will be slow and protracted, largely as a result of the presence of deeply entrenched interest groups in the government and the powerful influence of business lobby groups and of the military on the state. Moreover, democratic accountability will stay low with authority centred around the presidency. Threats to long-term political and social stability may persist, reflecting the stand-off between the state and its liberal opponents, as well as high unemployment rates and high levels of poverty.
Long-term performance: There is significant potential for strong real GDP growth over the long term. Egypt is a prime location as a base to export to Asia, Africa and Europe and has a plentiful and low-cost workforce. However, success will also depend on an ongoing commitment to economic reform and to major improvements in political and institutional effectiveness. The government must increase the efficiency of the bureaucracy; develop a more effective commercial legal system; continue to withdraw the state from economic activity; and reform the public finances. Progress is likely to be patchy, but The Economist Intelligence Unit expects real GDP growth to average 3.5% a year in 2019-30 and 2.9% in 2019-50, with labour productivity growth helping to offset slower population growth.

Long-term outlook: Long-term trends
Climate change and sustainability
Egypt has been struggling with rising temperatures in recent years, with summer heat typically averaging above 35 C. This results in spikes in energy consumption during the hot summer season by both households and industrial users. However, successive heat waves and worsening climate conditions globally could create new health dangers for residents of the country, as well as the broader Middle East and North Africa region-particularly as the summer season lengthens and humidity levels rise further. This may also reduce arable land in Egypt, which is already facing the threat of worsening water scarcity as construction of the Grand Renaissance Dam (located on the Nile, downstream in Ethiopia) is completed in the coming years. The reduced ability of the human body to cool off through sweating in higher temperatures and humidity conditions are likely to lower the productivity of workers involved in construction and other outdoor activities (even at night). All of this will boost demand for energy further as time goes by and weather conditions deteriorate. The government is increasingly looking to renewable sources, especially solar, to meet power demand, but remains heavily dependent on natural gas. As part of managing the greater demand for energy, local authorities will need to diversify the energy mix to include more renewable sources of power.
Technological developments
The government envisages the technology sector as being one of the main drivers of economic growth over the next five years, including the development of new information and communications technology (ICT) investment clusters, for example a proposed technology valley in the Suez Canal Economic Zone. Telecoms and the ICT sector have grown rapidly in recent years as 4G rollout has accelerated. Future growth is highly likely, considering the growing interest by foreigners in Egypt as a budding offshore IT centre. Indeed, despite the modest performance by regional comparison, Egypt has been gaining increasing attention by foreign companies as an outsourcing centre for IT operations-owing in part to the abundance of skilled workers and the country's proximity to European markets. A report by Gartner, an IT advisory group, ranked Egypt among the top nine locations for outsourcing in Europe, Africa and the Middle East.
There are currently more than 6,000 Egyptian companies active in the ICT sector, most of them in activities related to the internet. The government estimates that Egypt earns about US$1.5bn in annual exports of ICT-related services, and this figure is likely to climb steadily. ICT accounted for close to 4% of GDP by mid-2019, according to the government, and it plans for it to reach 5% of GDP by 2022, targeting 12% growth a year in the sector. Exports of digital services have also grown strongly. The government has begun to roll out e-government services for households in select areas; internet penetration is still fairly modest, although it is used in the business sector to a limited extent. The number of internet users rose by an estimated 15% to 45.3m in early 2019, giving Egypt an internet penetration rate of 48%, compared with only 20% in 2009. We expect internet penetration to exceed half of the population by 2020-21. About 44.3% of Egyptian households currently use the internet, according to data from the MCIT.
Long-term outlook: Methodology for long-term forecasts
The time horizon for the detailed forecasts and analysis in the Country Forecast report is a five-year period. The Main report also carries a section on the long-term outlook, including projections of key macroeconomic and market size variables up to 2050. Depending on the indicator, average growth rates in a sub-period or values at select points in time are reported. Many companies make strategic business decisions over timeframes in excess of five years. The Economist Intelligence Unit's long-term projections will provide information to facilitate such decisions. Long-term forecasts and scenarios are also vital in understanding some of the big economic issues that will shape global business in the coming decades. We are well placed to build on and extend the five-year forecasts to produce long-term projections and scenarios because of the existing forward-looking analysis and models in the Country Forecast (in particular, the business environment rankings model). These are used to forecast some of the key drivers of long-run growth, as explained in detail below.
Growth projections
The main building blocks for the long-term forecasts of key market and macroeconomic variables are long-run real GDP growth projections. We have estimated growth regressions that link real growth in GDP per head to a large set of growth determinants. The determinants of growth consist of the scope for convergence (based on initial GDP per worker at the start of a period); demographic variables; a set of policy variables (measuring the fiscal stance, openness to trade, and the government regulatory burden in product, credit and labour markets); a measure of institutional quality; geography (climate, location and the degree of primary export orientation); education levels and labour quality (as measured by mean years of schooling and life expectancy); the external economic environment (changes in the terms of trade); the level of development of information and communications technology (ICT); and historical legacies (history of independent statehood).
The regressions, which have high explanatory power for growth, allow us to forecast the long-term growth of real GDP per head for sub-periods up to 2050, on the basis of demographic projections and assumptions about the evolution of policy variables and other drivers of long-term growth.
Definitions of variables
The dependent variable is GDPG: Average annual growth in real GDP per head, measured at national constant prices.
The independent variables include:
LnGDPPL: The natural logarithm of GDP (adjusted for purchasing power parity-PPP) per worker (that is, per population aged 15-65) in constant 1980 US dollars at the start of each decade. Expressed as an index, US$=1.
LnSCHOOL: The natural logarithm of the mean years of schooling of the population aged over 15 at the start of each decade. Missing values for some countries are filled in by estimating mean years of schooling on the basis of an equation relating mean years of schooling (where available) to gross primary school enrolment ten years previously, and to secondary and tertiary enrolment ratios five years previously.
LnLIFEEXP: The natural logarithm of life expectancy at birth at the start of each decade. This variable also enters the equation in squared form, reflecting diminishing returns to growth of increases in life expectancy at high levels.
OPEN: Updated Sachs-Warner index of openness-the fraction of years during each decade in which a country is rated as an open economy according to the following four criteria: (1) average tariff rates below 40%; (2) average quota and licensing coverage of imports of less than 40%; (3) a black-market exchange-rate premium that averaged less than 20%; and (4) no extreme controls (taxes, quotas, state monopolies) on exports.
INST: Index of institutional quality (on a scale of 1-10) that is an average of five sub-indices of measures of the rule of law, quality of the bureaucracy, corruption, the risk of expropriation and the risk of government repudiation of contracts. Forecast values are based on corresponding indicators from our business environment rankings.
LABPOP: The difference between the growth rate of the working-age population (aged 15-65) and the growth rate of the total population in each decade.
TOT: The average annual rate of change of the terms of trade in a given decade.
GOVSAV: The average government savings ratio in each decade (current government revenue minus current government expenditure) expressed as a share of GDP.
TRADESH: The average share of trade (exports and imports of goods and services) in GDP, lagged by one decade to deal with the endogeneity of growth and trade.
GOVREG: An index on a scale of 1-10 of regulation of product, credit and labour markets. For forecast periods, the composite index is based on seven indicators from three categories of our business environment rankings model-from Policy towards private enterprise (ease of setting up new businesses, freedom to compete, price controls); from Financing (openness of the banking system, financial market distortions); and from Labour markets (restrictiveness of labour laws, wage regulation).
ICT: An index, on a scale of 1-10, of the development of information and communications infrastructure.
Control variables include PRIMARY: share of the exports of primary products in GDP at the start of a decade; TROPIC: percentage of the land area within a country that has a tropical climate; COLONY: history of independent statehood-a dummy variable taking the value of 1 if a country was a colony before 1945; and, in some specifications, regional dummy variables.
Summary of findings
As in other studies, income per head and human capital are found to be important determinants of growth, with the coefficient on the logarithm of GDP per worker suggesting a relatively modest pace of convergence. The measures of institutional quality and of government regulation enter significantly in all specifications. We found a strong positive impact on growth of government savings and openness in all specifications. The criteria for classifying countries as open are quite permissive. The crucial aspect of trade policy captured by the measure is that it is a high level of distortion, rather than modest levels, that is deleterious for growth. The trade share variable is also moderately significant. The openness index (which is more of a true measure of policy) is hardly affected by the inclusion of trade/GDP shares in the equation. The correlation of the two measures is only .26. Although a tropical climate is highly significant, as is the share of primary exports in GDP, other geographic indicators-such as access to the sea, distance from major growth centres and the proportion of the population residing near coastlines-were not significant. A colonial past (pre-1945) is found to have a significant negative impact on growth, even in more recent periods.
Productivity growth
The forecasts of GDP growth, of capital stock growth (based on estimated investment shares and assumed depreciation rates) and of growth in labour supply (based on projections of working-age population and assumptions on labour force participation) yield labour productivity growth and total factor productivity growth forecasts. The latter utilise the growth accounting identity, GY=b*GK+c*GL+A, where GY is growth of real GDP, GK growth of the capital stock and GL growth of human capital (the labour force adjusted for changes in skills). "A" stands for growth in total factor productivity; "b" and "c" are the shares of capital and labour in income. Trade values are forecast on the basis of simple import (function of GDP and relative prices) and export functions. Forecast market exchange rates (that is, the differential between PPP and market exchange rates) depend on the differential in labour productivity growth between a country and the US.

Data sources and definitions
Sources for global and domestic data are for historical data. The source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD

Guide to the business rankings model
Outline of the model
The business rankings model measures the quality or attractiveness of the business environment in the 82 countries covered by Country Forecast using a standard analytical framework. It is designed to reflect the main criteria used by companies to formulate their global business strategies, and is based not only on historical conditions but also on expectations about conditions prevailing over the next five years. This allows The Economist Intelligence Unit to utilise the regularity, depth and detail of its forecasting work to generate a unique set of forward-looking business environment rankings on a regional and global basis.
The business rankings model examines 11 separate criteria or categories, covering the political environment, the macroeconomic environment, market opportunities, policy towards free enterprise and competition, policy towards foreign investment, foreign trade and exchange controls, taxes, financing, the labour market, infrastructure and technological readiness. Each category contains a number of indicators that are assessed by The Economist Intelligence Unit for the last five years and the next five years. The number of indicators in each category varies from five (foreign trade and exchange regimes) to 13 (political environment), and there are 91 indicators in total.
Almost half of the indicators are based on quantitative data (eg GDP growth), and are mostly drawn from national and international statistical sources for the historical period (2014-18) and from Economist Intelligence Unit assessments for the forecast period (2019-23). The other indicators are qualitative in nature (eg quality of the financial regulatory system), and are drawn from a range of data sources and business surveys adjusted by The Economist Intelligence Unit for 2014-18. All forecasts for the qualitative indicators covering 2019-23 are based on Economist Intelligence Unit assessments.
Sources used in the business rankings model include Akamai Technologies, State of the Internet; CIA, World Factbook; The Economist Intelligence Unit, Country Risk Service, Country Commerce, Democracy Index, Risk Briefing; IMF, Annual Report on Exchange Arrangements and Exchange Restrictions; International Institute for Management Development, World Competitiveness Yearbook; International Labour Organisation, International Labour Statistics Yearbook; International Telecommunication Union, ICT Indicators Database; Transparency International, Corruption Perceptions Index; UN Conference on Trade and Development, Ecommerce Index; World Bank, World Development Indicators, Doing Business; World Economic Forum, Global Competitiveness Index; World Intellectual Property Organisation, IP Facts and Figures.
Calculating the rankings
The rankings are calculated in several stages. First, each of the 91 indicators is scored on a scale from 1 (very bad for business) to 5 (very good for business). The aggregate category scores are derived on the basis of simple or weighted averages of the indicator scores within a given category. These are then adjusted, on the basis of a linear transformation, to produce index values on a 1-10 scale. An arithmetic average of the ten category index values is then calculated to yield the aggregate business environment score for each country, again on a 1-10 scale.
The use of equal weights for the categories to derive the overall score reflects in part the theoretical uncertainty about the relative importance of the primary determinants of investment. Surveys of foreign direct investors' intentions yield widely differing results on the relative importance of different factors. Weighted scores for individual categories based on correlation coefficients of recent foreign direct investment inflows do not in any case produce overall results that are significantly different from those derived from a system based on equal weights.
For most quantitative indicators the data are arrayed in ascending or descending order and split into five bands (quintiles). The countries falling in the first quintile are assigned scores of 5, those falling in the second quintile score 4 and so on. The cut-off points between bands are based on the average of the raw indicator values for the top and bottom countries in adjacent quintiles. The 2014-18 ranges are then used to derive 2019-23 scores. This allows for intertemporal as well as cross-country comparisons of the indicator and category scores.
Measurement and grading issues
The indices and rankings attempt to measure the average quality of the business environment over the entire historical or forecast period, not simply at the start or at the end of the period. Thus, in the forecast we assign an average grade to elements of the business environment over 2019-23, not to the likely situation in 2023 only.
The scores based on quantitative data are usually calculated on the basis of the numeric average for an indicator over the period. In some cases, the "average" is represented, as an approximation, by the recorded value at the mid-point of the period (2016 or 2021). In only a few cases is the relevant variable appropriately measured by the value at the start of the period (eg educational attainments). For one indicator (the natural resources endowment), the score remains constant for both the historical and forecast periods.
