Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The 2019 general elections resulted in the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) obtaining a majority in the lower house of parliament. This will underpin political stability in 2019-23. The Economist Intelligence Unit expects the prime minister, Narendra Modi, to run a highly centralised administration.
Relations with the US will remain warm in 2019-23, albeit punctuated by trade tensions. Despite efforts to normalise relations, ties with China will remain strained, owing to border disputes and concerns about that country's rising influence in South Asia. Relations with Pakistan will also be tense, owing to continuing border tensions. Low-level military clashes between the two countries remain likely in 2019-23.
We do not expect concerted efforts to narrow the fiscal deficit in fiscal years 2019/20-2023/24 (April-March), as the government will continue to spend heavily on infrastructure and subsidy payments.
Real GDP growth will slump to 5.2% in fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March), owing to a slowdown in private consumption and infrastructure investment. Economic growth will recover to an annual average of 6.7% in 2020/21-2023/24.
We expect consumer price inflation to average 4% a year in 2019-23. Lower crude oil costs will restrain inflation in the first two years of the forecast period, allowing the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) to maintain an accommodative stance. The RBI will take a more hawkish stance from 2021 onwards as stronger domestic demand adds to price pressures.
In annual average terms the rupee will depreciate against the US dollar in 2019, and again in 2021-23, reflecting India's current-account deficit. However, the rupee will appreciate against the dollar in 2020 as the US loosens its monetary policy, widening the gap between US and Indian interest rates.
India will remain dependent on imports for its fuel and capital goods needs. The merchandise trade deficit will therefore widen during the forecast period. The services trade and secondary income accounts will record surpluses, partly offsetting the goods trade deficit. The current-account balance will remain in deficit in 2019-23, with the annual shortfall averaging the equivalent of 1.4% of GDP.

India's score rises over the forecast period, owing to improvements in the infrastructure category, but its overall regional ranking remains weak.
Country forecast overview: India's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: The government takes steps towards partial privatisation of some state-owned companies.
2021-23: The government continues to rationalise liquidation and bankruptcy laws to simplify the closing of loss-making businesses and their merger or acquisition by other corporate entities.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Restrictions on foreign investment in sectors such as insurance, aviation and media are eased. Sourcing controls on foreign investment in single-brand retail are also liberalised.
2021-23: Foreign investment in export manufacturing increases markedly, albeit in only a few geographic regions.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: A limited trade war with the US continues, despite the damage it inflicts on bilateral strategic ties.
2021-23: The government makes some efforts to further ease the process of borrowing overseas for companies and to reduce capital-account restrictions. However, full capital-account convertibility remains off the policy agenda.
Taxes
2019-20: Rationalisation of the goods and services tax (GST) continues, resulting in a reduction in the number of tax bands.
2021-23: Alcohol and petroleum products remain outside the scope of the goods and services tax (GST).
Financing
2019-20: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) relaxes regulatory norms for debt-laden banks, raising risks to banking sector stability but improving the availability of finance for corporate borrowers.
2021-23: Private-sector banks account for a rising share of total lending, while bad issues in public-sector banks persist.
The labour market
2019-20: Reforms to labour laws move at a glacial pace owing to obstruction by trade unions and opposition groups.
2021-23: Some labour reforms make headway at the state level. However, reforms at central-government level remain stuck, owing to a lack of political consensus behind the changes.
Infrastructure
2019-20: The government increases its budgetary allocation for projects such as the Bharatmala road connectivity scheme.
2021-23: Construction of a high-speed rail link between Mumbai and Ahmedabad continues, but the project misses its targeted completion date of August 2022.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Most technological innovation continues to be concentrated in a few clusters, such as Bangalore.
2021-23: The government makes efforts to digitise the delivery of public services, in an effort to cut corruption and promote the efficiency of "last-mile delivery" for such services.

Background: India gained independence in 1947 after two centuries of British colonial rule. Partition at the same time created the state of Pakistan, with which India has fought three wars (two of them over the disputed territory of Kashmir). India is the second-most populous country in the world, with an estimated 1.34bn people in 2017, according to the UN. Its economy was the sixth-largest in the world in 2017 when measured in nominal US dollars, but the third-largest at purchasing power parity exchange rates.
Political structure: India has been a democracy since independence. At federal level, the Bharatiya Janata Party holds a majority in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament), although it governs in a broader coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA). India follows the Westminster model of parliamentary government, with a prime minister as head of government. It has a president as the head of state. The country has a quasi-federal structure, with state governments having their own legislatures and enjoying a fair degree of freedom.
Policy issues: Progress on economic reform is constrained by a lack of consensus across the political spectrum over its nature and scope, and by a lack of will within the government to undertake politically risky structural reforms. The NDA administration has made headway in speeding up infrastructure projects, and this will remain a priority in the next five years. However, progress on more contentious issues, such as land and labour reforms, will be shallow.
Taxation: The government will maintain efforts to broaden the tax base in 2019-23, including by further digitising tax departments. This, coupled with strong economic growth, will support a pick-up in tax collection. Despite some reforms, including the introduction of a nationwide goods and services tax in 2017, India's tax system will remain highly complex.
Foreign trade: India's trade deficit widened to US$186.7bn in 2018, from US$148.1bn in 2017, while its surplus on the services account rose from US$75.9bn to US$80.8bn.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The BJP won the majority of seats in the Lok Sabha (the lower house of parliament) in the general election that took place in April-May 2019. The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect any threat to the BJP's dominance of the central government at any point during its full term (2019-24). This will ensure consistency in policy, particularly as this is the second consecutive term for the BJP.
The results of the recent election were testament to the popularity of the prime minister, Narendra Modi. He will remain the dominant figure in the government. Decision-making will remain centralised around the prime minister's office (PMO) and key ministers and officials whom Mr Modi trusts. The PMO and the National Security Advisor played a key role in the outgoing government, and we believe that they will continue to dominate the policy agenda in the next five years.
Sporadic instances of street violence occurred during the term of the first Modi government, directed particularly towards minority groups. The BJP's right-wing affiliates and sister organisations within the larger Hindu right-wing ecosystem (colloquially known as the Sangh Parivar) used the BJP's political power to pursue their socio-cultural agenda. This includes a goal of recasting India as a Hindu state-a view that puts them at odds with the country's large Muslim minority. Such attacks will persist over the forecast period, but we do not expect them to have a major impact on the business environment.
There is a risk that clashes between religious groups will intensify in states with a history of communal violence, such as Uttar Pradesh and Assam. Tensions between Hindus and Muslims have increased in recent years amid concerns among some Hindu groups about an influx of people from the neighbouring Muslim-majority nation of Bangladesh. However, state governments (which control the local police in India) will be keen to restore order quickly following any instances of communal violence, in order to avoid public criticism and international scrutiny.
The government's decision in August 2019 to revoke the special status accorded to the state of Jammu and Kashmir will result in a marked deterioration in political stability in that region. Despite the deployment of large numbers of troops and the arrest of many local leaders within the area, instances of unrest have been reported. We expect security risks in the area to remain high in the medium term. Any attempt by protesters to destabilise the region is likely to face a heavy-handed response from the government, including the use of curfews and riot-control forces. The government's move will also increase the risk of related terrorist attacks by separatist forces in major Indian cities such as Delhi and Mumbai.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
In the second half of 2019 assembly elections will be conducted in three states-Jharkhand, Maharashtra and Haryana. The BJP and its allies currently hold over 85% of all available Lok Sabha seats in these three states, and we expect the outgoing BJP governments in all three to secure a second term in office.
In the Rajya Sabha (the upper house), the BJP and its allies form the largest grouping, although they are significantly short of a majority. Given the BJP's strong performance in the general election, we now believe that the party will dominate the upcoming state elections, enabling it to nominate more members to the upper house (Rajya Sabha members are elected by state assemblies). The BJP and its allies within the larger National Democratic Alliance (NDA) are therefore expected to achieve a majority in the Rajya Sabha by mid-2021. This will enable the alliance to pass legislation without opposition approval.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Tensions with Pakistan will be heightened further by the Indian government's revocation of the special status granted to Jammu and Kashmir. Pakistan's response will be constrained by its foreign-exchange shortages, which will limit it to low-cost strategies. We believe that Pakistan's military will increase its support for militant groups in Indian-controlled Kashmir in the short term. This will raise the risk of terrorist attacks by non-state actors there. Although small-scale military exchanges between the two countries are likely to occur in 2019-23, we believe that the two governments will ensure that these do not escalate into a full-blown conflict.
Trade tensions between the US and India will persist over the next few years, slowing the expansion of bilateral trade flows. However, they are unlikely to escalate into a serious deterioration in relations. In general, ties will remain cordial, underpinned by a mutual desire to counter China's growing influence. To this effect, India has boosted security co-operation with the US in recent years, and this will continue during our forecast period.
China's growing influence in South Asia and its close ties with Pakistan will remain a bone of contention between China and India. Despite some attempts at a reset of bilateral ties in recent years, territorial disputes between China and India will persist, and relations will remain tense in 2019-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
The BJP government will enjoy considerable flexibility in determining the policy agenda, given its majority in the Lok Sabha. One area of priority will be resolving bad debt problems in the banking sector that have held back lending to business. In the budget delivered in July 2019, the government announced plans to provide Rs700bn (US$10bn) to help to shore up public-sector banks. We believe that this sum, if delivered in full, would be sufficient to substantially address balance-sheet problems, but implementation may be a challenge.
We expect incentives to be offered to four key labour-intensive sectors: construction, tourism, gems and jewellery, and garments and textiles. However, these incentives will be market-distorting, protectionist and a bone of contention with countries such as the US in 2019-23. More positively for India's economic productivity, the government plans to liberalise foreign investment restrictions in sectors including insurance, the media and aviation.
The government is unlikely to push for radical reforms that are politically contentious, such as a comprehensive overhaul of land-acquisition laws or labour regulations. However, piecemeal changes to such legislation, such as the relaxation of certain regulatory requirements, could be undertaken. Once the NDA has control of the Rajya Sabha, from mid-2021, this will ease the challenges in the legislative process. However we expect only limited gains from this, as the Modi administration will be hesitant to push ahead with productivity-enhancing reforms that could be politically damaging.
Infrastructure projects-particularly pet projects of the Modi government, such as the Bharatmala roads project and the Smart Cities Mission-will remain a priority, partly as a response to the rapid pace of urbanisation, and partly to boost the business environment. However, many projects will face financing difficulties, as they envision a level of public-private partnership that seems unlikely to be realised, given how subdued private investment activity remains.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The new government's first budget, for the remainder of fiscal year 2019/20 (April-March) was less populist than we had initially anticipated. More firms will be able to enjoy a concessional 25% rate of corporation tax after revenue thresholds were raised. The budget also continued the government's efforts to simplify and digitise the tax system, including the regime for the goods and services tax (GST). Efforts to deepen the tax base and increase levels of tax compliance will continue over the forecast period; India's tax/GDP ratio remains relatively low. More worryingly, there were signs in the budget that the government was seeking to use the customs regime to encourage import substitution-an approach that has failed badly in India in the past.
Welfare payments and infrastructure spending will remain key areas of focus for the government. It will seek to increase the reach of schemes such as the Ayushman Bharat health insurance scheme. We also expect subsidies for labour-intensive small-scale businesses, particularly those that are export-focused, in an effort to promote exports and employment. The rollback of an increased surcharge on high income earners will affect revenue collection in the short term. However, a one-off transfer of capital from the Reserve Bank of India (RBI, the central bank) in August will be more than adequate to offset this impact. Over the medium term, the fiscal deficit will remain significant, averaging the equivalent of 3.3% of GDP a year in 2019/20-2022/23.
This federal fiscal picture does not reflect the large deficits being recorded by several state governments, which are not included in the national figure. The deep deficits of some states, such as Punjab, will present implicit liabilities for the central government and could pose downside risks to GDP growth over the next five years by crowding out private investment.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The RBI will maintain inflation-targeting as the cornerstone of its monetary policy framework. It seeks to contain consumer price inflation within a 2-6% range, and close to a target of 4%, throughout 2019-23. However, strong political pressure on the RBI-which has forced out two heads of the bank under BJP rule-means that inflation is more likely to trend above 4% than below it.
Weak inflation, ebbing growth and pressure from the government have led the RBI to loosen policy several times in 2019. The most recent policy interest-rate cut in August, of 35 basis points, took the repurchase (repo) rate to a nine-year low of 5.4%. However, we believe that with inflation gradually recovering and policy rates already low by historical standards, the RBI will now hold rates until 2021. The central bank will then undertake some tightening in 2021-22 as demand-side pressures associated with the country's rapid economic growth build. As the pace of growth moderates in 2023, the RBI will return to a neutral stance.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The Indian economy grew at the slowest rate in more than six years in the quarter ending June 2019. Real GDP growth slowed to 5% year on year in April-June, compared with a rate of 5.8% in the previous quarter. Depressed consumer sentiment and tepid investment were the main reasons for the slowdown. Despite recent weak economic data, we believe that growth in most components is likely to have bottomed out and that the economy will start to regain momentum from the July-September quarter. A series of stimulus measures enacted by the government, coupled with a low-interest-rate environ-ment, are likely to spur demand and investment in the remaining quarters of 2019/20. Overall, we expect the economy to grow by 5.2% in 2019/20.
Real GDP growth is expected to recover further to an average of 6.7% in 2020/21-2021/22 as domestic demand strengthens. A recovery in global growth in 2021 will also stimulate exports; however, higher domestic investment will also suck in imports. Growth is expected to moderate to 6.4% by 2023/24 as tighter monetary conditions dampen investment growth and deter consumption. India will remain among the fastest-growing major economies throughout the forecast period.
We do not expect a significant improvement in the pace of job creation in the forecast period, as government efforts will focus on small-scale industries and are unlikely to have the desired effect in boosting employment. The focus on smaller firms will crowd out the larger-scale enterprises that would be more productive and effective job-creators in the longer term. This effect will be aggravated by outdated labour laws that deter companies from scaling up. Economic growth will therefore remain below potential throughout the forecast period, despite stable inflation. In factor-cost terms, the services sector will remain the largest component of the economy and will grow at a relatively brisk pace over the forecast period. Conversely, manufacturing will remain below potential owing to structural limitations such as challenges relating to land acquisition. Meanwhile, the agriculture sector will remain a drag on the economy. Public investment in the sector will be aimed at short-term gains, rather than fostering improved productivity.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Prices of food and oil will remain the key factors driving inflationary pressures in 2019-23. Food and beverages have a weighting of around 45% in the consumer price index, and so any volatility in agricultural output will affect price stability. Food price inflation has been weak in recent months, but we anticipate that it will accelerate in the second half of 2019, as crop yields during the summer harvest are expected to be lower than usual. Nevertheless, headline inflation will cool to 3.6% in 2019 on average, from 3.9% in 2018, owing to weaker crude oil prices this year.
Lower crude oil prices will also have a dampening effect on prices in 2020, but this will be offset by a modest pick-up in domestic demand growth, the RBI's accommodative monetary policy and the lagged effects of seasonal climatic factors from 2019. Average annual consumer price inflation will thus accelerate in 2020, to 4.2%. Later in the forecast period, continued strong economic growth will stoke demand-pull inflation, while a weakening of the rupee:US dollar exchange rate will exert an upward influence on prices in 2021-23, by pushing up the cost of imports. We expect consumer prices to rise by an annual average of 4% over 2019-23 as a whole.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Although the rupee has weakened sharply in the wake of the government's decision on Jammu and Kashmir, we regard this as a short-term effect. We continue to expect that a narrowing current-account deficit and improved investor sentiment will ease downward pressure on the rupee in 2019 as a whole, with the currency's exchange rate set to end the year stronger against the US dollar than it was at the end of 2018. However, in annual average terms the rupee will still depreciate in 2019, albeit mildly, weakening to Rs69.9:US$1, from Rs68.4:US$1 last year.
The rupee will appreciate slightly against the US dollar in 2020, supported by interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve (the US central bank) against a backdrop of an economic slowdown in the US. In 2021-23 the rupee will return to a gradual depreciating trend against the US dollar, reflecting India's persistent current-account deficit and relatively high levels of inflation. However, the country's real effective exchange rate will remain relatively stable during our forecast period, and benefits to India's export sector from the rupee's weakening against the US dollar will therefore be limited.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
A slowdown in merchandise imports, resulting from lower global oil prices and depressed demand for investment goods, will drive a narrowing of the merchandise trade deficit in 2019-20. From 2021 onwards, stronger investment and higher oil prices will suck in imports, reversing that trend. Merchandise exports will grow at a faster pace than imports over the next five years, but India's export manufacturing sector will be held back by restrictive labour laws and difficulties in securing land for production facilities.
Increased competition from other countries and changing industrial trends will weigh on the pace of growth of India's key service export sectors, particularly business process outsourcing and information technology. Nevertheless, the services balance will remain in surplus throughout the forecast period, making a positive contribution to the current account. Owing to the large shortfall on merchandise trade, however, the current account will remain in deficit, averaging the equivalent of 1.4% of GDP annually in 2019-23.
Inward direct investment will remain strong in 2019-23 as the expanding economy and growing consumer demand provide opportunities for businesses. We expect annual direct investment inflows to rise to US$68bn by 2023, from US$42.1bn in 2018. Inward portfolio investment slid into negative territory in 2018, owing to jittery investor confidence amid a currency crisis in emerging markets such as Turkey, which stoked fears of contagion, as well as rising US interest rates. We expect this trend to reverse in 2019-23 as investor confidence is gradually restored.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
The civic-military regime, led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV), is under severe economic and political pressure. The Economist Intelligence Unit has for some time believed that the Maduro regime's position is unsustainable. We currently base our forecasts on a political transition within the five-year period (2019-23) that introduces an interim administration led by Juan Guaidó, whom we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. Currently, we expect there to be some sort of regime change by the end of 2019. The timing and shape of the transition process, however, remains extremely uncertain, and we expect the entire forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
Our expectation of a change of government by end-2019 implies huge changes to policymaking, as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms required to resolve the economic crisis.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented under the transitional and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, with the Guaidó administration seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and in potential donor nations (such as the US and EU members) of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry.
The pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of a new administration, and how this stability might be impaired by likely demands from multilateral and bilateral lenders for politically difficult reforms. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and other multilaterals, and by the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. At the same time, the state-owned oil company, PDVSA, will need wholesale reform to open itself to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.

Venezuela is in 79th position globally in the business environment rankings for 2019-23, up from 80th in the historical period. Assuming regime change, improvements are expected, but it will take time for reforms to institutions, economic policy and the business environment to bear fruit.
Country forecast overview: Venezuela's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Start of rollback of interventionist measures, such as price controls, but concerns over political instability slow liberalisation. Corruption and selective application of regulations remain common and undermine free competition.
2021-23: Gradual improvement in contract rights and the burden of red tape under a new government, as well as a decline in ad hoc interventionism.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: Regulation by a new government protecting property rights introduced in an attempt to attract investment.
2021-23: Despite efforts, actual investment flows remain low amid probable economic instability. Intellectual property protection and private property rights improve.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Currency controls are made less opaque, but restrictions on private-sector access to foreign currency remain.
2021-23: Efforts to remove trade and capital controls are taken on a gradual basis, owing to the risk of economic dislocation. Domestic supply of foreign currency improves, albeit very slowly.
Taxes
2019-20: Risk of further unrest and political stability reduces the probability of tax increases, despite fiscal deficits. Severity of economic crisis precludes major public spending increases.
2021-23: Tax system remains complex and unwieldy, but declining risk of discriminatory ad hoc tax measures.
Financing
2019-20: Inflation remains high and concerns around economic instability restrict financing to only short-term.
2021-23: Economic adjustments take time to feed through to solid, sustainable growth in credit to the private sector and development of capital markets. Long-term finance remains in short supply.
Labour market
2019-20: Labour laws add substantially to non-wage costs. Large-scale emigration of skilled labour complicates hiring.
2021-23: Labour market rigidities persist, despite some increase in the flexibility of hiring and firing practices.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Underinvestment in the water network and electricity grid means that rationing and unpredictable blackouts continue. A new government undertakes some repairs to the power network.
2021-23: Private-sector investment starts to pick up, but there is a risk of continued water and electricity rationing.
Technological readiness
2019-20: E-government services remain almost non-existent and deteriorating infrastructure limits adoption of new technologies. Telecommunications sector is opened to foreign investment.
2021-23: Limited regulatory capacity and years of underinvestment continue to limit internet and mobile coverage.

Background: From 1958 until the mid-1990s, two parties-Acción Democrática and the Comité de Organización Política Electoral Independiente-alternated in power. Frequent economic crises and endemic corruption eventually led to a collapse in their support, culminating in the election of Hugo Chávez in 1998, a former lieutenant-colonel and leader of a failed coup in 1992. Mr Chávez's policy programme exacerbated political polarisation, but he survived several attempts to remove him from power. Mr Chávez died in March 2013. His chosen successor, Nicolás Maduro, has seen his popularity plummet as his mismanagement of a drop in oil prices has plunged the country into a massive economic depression.
Political structure: Although Venezuela is nominally a federal republic with separation of powers, the ruling Partido Socialista de Venezuela (PSUV) has systematically eroded republican institutions. In December 2015 the opposition coalition, Mesa de la Unidad Democrática, won control of the unicameral National Assembly. In January 2016 the politicised Supreme Court declared the legislature in contempt of court, blocking all subsequent legislation. Since August 2017 a PSUV-only Constituent Assembly has granted itself a remit over all legislative matters, becoming the country's de facto legislature and sidelining the National Assembly.
Policy issues: The most pressing policy issue is the need to stabilise an economy that remains mired in a long-standing economic crisis. The monetisation of vast public deficits has created an ever-increasing excess of domestic currency, triggering hyperinflation. Mismanagement of PDVSA, the state-owned oil company and originator of practically all foreign-currency inflows into the country, has resulted in a sharp contraction of oil production. This has restricted foreign-currency supply, giving way to currency controls, the rationing of imports and the emergence of black markets for both foreign currency and basic goods. The scarcity of foreign exchange has also led to arrears on most of the external debt issued by sovereign and state-owned firms.
Taxation: The top corporate tax rate is 34% for non-oil companies and 50% for oil firms. The value-added tax (VAT) rate stands at 12%.
Foreign trade: The goods trade surplus fell to an estimated US$18.8bn in 2018 as the destruction of domestic supply led to increasing import dependence. The Economist Intelligence Unit estimates the 2018 current-account surplus at 2.1% of GDP.

Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
The civic-military regime led by Nicolás Maduro of the Partido Socialista Unido de Venezuela (PSUV) is under severe economic and political pressure, and The Economist Intelligence Unit believes that its position is unsustainable. We currently expect a political transition within our 2019-23 forecast period that introduces an interim administration led by Juan Guaidó, who we assume will undertake emergency adjustment measures and prepare the ground for eventual free and fair elections. At present, we assume regime change by end-2019, but the timing and shape of the transition process is highly uncertain. We expect the entire forecast period to be characterised by political instability.
Our forecast for regime change is based on the extent of the economic and humanitarian crisis currently unfolding in Venezuela. This has deeply damaged support for Mr Maduro among the population at large; we believe that it will ultimately erode his backing among key supporters in the military who are propping him up in power. It is less clear, however, what the exact trigger for regime change will be. There are three main paths to a political transition: military intervention, a negotiated transition or some sort of internal coup. We assess the prospect of military action, by the US or Colombia, as very low. Although negotiations sponsored by Norway are set to resume (it is unclear when), we believe that trust issues on both sides are insurmountable and therefore do not expect a negotiated solution to Venezuela's crisis.
We believe that the most likely scenario for regime change is an internal coup. The escalation of US sanctions means that Mr Maduro can no longer guarantee the regime's raison d'être-the enrichment of its members-and we expect pragmatists within government and the military to turn on him, paving the way for some sort of political transition. However, a failed uprising on April 30th demonstrated the difficulty of this kind of initiative, and has incurred a heavy political cost, as the regime has become more vigilant of discontent among its ranks. The April uprising, which reportedly included top-ranking government officials alongside Mr Guaidó, confirmed cracks in the regime's ranks at the highest levels. Our forecast for regime change therefore still stands.
This forecast is underpinned by three key assumptions. The first is that regime pragmatists will prevail over hardliners. Despite the ongoing collapse of the patronage system, there are risks to this assumption, not least frequent purges within the military. The presence of dozens of important military figures also leads to co-ordination problems. Secondly, we are assuming that regime members will deem amnesty offers as credible. Risks to this assumption include a deep-seated distrust of the opposition and a fear of being prosecuted outside Venezuela (a well-founded concern, given accusations of drug- and weapon-trafficking against regime members). The third assumption underpinning our forecast is a continued lack of hard currency to sustain the patronage system. Risks to this forecast come in the form of greater than expected support from Russia or China, and from drug-trafficking and illegal mining activities, which could provide the regime with more hard currency than we currently expect.
We recognise the very high risks to our baseline view, and believe there are two main alternate scenarios. The first and more likely of these, is the maintenance of the status quo, with the population protest-weary, the regime hunkering down, the opposition deflating, and the country becoming increasingly isolated and impoverished. The second is one of prolonged chaos-including, possibly, armed conflict among regime factions. However, we expect neither of these scenarios to be feasible in the medium to long term. With no prospect of real reform, we believe that a chronically weak economy will ultimately make Mr Maduro's position untenable. Violent, chaotic conflict in Venezuela could prove the trigger for some kind of military action by the US and by Venezuela's Latin American neighbours to put an end to the crisis. For these reasons, we continue to believe that regime change in the forecast period remains highly likely, even if it does not occur in 2019.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The opposition's recently announced plans for a transitional government call for the renovation of all electoral authorities, and for elections within 12 months of its formation. Although this timeline is extremely ambitious, given the scale of the task, we expect national elections to take place by the end of 2020, under a transitional government. International assistance in organising elections would be necessary (and forthcoming). Deep-seated reforms to the electoral authority, the electoral registry and the voting system will be required, but rebuilding trust in the system will be difficult. If the Maduro regime manages to maintain the status quo, legislative elections would take place in December 2020. However, these elections would be neither free nor fair.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Mr Guaidó has marshalled strong support from the international community. However, efforts by most governments in Latin America (under the Lima Group banner) to support him have reached an impasse. Mr Guaidó's most committed champion, the US, has instituted crippling oil sanctions and has openly called for the Venezuelan military to accept him in place of Mr Maduro. Indeed, the US introduced new sanctions in August, the most important of which is a freeze on Venezuelan assets abroad that will further complicate the regime's attempts to sustain the current patronage system. The US administration's hawkish approach introduces risks of a military intervention. We currently do not foresee large-scale military action, in part because such an initiative lacks international legitimacy. If tensions rise and political violence increases, the possibility of smaller-scale interventions cannot be discounted.
Russia may well be helping the state oil company, PDVSA, to circumvent US sanctions (for a fee). That said, both Russia and China seem unwilling to provide the necessary financing-amounting to tens of billions of dollars per year-to stabilise the economy and the long-term future of PDVSA itself. Mr Maduro has openly courted the two countries, but seemingly with little success in terms of finance for investment. We believe that Russia and (especially) China would be willing to work with a successor government in an attempt to protect their current investments in Venezuela.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Our expectation of a change of government by end-2019 implies huge modifications to policymaking as a new administration works to end hyperinflation, restructure public debt, and rebuild institutions to restore confidence and promote investment. Until then, we do not expect to see the comprehensive economic and institutional reforms that are required to resolve the economic crisis. There has been evidence in recent months of attempts to tighten monetary policy in order to rein in hyperinflation and (in theory) to abandon foreign-exchange controls. However, we believe that such efforts are doomed to failure in the absence of comprehensive microeconomic reform and improvements in the rule of law and policy predictability that will not be forthcoming under the present regime.
Under our baseline scenario, we expect more orthodox economic policies to be implemented under the transitional and successor governments. Many of these policies have been outlined already, The prospective Guaidó administration is seeking to reassure stakeholders in multilateral institutions and potential donor nations-such as the US and European countries-of its capacity to stabilise the economy, address the humanitarian emergency, generate trust and legal security, ensure access to basic public services, and reactivate the oil industry. However, the pace and depth of the adjustment will be constrained by uncertainty over the stability of any new administration, and in particular, how this might be impaired by probable demands from multilateral and bilateral lenders for politically difficult reforms. Our benign baseline assumption is that macroeconomic stabilisation will be facilitated by financing from the IMF and other multilaterals (totalling US$46bn in 2020-23) and the restructuring of the government's debt obligations. This in itself will be a huge task for any administration. Meanwhile, PDVSA will need wholesale reform to open itself up to the foreign finance needed to increase output, a process that will require considerable political capital.
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
The authorities have not published complete official data on fiscal accounts since 2011. We expect the non-financial public-sector deficit this year to remain well into double digits as a percentage of GDP. The government relies heavily on monetisation to fund its deficits, driving hyperinflation and the rationing of foreign currency. Under our expectation of substantial currency adjustment, the public debt/GDP ratio will rise dramatically in coming years; however, our forecasts assume that a combination of debt restructuring and deep fiscal adjustment will gradually bring the ratio under control. The process will be complicated by the existence of considerable off-balance-sheet debt financing (mainly in the form of debt issued by PDVSA and development funds from China) that understates the true size of total public liabilities.
All of the sovereign's outstanding global bonds, and all but one of PDVSA's bonds, are in arrears. Bondholders are yet to go to the courts, perhaps waiting for news of policy shifts or a change in government. A US appeals court has ruled that PDVSA is an "alter ego" of the Venezuelan government; this will have far-reaching implications. For example, a Canadian mining firm, Crystallex, is seeking to seize shares of Citgo, PDVSA's US subsidiary. However, the latest US sanctions forbid the transfer of Venezuelan assets. This will, for the time being, shield Citgo and its Caribbean facilities, which the US government now considers to be under Mr Guaidó's purview.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
The government's financing needs will continue to force the Banco Central de Venezuela (BCV, the central bank) to print money in the short term. However, a significant increase in reserve requirements for the banking sector since the start of the year-and a strong contraction in domestic demand-have had a temporary steadying effect, which has slowed hyperinflationary pressures and allowed the bolívar to stabilise to some extent in recent months. We expect monthly inflation to rise again in the short term, given that the underlying causes of inflation remain unaddressed. However, given our assumption that a transitional government-which places a much greater emphasis on tackling hyperinflation-will come to power, we do not currently project a return to the extremely high rates of annual inflation of over 1,000,000% experienced in 2018 (although there are substantial political risks to this forecast). Instead, under a new government, we expect a substantial monetary adjustment in the context of an emergency macroeconomic stabilisation plan. The introduction of a new currency, a temporary peg or outright currency substitution in such a context is highly likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
After an estimated contraction in real GDP of 18.5% in 2018, we expect further reductions in 2019-20. Our forecast of an economic recovery in 2021-23 assumes a political transition that is supported by international assistance, and produces a credible macroeconomic programme with improved management of oil wealth. However, reform will take time to bear fruit, and we expect only a partial rebound in real GDP, following a decline of more than 65% in 2013-20.
Private consumption will continue to contract in 2019, reflecting the effect of hyperinflation on real wages, as well as government compression of imports, which account for a large share of consumer goods. Fixed investment will also diminish, reflecting difficulty in accessing imported inputs and foreign exchange. Moreover, power cuts and fuel shortages are now commonplace-particularly outside Caracas-owing to severe underinvestment in the country's power infrastructure. These have further damaged Venezuela's overall economic capacity. The dry season (January-April) will exacerbate power cuts.
Our forecast for a recovery in investment from 2020 assumes a political transition and a pick-up in oil investment. We expect oil output to bottom out at 650,000 barrels/day (b/d) by year-end, prevented from slipping any lower by PDVSA's joint-venture partners. In line with our baseline forecast of openness to foreign investment under a new government later in 2019, oil production will start to recover in 2020, but even in 2023 it will still be well below 2m b/d, the average output in 2017.
Export volumes will start to recover in 2020 on the back of recovery in the oil sector, but a rise in domestic demand (which has been artificially constrained) will initially absorb some of the projected increase in oil output. Import demand will rise sharply in 2020. These factors will initially constrain the rebound of GDP, but we expect real GDP growth to gather pace in 2022-23.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
Severely reduced domestic supply, currency constraints on import capacity and the monetisation of large public deficits have led to hyperinflation. Official inflation data were recently published by the BCV, but there is a significant gap between these and data from other sources. Amid continuing questions over the data, we will, for now, continue to use the monthly series produced by the National Assembly. These have indicated some disinflation in recent months, with inflation falling below the hyperinflation threshold of 50% per month. Huge fundamental imbalances between supply and demand persist, and we expect inflation to remain high for as long as the Maduro regime stays in power. On the basis of our assumption of regime change in the short term, we expect much tighter monetary policy and lower inflation, but supply bottlenecks and bouts of inflationary pressure are likely.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
Under our baseline forecast of political transition by end-2019, the introduction of a new currency (or outright currency substitution) to try to tackle inflation is a strong possibility, although the exact nature of such a move is hard to predict. Our forecasts assume extremely large currency adjustments that restore some competitiveness to the local currency in real terms over time. With few foreign reserves left to protect, the Maduro regime has announced a loosening of currency controls. Access to dollars via formal means will remain difficult and we believe that the foreign-exchange system will stay highly controlled in practice. In this environment, a strong black-market exchange-rate premium is likely to re-emerge. At end-August, the official exchange rate was BsS22,160:US$1, compared with a black-market rate of almost BsS25,950:US$1. The premium was wide, although still small by historical comparison.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
We have recently revised our current-account data in line with the BCV's publication of official figures for 2017-18. These show that Venezuela continued to post current-account surpluses in this period on the back of higher non-oil exports than we had expected. However, we continue to project a shift into current-account deficit this year, in view of the collapse of export earnings stemming from US sanctions on the oil trade. This deficit will emerge despite the non-payment of interest on bonded debt ("savings" in excess of US$5bn in 2019 alone). We have also excluded repayments to Chinese lenders, to maintain consistency with the World Bank's data, on which our debt forecasts are based. Later in the forecast period, we expect exports to grow as oil production increases, but we also foresee a surge in imports, as Venezuela's own productive base has been severely eroded. These factors will keep the current account in deficit, although we expect the shortfall to narrow to a manageable level of around 3.5% of GDP towards the end of the forecast period.
We currently expect that a new administration will secure sufficient finance to stabilise the balance-of-payments dynamics. However, there are considerable risks to this outlook. It hinges on substantial IMF finance, rapid macroeconomic stabilisation, speedy resolution of a debt renegotiation process, and a fast recovery in oil output after years of underinvestment and mismanagement.

Full text: Country forecast overview: Highlights
Muhammadu Buhari won a second and final four-year presidential term on February 23rd. The policy agenda he campaigned on did not involve considerable reform, only cosmetic improvements to the business environment.
The administration will struggle to tackle high levels of poverty and the country's ethnic and religious divisions. This will create a potent mixture that will lead to frequent violent instability and directly affect key economic sectors.
Policy will be interventionist. Import bans on agricultural and manufactured goods will be widened to support local industry and farmers, and the Central Bank of Nigeria will maintain an overvalued official naira rate with which to channel cheap US dollars to preferred buyers.
The multiple-exchange-rate regime will not be dismantled under a Buhari administration; the arrangement is critical for making petrol subsidies affordable and underpins the government's interventionist approach to industrialisation.
Even though a multiple exchange-rate system will persist, non-official rates will converge and so in reality Nigeria will run a dual exchange-rate regime. Oil prices will be high enough to prevent a return to capital controls (as temporarily imposed in 2016), but import restrictions will be widened, especially for food.
Fiscal expenditure will remain dominated by recurrent spending, despite attempts to boost capital investment. Efforts to boost non-oil tax revenue will be constrained by weak bureaucratic capacity and low economic growth.
Constrained by a crippling infrastructure deficit, as well as tight monetary conditions and instability in key agricultural regions, economic growth will be well below levels needed to boost job creation and increase living standards. This will perpetuate instability in a vicious cycle.
Inflation will remain high over the forecast period (2019-23) amid expansionary fiscal policy and high food prices stemming from government efforts to limit imports and support local producers. This in turn will keep credit conditions tight; even with some relaxation of the policy rate from 2021, inflation will be running too high for sustained monetary loosening, and credit growth will generally be slow.
Exports will be flat in 2019 and fall in 2020 as global oil prices come under pressure, but imports will also fall. Imports and exports will expand in 2021-23 but a current-account surplus will be maintained throughout the forecast period.

Nigeria's business environment score will improve slightly but its global and regional rankings will worsen as the administration struggles with the reform process and other countries make more significant improvements.
Country forecast overview: Nigeria's business environment at a glance
Policy towards private enterprise and competition
2019-20: Progress on market-oriented reforms remains slow, given various vested interests and inefficiencies. The upstream oil sector will remain characterised by joint-ventures between the state oil company and multinationals.
2021-23: Improving prospects for the non-oil private sector remains a priority, but progress will be slow.
Policy towards foreign investment
2019-20: An attempt to sell the state's interest in oil joint ventures with multinationals will meet serious challenges (the policy has been around for years), with resistance in the legislature to the permanent loss of a revenue stream.
2021-23: Higher world oil prices and so easing fiscal pressures lessen the need to embark on a divestment programme. Energy companies will anyway be hesitant to increase their stake in a difficult operating environment, especially onshore.
Foreign trade and exchange controls
2019-20: Import bans are widened dramatically, but capital controls will not be necessary, barring another oil price crash.
2021-23: A premium between the overvalued official and parallel-market exchange rates persists.
Taxes
2019-20: Focus intensifies on boosting tax compliance, especially given weak prospects for oil revenue. Value-added tax (VAT) is increased to fund a higher minimum wage, which will markedly increase the fiscal cost of the civil service.
2021-23: Tax rates for the oil and gas sector increase under new legislation, particularly for offshore oilfields. The need for new consumer taxes is alleviated by higher world oil prices and, as a result, hydrocarbons revenue.
Financing
2019-20: Funding for well-planned projects becomes easier to raise domestically following the completion of the 2019 elections, as local capital markets deepen (with greater foreign participation) and the banking sector develops.
2021-23: Credit conditions become easier for businesses as the current-account surplus boosts savings and investment.
The labour market
2019-20: Employers face major problems, including a shortage of skilled manual workers, restrictive visa regulations and poor health indicators.
2021-23: Employers continue to struggle to find suitably qualified staff; unemployment remains high and the market loose.
Infrastructure
2019-20: Government spending on the priority area of infrastructure hits capacity constraints and is crowded out by other spending categories, including debt-servicing and higher public-sector wages. Although there should be growth in private-sector investment, the government struggles to create an encouraging environment.
2021-23: Expenditure on infrastructure increases, but white elephant projects hold back the productivity of investment.
Technological readiness
2019-20: Nigeria continues to have a vibrant technology sector for an economy at its stage of development, but infrastructure is weak outside urban hubs.
2021-23: Research spending is likely to remain low compared with global averages, but some home-grown technology firms looking to adapt global technology trends to the Nigerian market continue to do well.

Background: Nigeria gained independence in 1960, and multiparty democracy was restored in 1999 after a protracted period of military rule. The first two presidential elections (in 1999 and 2003) were both won by a former military ruler turned civilian politician, Olusegun Obasanjo. Mr Obasanjo was unable to change the constitution to allow him to serve a third term in office, so in the 2007 election power passed to his handpicked successor, Umaru Yar'Adua. After Mr Yar'Adua's death in May 2010, his vice-president, Goodluck Jonathan, assumed the presidency and went on to win the 2011 presidential election. Mr Jonathan was defeated by Muhammadu Buhari in 2015, and Mr Buhari secured a second term in early 2019.
Political structure: Under the constitution adopted in May 1999, a strong executive presidency appoints a Federal Executive Council, comprising government ministers and ministers of state from each of Nigeria's 36 states. The executive is accountable to the bicameral National Assembly. Political parties tend to lack clear ideologies; in practice, personal and ethnic ties predominate. The People's Democratic Party (Mr Jonathan's party) had historically been the predominant political force, but the merger in 2013 of three large opposition parties to form the All Progressives Congress gave them, with Mr Buhari at the helm, the reach that they needed to take power in 2015 and secure re-election in 2019.
Policy issues: Successive governments have sought to improve macroeconomic stability and develop the nation's dire infrastructure, with mixed results. The government is struggling to end insecurity in various parts of the country. These tensions are stoked by the underlying problems of poverty and unemployment. Management of the naira by the authorities is a contentious issue, with important subsidy programmes hinging on an overvalued official exchange rate.
Taxation: Corporate profits in most non-oil sectors are taxed at 30%. Planned changes to the tax system for the oil and gas sector have been repeatedly delayed, creating uncertainty. Most other taxes are low, reflecting the fact that most revenue comes from the oil sector, with the total tax take very small as a share of GDP. With oil prices far lower than they were in 2010-14, it is likely that amendments to consumer taxes will be made, specifically in value-added tax (VAT, currently 5%).
Foreign trade: Exports are dominated by oil. The slump in oil prices from the second half of 2014 has almost wiped out what had historically been a large current-account surplus. The non-oil export base has been rendered globally uncompetitive by massive infrastructure deficiencies.

France 5.9 Netherlands 3.9
Outlook for 2019-23: Political stability
Muhammadu Buhari won a presidential election in February 2019 and will remain in power until his second (and final) term expires in 2023. However, managing the country's myriad security threats will prove an insoluble challenge. The foremost reason for this is an overstretched military and police force, which will be unable to cope with simultaneous security crises. Security crises will in effect be triaged, with resources being deployed to whichever is seen to be the most pressing at any given time.
Conflict in the north-east between the government and two Islamist terrorist groups, Boko Haram and the Islamic State in West Africa Province (ISWAP), is also a pressing issue in the north-east, with Islamist fighters better equipped and capable than they have been in recent years. As this is one of Mr Buhari's voter strongholds, the president will be keen to reassert control over the situation. Boko Haram and ISWAP will be aggressively countered, but the north-east of Nigeria will remain a low-level conflict zone, albeit limited to the north-east of the country, and the campaign will divert security forces away from pockets of instability elsewhere. One such hotspot is just to the south, in the agricultural Middle Belt of Nigeria, where violent clashes between settled farmers and nomads competing for land and water resources have killed several thousand civilians in recent years. Formal land-titling is a potential solution to the crisis, but as it would in effect alienate one group from communal holdings in favour of another, it would prove too contentious. Ultimately there is no foreseeable end to violence in the Middle Belt. Vigilantes will be used to make up for shortfalls in formal security personnel, but not be an effective substitute. Again, the direct effect of the conflict on the security situation will be localised, but the entire country will feel the secondary effects in the form of constricted food supply and, as a result, consumer prices.
Another localised conflict with countrywide consequences will be militant activity in the oil-producing south, where insurgents are demanding more hydrocarbons revenue to be kept locally for development. Reforming how federal revenue is allocated is a massive task and one that The Economist Intelligence Unit does not expect to be achieved in the forecast period. Our assumption is that attacks by aggrieved militants and saboteurs on oil infrastructure will continue to be a major security problem in Delta state, with indirect consequences for the entire federation in the form of disrupted oil exports.
Given the fragility of Nigeria in terms of domestic security, conflicts will, at times, even penetrate into the administrative capital, Abuja, and the commercial capital, Lagos. Recently, adherents of an incarcerated religious Shia leader, Ibrahim Zakzaky, have been protesting for his release in Abuja, and several deadly clashes with the security forces have taken place. In a sign of how overwhelmed the government is, Mr Zakzaky was recently allowed to travel to India for medical treatment, which will temporarily defuse tensions. However, if he is not released, this is a crisis that will need further (and priority) attention from the security forces. In a more general sense, the military and the police will be too poorly equipped to suppress pervasive banditry and kidnapping across the country. Here, widespread poverty and unemployment are feeding into a cycle of crime that will be difficult (if not impossible) to break, given a bleak economic outlook.
Outlook for 2019-23: Election watch
The election in February 2019 reaffirmed a deep electoral divide between the north, which supports the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) and southern Nigeria, a stronghold of the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP). In the next general election in 2023, custom dictates that the candidates of both main parties will be southerners, giving the PDP a chance to improve on abysmally low turnout there in the 2019 presidential vote. The contest will be the opposition's to win. Nigeria's economic outlook up to the next election does not point towards a material decrease in widespread poverty. Frustration with declining living standards and high levels of crime and instability will be directed at the APC, affording the PDP a winning edge.
Outlook for 2019-23: International relations
Many of Nigeria's militant groups operate across land and sea borders, and international co-operation will therefore be needed to tackle the threat that they pose. Relations with South Africa have recently deteriorated over xenophobic attacks against Nigerians living in South Africa. Nigerian politicians have insisted that the authorities in South Africa do more to protect foreign residents. The South African authorities have long struggled to curb xenophobic violence, and serious bouts do occasionally occur, but although the issue is emotive, the issue is unlikely to undermine high-level ties.
India will remain important as the largest market for Nigerian oil and become a bigger source of foreign investment. China will also remain a significant source of investment, but actual inflows will fall short of the headline-grabbing pledges made, given an extremely challenging local business environment. Nigeria will remain an important player in Sub-Saharan Africa given its size, but its domestic challenges tend to keep policymakers inwardly focused. For example, although Mr Buhari recently signed a continent-wide free trade agreement it is likely that protected sectors (notably in agriculture, where other countries would have a competitive advantage) will be shielded from foreign competition.
Outlook for 2019-23: Policy trends
Economic policies in Mr Buhari's second, final term will continue the interventionist trend that characterised his first. Measures to liberalise and unify foreign-exchange markets or move to more market-led pricing in the energy sector will not be pursued. An overvalued official naira rate is critical for maintaining fuel subsidies (over 90% of petrol is imported), and Mr Buhari will not willingly undo pump-price caps and risk a popular backlash. Although in practice very little foreign exchange is traded at the official rate, the existence of a multiple-exchange-rate system brings with it the risk of capital controls and will be off-putting to those acquiring illiquid assets in Nigeria, such as direct investments. Foreign direct investment will be kept well below Nigeria's potential as a result, with projected inflows equating to less than 1% of GDP throughout the forecast period. To defend foreign reserves and the official rate, and thereby try to build confidence, the CBN will progressively widen import restrictions in 2019-20 (the average oil price will fall in both years). Impetus to this policy will most probably come from a British court ruling that an Irish natural gas firm can apply to seize US$9bn in Nigerian government assets in the UK, equal to 20% of Nigeria's gross foreign reserves.
Elsewhere, efforts will be made to cleanse and reboot inefficient state-owned industries such as the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC)-which dominates all segments of the oil sector-but no structural reforms will take place. There will be some effort to reduce the NNPC's stake in the upstream oil joint ventures that it has with international oil companies, but uncertainty about fiscal terms (with deep political divisions about how to distribute hydrocarbons revenue having stalled critical legislation) means that investor interest will be short of official expectations, and parliament will resist selling off key public assets cheaply. As a consequence, the NNPC will continue to dominate the oil sector, with the political elite working to direct the flow of resources to favour specific geo-ethnic and political constituencies (as well as for illicit personal gain).
Outlook for 2019-23: Fiscal policy
We expect small fiscal deficits throughout the forecast period. The government wants to diversify its revenue base away from oil, and non-oil revenue will rise through efforts to collect overdue taxes and a probable increase in value-added tax (VAT) from 5% now to 8% in 2020 (as oil prices and revenue decline). Increases will be from an extremely low base however. Tax avoidance is widespread, and instability impedes collection in many parts of the country. Petrol subsidies (whereby losses incurred by the NNPC's retail arm are deducted from federal revenue) will be another drain, and budgeted revenue levels will be undermined by overambitious oil production targets. For example, in 2019 the government expects output of 2.3m barrels/day-a level not seen since the oil price slump, and one unobtainable given underinvestment and OPEC production quotas. In all, federally retained revenue is not expected to rise above 3.7% of GDP.
After expansion in 2018, spending will decline as a proportion of GDP in 2019 with a low capital budget and poor execution. Partly offsetting this will be higher spending on wages and public-sector benefits, including via the introduction of a new (increased) minimum wage. Generally, however, fiscal flexibility will be restricted by high levels of debt-servicing and pressing security needs. But with oil prices-and, as a result, revenue-under pressure and there being considerable political pressure to curb the fiscal deficit, we expect the spending/GDP ratio to dip again in 2020 and only increase materially as elections in 2023 approach. Altogether, we expect an average budget deficit averaging 1.9% of GDP in 2019-23.
Long-term public debt sustainability will remain in doubt. Central government debt is low as a proportion of GDP compared with other emerging markets, but it is set against an abnormally low revenue base. Debt service can take up to half of federal revenue, which is alarming even by heavily-indebted emerging market standards. A sovereign default is unlikely, but repayment difficulties are possible at state level, where revenue collection is weaker.
Outlook for 2019-23: Monetary policy
Monetary policy will concentrate on fostering an economic recovery. However, this will generate contradictory pressures in the early part of the forecast period. The Central Bank of Nigeria (CBN) is minded towards boosting the supply side of the economy, but inflation is well above the targeted upper limit of 9%, and loosening in 2019-20 would risk capital outflows and naira stability at a time of low oil prices. Notwithstanding a 50-basis-point rate cut to 13.5% by the CBN in March (upheld in May and July), we do not expect rates to move much during 2019-20, keeping rates in Nigeria attractive to foreign investors as monetary policy in the US loosens. Our baseline forecast is for interest rates to fall from 2021 as inflation enters into a sustained downtrend, giving the CBN a chance to act on its growth-first strategy. We also expect that oil prices will rise during these years, driving higher foreign-exchange inflows.
Outlook for 2019-23: Economic growth
The economy will for the most part be mired in a low-growth cycle, although there will be improvements over time. In 2019-20 the economy will grow by an average of just 2.1%, held back by power shortages, insecurity, high inflation and tight credit conditions. With no room for fiscal activism, monetary policy is the main lever that can drive a recovery. In 2021-23 as global markets strengthen and inflation gradually decelerates-allowing for some monetary easing-the rate of growth will quicken to an average of 3.3%, although this remains well below potential.
From a sectoral viewpoint, agricultural growth will be lacklustre. Although boosting food production is a key government objective, weak infrastructure and violent competition for access to land in the fertile Middle Belt will continue to be severe impediments. Industrial production will be curtailed by militancy and labour agitation in the oil sector, and investment will be held back by uncertainty about future fiscal terms. Egina, a new offshore oilfield, will drive higher condensate output, but hydrocarbons production is not expected to return to levels prior to the 2015 commodity-price crash. That said, a private refinery coming on stream by 2021 will be a boost to downstream oil activity. The manufacturing sector will continue to struggle in the face of electricity shortages, as well as cheap goods from abroad, which are often smuggled into the country to bypass import bans. The services sector is less affected by instability and so will be a stronger contributor to growth than industry, but it will nonetheless be held back by protectionism (affecting trade) and the struggle in the communications sector to profitably roll out data services beyond urban hubs.
Outlook for 2019-23: Inflation
From a rate of 12.1% in 2018, average inflation will remain elevated in 2019, at 11.5%, as an increase in the minimum wage combines with disruptions to local food supply and widening import restrictions on consumer goods. In 2020 inflation at 11.3% will remain well above the CBN's targeted ceiling of 9% as widening foreign exchange restrictions continue to lead to higher prices. We also expect a 3-percentage-point rise in VAT in that year, prompted by lower oil prices (and fiscal revenue coming under pressure). With base effects from this fading, core inflation will gradually ease over the rest of the forecast period, bringing the headline rate down with it to an average of 8.8% in 2023. In combination with hardening foreign exchange restrictions on food imports, conflict and agricultural supply disruptions in the Middle Belt-Nigeria's breadbasket-will prevent a faster slide.
Outlook for 2019-23: Exchange rates
We expect the multiple-exchange-rate system to persist throughout 2019-23, with an official rate used for government business and a more market-determined rate applicable to investors and exporters, which will be broadly in line with retail rates and the parallel market. Such a system allows the government to subsidise sectors deemed important for economic or political reasons, including the NNPC, which budgets for petrol imports at the official rate. The central bank governor, Godwin Emefiele, has proven willing to adopt unconventional measures to keep the naira stable, which he argues is essential to avoid an inflationary spike and capital flight. Measures to defend the naira as oil prices decline in 2019-20 will include foreign-exchange restrictions to curb what has been a surge in import demand, but there will not be a need for capital controls (as were introduced temporarily in 2016). Progressively easier global monetary conditions during these years will support the naira through portfolio inflows, predominantly into fixed-income securities. Higher global crude prices thereafter will continue to support the official rate. In real terms, currency stability (for both the official and more market-determined rates) means real appreciation of the naira against trading partners as inflation remains high. For this reason there is a downside risk of policymakers opting to devalue or allowing more market-determined rates to weaken in order to regain international competitiveness. However, the CBN's industrial strategy (the central bank has long had similarities with a development agency) is focused on supplying the domestic market, so such an eventuality is not forecast.
Forecasting the naira
Although The Economist Intelligence Unit forecasts both the official and the secondary market rates, it is the official rate that appears in most of our data presentations, as it is the longest-running and best-tracked variable. For example, the current market-determined rate, known as the Nigerian Autonomous Foreign Exchange Rate Fixing (Nafex), has only been in full operation since April 2017, making historical calculations challenging. Indicators that are converted into US dollars at the official rate are essentially overvalued, which is in line with official calculations.
Outlook for 2019-23: External sector
The profile of export earnings will move in tandem with oil production and price trends. Falling oil prices in 2019 will be counteracted by rising output, but in 2020 the steeper price effect will cause earnings to fall. Higher global prices in 2021-23 and output gains (with a new mega-refinery coming on stream in around 2021, which we expect to be export-oriented, will return exports to growth.
Nigeria's government actively promotes import-substitution through foreign-exchange restrictions on certain goods (mainly manufactures and agricultural produce). A succession of such restrictions implemented in 2019 will cause imports to flat-line in that year-despite fast growth in the first half-and fall in 2020. As the economy gathers pace in 2021-23 and global oil prices rise (refinery capacity is low, and Nigeria imports much of its petrol needs), imports will then grow faster.
Trade-related services imports and profit repatriation in the oil sector will keep the services and primary income balances firmly in deficit. Workers' remittances will remain an important source of hard currency, albeit dipping in 2020 as growth falters in the US (home to a large Nigerian diaspora). Overall, the current-account surplus will average 1.5% of GDP in 2019-20, widening to 2.5% of GDP in 2021-23 as oil prices strengthen and the new refinery comes on stream.

Data sources and definitions
The sources for global and domestic data refer to historical data; the source for all forecast data, unless otherwise stated, is The Economist Intelligence Unit
Global data
US and OECD GDP growth: OECD
World trade growth: Economist Intelligence Unit aggregate
US and OECD consumer price inflation: OECD
Oil prices: IEA average import price
Non-oil commodity prices: IFS
Manufactures prices: UN, Monthly Bulletin of Statistics
US$ 3-month commercial paper rate: IFS
EUR 3-month interbank rate: IFS
Domestic data
Population: UN
Trade by country: IMF, Direction of Trade Statistics
Balance of payments: IFS and CBN, Annual Report and Statement of Accounts
Inflation: IFS, CBN and Federal Office of Statistics
Exchange rate: IFS; principal rate expressed as naira:US dollar
Interest rate: IFS; year-end lending rate
GDP growth and expenditure breakdown: World Bank, World Tables; 1987 prices
US$ GDP: IFS; in current prices converted from local currency at annual average market exchange rate
GDP per head: US dollar GDP divided by population
Oil production: IEA; m barrels/day
Oil price: The Economist Intelligence Unit; dated Brent Blend
FDI: IFS, UNCTAD, World Investment Report and CBN
Total external debt: sum of long- and short-term debt and IMF credits
Long-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end medium- and long-term publicly guaranteed and non-guaranteed debt outstanding, with an original maturity of more than one year
Short-term external debt: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; year-end debt outstanding, with an original maturity of less than one year
IMF credits: IFS and country page on website
Total debt service: World Bank, International Debt Statistics; principal repayments made against long-term debt, plus interest payments and IMF charges on total external debt
Debt-service ratio: ratio of total debt service paid to exports of goods and services
Interest-payments ratio: ratio of total interest paid on external debt to exports of goods and services
Abbreviations
CBN: Central Bank of Nigeria
IEA: International Energy Agency
IFS: International Financial Statistics
IMF: International Monetary Fund
NPC: National Population Commission
OECD: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
UNCTAD: UN Conference on Trade and Development
